abstract: -Among the great dailies in New-York, we consider the TIMES at the highest point of perfection. There is a freshness and attractiveness about its columns that is truly refreshing in these days of more stereotype expression. So far as ordinary news is concerned, when you read one, you have read all, but when we come to foreign and domestic correspondence, the TIMES is superior in our opinion to all the rest. While all its correspondents are pleasing and instructive, one of them, "Glaucus," is the most pleasing to us. The literary qualities of the TIMES are unsurpassed. Its book criticisms are unequaled, and its editorials generally, may be classed among essaic writing. We are not personally acquainted with the editor, Mr. RAYMOND, or any of his corps, but we judge the paper on its merits, and we hold it in high estimation. In our judgement, for news, judicious discussion of important subjects, literary strength, and interesting correspondence, it has no superior anywhere. We should be happy to see it circulate largely among us. -- Suffolk Union.

abstract: -It is reported, from Washington, that the Chiriqui survey is a success, and that a practicable railroad route has been discovered across, the Isthmus between Chiriqui and the Gulf of Dolce. This does not tally with our accounts from Panama, where a very different impression appears to have prevailed. There seems to be, however, no reason to doubt that Lieut. MORTON did discover a pass in the mountains, but whether it will ever be made available for the purposes of railway communication between the two oceans is a point that time only can determine. There is at present very little apparent probability of the execution of so costly an undertaking.

abstract: The Legislature of Georgia devoted its session, yesterday, to the consideration of a bill, attaching a fine of $2,000 to the sale of "a  bale of cotton or a barrel of apples," to anybody at the North. The proposition is reported to have occasioned a vehement debate, in which the line between the Secessionists and the Unionists was distinctly drawn.

abstract: In several places on Broadway the sidewalk is completely occupied by materials for new buildings, or has been taken up for the construction of vaults. This compels pedestrians to go out into the open street, and take their chances of safety among the omnibuses, carriages and carts by which Broadway is always crowded. No one can fail to have remarked the extreme inconvenience to which ladies as well as gentlemen are thus exposed.

abstract: Russell Sturges vs. The steamboat R.L. Mabey. -- This was a motion to modify a decree. The action was brought by the owner of the steam-tug Hector to recover the damages sustained by her in a collision with the Mabey. The libel was dismissed in the District Court, and that decree was affirmed by Judge NELSON, in the Circuit Court on appeal. From that decree the libelant appealed to the Supreme Court at Washington, and that Court reversed the decree of the Circuit Court, and directed it to enter a decree for the libelant with a reference to a Commissioner to ascertain his damages. The reference was had, and the Commissioner reported for the amount of repairs put on the Hector the sum of $1,603 03, and for the detention of the boat fourteen days to make the repairs, $1,050. The claimant excepted to this report, and, on exception, the Court allowed the sum of $1,603 03 for the repairs, but struck out entirely the item for demurrage, holding that the evidence of the damage sustained by the detention was not sufficient under he case of Williamson vs. Barrett (13 How., p. 110.) The libelant Proctor there upon applied, on an affidavit setting forth that he had supposed the evidence he offered to be in exact conformity with the rule laid down in that case, and could, on a rehearing, bring it within that rule, to have the case referred back again to the Commissioner, or for a rehearing of the exceptions.

The claimant excepted to this report, and, on exception, the Court allowed the sum of $1,603 03 for the repairs, but struck out entirely the item for demurrage, holding that the evidence of the damage sustained by the detention was not sufficient under he case of Williamson vs. Barrett (13 How., p. 110.) abstract: The fear of secession, our correspondent telegraphs, was not so strong yesterday at the Federal Capital as it had been previously. Many of the Southern members of Congress who have arrived, have brought their, families, which is considered as indication that they intend to remain. Among the arrivals yesterday was Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, and his rooms last night were crowded with visitors, anxious to hear his views relative to the present crisis. He talks hopefully, and counsels moderation, forbearance and compromise. The opinion appears to be pretty generally received that early in the session, before the assembling of the South Carolina Convention, the leading Republicans in Congress will bring forward some measure calculated to reassure the South, which, if it will not prevent the secession of South Carolina, will at least prevent any other State from following her. Indeed, it is asserted that a compromise measure is actually in the course of preparation, which, will cover the entire sectional issue, and leave no State the shadow of an excuse for wishing to leave the Union. It is now stated that Secretary COBB will not resign his position in the Cabinet until after the assembling of Congress and the delivery of the President's Message. It is expected that Messrs. COBB, FLOYD and THOMPSON, will then issue a manifesto disclaiming the sentiments of that document, and that this will lead to a rupture with the President and other members of the Cabinet. Nothing of special interest is telegraphed from South Carolina. The proceedings of the Legislature yesterday were unimportant. In the Georgia Legislature, on Thursday, a debate took place on the bill to protect the rights of the citizens of the State, which called out strong Union sentiments from several members, and quite a scene of commotion ensued. The debate was finally postponed. Yesterday, the Legislature chose Presidential electors. The Breckinridge ticket received 173 votes, the Bell ticket 54, and the Douglas ticket 8 -- about 70 members not voting. We publish this morning a variety of correspondence and newspaper extracts bearing on the subject of secession, which will be found highly interesting. Among the latter will be noticed the views of Mr. THURLOW WEED.

abstract: The famous old story of Mr. JOHN WILKES and his female admirer has been fairly surpassed by the reception accorded in Paris to Gen. DE LAMORICIERE, by the partisans of his Holiness the Pope. When Mr. WILKES' ardent friend was entreated to admit, that whatever the other merits of her idol might be, he did at least and most unquestionably squint, she indignantly replied, that "Mr. WILKES squinted, to be sure; but that he squinted no more than a gentleman and a man of honor ought to squint." In like manner, only in a more intense rapture of single-minded devotion, the good Romanist partisans of HENRY V. and PIUS IX., in the Faubourg St. Germain, now maintain that, if Gen. DE LAMORICIERE has been beaten in Italy, he has been beaten no more than a great captain and a hero ought to be.

lead_paragraph: DEAR SIR: I am happy to be able to certify to the efficiency of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP, and to the truth of what it is represented to accomplish. Having a little boy suffering greatly from teething, who could not rest, and at night by his cries would not permit any of the family to do so, I purchased a bottle of the SOOTHING SYRUP, in order to test the remedy, and, when given to the boy according to directions, its effect upon him was like magic; he soon went to sleep, and all pain and nervousness disappeared. We have had no trouble with him since, and the little fellow will pass through with comfort the excruciating process of teething, by the sole aid of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP Every mother who regards the health and life of her children should possess it.

abstract: SUICIDE OF AN APOTHECARY. -- Coroner SCHIRMER, on Thursday, held an inquest in the case of HERMAN KNUTT, a German druggist, about 40 years of age, who poisoned himself on Wednesday morning, by taking laudanum. From the testimony, it was shown that deceased recently became the proprietor of a drug-store at No. 103 First-avenue, but in consequence of his intemperance, his business suffered, and he became embarrassed in his pecuniary affairs. One of the witnesses, a clerk in the employ of the deceased, stated that he was drunk from morning till night, and on several occasions customers had been sent from the store by representing that the medicines for which they inquired were not in the place, when at the same time the articles were on the shelves. On Wednesday, deceased did not come from his bed-room at the usual hour, and witness went to learn the reason. Deceased then asked that one of his friends might be sent for, upon whose arrival he stated that he had taken laudanum to end his life. A physician was summoned, who administered the usual antidotes, but they proved unavailing, and he died in the evening.
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE OF AN APOTHECARY. -- Coroner SCHIRMER, on Thursday, held an inquest in the case of HERMAN KNUTT, a German druggist, about 40 years of age, who poisoned himself on Wednesday morning, by taking laudanum. From the testimony, it was shown that deceased recently became the proprietor of a drug-store at No. 103 First-avenue, but in consequence of his intemperance, his business suffered, and he became embarrassed in his pecuniary affairs. One of the witnesses, a clerk in the employ of the deceased, stated that he was drunk from morning till night, and on several occasions customers had been sent from the store by representing that the medicines for which they inquired were not in the place, when at the same time the articles were on the shelves. On Wednesday, deceased did not come from his bed-room at the usual hour, and witness went to learn the reason. Deceased then asked that one of his friends might be sent for, upon whose arrival he stated that he had taken laudanum to end his life. A physician was summoned, who administered the usual antidotes, but they proved unavailing, and he died in the evening.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN -- MR. EDWIN BOOTH AS "RICHELIEU." -- Surprises, in the dramatic world, now-a-days, rarely occur. Mr. BARRY CORNWALL and others have told us into what a state of surprise the dramatic world of London was thrown, many years ago, when, on that memorable cold Winter's night, at Drury Lane, EDMUND KEAN made his first triumph, in the character of Shylock. There have been surprises since in England and in this country. We were surprised here, many years ago, by Miss CUSHMAN; later, by Miss HERON, as Camille, and by others, in a lesser degree, whom we need not name. The surprise of last night was equal to the best of these -- not including EDMUND KEAN, as we only take his victory on the credit of his biographer and from cotemporary criticism.

abstract: Justice BRENNAN yesterday held for examination a man named Abner S. Young, charged with having attempted to pass a counterfeit $5 note on the Rockland County Bank of Nyack, N.Y., at the liquor-store of John Marselius, No. 620 Water-street. The accused tendered the bill in payment for a glass of brandy, pretending that he had no change. It was at once seen to be counterfeit, and he was handed over to an officer. Upon searching him, $1 50 in change was found in his pockets. Two colored seamen, named John Jefferson and James Jackson, were also taken before Justice WELSH on the complaint of Dennis Davis, tailor, at No. 113 Chatham-street, who alleged that he had received from them a counterfeit $10 note, purporting to be the issue of the Bank of Andover, Massachusetts, in payment for a pair of pantaloons. It was shown that the accused had previously attempted to dispose of the bill at another store, where its worthlessness had been made known to them. They were held for trial.

abstract: Interesting intelligence has been received at the Indian Office, from New-Mexico. The volunteers have been quite successful in the Navajo Campaign, killing many Indians and taking a large amount of stock and some prisoners. The Peublo Indians, who went out with the volunteers, had returned, bringing a number of horses, sheep and prisoners. They also killed some Navajoes.

abstract: -The Prison Discipline Association now holding its sessions in this City might make a profitable adjournment to the cells and corridors of Sing Sing. It is well known that ever since the abolition of the lash, through the charitable efforts of the Society, punishments have been substituted greatly exceeding in cruelty and absolute brutality the most savage use of the whip; and, notwithstanding that for the last six years public attention has been called to these inquisitorial contrivances, they still obtain in all our State Prisons. To the extreme suffering inflicted by these engines recent and painful testimony has been borne by Mr. THEODORE TILTON and Mr. GEORGE MATSELL.

abstract: On Thursday night the City Railroad Company caused a rail-track to be laid on Fifth-avenue, near the entrance of Greenwood Cemetery, between Twenty-fourth and Twenty fifth streets, parallel to the track of the Central Railroad Company. The object of laying the track at this time was to prevent the Central Company from restraining them by injunction. Yesterday morning the new track was torn up by the Central Company.

abstract: -The pains taken to assure the commercial public that southern merchants intend to pay their debts, are superfluous. Any buyer, of sound credit originally, of ordinary honesty, and present ability, will find nothing in the present relations of the two sections to dissuade him from an honorable fulfilment of his obligations. The dishonest may, of course, plead the political crisis as a reason for withholding payment; but were this pretext wanting, another would doubtless have been found, and the result would have been precisely the same. The Southern States, of course, share in the embarrassment which the actual panic communicates to all the States. Doubtless, in the shortness of its crops, and the fact that they have not reached the market, the South is still more severely cramped than either the North or the Northwest. But these causes are temporary; and as they disappear, Southern remittances, we venture to predict, will come forward with their usual promptness. No more damaging aspersion could be cast upon the South, by even the malicious ingenuity of Abolitionism, than to charge its merchants as a class with the design to defraud their private creditors, under pretence of public wrongs.

abstract: Some weeks ago, when the special policy of the Disunionists was to dispel all fears of a collision with the General Government, the Charleston Mercury declared, as if by authority, that no such danger would be incurred if the final step were only taken before the 4th of March. abstract: In this Court, yesterday, Justices CONNOLLY, KELLY and STEERS, disposed of a very light Calendar. Of nineteen persons charged with assault and battery, seven were dismissed, no witnesses appearing against them; three were discharged under suspended sentence, one was allowed postponement, two were remanded, two were fined and four were acquitted. Of nine persons charged with petty larceny, one was dismissed, no witness appearing against him; five were discharged under suspended sentence, one was fined, one imprisoned and one acquitted.
lead_paragraph: In this Court, yesterday, Justices CONNOLLY, KELLY and STEERS, disposed of a very light Calendar. abstract: The final preparations were made yesterday, on board the receiving-ship North Carolina at Brooklyn, to dispatch in the California steamer to-day, a new crew for the U.S. corvette Cyane, of the Pacific squadron; together with some reinforcements for the short ships' companies of the fleet. The sailors will be marched to the steamer this forenoon. The Cyane arrived at Panama from Acapulco, Mazatlan, and La Paz on the 10th inst., to await exchange of crews, which will obviate the necessity of sending her home "round the Horn." All the ships in the Pacific will probably be assembled at Panama when the outward bound company arrives there. The Lancaster, Narragansett and St. Marys, are already in port, while the Levant from Honolulu, and the Saranae from San Francisco were due at last advices.

abstract: -The annual examination of the Croton Aqueduct commences on Tuesday, when the supply will be cut off, and the City must depend for a few days on what is already in the reservoirs. As the supply is unusually low this season, there is absolute necessity for unusual care in the prevention of waste and needless consumption. The Board appeal to the public to be as economical in the use of water for domestic and other purposes as possible.

abstract: Mr. JOHN WHITED, an old and much respected citizen of Newburgh, Orange County, died very suddenly at his residence in that village, a few days since. He had risen in the morning in his usual health, when a short time after be tell to the floor and instantly expired. He was about 70 years of age. Mr. WHITED was formerly proprietor of the Orange Hotel in that village, and up to the time of his death was proprietor of a line of stages.

abstract: M. Lenon vs. A. Borst. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff, as assignee of the firm of Hilger & Co., to recover a balance alleged to be due that firm, by the defendant. The defendant now set up a counter claim, and the plaintiff, by way of reply, denies the claim. Motion was now made by the defendant to strike out the reply, on the ground that no counter claim is alleged in the answer, urging that it should have been pleaded; and, unless it was so pleaded; a reply was unauthorized, under the amendment of section 153 of the Code.

abstract: Your readers have doubtless expected important and decisive intelligence by this mail, but I am sorry to say events still move very slowly here, although it cannot be denied that steady progress is being made by the liberal cause. The Liberal forces are yet besieging Guadalajara, but our advises, which are to the 24th ult, indicate that its fall must speedily occur.

abstract: The support so long furnished the Clerical Party in Mexico by the British Government is producing its natural fruits. The intrigues of Mr. OTWAY, the English resident, for more than eighteen months sustained the factions of ZULOAGA and MIRAMON at the capital against the most strenuous attacks of the Liberals; while the refusal of the Legation at all times to recognize the Juarez Government has given great additional moral power to the reactionary party.
lead_paragraph: The support so long furnished the Clerical Party in Mexico by the British Government is producing its natural fruits. The intrigues of Mr. OTWAY, the English resident, for more than eighteen months sustained the factions of ZULOAGA and MIRAMON at the capital against the most strenuous attacks of the Liberals; while the refusal of the Legation at all times to recognize the Juarez Government has given great additional moral power to the reactionary party. The civil contest has thus been protracted far beyond what would have been its natural term. There is every reason to believe that had England joined the United States in its acknowledgment of the constitutional regime, the war would have been brought to a close six months ago; and Mexico by this time would have been started on a career of civil, social and industrial regeneration.

abstract: The Herald's material for disunion sensation is running low. It refers to the fact that the Palmetto flag is actually flying from the mast-head of vessels in the harbor of New-York, as evidence that the secession mania has seized upon the shipowners and sea captains. The truth is that the Palmetto flag has been flying for the last seven years at the topgallant masthead of two lines of schooners and small brigs which have done the cotton and rice freighting between Charleston and New-York. It has been used, like a multiplicity of other private signals in the harbor, as a distinguishing pennant, to indicate that vessels of a particular line are in port, and may be found at a given pier by any one having freight for Charleston. Capt. MARSHALL's Liverpool line flies a black ball on a red ground as the private signal of his line. To the diseased imagination of some people this may be supposed to symbolise war with Great Britain and consequent bloodshed, though the owner or captain of any of these ships probably never dreamed of attaching any such meaning to the flag.
lead_paragraph: The Herald's material for disunion sensation is running low. It has been used, like a multiplicity of other private signals in the harbor, as a distinguishing pennant, to indicate that vessels of a particular line are in port, and may be found at a given pier by any one having freight for Charleston. Capt. MARSHALL's Liverpool line flies a black ball on a red ground as the private signal of his line. To the diseased imagination of some people this may be supposed to symbolise war with Great Britain and consequent bloodshed, though the owner or captain of any of these ships probably never dreamed of attaching any such meaning to the flag.

abstract: There is a general demand for measures of Conciliation. On all sides there seems to be a general disposition to do whatever can be done fairly and justly, to remove causes of complaint and restore peace and mutual good feeling to the different sections of the country. By Common consent, moreover, the most prominent and tangible point of offence seems to be the legislation growing out the Fugitive Slave law.
lead_paragraph: There is a general demand for measures of Conciliation. On all sides there seems to be a general disposition to do whatever can be done fairly and justly, to remove causes of complaint and restore peace and mutual good feeling to the different sections of the country. By Common consent, moreover, the most prominent and tangible point of offence seems to be the legislation growing out the Fugitive Slave law. Several of the Northern States have passed Personal Liberty bills -- with the alleged intent to prevent the return of fugitive slaves to their masters. From Union men in every quarter of the South, come up the most earnest appeals to the Northern States to repeal these laws. Such an act, we are assured, would have a powerful, effect in disarming the disunion clamor in nearly all the Southern States, and in promoting the prospects of a peaceful adjustment of all pending differences.

abstract: The market continues quiet and sales from first hands are limited. To-day there is an improved demand for Candles by the Trade: 2,000 boxes Adamantines changed bonds at 24 c, @ 24 c., being c, better. Provisions of all kinds are heavy and tending downward. Butter is very slow, with only a few packages extra brands lathmus selling at 32 c.
lead_paragraph: The market continues quiet and sales from first hands are limited. To-day there is an improved demand for Candles by the Trade: 2,000 boxes Adamantines changed bonds at 24 c, @ 24 c., being c, better. Provisions of all kinds are heavy and tending downward. Butter is very slow, with only a few packages extra brands lathmus selling at 32 c. Recent receipts of Spirits Turpentine have depressed the market; prices nominal; 80c. could not be obtained on Saturday. The Emily N. Seyburn arrived with a cargo of Cuba Sugar. It is advertised at auction, and other holders are pressing their lots; qualities lately worth 10c. can be had for 8 1/2c., with no buyers; all descriptions are unfavorably affected; small sales of Crushed at 14 5/6c.@14 3/4c. Spirits dull and unchanged. A steady business doing in Wheat for export; receipts light; prices -- good shipping qualities command $1 50@$1 55, and extra $1 60. Flour is suffering a little. Barley of superior quality is selling for New-York in moderate quantity at $1@$1 05 cental. Export orders for Breadstuffs are mostly filled, but will be renewed us soon as tonnage can be obtained. The Tropic sailed to-day for New-York with 1,500 sacks of Barley, 6,500 sacks of Wheat, 800 bales of Wool, 15,600 Sides, 371 bbls. Ham, 90 bbls. Pork, and a quantity of hardwood. Her cargo is valued at $125,000. Financial affairs are healthy, but scarcely easy. The country owes largely to the city trade for steamer engagements. Yesterday Money rated at 1 1/2@1 1/2 cent., with a brisk demand. Gold bars, $8 70@$8 80. Sight Exchange on New-York, 2 3/4 cent. premium.

abstract: The Charter Election which takes place tomorrow, though not presenting any of those abstract issues which furnish a congenial theme to eloquence, is yet destined to have the most important and controlling influence over the affairs of our City and the education of the rising generation for the next two years. Many candidates are in the field numerous, in fact, as the turkey-buzzards collected round a carcase in the swamps of Florida, all with
lead_paragraph: The Charter Election which takes place tomorrow, though not presenting any of those abstract issues which furnish a congenial theme to eloquence, is yet destined to have the most important and controlling influence over the affairs of our City and the education of the rising generation for the next two years. Many candidates are in the field numerous, in fact, as the turkey-buzzards collected round a carcase in the swamps of Florida, all with eager and whetted beaks, prehensile claws, and appetites strongly yearning for their portion of the public spoil. Fortunately, we are not without a few candidates of the better class, presented by different parties; and it behooves every good citizen to scrutinize jealously, and with but little reference to political divisions, the characters and antecedents of each candidate for his vote.
headline: {'main': "To-morrow's Election.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "To-morrow's Election.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Those Whose lives have been so protracted as to enable them to remember the crisis of 183233, cannot fail to be impressed with the various points in common, and points of contrast, between the events of that period and those of the present day. Acting upon convictions of more or less sincerity and intensity, South Carolina twenty-eight years ago felt herself compelled to question the impartiality and impugn the authority of the Fed
lead_paragraph: Those Whose lives have been so protracted as to enable them to remember the crisis of 183233, cannot fail to be impressed with the various points in common, and points of contrast, between the events of that period and those of the present day. Acting upon convictions of more or less sincerity and intensity, South Carolina twenty-eight years ago felt herself compelled to question the impartiality and impugn the authority of the Federal Government, and misinterpreting and misapplying the platform of Southern Republicanism contained, in the Virginia resolutions of 1798-99, asserted the right of a State to set at defiance the enactments of Congress, and, if necessary, to withdraw from the Confederation. The origin, character and event of the conflict provoked by these positions throw so much light upon the actual conditions of things, that it cannot be otherwise than instructive to recall their leading historical points.

abstract: Judge GOULD opened Court on Saturday at 1 o'clock, for the purpose of sentencing Billy Mulligan, convicted of a felonious assault on Officer Oliver. For a long time before the Court-room was opened, the entire hall-way of the building was thronged with members of the sporting public, dressed and barbered in the mode of that fraternity. When the doors were opened they poured like a rushing torrent into the room, shivering the side glasses of the door-way, and rendering the same fate imminent to any person of short stature or weak frame who happened to be in the press. Every seat and available standing place, both within and outside the bar, was occupied by an interested looker-on.

abstract: The public awaits, with profound anxiety, the forthcoming Message of the President. It ought to be sent to Congress to-day _____ but intimations are current that it will be postponed until to-morrow, on account of changes that have taken place in Mr. BUCHANAN's mind, as to its contents on the subject of secession. We do not suppose that Mr. BUCHANAN has any doubt as to what he ought to say upon that point. His path is so plain that a much less sagacious mind than his would have no excuse for mistaking it. But his doubts turn upon the wisdom -- the expediency of saying what he knows to be true.
lead_paragraph: The public awaits, with profound anxiety, the forthcoming Message of the President. abstract: CHARLES MCAULEY, who, it is alleged, killed PATRICK KELLY, at No. 215 Front-street, on Thursday night last, by stabbing him with a knife, after having eluded the Police for nearly forty-eight hours, deliberately walked into the Second Police Precinct Station-house at about 8 o'clock on Saturday evening and surrendered himself to Sergeant RHODES, who was then in charge. MCAULEY is of small stature and anything but a desperado in his general appearance. Remorse for the terrible crime and the trouble which he has brought upon his innocent family was what decided him to surrender himself. As will be seen by the testimony of Mr. MCDONALD, (annexed,) whose house he entered immediately after the offence was committed in a distracted state of mind, and exclaimed, "Oh, what will my children do," the whole trouble seemed to be about them.

abstract: Justices BROWNELL, KELLY and WELSH, on Saturday disposed of the usual number of cases. Of twenty persons charged with assault and battery, six were discharged, no witnesses appearing against them; one was discharged by request of complainant, two were discharged under suspended sentence, one was allowed a postponement, two were fined, seven were imprisoned, and one was acquitted. Of thirty persons charged with petty larceny, two were discharged, no witnesses appearing; one was discharged under suspended sentence, three were allowed a postponement, six were remanded, fourteen were imprisoned, and four were acquitted.
lead_paragraph: Justices BROWNELL, KELLY and WELSH, on Saturday disposed of the usual number of cases. Of twenty persons charged with assault and battery, six were discharged, no witnesses appearing against them; one was discharged by request of complainant, two were discharged under suspended sentence, one was allowed a postponement, two were fined, seven were imprisoned, and one was acquitted. Of thirty persons charged with petty larceny, two were discharged, no witnesses appearing; one was discharged under suspended sentence, three were allowed a postponement, six were remanded, fourteen were imprisoned, and four were acquitted.

abstract: OBSERVANCE OF THE SUNDAY LIQUOR LAW. -- The vendors of intoxicating drinks who have been allowed for nearly a year past to violate the liquor law, by selling on the Sabbath with impunity, seemed generally to have a realizing sense that the recent movement of Superintendent KENNEDY to stop the traffic has been made in earnest. Yesterday, in comparison with other Sundays, few places were opened -- the side doors and back entrances in most instances being closed even to the familiar faces of the regular customers. The movement was inaugurated a week ago, and its result was then manifested by a decrease of about one-fourth in the usual number of arrests for intoxication. Yesterday the total arrests for the offence was thirty-three -- being a decrease of seventeen from the number of the previous Sunday. Thirty-one keepers of drinking places, however, yesterday persisted in disregarding the warning they had received from the Police, with reference to the matter, and consequently they were taken into custody. A few of the offenders were arraigned before the Police magistrates and required to give bail, but as the Courts close at 12 o'clock on Sunday, the majority were confined in the cells of the various Station-houses, their apprehension having been effected after that hour. It is thought that the experience of a night's imprisonment will have a salutary effect, and that hereafter the observance of the law will be more apparent. Following are the arrests reported in each Precinct:

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning will be found exceedingly interesting, in view of the fact that Congress assembles to-day. It is understood that the President's Message will not be delivered until to-morrow. This delay is thought best by Mr. BUCHANAN, in order to allow time for the preparation of some measure of compromise, before the exciting topic of secession shall be introduced by the reading of his views upon the subject. The President will, it is asserted, deny the right of any State to secede, but will admit that there is no power in the Constitution to force her to remain in the Union, and will declare his purpose to veto any force bill should Congress see fit to pass one. He will not recommend a general Convention of the States, but will suggest that such a Convention might concert measures to restore quiet. Meantime, it is believed in some quarters that a plan of permanent reconciliation will come from a committee of both Houses, to be composed of a Senator and a Representative from each State, to whom shall be submitted the President's Message without debate, and who shall report an amendment to the Constitution, to cover, all the ground of difficulty. This plan, however, may be defeated by the Secessionists, who have, it is understood, already prepared a resolution, which will be presented to-day, declaring the right of a State to secede at will. Such a resolution would undoubtedly be overwhelmingly rejected, which would give the South Carolina members a pretext for withdrawing immediately, when they might be followed by those of other States. There is undoubtedly, however, a strong Union sentiment among the Southern members. Such men as LEACH of North Carolina, BOULIGNY of Louisiana, ANDERSON of Missouri, ADAMS and BURNETT of Kentucky, and NELSON and ETHERIDGE of Tennessee, are open in their condemnation of the secession movement. It is expected that the Republicans will make an attempt to push the Appropriation bills through before the discussion commences, and for this Mr. SHERMAN, the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, is fully prepared. Senator DOUGLAS was complimented with a serenade on Saturday evening, and took the occasion to express his most unqualified condemnation of the secession movement, and his unalterable devotion to the Union. He declared his intention to bury all animosities, and labor only for the preservation of the country. This declaration has had the effect of rallying around him many who have quite recently been his bitter enemies. Our dispatches from various points in the South do not vary much in their character from those previously received. The South Carolina Legislature is principally occupied at present in legislation of a local interest, though some measures looking to a more strict internal arrangement, and to the defence of her sea-coast, have been introduced, but not acted upon. In Florida a State Convention is to be held, the time for which has not been decided. Gen. HOUSTON, of Texas, has been petitioned to assemble the Legislature of that State in extra session, but refuses to do so unless a majority of the people demand it.

abstract: The second session of the Thirty-sixth Congress commenced yesterday; and whatever may be the course of events hereafter, there certainly was little indication on the first day that anything extraordinary was expected to occur. The only things which could lead to the supposition that any action out of the ordinary course was looked for, were the unwonted stillness which pervaded the Capitol, notwithstanding the suffocating crowds in the galleries, and the presence, for the first time, of all the Foreign Ministers -- showing the deep interest felt by the Diplomatic Corps in the pending crisis. The South Carolina Senators, of course, were absent; but the members of the House from that State, were in their seats. The Senate did nothing beyond the appointment of the usual Committees to notify the House and the President that they were ready to proceed to business. They adjourned about 1 o'clock. In the House, after the appointment of Notifying Committees, to correspond with those of the Senate, Mr. GROW, of Pennsylvania called up a motion, made last session, to reconsider the vote by which the Homestead bill was referred to the Committee of the Whole, but the motion was postponed, while the members drew for seats. Mr. WASHBURNE, of Maine, as he will vacate his seat on Jan. 1, to assume his duties as Governor of that State, was, at his request, excused from serving on the Committee of Ways and Means. Mr. GROW again renewed his motion in reference to the Homestead bill; but it being understood that the President's Message would not be received until to-day, he gave way to a motion to adjourn, which was carried at 1 1/2 o'clock.

abstract: We have no later dates from Bogota than those by my last, from which you got a few faint glimmerings of what was going on where up to the middle of October. The news is confirmed that all the Government dispatches of that date and most of the mail matter, except the British Minister's packages, were seized by the Revolutionists on the Magdalena River.

abstract: A rumor, sufficiently authentic to all appearance to call for comment, alleges that on the retirement of Mr. COBB from the Secretaryship of the Treasury, it is the intention of Mr. BUCHANAN to offer the vacant portfolio to Mr. AUGUSTUS SCHELL. Absurd and almost incredible as such a suggestion must appear to those who, unfortunately for themselves, have had occasion to notice Mr. SCHELL'S...
lead_paragraph: A rumor, sufficiently authentic to all appearance to call for comment, alleges that on the retirement of Mr. COBB from the Secretaryship of the Treasury, it is the intention of Mr. BUCHANAN to offer the vacant portfolio to Mr. AUGUSTUS SCHELL. Absurd and almost incredible as such a suggestion must appear to those who, unfortunately for themselves, have had occasion to notice Mr. SCHELL'S discharge of his duties as Collector, -- the rumor, we repeat, is widely current and has received sad acceptance in circles more likely than any other to know the President's intentions. We sincerely trust, however, for Mr. BUCHANAN's sake, that no such act of supreme folly may be allowed to mark the closing months of his term. We grant that Mr. SCHELL has always yielded the most supple acquiescence to orders for the guillotining of refractory subordinates; he has never hesitated to levy party-assessments with unsparing hand; he was foremost, in the ranks of the Seceders, both at Charleston and Baltimore, under orders from Washington; and the skull-injury, under which he still suffers, was doubtless received in the "National cause," as understood by Mr. BUCHANAN. But all these admitted services and claims find ample recompense, we submit, in his present office, which has paid him about thirty-five thousand dollars a year.

abstract: A few years ago one would hardly have ventured the prediction that the Pope of Rome would announce a new dogma of belief as indispensable to salvation, and, what is more, succeed in thrusting the dogma into the accepted creed of Catholic Christendom. Yet the men of this generation have lived to see such a circumstance occur. But who, when the Papal power seemed thus triumphant, would have dared prophecy that the wearer of the tiara would, in a few short years be reduced to beg alms of the faithful of his flock, and that the famous Peter's pence would be revived? If the promulgation of the "Immaculate Conception" carried one back to the days of Councils of Trent and of Nice, the claim for Peter's pence may well remind us of the Crusades. History seems, indeed, only to be traveling in a cycle, when events are thus repeated that occurred nearly a thousand, years ago. The trouble is that the actors in these events, although they perform on the same stage, are not inheritors of the peculiar powers of their predecessors.

abstract: A prize-fight came off at Bull's Feery, N.J., yesterday morning, between two light-weights, named DENNIS HORRIGAN and WILLIAM CLARKE, for $100 a side, in which the latter was declared the victor after fighting forty-four rounds. The fight was witnessed by about seven hundred persons.

abstract: The Putnam Phalanx, of Hartford, Conn., whose intended visit to Mount Vernon has for some time been announced, arrived in this City, by the New-Haven train, yesterday about 3 o'clock, P.M., having been detained some two hours at Stamford, Conn. They marched from Twenty-third-street, passing through Union-square, where they paused for a short time and paid their respects to the equestrian statue of WASHINGTON. Their arrival and march attracted great attention, and from the cars to the Astor House they were escorted by a large assemblage of people. They wear the uniform of the Continental Army, pure and simple, which certainly never appeared so well since it was worn by our fathers, as it does upon the Putnam Phalanx. Many of the members of this corps are men extraordinary for their physical propations, several of the officers for their venerable years, and all, without exception, for their soldierly bearing. Mayor GOODWIN, the Commander, stands six feet six inches in his stockings, and is a most venerable personage, his flowing hair and beard being of a snowy whiteness. Notwithstanding he is near seventy years of age he walks with a step as elastic, and a gait as erect as the youngest of the corps. They number 90 muskets, and traveling with them on this pilgrimage to the Tomb of WASHINGTON are a large number of honorary members. They proceeded to the Astor House, where dinner had been long in waiting for them. There they spent about an hour, and then reformed and marched at 5 o'clock to the Jersey City ferry, which they crossed and then took the cars for Philadelphia en route to Washington. Com-Company 3, of the Continental Guard of this City, Capt. WM. RAINER did escort duty on the occasion. The following are the officers of the Company: Major Horace Goodwin; Staff Adjutant Joseph D. Williams; Quarter-Master, E.B. Strong; Paymaster, Jas. B. Crosby; Commissary, Henry C. Denning; Assistant-Commissary, Alonzo W. Brige, Judge Advocate, Isaac W. Stewart; Chaplain, Rev. Asher Moore; Surgeon, Dr. Thomas Miner; Sergent-Major, Wm. Isham; Quarter master-sergent, Oliver Ellsworth; Ensign Wm. J.D. Enslow.

abstract: There is no mistaking the fact that there is a concerted plan on foot among the enemies of the Republican Party, to bring it and the President elect into the disgraceful attitude of disowning the principles and policy to which they stood pledged before the country prior to the election. To accomplish this object, the most unpatriotic means are resorted to. The South has been excited to the highest pitch of...
lead_paragraph: There is no mistaking the fact that there is a concerted plan on foot among the enemies of the Republican Party, to bring it and the President elect into the disgraceful attitude of disowning the principles and policy to which they stood pledged before the country prior to the election. To accomplish this object, the most unpatriotic means are resorted to. The South has been excited to the highest pitch of frenzy, by parading before her people every extravagant speech and writing of ultra Abolitionists and inconsiderate Republicans; while the wise, just and conservative views of Mr. LINCOLN himself, the broad and national policy displayed in the Chicago Platform, and the moderate and judicious expositions of the party's principles and aims, which its leading organs have put forth, before and since the election, are carefully withheld from Southern eyes. To intimidate the President elect and his friends, the same arts of suppression and exaggeration of Southern sentiment are resorted to. Every indication of conservatism and love for the Union which is given by the Southern people, is carefully excluded from the columns of these journals, while no treasonable utterance, no extravagance of Pro-Slavery fanaticism, no expression of sectional animosity, is permitted to fall unhonored into the oblivion which it merits.

abstract: Elijah Jones vs. The New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company. -- This is an action brought to recover damages against the defendants for putting the plaintiff off their cars. The plaintiff, it apears, was desirous of going from Jersey City to Matuchin, and bought a ticket for that place. He took his station on a train which went no further than Rahway. When called on by the conductor, he showed the ticket which he had bought, but was informed that that ticket was not good for that train, and that he must pay fare. He declined to pay fare, but claimed the right to go on that train as far as it went, and retaining the ticket to take the next train to Matuchin. The conductor declined to allow him to go on, and put him off the train about a mile and a half from Jersey City, but using no more violence than was necessary. The ticket which he had bought expressed the contract that the passenger had the right to go on that day "in a continuous train."
lead_paragraph: Elijah Jones vs. The New-Jersey Railroad and Transportation Company. -- This is an action brought to recover damages against the defendants for putting the plaintiff off their cars. The plaintiff, it apears, was desirous of going from Jersey City to Matuchin, and bought a ticket for that place. He took his station on a train which went no further than Rahway. When called on by the conductor, he showed the ticket which he had bought, but was informed that that ticket was not good for that train, and that he must pay fare. He declined to pay fare, but claimed the right to go on that train as far as it went, and retaining the ticket to take the next train to Matuchin. The conductor declined to allow him to go on, and put him off the train about a mile and a half from Jersey City, but using no more violence than was necessary. The ticket which he had bought expressed the contract that the passenger had the right to go on that day "in a continuous train."

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE The genius of MOLIERE gave a hypocrite to the world, and named him Tartuffe. In France he is the representative hypocrite, while on the English stage, Charles Surface is but a meagre member of the family. In short Tartuffe is the hypocrite, par excellence, on the stage, and off it.

abstract: Before Judge Daly.  Augustus B. Heriott et al. vs. Catharine N. Sinclair. This is an action by the plaintiff as assignee of John Beck and others engaged with him in business, upon the note of Mrs. Sinclair, made several years ago for $552.35. The note was given for goods sold to the defendant subsequently to her divorce from her husband.

abstract: No more significant indication of the general desire of the Republican Party to render the most full and complete justice to the South has been afforded, than is found in the articles we have copied from day to day from the Albany Evening Journal. The editor of that paper holds a far more prominent and influential position in the councils of that party than any other man in the Union who is out of high office. To a political sagacity rarely equaled, he adds a ripe experience and a knowledge of the practical conduct of public affairs unsurpassed by that of any man now in public life. Wedded as he is to the fortunes of the Republican Party, whatever counsel he may give can be prompted only by a regard for its welfare, as essential to the welfare of the country at large. What he says, therefore, on the condition of the country, deserves the attention which it is sure to receive.

abstract: STABBED HIS WIFE. -- A man named HUGH O'NEIL, residing at Hudson City, was arrested by Constable MCLEON yesterday on a warrant issued by Recorder MARTIN, charging him with having committed a felonious assault upon his wife. It is alleged that O'NEIL while intoxicated quarreled with his wife, and taking out a pistol, signified his intention of shooting her. Instead of this, however, he drew a dirk-knife, and seizing his wife by the throat, thrust her against the wall and stabbed her on the side of the head. The wound was a very severe one, but not dangerous. O'NEIL was committed to the County Jail, to await trial in January.

abstract: A number of Germans met on Sunday evening in the lager-bier saloon No. 142 Essex-street, and entered upon a corousal. In the midst of their jollification offense was taken by two brothers, named Xavier and Carl Hockreiter, at something which was said by Leonard Gandor and Henry Klatz, and a fight was the consequence. Suddenly Gandor and Klotz called out that they had been stabbed, when others of the party interposed, and detained the assailants un-the police arrived and took charge of them. Gandor was removed to his residence, No. 140 Essex-street, where he was attended by Police Surgeon Wells, who pronounced his wound to be of a dangerous character. Klotz was not so seriously hurt. The prisoners were yesterday taken before Justice BRENNAN, who committed them, pending the result of the injuries they are charged with having inflicted.

abstract: CITY MORTALITY. The report of the City Inspector for the week ending Saturday last, gives 409 as the number of deaths during that time, of which 103 were men; 92 women; 102 boys; and 112 girls; being an increase of 40 over the mortality of the preceding week, and 28 over that of the corresponding week in 1859. Of the number 193 were under 5 years of age.
lead_paragraph: CITY MORTALITY. -- The report of the City Inspector for the week ending Saturday last, gives 409 as the number of deaths during that time, of which 103 were men; 92 women; 102 boys; and 112 girls; being an increase of 40 over the mortality of the preceding week, and 28 over that of the corresponding week in 1859. Of the number 193 were under 5 years of age. The principal diseases and causes were -- Apoplexy 4; asthma 3; bronchitis 7; consumption 65; cancer of stomach 2; congestion of brain 13; do. lungs 4; convulsions, adult, 3; infantile 25; croup 16; debility, adult, 7; do. infantile 9; dropsy 4; do. in head 12; diarrhoea 7; diphtherite 13; dysentery 2; fever, bilious, 1; do. puerperal 2; do. remittent 3; do. scarlet 21; do. typhoid 4; do typhus 6; whooping cough 4; heart disease 11; inflammation of bowels 6; do. brain 13; do. lungs 30; do. stomach 2; measles 2; marasmus, adult, 5; do infantile 20; rheumatism 2; small-pox 4; teething 2; palsy 5; ulceration bowels 2; do. throat 2; burned or scalded 3; casualties 5; delirium tremens 5; intemperance 3; lockjaw 2; old age 3; poison 2; premature birth 3; suffocation, accidental, 4. abstract: The course of affairs om Mexico presents so many spurious crises, that we grow incredulous in the presence of real ones. He would be a sharp chronologist who could enumerate the times, since January, 1858, when the derangements of that unhappy Republic were on the eve of a solution; and when that era was about to dawn when a vexed people should be permitted to enter upon a career of peaceful industry and prosperity.
lead_paragraph: The course of affairs om Mexico presents so many spurious crises, that we grow incredulous in the presence of real ones. He would be a sharp chronologist who could enumerate the times, since January, 1858, when the derangements of that unhappy Republic were on the eve of a solution; and when that era was about to dawn when a vexed people should be permitted to enter upon a career of peaceful industry and prosperity. It would be safe to say the prophecy has been repeated, by the Press, taken in the aggregate, five times weekly within the period named; and yet Mexico is still in convulsions, and peace and prosperity are still strangers to its people.

abstract: By reference to our report of the proceedings had yesterday before the Special Committee of the Board of Supervisors, it will be seen that the City Chamberlain still adheres to that line of technical resistance which has already done so much to shake the confidence of the public in the security of the City and County Funds. It is now admitted that of the County money, Chamberlain PLATT holds to-...
lead_paragraph: By reference to our report of the proceedings had yesterday before the Special Committee of the Board of Supervisors, it will be seen that the City Chamberlain still adheres to that line of technical resistance which has already done so much to shake the confidence of the public in the security of the City and County Funds. It is now admitted that of the County money, Chamberlain PLATT holds to-day in his hands within a fraction of two millions of dollars; that for this vast amount of ready capital he pays no interest whatever; and that up to this time he has utterly, refused to give those bonds required by law for the safe-keeping of the amounts intrusted to him as County Treasurer. With reference to the City funds proper, Mr. PLATT declined any form of answer, either under oath or upon mere assertion, his counsel, Ex-Judge WHITING, interposing the technical objection, that the Supervisors, as a County body, had no right to inquire into City affairs.

abstract: FATAL RESULT OF THE STABBING AFFRAY IN ESSEX-STREET. -- Coroner SCHIRMER was yesterday summoned to hold an inquest at No. 148 Essex-street, upon the body of LEONARD GANDER, one of the Germans who was stabbed on Sunday night at the lagerbier saloon No. 142 Essex-street, while fighting with two brothers named XAVIER and CHARLES HOCKREITER. In consequence of his inability to procure the attendance of the witnesses of the affray, the Coroner postponed his investigation, but his Deputy, Dr. HOUTON,made a post-mortem examination of the body of the deceased, which resulted in showing that his death had been caused by a wound in the side, the knife having entered his left lung. HENRY KLOTZ, the other man who was stabbed on the same occasion, is in a very precarious state, and Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday took his ante-mortem deposition with reference to the circumstances of the fight. Upon his testimony the jury rendered a verdict charging the brothers HOCKREITER with having inflicted the injury. The inquest in the case of GANDER will be conducted to-day at the Thirteenth Ward Station-house, commencing at 9 1/2 o'clock. All the persons who engaged in the affray are said to have been very much intoxicated when it occurred.
lead_paragraph: FATAL RESULT OF THE STABBING AFFRAY IN ESSEX-STREET. -- Coroner SCHIRMER was yesterday summoned to hold an inquest at No. 148 Essex-street, upon the body of LEONARD GANDER, one of the Germans who was stabbed on Sunday night at the lagerbier saloon No. 142 Essex-street, while fighting with two brothers named XAVIER and CHARLES HOCKREITER. abstract: FALL OF A DRAW-BRIDGE.--At about 11 o'clock yesterday morning, the Draw-bridge over Newtown Creek, connecting Greenpoint with Queen's County, on the road commenced some years ago by the now defunct Flushing Plank Road Company, but never completed, fell by the weight of a team, injuring one person severely, and several horses. The team was what is known as a stone truck, and was drawn by ten horses. Swung to the truck was a piece
lead_paragraph: FALL OF A DRAW-BRIDGE. -- At about 11 o'clock yesterday morning, the Draw-bridge over Newtown Creek, connecting Greenpoint with Queen's County, on the road commenced some years ago by the now defunct Flushing Plank Road Company, but never completed, fell by the weight of a team, injuring one person severely, and several horses. The team was what is known as a stone truck, and was drawn by ten horses. Swung to the truck was a piece of marble about nine feet long and three feet square at the end, weighing about sixteen tons. The truck-master, instead of crossing the centre of the bridge, as advised, attempted to cross on one side. As the team got upon the draw, the chains supporting it gave way -- the draw sank down one side, and upset the truck and four horses into the river. A man in charge of the wheel-horses had one of his legs broken in two places, by getting caught between the team and rail of the bridge. He was attended by Dr. S.K. SNELL, who does not consider his injuries of so serious a character as to be necessarily fatal. The horses were got out of the river alive, but all of them were more or less injured -- one or two seriously. The cart and stone are yet in the river, and it will be a nice job for somebody to recover them. The Company owning this bridge is defunct, it is said, but there is a toll-house on the spot, and it is understood that the toll-taker keeps the bridge in repair for the fees he receives. An interesting legal question may grow out of this case, as to who is responsible for damages, should the owner of the team feel disposed to sue somebody. This bridge has never been considered a very strong one; but as soon as the team was capsized yesterday, the draw sprung back into place, so that travel over it was not interrupted. It sags a little on one side -- that is all.

abstract: Every Isthmian Steamer brings almost the same story from New-Granada. Month after month the same scenes are enacted and reenacted there. Now the Government party have gained an advantage which is announced from official quarters, as a crowning victory; now their opponents are conquerors, and we are assured that the flight of President OSPINA from the Federal capital may be expected within a week. Just at present our NewGranadian advices come to us filtered through.
lead_paragraph: Every Isthmian steamer brings almost the same story from New-Granada. Month after month the same scenes are enacted and reenacted there. Now the Government party have gained an advantage which is announced from official quarters, as a crowning victory; now their opponents are conquerors, and we are assured that the flight of President OSPINA from the Federal capital may be expected within a week. Just at present our NewGranadian advices come to us filtered through revolutionary sources, and we hear of an "important victory" near Santa Martha. It appears, however, upon examination, that this important battle was nothing more than a row in which some two hundred men on either side were engaged. The Revolutionists say that one hundred and seventy-five of their opponents were killed and wounded, which would allow for the escape of thirty; but the very bloodless character of the generality of wars waged by Spanish Americans, and the partiality of the combatants for exaggeration, permit us to hope that the account of the massacre at Santa Martha has been somewhat overdrawn.

abstract: The wretched weather of yesterday was much in favor of the "Unterrified Democracy," who rejoice in nothing so much as drizzly skies and filthy streets on the days of election. And yesterday was a day after their own heart -- half-melted snow-flakes constantly falling, while the cross-walks were covered, ankle-deep, with mire and sludge. Owing in great part to this cause, the Democracy have gained an Alderman, -- the Republicans holding five out of the nine seats contested for yesterday in the present Board, while the Democracy will have five out of the nine in' the Board of the ensuing year.

abstract: The fourth and last annual report of Mr. COBB is by no means a cheery document. Its figures of the past fiscal year, ending 30th June, 1860, constitute, it must be confessed, the only relief to the otherwise discouraging exhibit and present despondent tone of our retiring Chancellor of the Exchequer. His estimates on the future of the revenue might be deemed sufficiently encouraging to his successor under the next Administration, were it not that, under the existing prospects of trade as pictured by the Secretary himself, they can scarcely be taken as even a respectable guess at the Ways and Means of even the next half year, much less for the fiscal year 1861, beginning July 1, 1861, for which the law requires him to present his estimates.

abstract: The President's Message was delivered to both Houses of Congress yesterday at noon, and we print the document in full elsewhere. In the House, after the reading of the Message had been concluded, Mr. SHERMAN moved its reference to the Committee of the Whole. Mr. BOTELER, of Virginia, however, desiring to present a resolution, the motion was withdrawn, and the resolution read. It provided that so much of the Message as relates to the present perilous condition of the country be referred to a Special Committee of one from each State, with leave to report at any time. Mr. MCCLERNAND, of Illinois, moved an amendment, rehearsing the causes of difficulty, and proposing that the Committee be instructed to report by bill, or by amendment to the Constitution, and more particularly as to whether any further legislation is necessary to insure a more prompt compliance with that provision of the Constitution relating to the rendition of fugitives from service or labor. Mr. BOTELER, however, declined to accept Mr. MCCLERNAND's amendment, and also one offered by Mr. SHERMAN, proposing that the Committee be limited to fifteen. At the suggestion of several members Mr. BOTELER modified his resolution by striking out the words "with leave to report at any time;" after which Mr. MORRIS, of Pennsylvania, proposed an amendment, which was also rejected, pledging the members to sustain the Union at all hazards. The ground of objection to this resolution was that Mr. BOTELER's resolution was distinctively before the House. After various other suggestions, none of which were thought available, a vote was taken on Mr. BOTELER's proposition, and it was adopted, 145 to 38. Before the vote was announced, a number of Southern members, who had not voted, gave their reasons for declining, which were generally that their States had called Conventions to consider the same questions proposed to be discussed by the Committee, and that the people would decide them for themselves. Mr. MILES, of South Carolina, went further, however, and declared that his State was out of the Confederacy, except as to the there form, and that therefore her delegation took no interest in the question. The House did nothing else of importance, and adjourned at 3 o'clock. In the Senate, after the reading of the Message, Mr. CLINGMAN, of North Carolina, in moving its publication, opened the discussion upon the disunion question, and expressed strong secession views. Mr. CRITTENDEN, of Kentucky, followed him in a strong Union speech. The remarks of both gentlemen are given in full elsewhere. The Senate soon afterwards adjourned.

abstract: The country has now the benefit of Mr. BUCHANAN's advice on the political crisis. The Message is out, and discusses the subject at length. The document will scarcely reward the anxiety which has awaited its appearance. There are many things in it which are true, and some which are new; but its true things are not new, nor are its new things true. It is probably the most elaborate effort Mr. BUCHANAN has ever made to appear bold without taking any risks, and firm without the necessity of proving his firmness. It is possible that it may tranquillize the country, but if so, the disturbance of the public peace is much less serious than has generally been supposed.

abstract: Secretary TOUCEY says that the Board of Officcers appointed under an act of last session to examine the sailing vessels of the Navy, to determine the expediency of converting them into efficient war steamers, examined all the brigs, sloops, frigates and shipsof-the-line at the Navy-Yards from Kittery, Maine, to Gosport, Va. The character of those at sea being well known, from the records of the Department, they were included in the opinion of the Board.
lead_paragraph: Secretary TOUCEY says that the Board of Officcers appointed under an act of last session to examine the sailing vessels of the Navy, to determine the expediency of converting them into efficient war steamers, examined all the brigs, sloops, frigates and ships-of-the-line at the Navy-Yards from Kittery, Maine, to Gosport, Va. The character of those at sea being well known, from the records of the Department, they were included in the opinion of the Board. The Board deem it expedient to introduce steam power into the ships-of-the-line only. The Delaware is considered too defective for that purpose. The eight of them can be razeed and converted into first-class steam-frigates, at a cost of about $382,000 each, while those of the Minnesota class cost about $725,000 each. The report is submitted with his concurrence, as the line-of-battle-ships, in the present age of steam navition, could not go to sea with a reasonable degree of safety.

abstract: Throughout the year since our last meeting, the country has been eminently prosperous in all its material interests. The general health has been excellent, our harvests have been abundant, and plenty smiles throughout the land. Our commerce and manufactures have been prosecuted with energy and industry, and have yielded fair and ample returns. In short, no nation in the tide of time has ever presented a spectacle of greater material prosperity than we have done until within a very recent period.

abstract: The annual sale of property upon which assessments have remained unpaid for five years, commenced yesterday in a basement room of the City Hall, formerly occupied by the Chief of Police -- Mr. WM.S. DUKE being the auctioneer. The assessments are laid for various purposes, i.e., fencing vacant lots, filling in, opening streets, flagging, paving, &c., and in many cases the work has been done without the knowledge of the party assumed to be benefited thereby. In the present sale, the property is not divided into heads as in a tax sale, thus rendering it necessary for property owners to examine the entire list, consisting of 1,699 parcels, to ascertain if any of his property is up for sale. The property is sold for the lowest number of years bid, subject to the assessment, accrued interest, charges for advertising, &c., and the owner has a right to redeem it within a specified time, on payment to the purchaser of the amount paid by him, with fourteen per cent. interest, so that, in any event, the chances of a good speculation are decidedly in favor of the purchaser. There were many parties present who bid in their own property, thus saving the fourteen per cent. interest, and there were many of our leading citizens and speculators, who attend these sales regularly. The sale will continue from day to day, commencing at 12 M., and will continue, probably, ten or twelve days. The auctioneer disposed of only 107 lots yesterday, leaving nearly 1,600 yet to be sold.

abstract: SEWING-MACHINE INJUNCTIONS. -- In the United States Circuit Court, District of New-Jersey, Jersey City, yesterday, on motion of GEORGE GIFFORD, Esq., of counsel for the Wheeler & Wilson Manufacturing Company and the Grover & Baker Sewing-Machine Company, Judge DICKERSON granted injunctions in eight sewing-machine cases against parties in Newark, who were sued for infringing the sewing-machine feed patents owned by these Companies. These are the same patents in favor of which a very large number of decisions have at various times been made by United States Circuit Courts, and the validity of which has always been sustained.
lead_paragraph: SEWING-MACHINE INJUNCTIONS. -- In the United States Circuit Court, District of New-Jersey, Jersey City, yesterday, on motion of GEORGE GIFFORD, Esq., of counsel for the Wheeler & Wilson Manufacturing Company and the Grover & Baker Sewing-Machine Company, Judge DICKERSON granted injunctions in eight sewing-machine cases against parties in Newark, who were sued for infringing the sewing-machine feed patents owned by these Companies. These are the same patents in favor of which a very large number of decisions have at various times been made by United States Circuit Courts, and the validity of which has always been sustained.

abstract: The jury impanneled by Coroner HORTON to investigate the circumstances attending the death of CHARLES MCCAULEY, at No. 215 Front-street, on the night of Nov. 29, concluded their labors yesterday, rendering a verdict holding PATRICK KELLY for murder; whereupon the accused was formally commited to the County Jail to await the action of the Grand Jury. The testimony of importance, taken yesterday, was that of MCTAMANY, who was stabbed in the affray between the accused and deceased.

abstract: question is frequently asked, we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upwards of thirty years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a Female Physician and Nurse, principally among children. She has specially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class; and, as a result of this effort and practical knowledge, obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health; and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children certainly do RISE UP and bless her; especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an untimely grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits, and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of Mrs. Winslow's Soothing Syrup. Try it mothers, TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: The Fire Department of the City of New-York vs. Nathaniel Johnson. -- This is an action brought by the plaintiffs to recover a penalty of $100 for a violation of the Fire laws, in the rear of the lot No. 490 Hudson-street, in this City. It appears that the one-story building on the rear of the lot contains a steam boiler, and the rear wall of that building is claimed to be less than eight inches thick about its centre. It is claimed by the plaintiffs that the upper part of the wall rests on the boiler, and is supported by it and by the wall of a stable adjoining. The space in the wall less than eight inches thick appears to be about eight feet in length by two and a half feet in width, and it is claimed that this is a violation of the sixth section of the Fire law of 1856, requiring the outside walls of all buildings to be eight inches thick. In addition to the penalty of $100, the plaintiffs seek to have the building taken down in pursuance of section 31 of the same act. The law requires that a notice to cease further violation shall be served on the defendant. The notice served in this care read verbatim as follows: "You are hereby notified to remove the following named violation of the fire laws, to wit.: a steam-boiler without an eight-inch wall. I have examined it, and I find it lays close up against Mr. Lyons' wall.

abstract: - The Charleston Mercury is becoming alarmed at the indications of delay in the secession movement. It is especially, afraid of the proposition to postpone action until Virginia and the other Southern States can be consulted. The refusal of the Old Dominion to meet South Carolina in conference, after the JOHN BROWN affair, is reproachfully called to mind, and her motive in now seeking such a conference is denounced as selfish and base:

abstract: The United States vs. Ten Cases, marked J.H.S., containing Petticoating.--This action was  brought to forfeit the goods for undervaluation. It was brought to trial in February, 1858, before Judge Hall, who was holding the Court at that term, and a Jury. There was no evidence of a fraudulent undervaluation on the part of the importers, except the evidence of the Custom-house appraisers that the goods were worth more than was stated in the invoice.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Ten Cases, marked J.H.S., containing Petticoating. -- This action was brought to forfeit the goods for undervaluation. It was brought to trial in February, 1858, before Judge Hall, who was holding the Court at that term, and a Jury. There was no evidence of a fraudulent undervaluation on the part of the importers, except the evidence of the Custom-house appraisers that the goods were worth more than was stated in the invoice. The Judge, thereupon, directed the Jury to find a verdict for the Government, subject to the opinion of the Court, to which direction the counsel for the claimant excepted, desiring the Judge, on the contrary, to direct an absolute verdict for the claimants. A bill of exceptions was drawn, corrected in his own hand-writing by Judge Hall, and signed and sealed by him, and on this a motion for a new trial was made by the counsel for the claimants before Judge BETT[???], and by him granted on the 3d of February, 1859, he holding that the question of intent should have been submitted to the Jury. In his decision of that motion he intimated that Judge Hall had probably settled the bill of exceptions inadvertently, not noticing that it averred that he had taken the case away from the Jury.

abstract: Trade continues dull, with little of interest legitimately transpiring in the market. Attempts to force sales of Cuba sugars and spirits turpentine at auction, have been met unfavorably. The Emily Seyburn's cargo, 500 bbls. Muscovado, was advertised at auction, and holders of other parcels dropped their prices from 10c. to 8 1/2c. Upon the offering of the cargo, 20 hhds. sold at $9 47 1/2 per hundred pounds, and the balance was withdrawn. A similar course was pursued in regard to spirits turpentine; a late import was put up at auction, and being competed with by other holders, resulted in sales of about 5,000 gallons, at 90c.@95c., bids failing for any larger quantity. Candles have continued to move freely; sales, since the last dispatch, comprise 3,500 boxes Adamantines, at 24 1/4c.@24 1/2c., the market closing firm, with indications of an advanced rate the coming week. Provisions of all kinds meet very little inquiry; the tendency of the market is still unfavorable.

abstract: In this Court, before Recorder BARNARD, yesterday, after calling various cases in which parties were not prepared, the first trial was that of Terrant P. Merrian, indicted for assault and battery on Warren A. Headen, a Clerk for the New-York and Erie Railroad Company. The difficulty arose between the parties, who were fellow-boarders, concerning the occupation of a closet. During the dispute complainant testified that the prisoner used abusive language toward the lady of the house. Complainant then interfered, and hence the assault arose. Under this state of circumstances the jury acquitted.

abstract: Hon. J.R. FLOYD, Secretary of the War Department, reports that the actual and authorized strength of the Army remains substantially the same as last year. The troops available for service against the Indians have been engaged in campaigns of the greatest activity, and the Army has been constantly in the field, and upon an active war footing. The Department of Texas has been restored to tranquility; the Rio Grande frontier from Fort Fillmore to Fort Brown is well protected, and a very active campaign has been carried on against the Kiowa and Comanche Indians, upon the head waters of the Arkansas and the Canadian, resulting in breaking them up and dispersing them in every direction. To chastise the Indians in New-Mexico a large part of the troops have been stationed in Utah southward to New-Mexico, and there seems to be every prospect that they will meet with the punishment which they deserve. Allusion is then made to the battle with the Pah-Utes in Carson Valley, in which Mr. ORMSBY was killed, and to the subsequent overwhelming defeat of these Indians by Col. HAYS. The Snake Indians in Washington Territory, on the road between Forts Bridger and Walla-Walla, have been hostile during the past season, and have not yet been reduced to subordination. All these operations have been carried on when the appropriations were made only to maintain the Department on a peace footing, and have rendered necessary an unforeseen expenditure of about half a million dollars. Secretary FLOYD urges the necessity of restoring the superintendence and control of the Indians to the War Department, since it is impossible to keep them in subjection in any other way than by a display of military power. He thinks much might be saved to the Treasury by devolving on officers of the Army duties which are now discharged by others at high rates of compensation.

abstract: - There is some curiosity to know the reason why no allusion was made in the President's Message to either Peru or Paraguay. Our peaceful relations with almost every country in the world, even with the petty Republics of Central America, are complacently discussed, but the two countries with which we have unsettled difficulties are curiously ignored. We have just broken off all diplomatic intercourse with Peru, and if we mean to act up to our professions and enforce our claims against her Government, the next move en regle would be the appearance of a couple of American men-of-war in the harbor of Callao. This step would be anticipated if France or England were parties to the dispute; but Peru, in displaying a refractory temper towards the United States, calculates, doubtless, on the present distracted condition of our domestic affairs. The causes, however, that may involve this country at any moment in war, surely merit some notice in a Presidential Message. The late award of the United States and Paraguay Commission is also passed over in silence. As it is in the power of the President to annul that award, some indication of his approval or disapproval was looked for, but it has been looked for in vain.
