abstract: -Now that the Charter election is over, and in view of the triumphant indorsement given to so many of the Japanese Aldermen by their intelligent constituencies, there can be no good reason, we submit, for any further delay in making public and taking definite action upon the various items of the grand Asiatic operation. However blamable the Aldermen may have been in the motives which lay behind their public votes and acts, it should not be lost sight of that many honest tradesmen are to-day suffering serious inconvenience, if not positive danger of bankruptcy, through the non-fulfillment by the City of those bargains which the Aldermen made.
lead_paragraph: -Now that the Charter election is over, and in view of the triumphant indorsement given to so many of the Japanese Aldermen by their intelligent constituencies, there can be no good reason, we submit, for any further delay in making public and taking definite action upon the various items of the grand Asiatic operation. However blamable the Aldermen may have been in the motives which lay behind their public votes and acts, it should not be lost sight of that many honest tradesmen are to-day suffering serious inconvenience, if not positive danger of bankruptcy, through the non-fulfillment by the City of those bargains which the Aldermen made.

abstract: The gentlemen of the Albany Regency have not been fortunate in their alliances. Their fusion with the trading chiefs of the Native American Party was not ratified by the rank and file either of the Democratic or American organizations. "Fusion" failed to receive last month anything like the joint vote cast for FILLMORE and BUCHANAN four years ago -- the great masses of the Americans seeming to have united their "lives, fortunes and sacred honors" with the Republicans, while only a few of their abandoned leaders accepted commissions and epaulettes in the Regency's mongrel coalition.
lead_paragraph: The gentlemen of the Albany Regency have not been fortunate in their alliances. abstract: One of the most curious effects of binocular vision is to be observed on the Kansas frontier. The spectator on one side of that invisible line sees on the other a vast army of outlaws, capable of all and guilty of most imaginable outrages; swarming about the country, and prepared for an early and murderous onslaught upon the unoffending and unprepared population of Missouri. The leader of these ravening miscreants is represented as a more than sanguinary Thug, thirsting for the blood of slaveholders in preference to any other beverage; and addicted by a singular perversion of taste to the apotheosis of the negro, and the perdition of the white. His heaven-daring designs contemplate, we are assured, the subjugation of several Slave States, with the extinction of Slavery, and the possession of free farms by free men. Already, it is stated, his men have seized a federal fort, plundered a land office, broken up a federal court, and have shot down or banished every Missourian who fell in their way.

abstract: Whether Chief-Justice TANEY does or does not propose to expire officially just in time to prevent the Administration of Mr. LINCOLN from nominating his successor may still be regarded as an open question. In the last and most lamentable of his annual messages, amid the prayers and prognostics to which His Excellency is moved by the perils of the Union, the President finds time and space to bestow the following elaborate benediction upon his pet Pennsylvanian, the Attorney-General:

abstract: The question of disunion was still further debated in the Senate yesterday. After some unimportant preliminary business, Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, introduced a resolution instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the propriety of establishing an armed police in border States, to maintain the general peace and to execute more effectually the Fugitive Slave law. On motion of Mr. CAMERON, of Pennsylvania, it was made the special order for Monday next.
lead_paragraph: The question of disunion was still further debated in the Senate yesterday. After some unimportant preliminary business, Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, introduced a resolution instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the propriety of establishing an armed police in border States, to maintain the general peace and to execute more effectually the Fugitive Slave law. On motion of Mr. CAMERON, of Pennsylvania, it was made the special order for Monday next. This resolution was suggested by the new troubles which have broken out in Kansas. Mr. HALE, of New-Hampshire, then moved the reconsideration of the vote by which the President's Message was ordered to be printed, and proceeded to comment in severe terms upon its inconsistencies. He thought the President should have pointed out some rule for guidance in the present difficulties. He had failed to meet the question boldly, and now the only thing which can avert a civil war is a resort to the ballot-box. Mr. HALE was followed by Mr. BROWN, of Mississippi, who considered disunion inevitable, and by Mr. IVERSON, of Georgia, who declared that five States would be out of the Union before the 4th of March; that the true policy of the Slave States was to leave the Confederacy, and that no power under Heaven could prevent it. He believed that the next twelve months would find the Southern Confederacy the most prosperous and powerful which ever existed. Mr. IVERSON's language was very violent, and special pains were taken by him to declare that the seceding States would be ready to fight for the position which they would seek to assume: Mr. DAVIS, of Mississippi, hoped the Message would be printed, and deprecated threats. Mr. WIGFALL, of Texas, asserted the right of each State to act for itself, and compared the violation of the laws by the States to the breaking of treaties by foreign powers. He declared his inability to comprehend the purport of the Message, and believed that the President would precipitate the very trouble which he intended to avoid, He concluded by declaring his intention to introduce at an early day a resolution to ascertain whether any order had gone out from the Departments in reference to Federal authority in those States proposing to secede. Mr. WIGFALL was followed by Mr. SAULSBURY, of Delaware, who made a strong speech for the Union. He declared that Delaware was the first State to adopt the Federal Constitution, and would be the last to countenance any act calculated to lead to a separation of the States. His remarks were warmly applauded. On motion of Mr. HAMLIN, the Senate adjourned at 2 1/4 o'clock. In the House, the secession question was not touched upon. Mr. GROW succeeded in calling up the Homestead bill, and it was finally passed, 132 against 76. The Pension Appropriation bill, and that for the support of the West Point Military Academy, having been reported by Mr. SHERMAN, from the Committee of Ways and Means, were also passed. An attempt was made to refer the Post-route bill, returned from the Senate at the last session with amendments, to the Post-office Committee, but it failed.

abstract: Robert E. Curtiss and others vs. Geo. Marshall. -- This cause came on for trial in May, 1860, before Judge WOODRUFY and a jury, in which the plaintiffs recovered the sum of $500 for a refusal on the part of the defendant to perform his contract. A motion for a new trial was argued at Special Term. It before Judge HOFFMAN, and the motion denied. It appeared on the trial of this cause that Hiram Curtiss, in the Spring of 1857, made a contract with defendant by which Marshall was to receive at his lumber-yard in this City, and Curtiss was to deliver 100,000 feet of pine lumber, to be delivered during that year as Marshall should require, monthly. During the Spring and Summer of that year 38,000 feet were delivered under this contract, for which Marshall gave his notes. During the Fall Marshall desired Curtiss to suspend delivery for a short period. Curtiss, it appears, had on hand 60,000 feet of lumber for delivery to the defendant. In December, 1857, their contract was modified as to the time of the delivery of the lumber, by which it was arranged that Marshall should receive the balance of the lumber all at one time, after he had used up the lumber he had already received of Curtiss. Curtiss assigned the lumber and the claim to the plaintiffs, who, in March, 1858, called upon Marshall to have him take the lumber. This Marshall absolutely refused to do, but was, as alleged, on that day taking lumber of other parties.
lead_paragraph: Robert E. Curtiss and others vs. Geo. Marshall. -- This cause came on for trial in May, 1860, before Judge WOODRUFY and a jury, in which the plaintiffs recovered the sum of $500 for a refusal on the part of the defendant to perform his contract. During the Spring and Summer of that year 38,000 feet were delivered under this contract, for which Marshall gave his notes. During the Fall Marshall desired Curtiss to suspend delivery for a short period. Curtiss, it appears, had on hand 60,000 feet of lumber for delivery to the defendant. In December, 1857, their contract was modified as to the time of the delivery of the lumber, by which it was arranged that Marshall should receive the balance of the lumber all at one time, after he had used up the lumber he had already received of Curtiss. Curtiss assigned the lumber and the claim to the plaintiffs, who, in March, 1858, called upon Marshall to have him take the lumber. This Marshall absolutely refused to do, but was, as alleged, on that day taking lumber of other parties.

abstract: THE HOMICIDE OF LEONARD GANDER. -- Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday investigated the circumstances connected with the affray which occurred on Sunday evening last, at the lager-bier saloon No. 142 Essex-street, when LEONARD GANDER, a young German, residing at No. 148 Essex-street, was mortally wounded by another German, named XAVIER HOCKREITER. It appeared from the evidence that GANDER and some friends had been carousing together in the bier saloon, and that the former went out for a few moments upon the sidewalk. Presently his companions heard angry words passing between him and two other men named XAVIER and CHARLES HOCKREITER, father and son, who came along the street. What occasioned the dispute, however, did not transpire, and when the other persons came out of the saloon, XAVIER HOCKREITER was chasing GANDER around a wagon, which stood in the street, and finally succeeded in stabbing him with a dirk-knife which he carried in his hand. HENRY KLOTZ, one of GANDER's friends, ran up to assist the latter, and he knocked HOCKREITER into the gutter. CHARLES HOCKREITER then went to his father's assistance and struck KLOTZ, who also knocked him down, but he regained his feet and stabbed his antagonist. The police by this time came up and arrested the HOCKREITERS who were taken to the Station-house, and the injured men were conveyed to their respective homes, GANDER's death occuring on Tuesday morning from the effects of the wound. Dr. BOUTON made a post-mortem examination of the body and found that deceased had received a stab in the left side, cutting into the stomach, and sufficient, in his opinion, to cause death. The jury declared upon the evidence that deceased had died from exhaustion, consequent upon hemorrhage from the wound, and charged XAVIER HOCKREITER with having inflicted the injury with some instrument to them unknown. The accused was then committed to the Tombs, pending action by the Grand Jury. He said that he was a native of Germany, 47 years of age, and a turner by trade. With reference to the charge, he stated that it was not true that he had inflicted the stab, as he had no knife to do it with. Deceased was 19 years of age.

abstract: The Committee on the Judiciary had under consideration to-day the case of Judge WATROUS, of Texas. Much testimony has been adduced, tending so strongly against him that it is understood they will report soon in favor of his impeachment. Gov. HOUSTON is understood to have done much to bring about this result. I am told by a gentleman from Texas that WATROUS is understood to sympathize with the secession movement in Texas.

abstract: The Electoral College met at 10 o'clock this morning, and without delay proceeded to cast the vote of the State for LINCOLN and HAMLIN. STEWART L. WOODFORD of New-York, was appointed a messenger to convey the certified copies to Washington, and GEORGE BULL, of Erie, was deputed to deposit a copy with the United States Judges. The College then adjourned.
lead_paragraph: Special Dispatch to the New-York Times.

abstract: - Mr. BUCHANAN's devotion to Lecompton, -- the worst and most fatal of his many follies, -- would be more touching if it were not quite so ridiculous. Quite a considerable portion of his Message is devoted to a glorification of this unhappy subject, and his own action in relation thereto. He tells us how prompt he was "to exert the whole constitutional powers of the Executive" to check the designs of those "violent revolutionary leaders" who could not see the dusky beauty of "Lecompton" with his partial eyes. He boasts of his quickness in sending "a strong detachment of the army" to "assist the civil magistrates in enforcing the laws," and "to aid the Marshal of the United States and his Deputies." So dazzling, he assures us, were the charms of this idolized "Lecompton," that he could not have refused submitting it to Congress "without violating his clearest and strongest convictions of duty."
lead_paragraph: - Mr. BUCHANAN's devotion to Lecompton, -- the worst and most fatal of his many follies, -- would be more touching if it were not quite so ridiculous. He boasts of his quickness in sending "a strong detachment of the army" to "assist the civil magistrates in enforcing the laws," and "to aid the Marshal of the United States and his Deputies." So dazzling, he assures us, were the charms of this idolized "Lecompton," that he could not have refused submitting it to Congress "without violating his clearest and strongest convictions of duty."

abstract: -Upon one point President BUCHANAN seems sufficiently resolute. He adheres to his Lecompton policy with unyielding tenacity. Regardless of the fact that it dissolved the Democratic Party, he thinks that nothing else can prevent the dissolution of the Union. The doctrine of Congressional protection for Slavery in the Territories has just been discarded by an overwhelming majority of the American people, -- and the President proposes forthwith to have it engrafted upon the American Constitution. Mr. BUCHANAN is certainly a rare specimen of a statesman. Fortunately the species expires with him.
lead_paragraph: -Upon one point President BUCHANAN seems sufficiently resolute. He adheres to his Lecompton policy with unyielding tenacity. Mr. BUCHANAN is certainly a rare specimen of a statesman. Fortunately the species expires with him.

abstract: There is a universal desire for "conciliation." Everybody demands that something shall be done to save the Union and restore peace to the country. Upon this point all men, of all parties and of all sections, are agreed. But next comes the question, what shall be done? The general reply is, that measures, of compromise must be adopted; -- the two sections must come to a mutual understanding; -- there must no longer be hostility on one side, or apprehension on the other. Each must respect the other's rights, -- consult its interests and be prepared, if need be, to sacrifice something for its welfare. Up to this point there is a very gratifying sentiment of unanimity. The love of the Union seems paramount in all hearts. Everybody is loyal to the Constitution and is quite prepared to make any effort that may be necessary for its preservation.

abstract: On Tuesday evening Mr. John Patton, of No. 91 East Thirty-first-street, went into the billiard saloon No. 679 Broadway, having with him a small trunk, containing $500. He had temporary occasion to leave the place, and supposing his trunk would be safe until he returned, he laid it away in a corner. Upon returning to the saloon after an absence of a few minutes, he found that his property had been taken away, and suspecting Antonio Cordova, Frank M. Robalcaba, and three other men, all natives of Cuba, who were the only persons present, to be the thieves, he called in Detectives King and Smith to arrest them. They were taken to Head-quarters, where in possession of one was found a five-dollar bill, which Mr. Patton believes he can identify as a part of his money, and another admitted that he had been implicated in the larceny. It is thought that all the money will be recovered. The prisoners were committed for examination by Justice KELLY.

abstract: The brig G.T. Ward, BRIGGS, master, which arrived to-day from St. Marks, reports that on the 2d inst., Barnegat bearing west 15 miles, during a heavy blow from W.N.W., fell in with the British schooner Alma, of St. Andrews, N.B., Capt. HAYES, from Kingston, Jamaica, 25 days out, bound to New-York, with foremast head and both topmasts gone, the mainboom and all sails blown away and leaking badly. The G.T. Ward took from her the captain and crew, six in all, and brought them to this port. Capt. H. reports that on the 20th ult., GEORGE NASON, seaman of Nova Scotia, died, and at the time of being taken off all hands were sick. They had had a succession of very heavy gales since leaving Kingston. On the 2d inst., at night, saw a vessel on fire, which was supposed to be the Alma. The A. had a cargo of pimento, logwood, rum, &c. She was built at St. Andrews, N.B., 100 tons burden, about seven years old, and is owned by WM. WHITLOCK, at St. Andrews, and rates A 2.

abstract: In a recent speech delivered by Mr. BRIGHT at Wakefield, England, he referred to a letter he had received about two years ago from Mr. COBDEN, who was at that time in the United States of America, and in which the writer said that, notwithstanding the artisan and laboring class in England had made greater progress during the last twenty-five years than they had during any former similar period, of time, those classes in the United States were much further advance than they were in England. This was a remarkable fact, and Mr. BRIGHT had never heard any man who disputed it. He met not long ago a gentleman connected with what was generally reported the most reputable of the Press in England, who had been spending some days in the United States, and he gave the same accounts. He wanted to know what made the difference. It was not necessarily the form of Government. It was not a question not latitude or longitude; and people had to work in the United States; the machinery there did more labor, and the land was not even as fertile. How came it then, he asked their public writers, he asked their statesmen, he asked ministers of religion -- how came it, then, -- this fact was notorious and indisputable -- that in the United States the great body of the artisans and laboring classes were so much better off than they were in England? He knew, of three causes that would account for it. In the United States the land was wholly free from all feudal law and tenures; the people were instructed by an extensive and thoroughly working common school, useful to a degree infinitely beyond what the people of this country ever dreamt of; and, further, that, from some cause or other that he could not then inquire into, the Government of the United States, although the population of each country was about 20,000,000, spent nearly $#163;60,000,000 sterling less than the Government of this country. He only stated facts, and he said they were not in the least questions of party, not questions of forms of government, but questions of principles with regard to our legislation.

abstract: It is often said that the apprehension of danger is worse than the danger itself. It is not easy to say what evils would follow a dissolution of the Union, -- but they could scarcely be more serious than the general fear of that event has already caused to our business interests. Our people have been told so often by the Herald and other political or professional alarmists, that our commerce, which is our life, will be utterly destroyed by disunion, -- that our Shipping, with all its incidental branches of employment, will be instantly transferred to Southern ports, and that property of all kinds will fall to one-fourth of its present value, that they have actually come to believe it. And many of them seem already inclined to sell their property in Railroads, Real Estate, Banks, &c., &c., at almost any sacrifice rather than risk the threatened depreciation.

abstract: We have already spoken of the manner in which every effort of the Republicans to promote a spirit of conciliation and to adjust the differences which disturb the public peace, is received by the leading organs of the Democratic Party. lead_paragraph: We have already spoken of the manner in which every effort of the Republicans to promote a spirit of conciliation and to adjust the differences which disturb the public peace, is received by the leading organs of the Democratic Party. With scarcely an exception those efforts are made the occasion for fresh taunts and abuse. The Washington Constitution fills its columns day after day with partisan denunciations and slanders of the party which has just elected a President of the United States, -- and with arguments to convince the South that their only chance of safety lies in secession. The Journal of Commerce, with better motives, is equally intolerant and partisan in its tone, -- while the Herald pursues the only course which can give it importance or influence of any sort, by fanning the excitement and doing everything in its power to prevent the restoration of peace.

abstract: Great injustice is done to Vermont by the sweeping statement which is going the rounds of the Press, and has figured largely, of course, as a stimulant to secession, in the Washington Constitution, that Vermont had utterly refused to repeal her Personal Liberty bill. The Legislature, by a joint resolution, instructed the Committee, appointed to revise.
lead_paragraph: -- Great injustice is done to Vermont by the sweeping statement which is going the rounds of the Press, and has figured largely, of course, as a stimulant to secession, in the Washington Constitution, that Vermont had utterly refused to repeal her Personal Liberty bill. The Legislature, by a joint resolution, instructed the Committee, appointed to revise the Statutes of the State, to inquire whether any of its provisions were in conflict with the Constitution of the United States; -- and Senator WOODBRIDGE, in the debate on the subject, expressed the general sentiment of the Legislature when he said that "the people of Vermont, the Legislature of Vermont, the Judiciary of Vermont, do not wish, and will not tolerate, upon our statute books, any law that conflicts with the Constitution and laws of our General Government."

abstract: We have received the statement of MULLIGAN concerning the alleged forgery of the Broderick will. It is very full and particular -- giving names and dates and all the details of the alleged conspiracy. We cannot publish it, because it would be libelous; and, even if every word of it were true, the only witnesses are the parties concerned, who would not testify, and MULLIGAN, whose testimony is now rendered worthless. But we certainly think the matter calls for the rigid investigation of the legal authorities. There has always been a mystery about this will which has never been cleared up to the satisfaction of the public.

abstract: The Board of Charities and Corrections held their regular meeting yesterday, at their rooms, in Bond-street, the President, Mr. DRAPER in the Chair. The Committee of the Whole made a report, from which we make the following abstracts: 363 persons (152 males and 211 females) were transferred, to the Work-house on Blackwells Island, from the 22d of November to the 1st of December, as vagrants and disorderly persons. Of these, 159 had been committed twice, 43 three times, 36 four times, 20 five times, 35 six times, 18 twenty times, 14 thirty-nine times, 5 fifty times, I sixty times and 1 one hundred times. The contract for plumbing the City Prison was awarded to A.G. GERATY, at $168.

abstract: Last evening, at about 6 1/2 o'clock, an explosion of two medium-sized shells took place on board the Spanish frigate Berenguela, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, which resulted in fatal injuries to two men, and in serious ones to four others. The charges of two guns had been temporarily removed and placed in a corner of the ship. Some sparks of fire, emitted from a cigar, having been communicated to them, they burst with terrific force, causing two sailors to jump off the dock into the dry dook, where they probably received fatal injuries. The ship was immediately discovered to be on fire, which was speedily extinguished by the firemen of the yard. The Berenguela sustained little damage. The dangerously-wounded sailors were conveyed to the Naval Hospital. Two 80 pound shells were lying near those that exploded, but providentially did not ignite.
lead_paragraph: Last evening, at about 6 1/2 o'clock, an explosion of two medium-sized shells took place on board the Spanish frigate Berenguela, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, which resulted in fatal injuries to two men, and in serious ones to four others. The charges of two guns had been temporarily removed and placed in a corner of the ship. Some sparks of fire, emitted from a cigar, having been communicated to them, they burst with terrific force, causing two sailors to jump off the dock into the dry dook, where they probably received fatal injuries. The ship was immediately discovered to be on fire, which was speedily extinguished by the firemen of the yard. The Berenguela sustained little damage. The dangerously-wounded sailors were conveyed to the Naval Hospital. Two 80 pound shells were lying near those that exploded, but providentially did not ignite.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen, acting as a Board of Canvassers, in session most of the day yesterday, canvassing the returns of the recent election. The First-Ward was the only one completed, and the official canvass declared the elections of HENRY SMITH, (Rep.,)for Alderman; THOS. FITZPATRICK, (Dem.,) for School Commissioner, and L. NOLTE, School Inspector. After partially canvassing the Second, Third and Eighth Wards, the Board adjourned to 9 o'clock this morning.

abstract: The visit of the Empress EUGENE to the Scotch metropolis has been received by its inhabitants with much gratification and pride. Coming as she does ostensibly in incognito, she has, nevertheless, wherever recognized, obtained a welcome of the most genuine description. Old countries have long memories, and Scotland does not forget that before the union with England, to which she owes so much, her great ally and friend was France; and to the illustrious lady herself a still closer tie is owned, for she is of the family of the Kirkpatricks, whose history may be traced from the time of ROBERT BRUCE. Scotland has before now been the place of exile of French monarchs, for CHARLES X. resided long in Holyrood; but hitherto it has not been honored with a visit from any of me reigning houses of France.

abstract: Thomas S. Hathaway vs. The Sun Mutual Insurance Company. -- The facts of this case appear from the case made as follows: In 1855 the brig Berinda was insured by the defendant for the sum of $10,000, the vessel being valued at $20,000; and it appears that the owners had by the policy the privilege of making further insurance upon the vessel at any time within one year from the date of the first policy. She sailed in February, 1855, from Hong Kong, in China, to Shanghai, intending to return again, but met with disastrous weather on the voyage; and on the 20th of February, in the same year, took a Chinese pilot near Guzluff, and the next day proceeded up the river Yang-tze-Kiang.

abstract: The reg  NEW-YORK SANITARY ASSOCIATION. The reg  ular monthly meeting of this Association was held at the Cooper Institute last evening. It being the second annual meeting of the Society, the attendance was unusuallly large. Dr. HARRIS read the annual report of the Council, containing a summary of the doings of the Association during the past and preceding year of its existence, and setting forth the beneficial results of its organization. Gen. WETMORE read the
lead_paragraph: -- The reg NEW-YORK SANITARY ASSOCIATION. The reg ular monthly meeting of this Association was held at the Cooper Institute last evening. It being the second annual meeting of the Society, the attendance was unusuallly large. Dr. HARRIS read the annual report of the Council, containing a summary of the doings of the Association during the past and preceding year of its existence, and setting forth the beneficial results of its organization. Gen. WETMORE read the annual report of the Committee on amendments to the Constitution and By-laws, proposing several amendments, all of which were adopted; On motion, it was decided to hold a special meeting of the Association on the 20th inst., to consider a resolution offered by Dr. GRISOOM at the last meeting recommending the formation of female. Sanitary Associations; similar to those in operation in Europe, and from which it is claimed that great good results to the families of the poor. The annual election of officers of the association then took place and resulted as follows: President, Gen. F.E. MATHER; 1st Vice-President, R.H. McCurdy; 2d Vice-President, Dr. A.C. Post; Recording Secretary, Dr. Wm. R. Donaghe: Corresponding Secretary. Dr. E. Harris; Treasurer, N. Hayden; Librarian, W.B. Roberts; Members of the Council, Peter-Cooper, H.T. Cleaveland P.M. Wetmore, Lieut. E.L. Viole, Dr. Isaac Wood, Dr. J.H. Griscom, Dr. Stephen Smith, Dr. J. Frankel.

abstract: On Wednesday afternoon, Otto Hansman, a young man having a situation as clerk with Martin Fox & Co., fancy goods dealers, at No. 53 Vesey-street, was taken into custody by Detectives Tiemann and McCord, charged with having pilfered on different occasions a quantity of trimmings and other articles belonging to his employers. Subsequently he acknowledged himself guilty, and said that he had been assisted in his knavery by Arthur Geagling, a clerk engaged in the establishment of Minster & Kohn, No. 42 Vesey-street, who also had been in the habit of stealing from the store in which he was employed. An arrangement existed between the young men by which the goods obtained by one were to be disposed of by the other, and the money equally divided. In this way Hansman confessed that each of them had stolen about $200 worth of property, for which a market had been found at the store of Stein & Rosenstein, corner of Grand and Orchard streets, and at the tailor stop of Charles Gerst, in Chrystie-street. The price paid by these persons for the goods was so small that the officers entertained no doubt that they became purchasers with a full knowledge that the property was dishonestly obtained, consequently Justice KELLY was applied to, and warrants for the arrest of the alleged receivers were issued. Having been arrested, the accused were all committed for examination. Young Geagling is also in custody pending a hearing in the case.

In this way Hansman confessed that each of them had stolen about $200 worth of property, for which a market had been found at the store of Stein & Rosenstein, corner of Grand and Orchard streets, and at the tailor stop of Charles Gerst, in Chrystie-street. The price paid by these persons for the goods was so small that the officers entertained no doubt that they became purchasers with a full knowledge that the property was dishonestly obtained, consequently Justice KELLY was applied to, and warrants for the arrest of the alleged receivers were issued. Having been arrested, the accused were all committed for examination. Young Geagling is also in custody pending a hearing in the case.

abstract: At about 11 o'clock Wednesday night it was discovered that the two 36-inch mains, which supply nearly all the Croton water for the City, broke in Fifth-avenue, opposite the old Arsenal. Mr. CRAVERN, the Chief Engineer, was informed of the breakage at 12 o'clock, and by the time he arrived on the ground, (fifteen minutes thereafter,) all the water in the Lower Reservoir was exhausted, and a small lake was formed. In the neighborhood of the leakage.

Mr. POWELL,
lead_paragraph: The Disunion question occupied the attention of both Houses of Congress yesterday, to the exclusion of all other business. In the Senate, Mr. LATHAM, of California, presented a memorial from the Chamber of Commerce of San Francisco, asking for the establishment of a daily Overland Mail, but it was laid over for the present. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, then introduced a resolution, in accordance with the notice given by him yesterday, providing that so much of the President's Message as relates to the present condition of the country be referred to a Special Committee of thirteen. The Senate, however, without considering it, adjourned over until Monday. In the House, after some unimportant proceedings, the Speaker appointed the Committee of one from each State, in accordance with Mr. BOTELER's resolution, to consider and report upon all questions connected with the perilous condition of the country. This important Committee is constituted as follows:

abstract: We know not that the friends of the Negro have much more to expect from the new President. His powers are very limited, and will be confined within a space much narrower than their strictly legal extent by the same necessity which has made Mr. BUCHANAN abstain from any attempt on Cuba, and tolerate the anarchy and even aggressions of unhappy Mexico. For the safety of the Union itself we confess we have no fear. Of course, it will take some time before men can cool down from the bluster which has been so profusely used for electioneering purpose's to the language of moderation and truth. Some men have said these things so often that they are ashamed to show how little they believe them, and some so often that they have really learnt to believe them themselves. But when the cooler heads of the South begin to consider how imaginary is the injury which they have sustained, how vast are the interests involved, how heavy would be the cost, how considerable the danger, of disunion, and how impossible it would be for the Southern States to maintain in the face of the world the strong position they now hold as numbers of the great American Confederacy, we suspect that the South will think better of it, and turn its activity into the more practical channel of providing Mr. LINCLON with a Democratic successor in 1864.

abstract: A fire occurred shortly before 7 o'clock last evening in the four-story warehouse, No. 103 Maiden-lane, occupied by L. GAIL dealer in German drugs. The flames were first seen issuing from the top story, and apprehensions were entertained that the fire would do considerable damage in consequence of the scarcity of water, resulting from the breaking of the Croton main. The Fire Department, however, had made preparations for the emergency -- the steam-engines from an early hour in the evening: having been kept in readiness -- and as quickly as possible after the alarm, was sounded a line was formed from the river, whence a supply of water was obtained, and brought to bear upon the flames. In this way the fire was confined to the floor in which it originated, but the stock throughout the building was damaged to the extent of $10,000. The loss is said to be covered by insurance in City companies. The building was injured to the amount of $1,500. The stock of the Bay State Glass Company, in the adjoining premises, No. 101 Maiden-lane, was slightly injured by water; fully insured. In view of the danger to which the City is exposed from conflagration, on account of the lack of water, the Union Ferry Company has determined on keeping one of its boats with steam up at each ferry slip, to be ready at any moment that they may be made useful. The steam fire-engine "Victory," No. 13, of the Eastern District, Brooklyn, also volunteered their services to the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, and having, been accepted, they were stationed in the Park Under steam all night.

abstract: In this Court yesterday before Judge MULLEN, the prisoner Morrissett, in whose case the Jury had brought in a verdict of manslaughter in the first degree, at 11 o'clock on the previous night, -- was brought up for sentence. Counsel asked that sentence might be postponed a few days, in order that he might prepare a motion for a new trial on the two-fold ground of newly discovered evidence since the last trial, and because the finding of the Jury had not been in accordance with the evidence. The prisoner had either committed murder in the first degree, or else was entitled to an acquittal. If he engaged in burning his store, the act was a felony, and the resulting death of La Rochelle must be murder in the first degree.

lead_paragraph: In April, 1859, the Legislature of the State authorised the addition to the Central Park, as then laid out, of the ground lying between. One Hundred and sixth and One Hundred and Ninth streets, and the Fifth and Eight avenues, and during the Summer of that year Commissioners were appointed by the Superme Court to award damages and lay assessments for the property taken for the Park, as well as that benefited by it. This Commission concluded their labors a few weeks rinse, and the maps were deposited in the office of Mr. EWEN, Superintendent of street Improvements, and the public generally, as well as the parties specially interested, were invited to call and inspect them.

abstract: CLERICAL WIT. -- Rochester (N.Y.) is blessed with a clergyman named LAURIE, who is represented as being remarkably eloquent, successful and eccentric. As an evidence of the latter quality, the following anecdote will be pertinent. A few weeks ago, Mr. LAURIE exchanged pulpits with Rev. E.H. CHAPIN, of this City, and upon his rising to give out the opening hymn, many persons who had gone to church only to hear their favorite, retired; whereupon Mr. LAURIE, hymn book in hand, paused -- looked gravely around and quietly remarked, "All those who came here to worship E.H. CHAPIN have now an opportunity to retire; and those who came to worship the Everlasting God will please unite in singing the following hymn." There was no further departure till the service was concluded.

abstract: Austin Shuman vs. Michael McKeon. This is an appeal to the General Term of this Court, from a judgement in ejectment. The action was originally tried before Judge Pierrepont, under whose direction the jury found a verdict for the defendant. The original action was to eject the defendant, as lessee of George Harrison, from certain premises on the southeast corner of Bleeoker and Grove streets, in this  City.
lead_paragraph: Austin Shuman vs. Michael McKeon. This is an appeal to the General Term of this Court, from a judgement in ejectment. The action was originally tried before Judge Pierrepont, under whose direction the jury found a verdict for the defendant. The original action was to eject the defendant, as lessee of George Harrison, from certain premises on the southeast corner of Bleeoker and Grove streets, in this City. It seems that these premises were originally a part of Grove street, and that in 1836 proceedings were taken by the corporate authorities of this City to open a public place between Grove, Christopher and Fourth streets, and to improve Grove-street, between Fourth and Bleecker, by widening the same on the northerly side, and by closing a part of the said street on the southerly side. Application to the Supreme Court was made for that purpose, and Commissioners were appointed, who made their report in 1837, by which, among other things, it appeared that a gore of land lying in Grove-street, on the southerly side, (including the premises in question,) was required for the purpose of being closed, and vested the same to the use of the Mayor, Aldermen and Commonalty of the City. The Commissioners assessed the Corporation for the land so taken, (including the premises in question,) in the sum of $5,125. The property at the time of this proceeding was in the possession of one Oakley, and by subsequent grants it finally came into the possession of George Harrison, to whom the corporation subsequently granted, making his title perfect. It was admitted on the trial that defendant was a lessee of Harrison. It appeared on the trial that the lot in question lay in the public street after its widening, and before Oakley got his title to the adjoining land. It is contended by counsel therefore that whatever interest in this lot he ever had must have been derived solely from the fact that he was the adjacent owner. Oakley, it is contended, was divested of the title to this property in two different ways, first by the foreclosure of a mortgage which he had given to the executors of one Gerret Gilbert. In March, 1839, however, Oakley conveyed to one David H. Robertson whatever interest he had in the premises. It appears to be well settled, as contended by the counsel for respondent, that the fee of the street as far as the middle is vested in the owner of the adjoining lot, and that the same title will pass to the grantee, unless expressly excluded by the terms of the deed. In this case there do appear to be words in the grant to Harrison which would seem to exclude the street, and it seems that in the grant of Oakley to Robertson these premises are described as the same which were granted to him by the Manhattan Company. It is, therefore, contended that if the defendant is not entitled to possession, or if the plaintiff rejects and denies the effect of the proceedings to close a portion of Grove-street, the gore in question is remitted to its former state of a public highway, and the plaintiff has shown no right to possession thereto, Decision reserved.

abstract: It is a good thing to whistle for water once in a while, like the dry faucets in our houses. If an occasional antepast of the legitimate and fast-coming results of our habitual waste of Croton does not teach us a better system of water rates, we had better tap Lake Erie at once; for where people are charged, not for what water they want, but for what they can waste, no ordinary river will insure high tide in our reservoirs. This subject has already been referred to in the TIMES, in a manner which has called forth a general response and lengthy reports from the water departments of various cities. It is the unanimous belief of all persons who are conversant with the actual working of our system that water must be measured out to consumers.
lead_paragraph: It is a good thing to whistle for water once in a while, like the dry faucets in our houses. This subject has already been referred to in the TIMES, in a manner which has called forth a general response and lengthy reports from the water departments of various cities. It is the unanimous belief of all persons who are conversant with the actual working of our system that water must be measured out to consumers.

abstract: HIGHLY COMPLIMENTARY. We learn that the Mexican papers, several numbers of which have been issued as a serial by Mr. EDWARD E. DUNBAR, of this City, and formerly the Mexican correspondent of the TIMES, are attracting much attention in Mexico. We see it stated that the Constitutional Government is having the publication translated into Spanish, and taking measures to give it a wide circulation throughout the Mexican Republic.

abstract: A case is now before U.S. Commissioner BETTS, in which AMOS LEEDS, a young man about 22 years of age, stands charged with having purloined sundry letters from the Post-office in this City, addressed to individuals and firms, with the design of embezzling their contents. Among these was a registered letter addressed to CHARLES A. HAZLETON, of New-York, which contained a Bank check. This he obtained possession of, as alleged, by signing to the required receipt the name of Mr. HAZLETON. Other letters were then placed in the office to the same address, which LEEDS called for and received on the following day, when he was arrested by those who had been watching his movements.

abstract: The quiet neighborhood of Twelfth-street, near University-place, was profoundly shocked yesterday morning by the discovery of a murder which has seldom been paralleled in circumstances of atrocity, boldness, mystery and horror. The victim is Mrs. SARAH SHANCKS, a widow who, for many years past, has kept a small lace, embroidery and furnishing store in the Fifteenth Ward. She was a native of Boston, about 50 years of age, but much younger in appearance and in manner. Among her acquaintances she was esteemed as a person of good reputation, and her daughter is the wife of Mr. WILLIAM SMEATON, principal of the Fifteenth Ward Grammar School. For about a year past she had occupied the lower part of the two-story frame building No. 22 East Twelfth-street as a store and residence. By thrift and economy in the management. of her business she had accumulated a few hundred dollars, most of which, however, she seems to have unfortunately lost through over-confidence in the honesty of some male acquaintances. It appears from what has been learned of her history, that Mrs. SHANCKS was susceptible to flattery, and through this weakness of character had been more than once made the dupe of designing men, who, under professions of regard and promises of marriage, had persuaded her to loan them the savings of her industry. Generally, she has had a girl living with her to assist her in business, who occupied the same sleeping apartments, but for some days past she had been living alone Recently she lost the sight of one eye from sudden cold, and had since been partially disabled from business, during which time she obtained her meals from a boarding-house near by, and her food was brought to her by a little girl, a daughter of one of the neighbors.

abstract: By the explosion on board the Spanish frigate Berenguela, in the Dry Dock at the Navy-yard, Thursday night, three men only were seriously injured. There was no powder on board, as has been stated, except two charges which had just been drawn by a soldier named RAMON. These charges RAMON bad in a "passing box" and was conveying it to the magazine.
lead_paragraph: By the explosion on board the Spanish frigate Berenguela, in the Dry Dock at the Navy-yard, Thursday night, three men only were seriously injured. There was no powder on board, as has been stated, except two charges which had just been drawn by a soldier named RAMON. These charges RAMON bad in a "passing box" and was conveying it to the magazine. He had a lighted cigarette in his mouth, and a spark from that caused the explosion. RAMON was badly mutilated, and in the excitement of the moment, jumped from the frigate into the dry-dock, a distance of some thirty feet, receiving such injuries that he died soon after the accident. One man, who was in a hammock near where the explosion occurred, was blown out of his bed and severely burned, and lacerated about the face by some flying missile. Another man standing near was also pretty severely injured. The body of RAMON was interred yesterday in the Naval Hospital grounds, on Flushing-avenue. The wounded men are now in the Naval Hospital, where, under the care of House Surgeon GWINN and Assistant-Surgeon KIRBY, they will receive all the aid medical, skill can suggest.

abstract: At a meeting of the Century Club of this City, last week, LANO exhibited and oil-study of his forthcoming picture of MARY, Queen of Scots, heretofore spoken of in the TIMES. The subject is one which has not hitherto been treated by any artist of ability, and all who have been privileged to view the study congratulate Mr. LANG on the selection and treatment of a subject at once original, striking and interesting.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Century Club of this City, last week, LANO exhibited and oil-study of his forthcoming picture of MARY, Queen of Scots, heretofore spoken of in the TIMES. The subject is one which has not hitherto been treated by any artist of ability, and all who have been privileged to view the study congratulate Mr. LANG on the selection and treatment of a subject at once original, striking and interesting. At the same time, KENSETT exhibited a most charming lake-view landscape, which, with its most fitting oval frame, received the warmest commendation. HAYES produced a "Quadrupedal Puppy," which provoked a whistle from the observer, and displayed to the most gratifying extent the forte of this successful artist. G[???]GNOUX presented a view of the Niagara River, taken at Brock's Monument -- the completion of which, our readers will remember, was accomplished by the Prince of Wales during his recent visit. The portrait of a most loveable woman was sent in by GRAY, and received, as all of GRAY's women do, most extravagant admiration from one and all. Other pictures, for special notice of which we have not space or time, were exhibited by HAZELTINE, GIPFORD and others -- which were really very fine and deserving of the praise and favorable criticisms passed by the members of the Club, who, with their friends, were permitted to look upon them. Pleasant chattings, agreeable reunions and an enjoyable supper were the features of the evening's entertainment. Representatives from the artistic and literary world were numerous, and of the editorial fraternity, were gentlemen from the Atlantic Monthly, Albion, Home Journal, Illustrated News, Musical World; Vanity Fair and TIMES.

abstract: The People vs. Wm. abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  Of this country, as of the other Central American States, we have knwon comparatively little, save as they have been agitated by internal revolution, or been the scene of of foolish or fillibustering expeditions. Honduras, however, has been free from many of the evils which have afflicted her sister Republies. She has been more secluded, less aspiring, while she has been blessed with a more stable government.

abstract: The Legislature did but little business yesterday, the largest portion of the day having been devoted to the College Commencement. abstract: The Prince of Wales arrived in Oxford on the 21st ult., accompanied by Major-Gen. the Hon. R. BRUCE and Lieut.-Col. KEPPEL. The Oxford City Rifle Corps, under the command of Col. NORTH, M.P., attended as a guard of honor, and on the arrival of the Prince they saluted his Royal Highness by presenting arms, the band playing the National Anthem. His Royal Highness then proceeded in his private carriage to Frewen Hall, and the City Rifle Corps followed. The Mayor of Oxford was on the platform to receive His Royal Highness, to whom he was introduced by Major-Gen. BRUCE. The railway station and approaches to it were thronged with people, who cheered His Royal Highness very heartily. Flags floated from the various churches, public buildings, and private houses; merry peals were rung, and the whole city presented a scene of unusual animation. During the day His Royal Highness was waited on by Col. NORTH, M.P., and many distinguished members of the University, and in the afternoon made several calls.

abstract: The appointment of a Select Committee to consider the critical condition of the country seems to us a wise and judicious proceeding. Whatever else may come of its labors, the fact of its appointment and the manner in which it has been made up, indicate a full appreciation on the part of the North of the serious evils which menace the public peace, and a willingness on their part to do whatever justice and a regard for principle will permit towards meeting the demands of the Southern States.

abstract: Rev. J.C. FLETCHER ON SWITZERLAND Another of those entertaining lectures of Rev. J.C. FLETCHER, was delivered last evening, at Cooper Institute, before another large and interested audience. His theme was Switzerland, and he considered it with the same clearness of conception, elegance of diction and purity of pronunciation which have characterized all his recent public efforts.
lead_paragraph: Rev. J.C. FLETCHER ON SWITZERLAND Another of those entertaining lectures of Rev. J.C. FLETCHER, was delivered last evening, at Cooper Institute, before another large and interested audience. His theme was Switzerland, and he considered it with the same clearness of conception, elegance of diction and purity of pronunciation which have characterized all his recent public efforts. He glanced at the experiences of travelers in approaching the lands of lakes and mountains, photographed the main features of the country. -- the Jura, blue Geneva and Mont Blanc, "the monarch of mountains," crowned with perennial snow," -- examined its ancient and modern history, --especially dwelling upon the story of WILLIAM TELL, and denying in good set terms the truth of the assertion that the hero was a myth, -- and related many amusing anecdotes of his travels. Mr. FLETCHER will deliver the last lecture of the course at the same place next Monday evening. His subject will be "Italy and Garibaldi."

abstract: Upon the presentation, last year, of the Annual Report of the Secretary at War, we took occasion to comment upon the rapid and inexcusable growth of expenditures in that department of the public service. From a fraction less than $12,000,000, as they existed in 1851, they had risen to a fraction less than $30,000,000; and, upon examining the objects upon which the money was lavished, we predicted that if the same ratio of progression continued, before 1865 they would reach the enormous sum of $60,000,000; or two-thirds of the entire outlay of the Government. We are happy to state that the tendency to increase has at least been suspended. The present report of Mr. FLOYD indicates that the figures have fallen from $28,000,000,in 1858-59, to $19,000,000, in 1859-60 -- a saving of one-third. It is true, the expenditures for the three months ending Sept. 30, being the first quarter of the current fiscal year, ascend to about $6,500,000, prefiguring an enhanced aggregate for 1860-61; but before this year expires the present Administration will have retired from office, giving place to successors who will be bound by every consideration of self-interest to bring the expenses of the Government far within the limits indulged by the actual Cabinet. It is safe, therefore, to regard the growing extravagance of the War Department as arrested, and the policy turned in the direction of retrenchment and economy.

The present report of Mr. FLOYD indicates that the figures have fallen from $28,000,000,in 1858-59, to $19,000,000, in 1859-60 -- a saving of one-third. It is safe, therefore, to regard the growing extravagance of the War Department as arrested, and the policy turned in the direction of retrenchment and economy.

abstract: Ten days hence, the State of South Carolina, it is believed, will separate herself from the United States of North America, and establish an independent government. She will dissolve the United States Courts, eject the Judges and Marshal, break off the Post-office connections, expel the Federal Collector and Port-officers, and declare Charleston a free port of entry to the world. It is a grave question what should be the action of our Central Government in this entirely novel emergency. The President admits the duty of the Executive Power "to take care that the laws be faithfully executed," but declares that this is impossible, because there are no Federal Officers in the State who will consent to execute these laws, and no posse could be raised among the people who would assist them.
lead_paragraph: Ten days hence, the State of South Carolina, it is believed, will separate herself from the United States of North America, and establish an independent government. abstract: The New-Mexican mail, with dates to the 19th qlt., arrived to-day in time to connect with the mail going East this morning. The mail was detained by very deep snow and excessively cold weather. The Kiowa Indians stopped the mail at McKnees' Creek, and kept them half a day. Their object, they said was to make peace; and they could wipe out the party, but did not feel so disposed.
lead_paragraph: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Friday, Dec. 7.

abstract: Southern trade must still be worth something to Northern merchants, if there is any significance in the activity of those individuals who make a living by extorting money through threats of denouncing as "Black Republicans" those who do not comply with their demands. The latest scheme of this kind which has come to our knowledge is one devised by the publisher of a "Southern Steamboat and Railroad Guide," a pamphlet of nearly 200 pages, which is almost entirely filled with the cards of houses engaged in the Southern trade. Within the last day or two this gentleman called on a large fancy goods dealer in Chambers-street, who has advertised with him during the last year, presented a copy of the Guide for the current month, and with it a bill for advertising, amounting to $50. When told that the bill had been paid, he explained that it was for a future insertion of the card, and, by way of incentive, called the attention of his intended victim to a page which read in this wise: "To Southern Merchants. Avoid the Black Republican houses in New-York. Messrs. _____, No. -- street sell their diamonds and jewelry to the South -- have made their money out of Southern merchants, yet Mr. _____ votes for ABRAHAM LINCOLN for President, Mr. ______, of the above firm, told us that he wanted the 'Southerners money.' Will our Southern friends still continue to lavish upon this Black Republican house their money? Mark this house. In our January edition we intend to publish every Black Republican house in New-York that sells to the South." To the surprise of this enterprising publisher the exhibition of this document did not have the least effect on the nerves of his victim. The merchant coolly informed him that he had missed his mark entirely; that he had no fear of such threats as he was making, and that he would not allow his advertisement to go in the Guide on any terms. At this unexpected rebuff the publisher remarked, "Well, if you are not with us you are against us," and left the store. We have the satisfaction of knowing that he received a similar reception from a number of prominent firms on Chambers-street. If the roll of bills which he boastingly displayed to some on whom he called, were not largely counterfeit, he must have found some weak-minded merchants, who forgot that this dodge has been tried so frequently that Southerners by this time know perfectly well that money is the touchstone by which these black and white lists are made up. Those who feel any interest in ascertaining who refused to respond to this swindler's claim for money are referred to the January number of the Guide, where they will find them figuring as Black Republicans.

abstract: Our reports from Washington this morning are interesting. During the adjourment of Congress speculation turns upon the House Special Committee on the Condition of the Union, and the probable course which will be pursued by it. It seems to be generally understood that the members of the Committee will act simply as spokesman for their respective delegations, and under their advice.
lead_paragraph: Our reports from Washington this morning are interesting. During the adjourment of Congress speculation turns upon the House Special Committee on the Condition of the Union, and the probable course which will be pursued by it. It seems to be generally understood that the members of the Committee will act simply as spokesman for their respective delegations, and under their advice. It is believed that all those appointed on the Committee will serve, with the exception of HAWKINS, of Florida, and BOYCE, of South Carolina. The other members from the extreme Southern States will not decline to act, although they have been strongly urged to do so. As indicating the exact condition of affairs in South Carolina, and corroborative of the statements in the private letter which was published in the TIMES of yesterday, the views of a planter and slaveholder of that State, at present in Washington, will attract attention. He believes that the State will inevitably secede, but that she will Just as inevitably come back into the Union again in a short time, when the leaders in the present revolutionary movement will find that they have signed their own death warrants. This gentleman, our correspondent says, is a member of the Legislature and a delegate to the State Convention. Our dispatches from the principal points in the South continue of about the same character. The disunion feeling in Texas seems to be approaching a culmination. A circular has been issued by a member of the Legislature, calling upon his fellow, members to meet sometime in January whether Gov. HOUSTON chooses to call them together or not; and it is asserted that the Governor has signified his willingness to do so, provided he can be satisfied that a majority of the people of the State desire it.

abstract: It must be confessed that the aspect of public affairs at Washington is particularly gloomy. The Southern caucus held on Saturday evening is said to have shown that the Representatives of the Cotton States are unanimous in the opinion that secession is inevitable. Mr. COBB will probably withdraw .
lead_paragraph: It must be confessed that the aspect of public affairs at Washington is particularly gloomy. The Southern caucus held on Saturday evening is said to have shown that the Representatives of the Cotton States are unanimous in the opinion that secession is inevitable. Mr. COBB will probably withdraw from the Cabinet, in spite of the price that was paid in the Message for his remaining. And there seems very little probability that the Compromise Committee can agree upon anything which would lead the South even to pause in its mad career. We see nothing in the immediate future but a rapid, headlong movement towards a disruption of the Confederacy. The more important question remains, how shall it be met?

abstract: William Pickney vs. Henry H. Childs et al. -- The appeal in this case grew out of a compromise by the terms of which the appellants were to pay the respondents an amount of a debt at various times. The respondents, it appears, had commenced a suit against the appellants, but before an answer was put in, a compromise was made by which the appellants agreed to give a number of notes payable at different times, the gross sum of which amounts to their whole indebtedness; and, if any such notes were not paid sixty days after maturity, the respondents were at liberty to enter up a judgment against the applicants for the amount that then should be due. A written offer to this effect was made by the appellants which the respondents were to hold, and in case of a default in the payment of the notes according to the terms agreed upon, they were to present it to the Clerk and have the judgment duly entered up.
lead_paragraph: William Pickney vs. Henry H. abstract: The undersigned, in view of the now unquestioned fact that thousands of the people of Kansas are suffering from Famine, deem it but humane and Christian that some immediate steps be taken to afford relief to the famishing settlers of that unfortunate Territory. From testimony of the most trustworthy character, it appears that not less than 30,000 of the inhabitants of Kansas are suffering for necessary food and clothing, many of whom must inevitably perish during the coming Winter unless they shall receive assistance from abroad.

abstract: Congress, after resting since Thursday afternoon, will meet again to-day, when the final determination of those members of the House who have expressed a disinclination to serve on the Special Committee will be known. It will probably
lead_paragraph: Congress, after resting since Thursday afternoon, will meet again to-day, when the final determination of those members of the House who have expressed a disinclination to serve on the Special Committee will be known. It will probably be an exciting session, and the reports of the proceedings will be looked for with much anxiety. Meantime our dispatches from Washington are not of a very encouraging character. The Senators from the Slaveholding States held a conference at the Capitol on Saturday, at which the present condition of the country was freely discussed. The only result which seems to have been arrived at was the conviction that secession is a certainty. A large majority, according to our correspondent, considered it too late to save the present Confederacy, but they expressed the belief that a new one would be speedily formed. They do not seem to have given any opinion as to the basis on which it would be constructed. Persons recently arrived at Washington from the South report the excitement there as intense. At Charleston, if we are to believe the statements which reach us, a misunderstanding has already arisen between the Federal authorities and those of the city or State. Major ANDERSON, commanding Fort Moultrie, has been refused the privilege of sending to the Arsenal for supplies, and his messengers have been sent back without them, simply because among the articles desired were some percussion caps. The Government, it is understood, has been appealed to to send an additional force, as Major ANDERSON has at present only sixty or seventy men, poorly upplied; but the Administration has absolutely refused to do so. In connection with this refusal, vague rumors prevail that a formal notification will soon be given by South Carolina that she intends to capture the fort, when the Government will order it to be evacuated without a contest, to avoid a civil war. Of course, it is impossible to tell how much truth there may be in such rumors. Secretary COBB, it is asserted, has already resigned, and will vacate his post to-day -- in which case it is believed he will be followed by the Representatives from South Carolina and others. There is one thing, however, which may serve as a check upon too hasty action, and that is the character of the advices from England. The sympathy expressed there for the Federal Government, on the reception of the first reports of the secession movement, somewhat surprises the Disunionists, and they have no hesitation in saying that it is not what they expected. As a measure of financial relief to the Government, the House Committee of Ways and Means, it will be seen, have resolved upon the issue of Treasury notes.

abstract: Senator DOUGLAS has given notice of his intention to introduce a bill amending the Fugitive Slave law of 1850, so as to provide more effectually for the recovery of "persons held to service escaping from one State to another." We have no intimation of the character of its provisions. But if it should be framed in the proper spirit and with due regard to the exigencies of the case, it cannot fail to pave the way for action on the part of the Northern States, which may give the Union men of the South a better basis for their efforts to preserve the Union than they have at present.
lead_paragraph: Senator DOUGLAS has given notice of his intention to introduce a bill amending the Fugitive Slave law of 1850, so as to provide more effectually for the recovery of "persons held to service escaping from one State to another." abstract: We have already demonstrated that the North, whether the Union is preserved or not, must be carriers for the South so long as men employ the cheapest means to given ends. We do not dispute with the South the palm in raising cotton or sugar.
lead_paragraph: We have already demonstrated that the North, -- whether the Union is preserved or not, -- must be carriers for the South so long as men employ the cheapest means to given ends. We do not dispute with the South the palm in raising cotton or sugar. But the fervid sun necessary to mature these crops enervates and indisposes to physical activity. Muscular energy and love of labor is the product of temperate zones which the sun, for a portion of the year, leaves to snow and ice. South Carolina's only title to interfere in the matter of transporting her products must be her ability to underbid all her competitors. If she cannot do this, she can no more direct who shall carry her cotton, than who shall spin it. The consumer pays them both. When the planter or his factor sells it on the wharf at Charleston, he parts with all power over it. It would be a new principle in political economy were they to control its direction and say who should weave and wear it. South Carolina with equal sense might decide, in solemn council, the fortunate parties who were to be the carriers of tea from the Celestials to all outside barbarians. The absurdity of one assumption is not a whit more glaring than the other.

abstract: George Martin vs. The Mayor, &c., of New-York. -- In this case the defendants applied, upon the motion of the Comptroller, to have a judgment formerly obtained in the Marine Court by the plaintiff, for services alleged to have been performed for the City, set aside, upon the usual allegations of collusion and fraud. A transcript of the judgment was filed with the County Clerk, and thus, under the Code, the case was "deemed" a judgment of the Common Pleas. This motion was then made to open it, together with three others of a similar character. The following opinion of the Court will further explain the proceeding:

abstract: Business of all kinds, except the retail trade, continues not only dull, but there is absolutely little or nothing doing. All our staples are declining rapidly under the influence of the deranged money market, and he is a wise man indeed who can tell when the bottom will be reached. Everybody seems determined to wait and see.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY EVENING, Dec. 6, 1860.

abstract: A disturbance and fight had occurred between a party of drunken men at a liquor saloon in Bleecker-street, near Carmine, and SANGER was called in to settle it. While engaged in separating the disorderly characters come person, supposed to be CONNER, seized the policeman's club and struck him with it a blow upon the head, causing an injury which resulted in his death about nine months afterwards. CONNER was arrested for the offence, but the evidence against him was not strong enough to warrant his conviction.
lead_paragraph: A disturbance and fight had occurred between a party of drunken men at a liquor saloon in Bleecker-street, near Carmine, and SANGER was called in to settle it. abstract: On Saturday morning, as Officer Wogan, of the Fourth Ward, was passing through Pearl-street, he heard a sharp explosion in the candy manufactory No. 380, occupied by J. & M. Christy. The policeman broke in the door, and discovered that burglars had been endeavoring to blow open the safe with gunpowder, but they had escaped by the rear way before he gained admission. The departure of the rogues was so hurried that they took no plunder with them.

abstract: A mass meeting to consider the issues of the day, way held at Vicksburg, Miss., on the afternoon and evening of the 29th ult. The Whig says: "It was a magnificent and triumphant success. Notwithstanding the slanders which had been circulated about it that it was a 'submission,' a 'Union-at-any-price' gathering,  c., the people came to it, and it was the largest demonstration known in the State since the memorable canvass of "51."
lead_paragraph: A mass meeting to consider the issues of the day, way held at Vicksburg, Miss., on the afternoon and evening of the 29th ult. The Whig says: "It was a magnificent and triumphant success. Notwithstanding the slanders which had been circulated about it -- that it was a 'submission,' a 'Union-at-any-price' gathering, &c., the people came to it, and it was the largest demonstration known in the State since the memorable canvass of '51,"

abstract: A German baker, named AUGUSTUS STURMAN, doing business at No. 285 South Third-street, Jersey City, was run over by the-6 o'clock Central Railroad train from New-York, Saturday morning, and sustained serious injuries. Mr. STURMAN was crossing from Henderson-street over the railroad track, and after passing Mr. HOPE'S store, he recollected nothing further. He became conscious some two hours after.
lead_paragraph: -- A German baker, named AUGUSTUS STURMAN, doing business at No. 285 South Third-street, Jersey City, was run over by the 6 o'clock Central Railroad train from New-York, Saturday morning, and sustained serious injuries. Mr. STURMAN was crossing from Henderson-street over the railroad track, and after passing Mr. HOPE's store, he recollected nothing further. He became conscious some two hours after. The wagon was struck by the locomotive and completely demolished, and Mr. STURMAN was thrown some distance. Upon being taken to the drug store near the corner of Washington-street, Dr. QUIDOR was called, and upon examination, found that the left arm was badly crushed between the elbow and shoulder, and there was also a bad scalp wound on the back of the head, six or seven inches in length. After the wounds were dressed the injured man was sent home, and it is thought will recover, although it is possible that he may lose his arm. Mr. S. states that he neither saw nor heard the train, nor heard any whistle sounded or bell rung. It is also stated that there was no flagman at the crossing at the time of the accident. The horse had his left fore leg broken off at the ankle and one eye put out, and in this condition the poor animal was allowed to remain in the street for a number of hours. Considerable indignation was expressed by citizens in the vicinity, and some of them were for tearing up the track.

abstract: Novels are numerous this week, and the pile upon our table is pyramidical. First on the list, because the most bulky of the brood, comes Harrington, written by a prolific author, and published by THAYER & ELDRIDGE, of Boston. The book is entitled A Story of True Love; but a glance at the opening pages prompts the conviction that A Story of True Terror would have been its better name. What could the author have been thinking of when he dedicated such a volume to his wife? If that unfortunate lady be of a nervous temperament, she has our heartfelt sympathy. We trust the tale has never been unfolded in the family circle, since its effect on the younger members would certainly be disastrous in the extreme. Slumber would be driven from their eyes for an indefinite period of time, and chains and whips would, rattle about their ears instead. Even the youngest and best loved "pledge" would shudder so convulsively that its cradle would need no other rocking. The scene of the story opens at the South, and the plot throughout is skewered together with the iron terrors of Slavery. In the initial chapter we are introduced to a planter and an overseer, who only lack tails of being Satanic -- to an abused wife and a tortured negro. The horrors which such a concatenation of elements evolves in the course of five hundred and fifty odd pages will suggest themselves to the most unimaginative mind, and save the trouble of reading the book. A nonreader, however, will lose some very rare specimens of stilted style and lofty description. Thus, in chapter XVI., where we have glimpses of the moon after this fashion: "The gibbous moon hung midway down, the zenith over the vast and sleeping city, a lob of spectral light in the cold, blue heavens, over a fantastic brood of dreams." If the poets who are given to apostrophising Dian and projecting odes at the Pale Queen of Night, ever consent to forgive this man who styles her a "lob of light," they are a more forgiving race than is generally supposed. "Lob of light," is good. But to speak seriously on a serious subject, the evils of Slavery are many and manifold enough to be discussed in sober truth. When imagination ventures to deal with them a very prudent hand must guide the open, or the writer defeats his own purpose, since many who reject the preposterous pictures of fiction will not thereafter be disposed to believe even the plain and simple truth.

abstract: A day or two since Mrs. R. MacDono [???], with two children, arrived from Charleston, whence she had come by railroad, and engaged a hack-driver named George Pinckney to drive her from the depot to the Brandreth Hotel, for $1. After the lady and family were seated in the carriage, the Jehu advised her not to go to the Brandreth Hotel, as it was not at proper place for ladies. Being a stranger in the City, she received his words as truth, and when he urged the Lafarge House as the best she could select, and where she could be accommodated for $1 per day, she allowed him to drive her there. She was very speedily informed as to the terms of the house, and Pinckney then volunteered to take her to the Westchester House, on the corner of Broome-street and the Bowery, where, with her children and baggage, she was soon deposited. After staying a day or two, she called for her bill, being desirous of leaving the City, and among the items was a charge of $2 50 paid for hack hire. She tendered the amount of her bill, with $1 for hack hire, which was refused, and a clerk of the House, to make assurance doubly sure, removed from the carnage in waiting one of her trunks, us security for the charge of $2 50, which had been paid to Pinckney. Mrs. MacDonough at once made nor appeal to the First Marshal, Col. Burnham, who, after hearing her statement, directed the arrest of the hackman, which was speedily effected. On being confronted with that official, he at once acknowledged the corn -- owned up that he had charged and received $2 50 for a service which he had engaged to perform for $1, and was required to pay $10 as a fine for his rascality, and to see the lady's trunk restored to her. Having compiled with these orders, he was permitted to depart, with an admonition to cypher up the amount of his profits by the transaction.
