abstract: A telegraphic dispatch was forwarded about 12 o'clock on Sunday night to Police Superintendent KENNEDY, from Susquehannah Station on the Erie Railroad, giving information of the arrest at that place on Sunday forenoon, of a young man supposed to be the murderer of Mrs, SUSAN SHANCKS, at No. 22 East Twelfth-street, on Friday morning last.
lead_paragraph: A telegraphic dispatch was forwarded about 12 o'clock on Sunday night to Police Superintendent KENNEDY, from Susquehannah Station on the Erie Railroad, giving information of the arrest at that place on Sunday forenoon, of a young man supposed to be the murderer of Mrs, SUSAN SHANCKS, at No. 22 East Twelfth-street, on Friday morning last. The suspected person had arrived upon an emigrant train from this City, and several employes at the railroad depot, who had been informed through the newspapers and by telegraph, of the tragedy, observed him leave the train. As there were bloodstains upon his clothing and bandages upon his hands, it was suspected that he was the fugitive murderer. His confused manner and strange actions also increased the suspicions which had been excited, and, after a little consideration on the part of the persons at the depot, it was decided that his arrest should be effected. Accordingly, the town constable was sent for, and the man was taken into custody. After his apprehension, his hands were examined, and they were found to be badly lacerated -- the wounds being such as might have been caused by the broken bottles which the assassin of Mrs. SHANCKS had shattered upon her head and face. The prisoner was closely questioned by his custodians with reference to his knowledge of the murder, and his answers were such that little doubt is felt of his guilt. He stated that he was generally known by the name of ALFRED BUCHANAN, and that he had come to Susquehannah to see one THEODORE SPRINGSTEEN, with whom he was acquainted, and at his house he wanted to stay on Sunday night. He told many different stories about the manner in which he received the injuries to his hands -- but he finally admitted that he had committed the murder. When he made this admission he cried bitterly and said that he knew he should be hung. He added that his mother had told him he had better give himself up as that would be the best he could do for himself, but that his father had advised him to escape from the City, and he had adopted the latter course. Capt. CAFFREY, of the Fifteenth Ward, took the first train for Susquehannah after receipt of the intelligence, and the prisoner is expected to arrive in the City this morning.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder BARNARD, James Shay, a young man 19 years of age, indicted for highway robbery, pleaded guilty of an assault, with intent to rob. The Court suggested to the prisoner that if he would disclose the names of his accomplices, it would deal leniently with him. Accordingly, he communicated to the District-Attorney several names. The Court then imposed the sentence of two years and six months in the State Prison.
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder BARNARD, James Shay, a young man 19 years of age, indicted for highway robbery, pleaded guilty of an assault, with intent to rob. The Court suggested to the prisoner that if he would disclose the names of his accomplices, it would deal leniently with him. Accordingly, he communicated to the District-Attorney several names. The Court then imposed the sentence of two years and six months in the State Prison.

abstract: -- A Convention of Laymen of the Baltimore and East Baltimore Conferences of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which has been in session at Baltimore during the last week, adopted an address to the Baltimore Annual Conference. The document recites the history of the action taken by the late General Conference, charges that by it territory and population in the Baltimore Conference, represented by twenty-one circuits and stations, has been lost; that the building of churches had almost entirely ceased, and that no collection could be made for missionary purposes. In view of these facts the report recommended that the Baltimore Annual Conference should at its next meeting declare that the General Conference had, by its official action, sundered the bonds which united the two bodies. The minority report agreed as to the cause of the present difficulties in the Conference, but was in favor of delaying action severing connection with the General Conference.

abstract: Every man, inquisitive of the future, and anxious for the welfare of humanity, must be peering eagerly in these days through the mists that lie over our national course. We see breakers through the darkness and hear the roar of the storm, and wonder anxiously whether we are to pass safely through as we have so often done before, or what great disaster may impend over us. What is to be the issue? every one continually asks. At length American politics have taken on themselves a dignity equal to that of the questions which convulse the Old World. We no longer contend over petty matters of finance or party success; but the question is, the continuance or disruption of a Government, the formation of a new Power among the nations of the world, and the grand and formidable results which may follow such vast changes.

abstract: The Albany Allas and Argus pronounces the letter we published a few days since from a lady in South Carolina, describing the apprehensions felt there in regard to a slave insurrection, to be a fabrication. The only warrant for such a belief seems to have been the necessity of making a point against the Republicans. The imputation is as false as it is impertinent.
lead_paragraph: The Albany Atlas and Argus pronounces the letter we published a few days since from a lady in South Carolina, describing the apprehensions felt there in regard to a slave insurrection, to be a fabrication. The only warrant for such a belief seems to have been the necessity of making a point against the Republicans. The imputation is as false as it is impertinent. The document was precisely what it purported to be, -- a private letter from a married lady in the interior of South Carolina to her uncle in this City. The original was handed tous for publication, -- and the names of persons and places only were erased by us, to prevent the identification of the writer. If the editor of the Atlas and Argus desires it, we presume the original can be submitted to his inspection.

abstract: On Saturday night about 8 o'clock, Officer O'CONNELL, of the First Ward, found a German sailor named HENRY BENATUS lying upon the sidewalk in Albany-street. Believing him to be drunk, the Policeman conveyed the man to the Police Station, ...
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night about 8 o'clock, Officer O'CONNELL, of the First Ward, found a German sailor named HENRY BENATUS lying upon the sidewalk in Albany-street. Believing him to be drunk, the Policeman conveyed the man to the Police Station, where he was placed in one of the cells. Next morning the attendant, on going to the lock-up for the purpose of arousing the prisoners, found that BENATUS could not be awakened, and a closer look at him showed that he was dead. Coroner SCHIRMER was notified to hold an inquest, and subsequently a post-mortem examination having been made, it developed the fact that the man had died in consequence of a terrible blow upon the head which had fractured his skull. As soon as the cause of death had transpired, Capt. SILVEY dispatched officers to inquire as to the manner in which the injury had been given. In prosecuting their investigation, the police yesterday ascertained from JAMES AIRY, a boy nine years of age, that on Saturday night, about 7 o'clock, while making purchases in the grocery and liquor store No. 11 Albany-street, kept by a man named PHILIP COLLINS, he saw deceased there, quarrelling with the proprietor of the place, who struck him upon the head with a club. COLLINS was, therefore, arrested, and subsequently a sailor named HENRY SMITH presented himself at the Station-house and made a statement corroborating that of the boy. He said that deceased and himself had called at COLLINS' store to drink, and a dispute arose with reference to the price of the liquor. After bandying words for some time, COLLINS finally snatched up a club and struck deceased upon the head, knocking him down, while he, (SMITH,) fearing for his life, ran out of the place and went to his boarding-house, without waiting to see how much his companion had been injured. In addition to the arrest of COLLINS, the apprehension of his wife and other parties, who are said to have been present when the affray occurred, was ordered by Capt. SILVEY, and these persons are in confinement. The Coroner will go on with the investigation to-day.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday morning, before Judge BALCOM, the first business was the disposition of the case of Franz Hoffman, indicted for murder in the first degree, for having taken the life of Mrs. Schumacker and her infant child. The District-Attorney stated to the Court that, although the crime was an atrocious one, committed for plunder, he had concluded to accept a plea of murder in the second degree. He was led to this determination, not simply on account of doubt concerning the possibility of punishing the higher degree, but because he had received a report from Drs. Ranney and Ogden, who had examined the condition of the prisoner as to his sanity. That report was as follows:

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. If there were any consistency in an operatic public, it would seize with avidity the opportunity to hear a gay and lively opera like "Stradella," on a wet and dreary night like that which awaited its production yesterday evening.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- If there were any consistency in an operatic public, it would seize with avidity the opportunity to hear a gay and lively opera like "Stradella," on a wet and dreary night like that which awaited its production yesterday evening. But base considerations of dampness and discomfort have their dire influences, even when it is clearly proper to check them with the pleasant antidote of a jolly and agreeable work in one of the brightest opera-houses of the world. Thus it happened that there was a bad attendance -- a very bad attendance -- indeed, altogether too bad for hopeful reflections. We will turn, instead, to the performance, which was excellent "Stradella," although not so popular with the masses as "Martha," is in many respects a superior work. It contains an abundant supply of melody, several well-developed ensembles, and any quantity of strongly-flavored and more or less musical rhythms, which, if they fail to catch the ear, are sure to employ the heel. The plot, too, although lackadaisical in some respects, is enlivened with a vigorous vein of rascality. Barterino and Malvolio are agreeable villains, and much more acceptable than many of their betters. They were impersonated excellently last night, by Mr. FORMES and Mr. QUINT. The other parts were rendered most efficiently. Mme. FABBRI -- who seems to be equal to the entire repertoire -- was admirable; and we have seldom heard Signor STIGELLI to greater advantage than in the second and third acts of this opera. Indeed, in all respects the performance was more than an average one, and, under the genial circumstances of a good house, would have commanded a repetition. As it is, we think it might safely be reannounced. DONIZETTI's opera of the "Daughter of the Regiment" will be played here on Wednesday, with a cast which may be regarded as absolutely perfect. It is seldom that this agreeable work can be heard with three such artists as FABBRI, STIGELLI and FORMES.

abstract: CITY MORTALITY. The City Inspector reports that the number of deaths in the City during the week ending on Saturday last, was 338, viz; Men, 81; women, 81; boys, 82, and girls, 94 being a decrease of 71 on the week previous, and less 73 than during the corresponding week of 1859, of whom 141 were under 5 years of age.
lead_paragraph: CITY MORTALITY. -- The City Inspector reports that the number of deaths in the City during the week ending on Saturday last, was 338, viz; Men, 81; women, 81; boys, 82, and girls, 94 -- being a decrease of 71 on the week previous, and less 73 than during the corresponding week of 1859, of whom 141 were under 5 years of age. The principal diseases and causes were -- Apoplexy 5; bleeding, 2; do. from lungs, 2: bronchitis S; aneurism, 2; asthma 2; consumption 46; cancer, 3; do. of breast, 2; stomach, 1; congestion of brain 7; do. liver, 1; lungs, 5; convulsions, infantile, 18; croup, 8; debility, adult, 4; do. infantile 9; dropsy 6; do. in head 11; dyspepsia, 2; diarrhoea 3; diphtherite 7; dysentery 2: fever, scarlet 29; do. typhoid, 3; do typhus, 3; heart disease, 7; inflammation of bowels, 6; do. brain, 10; do. liver, 3; lungs 32; do. stomach, 5; marasmus, adult, 4; do infantile, 14; small-pox, 6;; burned or scalded, 4; casualties 7; delirium tremens, 2; old age, 7. Nativity -- United States 204; Ireland 86; Germany 18; England 12; Scotland 2; France, 5; Prussia, 2; British America, Holland, Sweden and Switzerland 1 each.

abstract: The West Twenty-third-street Presbyterian Church (Rev. FREDERICK G. CLARK, Pastor) was found to be on fire at 6 o'clock on Saturday evening last. The organ was entirely destroyed, and considerable damage done to adjacent parts of the church. The property was insured for upwards of $20,000. The damage, therefore, is amply covered, the chief misfortune being, that the congregation will be deprived of their place of worship for a few months.

abstract: The Washington Constitution has made the astounding discovery that, in all their suggestions for conciliation and compromise, the Republicans manifest a "dogged determination to keep the North in possession of the ground it has gained by the election of LINCOLN." That innocent, high-toned advocate of harmony evidently thinks it very unreasonable on the part of the Republicans, that they do not forthwith force Mr. LINCOLN to resign...
lead_paragraph: -- The Washington Constitution has made the astounding discovery that, in all their suggestions for conciliation and compromise, the Republicans manifest a "dogged determination to keep the North in possession of the ground it has gained by the election of LINCOLN." That innocent, high-toned advocate of harmony evidently thinks it very unreasonable on the part of the Republicans, that they do not forthwith force Mr. LINCOLN to resign and permit the South to elect a President more to their liking. Or in default of this, they cannot refuse to permit the South to amend the Constitution so as to suit themselves, and render it impossible for the incoming administration to move a step or lift a finger without their consent. "If the North insist upon being master," -- says the Constitution, -- that is, if the North insist upon installing in power the President who has just been elected, -- "it must be content to limit its authority to its own people, its own affairs, its own territory."

abstract: -- Mayor WOOD has shown so much respect for public opinion as to veto the resolutions passed by both Boards of the Common Council, granting extended privileges to the Third-avenue Railroad Company, and transferring as a burden to the City Treasury expenditures properly chargeable by ordinance to the Company's account. Happy to chronicle all steps working towards an improvement, we duly call attention to this interesting and curious fact. It is a striking illustration of the advantages attending the present differences between the Mayor and the dominant majorities of our City Fathers. With all these branches of our municipal government acting in harmony, no such veto as this could have been expected.

abstract: Yesterday, Capt. George F. Lemon, who recently commanded a steamboat plying between this City and Long Branch, was arrested upon an affidavit made by Mrs. Ophelia Taylor, widow of the late Joseph S. Taylor, formerly Street Commissioner of this City, charging him with having ruined her, under the declaration that he was a single man, and a promise of marriage. Since the accomplishment of his purpose.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Capt. George F. Lemon, who recently commanded a steamboat plying between this City and Long Branch, was arrested upon an affidavit made by Mrs. Ophelia Taylor, widow of the late Joseph S. Taylor, formerly Street Commissioner of this City, charging him with having ruined her, under the declaration that he was a single man, and a promise of marriage. Since the accomplishment of his purpose, she has discovered that he was not a single man at the time, and that his wife is still living. She also says that she is now confined to her house from sickness, and that she does not anticipate an entire recovery for six weeks to come. Upon her affidavit he was arraigned before Judge WELSH, and dented that he was guilty of the crime charged, but the magistrate required him to give bail in the sum of $3,500, pending further investigation. He found a bondsman in Mr. Smithson, a magistrate of Staten Island. A day or two ago an elderly lady residing in the same house with Mrs. Taylor, saw a hat upon the hall table, which she supposed to belong to the captain, and being opposed to his visiting the house, she threw it into the sink. She was mistaken, however, for it was subsequently discovered that the hat belonged to the physician of Mrs. Taylor. The unfortunate doctor was obliged to go home bare-headed.

abstract: The session of Congress, yesterday, was attended with far less excitement than we were led to anticipate, from the tenor of our dispatches of Sunday night. The discussions upon all topics connected with the subject of secession were conducted with calmness, and altogether a decidedly better feeling was exhibited on every side.
lead_paragraph: The session of Congress, yesterday, was attended with far less excitement than we were led to anticipate, from the tenor of our dispatches of Sunday night. The discussions upon all topics connected with the subject of secession were conducted with calmness, and altogether a decidedly better feeling was exhibited on every side. In the Senate, the Standing Committees of the last session were continued; Mr. LATHAM's resolution relative to the Overland Mail was referred to the Committee on Post-offices and Post-roads; a memorial from THADDEUS HYATT, presented by Mr. SUMNER, relative to the suffering people of Kansas, was referred to the Committee on Territories; and the Homestead bill was read the first time. Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, then called up his resolution, presented on Thursday, relative to the present condition of the country, and made a few remarks expressive of his views. Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, made a motion, which was agreed to by Mr. POWELL, to strike out everything from the resolution excepting that which referred to Federal affairs, and that it be referred to a Special Committee. During a discussion which intervened, Mr. LATHAM, of California, said that his State would remain with the Union under all circumstances -- intimating that she could otherwise never secure that great desideratum, a Pacific Railroad. Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, said the management of the country for the present was with the Democrats, but he should support the resolution. Mr. DOUGLAS hoped that there would be no more talk of party until this grave question was settled. Mr. DAVIS, of Mississippi, did not regard the proposition as one promising a good result. Several other speeches were made on the subject, among which was one by Mr. DIXON, of Connecticut, who combatted the idea that it is impossible for the two systems of free and slave labor to exist in the Confederacy, and the Senate adjourned at a late hour. In the House, Mr. HAWKINS, of Florida, proceeded to give additional reasons for asking to be excused from serving on the Special Committee on the Perilous Condition of the Union. He concluded by a warning that Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia and South Carolina were certain to secede, and to be followed by Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas. The tone of his remarks, however, was rather more moderate than was expected. Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, in a rather ill-conceived speech, argued in favor of excusing Mr. HAWKINS. Mr. MCCLERNARD, of Illinois, was unwilling to excuse him. Mr. SICKLES, of New-York, believed that the power to deal with the pending political question rests with the Republican Party, and he desired that the Legislatures of the Northern States might be convened in order that they might deal with it. The vote, on Mr. HAWKINS' request, was not taken, -- the discussion being interrupted by the introduction, from the Committee of Ways and Means, of a bill authorizing the issue of ten millions in Treasury notes, for the relief of the Government, The bill was passed after a brief debate, and the House adjourned.

abstract: We have shown the commercial relations existing between the North and South to be necessary sequences of laws or conditions, entirely independent of political relations or boundaries. The South can never be a maritime people; and not for the present generation, a manufacturing one.
lead_paragraph: We have shown the commercial relations existing between the North and South to be necessary sequences of laws or conditions, entirely independent of political relations or boundaries. The South can never be a maritime people; and not for the present generation, a manufacturing one. They must depend upon the North for their carrying trade, and for the greater part of the articles entering into their daily consumption. The commercial, manufacturing, and maritime greatness, which the South pictures to itself, is forbidden by nature, and is but a dream of ardent politicians, who have not yet taken the first lessons to qualify themselves for its accomplishment -- patient industry; the subjection of the gaseous part of one's nature, which is always urging him on to monstrous assertions and Quixotic essays, to the rules of discipline and common sense; a thorough education in the elementary principles on which are based all the various trades and industries of society, and without which there can be no progress, stability or strength. But climate, aptitudes, training, habits, and the result of these conditions, the present status, both North and South, are nothing to the plastic imaginations of our Southern brethren, who have only to stamp on the ground, and a new order of things is to flash into life, teeming with whatever science, or art, or culture, have produced -- in other words, with all that distinguishes the social organization of the North -- forgetting that the very existence of such a state of things necessarily involves the complete disappearance of their peculiar institution.
headline: {'main': 'The North and South Their Commercial Relations.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The North and South Their Commercial Relations.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The slave bark Cora arrived at this port on Saturday, and anchored at the Navy-yard at 4 o'clock P.M. The day of the week and the lateness of the hour of arrival prevented the formal surrender of the prize and of the prisoners to the United States Marshal. Accordingly, Sailing master EASTMAN and his officers, who came home in charge, retained nominal custody of the vessel and of the three mates, intending at the first opportunity on Monday to hand them over to the United States authorities. What amount of restraint, if any, was practiced towards the prisoners during the day does not appear, but at night they were placed in close quarters below. FREDERICKS, the first mate, was locked in a stateroom on Sunday night. On Monday morning when the door was opened it was discovered that he was gone. It is stated that he made his exit through the port-hole or side-light which ventilated and lighted his state-room. That he should have attempted so hazardous an experiment as to swim ashore in the icy state of the water, seems incredible, but, it is said, no strange boat was seen alongside during the night. The vessel is anchored some two hundred yards from the nearest wharf. A small boy was passed through the hole, which is considered as evidence that the prisoner might have gone that way. Report of the escape was made to the authorities, and Marshal RYNDERS, during the day, took WILSON and OLSEN into custody, and they were committed to the Tombs. The Marshal says his deputies, who have a description of FREDERICKS, are in pursuit of him. Heavy odds are offered that he will not be found. The examination of the two remaining prisoners will take place to-day before a United States Commissioner.

abstract: The annual election of the Representatives of the New-York Fire Department, was held last evening at Fireman's Ball. Full delegations were, in attendance from all the Companies in the City. Wx. A. WOODHULL, the President, occupied the chair. The Wade tables Committee reported that the expense of the cenotaph was $885.72, which amount had been fully subscribed and paid. The report was accepted, and a vote of thanks tendered to the Committee.
lead_paragraph: The annual election of the Representatives of the New-York Fire Department, was held last evening at Fireman's Ball. Full delegations were, in attendance from all the Companies in the City. Wx. A. WOODHULL, the President, occupied the chair. The Wade tables Committee reported that the expense of the cenotaph was $885.72, which amount had been fully subscribed and paid. The report was accepted, and a vote of thanks tendered to the Committee. The further consideration of reports was dispensed with, in order to proceed to the election of officers for the ensuing year. The annual report of the Trustees and of the Treasurer was presented, read and approved. The decrease in the receipts of the Department, in view of its increasing claims for pensions, &c., was referred to with regret. A special meeting was ordered for a week from Thursday. WM.H. WICKHAM received the nomination for President, and obtained 202 out of 215 votes. On taking the chair he was warmly received. He made a brief address, thanking the Board for the honor conferred, and promising to administer the duties of the office to the best of his ability. The following were the officers elected:

abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday concluded an investigation in the case of HENRY BENATUS, the sailor, whose death occurred on Sunday morning last at the First Precinct Police Station, in consequence of a fractured skull. The evidence showed that deceased, with HENRY SMITH, one of his shipmates, on Saturday evening went into the grocery store kept by PHILIP Counts at No. 21 Albany-street, to drink. Both men were somewhat noisy and intoxicated, and a dispute arose between them and the proprietor about the liquor. Two of the witnesses testified that the latter seized a club or poker and struck deceased upon the head, but another testified to the fact that the blow was given by a stranger who happened to be present. After receiving the injury BENATUS went out upon the side walk and lay down. There a policeman found him and took him to the Station-house, on the supposition that he was drunk, and on his way thither he stated that somebody had knocked him down with a club. On this statement of the facts the Jury brought in a verdict charging COLLINS with having given the fatal blow. He was examined in the prescribed way, when he stated that he was entirely innocent of the crime charged against him. The Coroner committed him to the Tombs.
lead_paragraph: Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday concluded an investigation in the case of HENRY BENATUS, the sailor, whose death occurred on Sunday morning last at the First Precinct Police Station, in consequence of a fractured skull. On this statement of the facts the Jury brought in a verdict charging COLLINS with having given the fatal blow. abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder BARNARD, the first case called for trial was that of August Ihl, indicted for felonious assault on Christophere Lose, on the 23d August last. Both parties to the fray were musicians. The difficulty occurred somewhere near the corner of Fifty-ninth-street and Broadway, as the complaintant and prisoner were returning from a serenading party in Seventy-second-street. They fell into some dispute, when Lose struck the prisoner with the mouth-piece of a musical instrument, when the prisoner drew a dagger, and stabbed him in the head and shoulder.

abstract: Indications are now apparent in the Navy that, in case of secession, many Southern Officers will resign. The South Carolinians lead in the determination. At present there are no important posts occupied by Southern men, save one -- the Flag Officer of the East India Squadron being a native of South Carolina. A Kentuckian also commands a fleet. The Navy-yards have no Southern Commandant, except Commodore ARMSTRONG of Pensacola, who was born in Kentucky. The general feeling among officers is for the Union; but the Southerners say they would hate to serve "a foreign State," and that secession involves their retirement.

abstract: -- Our excited correspondent, "Vigilant," wastes his breath in denouncing the Herald and its Editor. They are doing now but what they have been doing for twenty years. There never has been a time when that paper was not doing everything in its power to inflame the worst passions of the worst class of the community; and it is doing nothing more now. It seeks to increase the excitement of the public mind -- to fan the flame that threatens to consume the whole fabric of society, and to incite mobs and riots in the heart of our own community. But it has always done that -- and the merchants and business men of the City have always sustained it in doing so. They are sustaining it now, and they will doubtless continue to do so to the end of the chapter.

abstract: In our issue of last Monday we called attention to the fact, that all the incidents attending the butchery of Mrs. SHANCKS, in Twelfth-street, pointed clearly to an insane man as the only possible perpetrator of such a crime.
lead_paragraph: In our issue of last Monday we called attention to the fact, that all the incidents attending the butchery of Mrs. SHANCKS, in Twelfth-street, pointed clearly to an insane man as the only possible perpetrator of such a crime. The wanton and excessive barbarity of the murder was the main reason suggesting this belief -- it being a rare thing in the annals of crime for "a person possessing as much sanity as the average of murderers, to exercise any more cruelty than is requisite for the sure accomplishment of his purpose." We asked the Coroner to remark that, in the case under notice, "the deceased had received sufficient injuries to have killed half-a-dozen of her sex and age;" and coupling these circumstances with the reckless noise made during the commission of the crime and the hour selected for its perpetration, we found ourselves forced, by the rules of probable evidence, to conclude that the crime on its face gave evidence of "an insane origin."

abstract: Last Monday we called attention to the apparent completeness of evidence against the three officers of the slave-bark Cora, sent back to this port in charge of a prize crew from the Coast of Africa. No better case to serve as a test in reference to the possibility of enforcing the laws against slave-trading could have been prepared, even by the agreement of counsel on both sides. All three men were on board the vessel and acting as mates at the time of her capture on the high seas by the frigate Constellation; and under the hatches of the Cora were found no less than 700 negroes densely packed together.

lead_paragraph: At noon yesterday, Capt. CAFFREY, of the Fifteenth Ward, arrived in this City, having in custody ARTHUR BUCHANAN, the young carpenter against whom strong suspicions are entertained of being the murderer of Mrs. SHANCKS. BUCHANAN, it will be remembered, was apprehended in the town of Susquehanna, Penn., on Saturday night last, on account of his suspicious actions, and word was immediately sent to Superintendent KENNEDY, who forthwith directed. Capt. CAFFREY to proceed to the place named and investigate the matter. The Captain left here on Monday morning, and arrived at Susquehanna about 3 o'clock in the afternoon. Upon making himself known, he was conducted to the principal hotel, whore he found young BUCHANAN in charge of a constable. He immediately claimed the prisoner, who was handed over to his custody, and then made preparations to return to the City.

abstract: The advices brought from the African Squadron by the slave bark Cora, report the Constellation, San Jacinto, Mystic, Sumpter and Portsmouth, the whole fleet, in fact, cruising between the Congo River and Ambriz. Its concentration in that latitude arose from its proximity to the four or five barracoons on the station. A large force of Portuguese men-of-war was assembled near Ambriz, in consequence of some boundary difficulty existing between Ambriz and Portugal. Considerable fighting had been going on on shore.

abstract: The trial of Mr. BURCH, the Chicago banker, for conspiracy against his wife, has ended in his conviction. This was not the form which the suit assumed, -- but it was the issue which was really tried. The guilt or innocence of his wife became, long before the trial was over, entirely a secondary point in the minds of the jury and of the public at large. And the result of the long inquiry was not so much to acquit the wife of the crime alleged against her, as to decide that, if committed at all, it was through the procurement of her husband, and in pursuance of a plot which he had laid for her destruction.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Mr. BURCH, the Chicago banker, for conspiracy against his wife, has ended in his conviction. This was not the form which the suit assumed, -- but it was the issue which was really tried. The guilt or innocence of his wife became, long before the trial was over, entirely a secondary point in the minds of the jury and of the public at large. And the result of the long inquiry was not so much to acquit the wife of the crime alleged against her, as to decide that, if committed at all, it was through the procurement of her husband, and in pursuance of a plot which he had laid for her destruction.

abstract: The shrewd and politic statists of the Southern Republic, that is to be, propose several innovations in the conduct of public affairs. In diplomacy, for instance, where, it must be confessed, the attempts of Mr. DUDLEY MANN, Mr. BALLARD PRESTON and Mr. C.G. BAYLOR have not reflected the highest credit on the capacities of Southern statesmen in that particular, it has been determined to depart from prosaic precedent, and woo foreign assistance by the aid of song. In pursuance of this astute policy, the favor and alliance of the French Government are sought by the adoption of the "Marsellaise" as a substitute for "Yankee Doodle" and "Hail Columbia." These latter are banished, consigned forever to some musical gehenna; the former is tooted by bands in the street, sung by stentorian voices in public meetings and drills, and warbled by fair Disunionists in bower and hall. The initial idea is a happy one; but in practice it is not likely to have a fortunate result. The "Marsellaise" is proscribed in France. The Empire refuses to tolerate it; and as well might the favor of a patriotic son of Erin be sought in strains of "Boyne Water" or "No Surrender," as that of LOUIS NAPOLEON by the music of ROUGET DE LISLE. Partant pour la Syrie, we venture to remind these acute Southern politicians, would not only grate less harshly on the ear of their great Imperial ally, but the very words would have their significance. Or as a stimulant to the prevalent military, spirit, why not Mourir pour la Patrie? The whole subject is an interesting and eminently practical one, and will bear careful study.

abstract: We have the gratifying report this morning that Hon. J.B. GUTHRIE has accepted the seat in the Cabinet vacated by Mr. COBB. We hope it may prove to be true. The change will be a happy one. During the previous administration of the Treasury by Mr. GUTHRIE, the financial affairs of the Government and country were never more satisfactorily conducted. The commercial community felt that perfect confidence in the caution, economy and resources of the Secretary, without which the utmost timidity and distrust are so apt to prevail in the conduct of business, and the basis of a panic is so often prepared.

abstract: On Wednesday last a man, apparently about 50 years of age, was found by the police upon the sidewalk in Forty-second-street, near Eleventh-avenue. He was unconscious, and suffering evidently from injuries to his head. Not knowing his name nor his place of residence, the officer removed him to Bellevue Hospital, where his death occurred on Sunday. Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest yesterday upon the body, and a post-mortem examination having demonstrated that death was the result of compression of the brain, superinduced by external injuries, a verdict to that effect was returned. No evidence was obtained as to the manner, or by whom, the injuries were inflicted.

abstract: On Monday evening JOHN DEWISE, a native of this City, 30 years of age, was admitted to Bellevue Hospital, suffering from a shocking wound in his throat, which he had inflicted with a razor, while laboring under an attack of delirium tremens: He received surgical attention, but the efforts made to save his life were ineffectual. Coroner JACKMAN, yesterday, held an inquest upon the body......The same Coroner investigated the circumstances attending the death of ELIZABETH STEWART, a young married woman, living at No. 16 Leonard-street. It transpired that deceased had long been of intemperate habits, and on Sunday night, while under the influence of liquor, she drank the contents of a vial of laudanum, saying at the time that she would be dead in a few hours. A physician was called, and antidotes were administered, but they failed to be of benefit, and her death resulted on Monday morning.

abstract: We learn that invitations were issued upon last Saturday to many eminent "Fusionists" for a meeting to be held last Monday afternoon at the office of his Honor the Mayor. The cards of invitation gave only vague hints as to the objects of the proposed conference; but those who are in the secret say, that the Mayor is anxious to erect the counties of Suffolk, Queens, Kings, Westchester and Richmond, together with the City of New-York, into an independent Sovereignty, to be called either the State or Kingdom of Manhattan. Whether His Honor the Mayor is in favor of adhering to the republican form of government, with only the security of a patent vesting the Governorship in himself for life; or whether he has finally resolved on declaring an unlimited monarchy, with provisions for retaining the succession in his heirs-male forever, -- we have not yet been able to ascertain.

abstract: Pursuant to a call, signed by many prominent citizens, a public meeting was held at the Cooper Institute, last evening, to adopt measures for the relief of the starving people of Kansas. About 500 ladies and gentlemen were in attendance. W.C. BRYANT was appointed Chairman, and the meeting was formally opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. GILLETTE. The Chairman briefly stated the objects of the meeting, and alluded to the prompt and liberal...
lead_paragraph: Pursuant to a call, signed by many prominent citizens, a public meeting was held at the Cooper Institute, last evening, to adopt measures for the relief of the starving people of Kansas. About 500 ladies and gentlemen were in attendance. W.C. BRYANT was appointed Chairman, and the meeting was formally opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. GILLETTE. The Chairman briefly stated the objects of the meeting, and alluded to the prompt and liberal aid extended a few years ago to famishing Ireland, and more recently to the Syrian Christians. Now the cry of want arises from our own countrymen and brethren. The people of the newly-settled Territory of Kansas had seen their labors for a whole year utterly lost, in consequence of the long-continued drought, and were in imminent danger of suffering all the horrors of famine. Much suffering had, already been experienced. Our relief would come late, but it was not too late to prevent much misery, and to rejoice many hearts. In conclusion, he introduced to the audience Rev. C.C. HUTCHINSON, of Kansas.

abstract: The investigation relative to the circumstances connected with the murder of Mrs. SARAH SHANCES, on Friday last, was resumed yesterday before Coroner JACKMAN, at the Fifteenth Ward Station-house. Two o'clock in the afternoon was the hour which had been fixed upon for the inquest to go on, and long before that time a great many persons had assembled to hear the testimony, or to obtain a sight of ALFRED BUCHANAN, the young man who is in custody on suspicion of being the murderer. The prisoner was brought into the room about 2 1/2 o'clock, and his appearance caused a deep sensation. Accompanying him were his father and brother, both of whom remained at his side until the close of the proceedings. As soon as the young man took his seat, he buried his face in his hands, and for some moments sobbed bitterly; then becoming more composed, he looked vacantly around him, until the examination was commenced. Afterwards, for the most part, he seemed to take great interest in what transpired, keeping his eyes fixed upon the witnesses as they rendered their testimony. When his mother was called to the stand, he again burst into tears. Upon entering the room, she went up to him, and throwing her arms about his neck, she kissed him several times, then looking him earnestly in the face, she said, "Oh, my son, my son, God have mercy upon you. If you are guilty, I implore you to confess it." In reply, he called upon God to witness that he was innocent, repeating the expression two or three times. This scene affected all who were in the room, many being unable to restrain their tears, and frequently during the time that the almost heart-broken woman was giving her testimony, her emotions were such that she would for a time be unable to proceed. Her evidence, and that of the other witnesses, corroborates in the main the report which we published yesterday, with reference to the grounds of suspicion against the prisoner, but no point stronger than the exhibition of his wounded hands, was elicited. No efforts had been made by the Police to ascertain the truth of what the prisoner had said in regard to the manner in which he had been hurt, and testimony on that point being considered important, the case was adjourned until to-day, in order that it might be procured.

abstract: What is Sectionalism? Ten years ago a Sectionalist was a man who advocated the Wilmot Proviso. Four years ago it was a man who did not advocate Squatter Sovereignty. Last October it meant a man who did believe in Squatter Sovereignty and would not support a Slave Code for the Territories. Now, -- in December, -- a man who opposes Disunion, -- who supports the Constitution, and insists upon enforcing the laws, is a Sectionalist. What the word will mean next year, remains to be seen. But we venture to predict that it will not be exactly what it is held to mean now.

abstract: The President having settled the question in his Message that the Federal Government has no power to Prevent the secession of a State, one great obstacle to the acquisition of the Island of Cuba seems to be removed; and it would not be surprising if Spain should at once conclude a treaty ceding that fine colony to the United States for the moderate sum of two or three hundred millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: The President having settled the question in his Message that the Federal Government has no power to Prevent the secession of a State, one great obstacle to the acquisition of the Island of Cuba seems to be removed; and it would not be surprising if Spain should at once conclude a treaty ceding that fine colony to the United States for the moderate sum of two or three hundred millions of dollars. It is confidently asserted that the Cubans are warmly attached to the mother country, and if the Spanish Government reposes confidence in Cuban loyally there can be no doubt that the island will be transferred to the United States as soon as the President's Message reaches Madrid. The Queen's Government is too shrewd to lose so fine an opportunity of filling the money cheat at no greater sacrifice than the temporary loss of her monopoly of the Cuban trade. For, as soon as the American Government pays for the island, and it is admitted into the Union as an independent State, it can immediately secede, and "reannex" itself to the crown of Spain.
headline: {'main': 'Annexation of Cuba Made Easy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Annexation of Cuba Made Easy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Everybody understands, by this time, that the secession of South Carolina will amount to nothing at all, until it takes the practical shape of resistance to the laws of Congress. She may pass as many ordinances of secession as she pleases, -- so long as she pays the duty on her imports. She threatens to stop payment, and if she is in earnest in her scheme of secession, she will do so. But when this stoppage is to take place, we are not informed. A vague and very improbable rumor asserts that she has assured Mr. BUCHANAN she will not do so during his Administration. Who had any authority to give such assurances, we do not know. Nor can we say whether they were prompted by the kind desire to spare the venerable President needless personal uneasiness, or by the wish to lull the Government into a security which should prevent preparation for the contingency.

abstract: Southern economists seem to labor under the belief that a miraculous virtue belongs to the foreign trade of a nation, the possession of which will infallibly insure commercial prosperity, and that the stagnation and insignificance which are characteristic of most Southern seaport towns are solely attributable to the fact, that the Northern cities have monopolized the whole commerce of the nation with Europe and other countries.

abstract: James R. Wolf Kiel vs. The Sixth-avenue Railroad Company. -- This was an action brought to recover damages for injuries received on the defendants' road in August, 1859. There appears to be somewhat of a conflict of evidence in this case. The evidence on the part of the plaintiff, however, appears to slow that the plaintiff and his friend went down Twenty-ninth-street, from Broadway to Sixth-avenue, for the purpose of taking the cars. They saw a one-horse car coming down the avenue and hailed it, and then ran to meet it. The car stopped and both plaintiff and his friend attempted to get on ton; plaintiff's friend succeeded in doing so, but while the plaintiff was trying to get to the top of the car his foot slipped off the step, and was caught and crushed between the wheel and the track. The defendants show that the driver at the time of the accident was engaged in making change for the passengers seated at his side and saw nothing of plaintiff or knew nothing of him until he felt the car jolt as if it had passed over a stone. That the car was then stopped and the plaintiff was found holding on to the car with his foot badly hurt. The evidence shows that the plaintiff is seriously and permanently injured. The defense is that the injuries sustained by plaintiff are the result of his own negligence in attempting to get upon the car before it was stooped. The Jury retired and brought in a verdict for the plaintiff, assessing the damages at $1,808 50.

abstract: William Smeaton, son-in-law of deceased, recalled: I last saw Mrs. Shancks alive on the Tuesday previous to the murder; I called at her store in the afternoon, between three and four o'clock; the prisoner was there at the time; Mrs. Shancks told me about his having done some work for her -- made a stepladder; she said that she did not like him, and she wanted to get rid of him; she was afraid that he would steal from her and that he might injure her in some way; she shuddered when she spoke about him; she told him that he might take the paper home which he was reading, but before he left the store I looked at him sternly; I may have seen the prisoner at Mrs. Shancks before that occasion, but I will not say confidently that I have; Mrs. Shancks left the impression on my mind that the prisoner was very disagreeable to her, but she did not explain to me why she felt so toward him.

abstract: Henry P. Farrington vs. Sylvester S. Mangan. -- This was a motion to dissolve an injunction granted by Judge HILTON against the defendant on the 5th day of December, by which the defendants in this cause were enjoined from obstructing the owner of the pier at the foot of Laight-street, in this City, by the use of permanent vessels for the storage of grain and produce. The counsel for the defendant, in moving a dissolution of of this injunction, assumed the ground that the plaintiff Farrington, is not entitled by law to more than the width, of three vessels, and that the defendant has the same light; that at the present time there is no regular mode prescribed to collect wharfage on more than three vessels. It seems that both these parties hold leases under the City, and it is assumed that if there is any actual obstruction of the rights of either party the Harbor-masters have full power under the statute to relieve the party aggrieved. The Court upon the conclusion of the argument said that without further considering the case, the facts were sufficiently distinct and comprehensive to warrant it in passing upon the question. The Court will not in this instance pass upon the question of title; that must be left to be determined by the suit brought to test the question. The injunction, however, should be modified by giving the plaintiff only the right to the width of one vessel along the bulkhead.

abstract: There are probably many of our readers who remember the brilliant and remarkable series of lectures on SHAKESPEARE delivered in this City, some years since, by Rev. H.N. HUDSON. abstract: THE HEENEY ESTATE AGAIN The Heeney estate valued at $1,000,000, more or less, and located in the Sixth Ward was before the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday. The property is in the possession of the Brooklyn Benevolent Society, who claim to hold it under a codicil to will, made in 1844.
lead_paragraph: THE HEENEY ESTATE AGAIN. -- The Heeney estate -- valued at $1,000,000, more or less, and located in the Sixth Ward -- was before the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday. The property is in the possession of the Brooklyn Benevolent Society, who claim to hold it under a codicil to will, made in 1844. The plaintiffs, JAMES HEENEY and ALICIA C. HEENEY, claim the property as his heirs at law, being next of kin, and also under a will made in 1843. The case was tried before Judge BROWN in 1858, and was dismissed on the ground that the plaintiffs were aliens at the time Mr. HEENEY died. The appellants counsel say that the Court erred in this decision, and hence have brought it before the General Term. Decision reserved.

abstract: Some few weeks since the Board of Aldermen adopted a resolution (in answer to the prayer of certain petitions) granting permission to erect a shed on pier No. 44 North River, occupied as a depot for the Liverpool line of steamers, of which the City of Washington was the pioneer. The resolution was concurred in by the other Board, but the parties interested, assuming the certainty of the Mayor's approval, proceeded at once to the construction of the shed, As the erection of sheds or buildings of any kind on the wharves or piers is expressly forbidden by the statute, any action of the Common Council is simply and utterly illegal. The parties interested were yesterday notified by Col. BURNHAM, the First Marshal, to desist from further prosecution of the work, but assured of the support of the Common Council, they set his order at defiance, and proceeded with the work. As the Marshal found that throwing dirt had no effect he was compelled to resort to stones, and a posse of Capt. Hart's squad were dispatched to the pier with directions to arrest the violators of the law. At the commencement of each year each member of the Common Council is furnished with a copy of the Revised Statutes and the Revised Ordinances, but that that they either do not, or, (as in many instances is not improbable,) cannot read them, is abundantly evidenced by the constantly recurring instances of their willful violation. It is not many years since the great commander of the North River steamboats undertook to erect an office on the pier occupied by his boats, but as the City was blessed then by a Common Council who were not compelled to make their living out of "jobs," he was forced to pull it down, as being a violation of law.

abstract: Hon. W. L. YANCEY--Dear Sir: You will see from my last letter that I have no faith in the validity or sincerity of the reasons assigned for a secession of the Southern States. The motive for that movement is neither the failure of the North to surrender fugitive slaves, nor the enactment of Personal Liberty bills, nor the practical inability of Southern slaveholders to take their slaves into the Territories of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Hon. W.L. YANCEY -- Dear Sir: You will see from my last letter that I have no faith in the validity or sincerity of the reasons assigned for a secession of the Southern States. The motive for that movement is neither the failure of the North to surrender fugitive slaves, nor the enactment of Personal Liberty bills, nor the practical inability of Southern slaveholders to take their slaves into the Territories of the United States. If you could have full and sufficient guarantees upon every one of these points you would be just as zealous, though not perhaps so sanguine, an advocate of secession as yon are now. What you and your associate conspirators seek is the restoration of the African Slave-trade. To use your own words, "We of Alabama want slaves to be cheap; -- we want to buy, not to sell them. It is a Virginia idea that slaves ought to be high. Virginia wants $1,500 each for her negroes: -- we want to get them cheaper." "CHEAP NEGROES" is the grand consummation at which you aim, -- the mighty motive which rouses you to the task of destroying a Government which was formed to "secure the blessings of Liberty to ourselves and our posterity."

abstract: The Board of Supervisors at their meeting yesterday adopted a resolution offered by Mr. PURDY, directing a Committee to report upon the propriety of taxing plaintiffs in Civil Courts the sum of $2 upon the commencement of each suit, and $3 upon the bringing of the same to trial, the avowed object being to render the County Courts self-sustaining, and to save the quiet and peace-loving citizens from being compelled to bear the burden of expenses imposed on them by the litigious. If this resolution should be confirmed by the action of the Supervisors, the business of the Courts will be seriously diminished.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors at their meeting yesterday adopted a resolution offered by Mr. PURDY, directing a Committee to report upon the propriety of taxing plaintiffs in Civil Courts the sum of $2 upon the commencement of each suit, and $3 upon the bringing of the same to trial, the avowed object being to render the County Courts self-sustaining, and to save the quiet and peace-loving citizens from being compelled to bear the burden of expenses imposed on them by the litigious. If this resolution should be confirmed by the action of the Supervisors, the business of the Courts will be seriously diminished.

abstract: It appears from the Tax returns of the City of Boston that the twelve candidates elected upon last Monday to seats in the Board of Aldermen for that city are assessed upon an aggregate of real and personal estate amounting to $726,100, giving, an average property of $60,508 33 to each of the twelve good men and true selected as City Fathers. Such a Board as this cannot certainly have much interest in swelling the future burden of city taxes; but it is a fact worth mentioning that Mr. SILAS PIERCE, the wealthiest man of the twelve, paying taxes on real and personal estate to the amount of $188,900, is now reelected to office for the fourth time. The second wealthiest man, JONATHAN PRESTON, put down at $122,300 has also served in three previous Aldermanic terms, having likewise been State Senator. The third wealthiest man, T.C. AMORY, Jr. owning real and personal estate to the amount of $101,000, is also, familiar with Aldermanic duties and privileges, having previously served his country both in the Board and in the State Assembly. Let it be added to these curious facts that JOHN F. PRAY, the poorest man of the twelve, and only assessed at $4,500 for real and personal estate together, "has never before held any public office" --being described on the contrary, as being "a regular attendant on the Twelfth Congregational Church for the last thirty years" -- and it will be seen at once what a glorious opportunity Mr. PRAY has now opening up before him. In about four years from now, we shall examine with interest the amounts placed opposite Mr. PRAY's name in the real and personal estate assessment lists of the City of Boston.

abstract: The session of Congress yesterday was an extremely quiet one, though the proceedings were interesting. In the Senate, an amendment to Mr. MORRILL's Tarriff bill, referred to the Committee on Finance on Tuesday, was offered by Mr. BIGLER, of Pennsylvania, and was similarly referred. The House bill authorizing the issue of Treasury notes for the relief of the Government was reported by Mr. HUNTER, from the Finance Committee, amended by inserting fifty instead of one hundred dollars as the minimum value, and providing that the proceeds of the sales of the public lands be set apart as security for their redemption. After considerable debate relative to the details of the bill, participated in by Messrs. HUNTER of Virginia, ANTHONY of Rhode Island, HALE of New-Hampshire, CAMERON of Pennsylvania, FESSENDEN of Maine, SEWARD of NEW-YORK, COLLAMER of Vermont, and others, the amount was cut down to three millions, and the measure passed. The limitation of the amount to three millions, barely sufficient to carry on the Government until the 4th of March and the pledge of the public lands for the redemption of the notes, thereby relieving those States proposing to secede from any portion of the debt, are considered as significant indications of a belief in disunion. Mr. POWELL's resolutions in reference to secession were then taken up, and Mr. WIGFALL, of Texas, occupied the remainder of the session, until nearly 4 o'clock, in an exposition of his peculiar views regarding the pending crisis. In the House, pursuant to the arrangement made on Tuesday, the various States were called upon for propositions relating to the present condition of the country, and the best means of averting the threatening calamity of disunion. Resolutions were submitted by Messrs. THAYER of Massachusetts, JOHN COCHRANE of New-York, ADRIAN of New-Jersey, MORRIS of Pennsylvania, STEWART of Maryland, LEAKE, SMITH and JENKINS of Virginia, COX, HUTCHINS, SHERMAN and BINGHAM of Ohio, MALLORY and STEVENSON of Kentucky, ENGLISH, KILGORE, HOLMAN and DAVIS of Indiana, MCCLERNAND of Illinois, NOELL of Missouri, HINDMAN of Arkansas, and LARRABEE of Wisconsin. The proposition were severally read and referred to the Union Committee. Mr. BONHAM, of South Carolina, as he did not expect to remain long a member of Congress, asked to be excused from serving on the Military Committee. The request was complied with. A bill was reported from the Committee on Public Lands by Mr. THAYER, which creates the land district of Dacotah, and provides for the admission of a delegate in Congress from that Territory. It was referred to the Committee of the Whole, and after some other unimportant business the House adjourned.

abstract: There was an animated contest in the Legislature for an election of Governor to-day. The following is the second ballot: Necessary to a choice, 82; Pickens, 53; Johnson, 50; Rhett, 28; Jamieson, 27; Townsend, Barnwell and Chesnut one each; blank, 1. On the first ballot PICKENS and JOHNSON tied. The election was postponed until Wednesday.

abstract: -- The Board of Councilmen last night made an active attempt to pass a reduced Japanese bill, without giving the items; but as all the "ring votes" were not present, the engineers in charge of the measure got frightened, and a motion to adjourn was carried. The proposed reduction is a substantial one, cutting down the total of the bill from $105,000, the Aldermanic figure, to $90,000, which must be somewhere in the neighborhood of an honest amount. But why do the Councilmen, while acting to this extent in the public interest, refuse to give us the items as originally rendered by the Reception Committee of the Board of Aldermen? We are heartily anxious to have this disgraceful affair concluded and put out of sight forever. We know that in some instances honest tradesmen are suffering very serious inconvenience through the failure of the City to pay these bills.

abstract: TROUBLE IN BROOKLYN Some weeks since we gave an account of the mysteries and miseries, the ups and downs of life which had followed a beautiful damsel of the City of Churches, a young lady whose father stands high as a man of character, wealth, and influence, and now we are privileged to add a last link to the chain of singular events. lead_paragraph: TROUBLE IN BROOKLYN Some weeks since we gave an account of the mysteries and miseries, the ups and downs of life which had followed a beautiful damsel of the City of Churches, a young lady whose father stands high as a man of character, wealth, and influence, and now we are privileged to add a last link to the chain of singular events. Having been to Europe, where she was the suffering recipient of outrageous treatment, and having fled from her, husband to her father's home, she was supposed to be quietly settled for life. Judge, then, of her surprise" and of the parental indignation when, on Sunday last, the scallywag of a husband was seen leisurely walking up the front steps. He had arrived on the Africa the day before, and facing the enemy in its own castle, he succeeded, by dint of quiet submission to reproach, and eloquent pleadings and profuse promising, in establishing himself once more upon the houshold hearth. He explains the whippings, cursings, and other brutality by saying that he was in a measure out of his head, and that when he came to himself he was in the greatest imaginable agony on account of the treatment he had given his wife. When the babe was brought from the nursery the father seized it in his arms and burst into tears. The reconciliation between husband and wife will be the means of restoring peace to one of the largest and most influential family-circles in the city.

abstract: South Carolina,  it seems, considering herself "on a war footing," has adopted the usages of war so far as to send spies into the enemy's camp mainly for the purpose of studying the chances of success. We copy from the Charleston Mercury
lead_paragraph: -- South Carolina, it seems, considering herself "on a war footing," has adopted the usages of war so far as to send spies into the enemy's camp mainly for the purpose of studying the chances of success. We copy from the Charleston Mercury the report of one of these emissaries -- who seems to be a shrewd observer and a careful and prudent gentleman. His name is C.C. SPENCER. He stopped at the St. Nicholas, where he registered his name as "from Maine," fearing, we suppose, that he might be taken and hung if it were known that he really belonged to Alabama. But he made very good use of his time here -- saw a great many influential persons, and makes a very sensible and judicious report of facts to his employers.

abstract: A movement is on foot, under the auspices of Mayor WOOD, to call a Union meeting for the purpose of staying, if possible, the disunion movement of some of the Southern States. Quite a number of our prominent citizens are engaged in it, and the cooperation of the Common Council has been proposed. The debate on the subject last night was neither very dignified nor judicious.

abstract: The Third-avenue Railroad Company publish, in another column a reply to the objections urged by the Mayor, in his veto of the resolutions recently passed by the Common Council for their benefit. Some of their claims to further accommodations are doubtless valid, -- but we certainly see no reason why they should be released from any of the obligations which were imposed upon them at the outset. Besides, if they require increased space for the prosecution of their business, we see no reason why they should not pay for it like any other private Corporation.

abstract: PHILIP ST. GEO. COCKE, a wealthy planter and prominent citizen of Virginia, writes to the Richmond Examiner representing that the party which has now triumphed is the one which for thirty years has sought to poison the mind of the slaves and instigate them to insubordination, poisoning and pillage. He therefore urges his fellow citizens to prepare for dissolution, but not to take precipitate action.

abstract: To say that the debate in the Board of Alderman last night, in reference to the payment of $6,000 for dredging out the slip allotted to the Great Eastern, was an exciting affair, would be doing it less than justice. It was spirited in the extreme, and its revelations had all that sincerity and unreserve which we are chiefly in the habit of expecting from gentlemen with whom "the salmon has disagreed." It was a genuine post-prandial debate, or rather colloquy, in regard to the practical science of "big things" -- a term, we believe, of Aldermanic origin, but fast merging into the common diction of the people.
lead_paragraph: To say that the debate in the Board of Alderman last night, in reference to the payment of $6,000 for dredging out the slip allotted to the Great Eastern, was an exciting affair, would be doing it less than justice. abstract: The Treasury Note bill has, with unusual good fortune, passed the several forms of legislation, and in all likelihood has also received before this the President's signature. In its progress from the hands of the House Committee of Ways and Means it experienced one or two amendments. One consisted in the reduction of the amount to a sum sufficient to meet the urgent exigencies of the Treasury, without furnishing a surplus for use after the Fourth of March. The other, and a highly material amendment, was the erasure of the clause pledging the public lands as a security for the loan.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Note bill has, with unusual good fortune, passed the several forms of legislation, and in all likelihood has also received before this the President's signature. abstract: The Chicago Tribune has several interesting incidents of the excitement in the South, which are furnished it by a gentleman just returned from New-Orleans. In that city the excitement runs high, and all Northern men have been obliged to leave the St. Charles Hotel for more quiet quarters. One evening, in the reading-room of that establishment, the crowd was assembled as usual, and the Abolitionists were the theme. Becoming excited, one man, said to be wealthy and influential, pulled out his pocket-book and said, "Here are $5,000 which I will subscribe to a fund to procure the assassination of Lincoln and Hainlin; who'll swell the pile? In ten minutes, or less, more than $40,000 had been offered for this infamous purpose, and the names of the subscribers were taken down. In further proof of the prevailing frenzy, the informant of the Tribune relates the escape of Prof. MITCHELL, the well-known astronomer. He was on the cars going South, and when near Jackson, Miss., a man somewhat inflamed with liquor entered into conversation with him on political subjects. The Professor was cautious and reserved; but venturing to say that he thought Mr. LINCOLN was a conservative man and would not do injustice to the South, his Pro-Slavery friend was greatly incensed; and when the train halted at Jackson, jumped to the platform and shouted to the crowd about the station, "There's a d_____d Abolitionist on the train! Lynch him! Lynch him!" Instantly, at least fifty men jumped on and commenced a search for the offensive specimen of Northern opinion; but before the Professor could be pointed out, the conductor, seeing the danger, pulled the bell-cord and the cars moved off, and with them the Professor with a whole skin.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Tribune has several interesting incidents of the excitement in the South, which are furnished it by a gentleman just returned from New-Orleans. abstract: -The President's Washington organ, the Constitution devotes a column to a very savage attack on JOHN BELL for his recent Union letter. He "has declared himself in favor of Southern submission to Mr. LINCOLN," says this official print -- "in opposition to the right of secession." These "dreary echoes of the same purposeless story are sickening." "Mr. BELL talks only for the purpose of hearing his own sweet voice." His only motive is "an anxiety to figure as Mr. LINCOLN's apologist, and a supporter, if not a member of his Administration."

abstract: The great social problem for all the large cities of this country lying at the bottom of the trouble from poverty which arises every winter, is, how to connect the supply and demand of labor? The good fortune of our country is an almost unlimited extent of fertile territory, and proportionally great demand for industrious hands to cultivate it. lead_paragraph: The great social problem for all the large cities of this country lying at the bottom of the trouble from poverty which arises every winter, is, how to connect the supply and demand of labor? The good fortune of our country is an almost unlimited extent of fertile territory, and proportionally great demand for industrious hands to cultivate it. But on the other side, immigration, with attendant ignorance and poverty, gathers together in the large cities multitudes of strong men and hard-working women, who each season lose a certain portion of their employment and become dependent on charity. If a Winter of business revolution or panic occurs, this evil is vastly increased. Each year, people who look beyond the temporary assistance of the unfortunate, ask why they should forever be called upon to fill these leaky vessels of the poor, when there is bread enough and to spare for them, and to be earned by honest labor, in our country districts. Why not connect supply and demand, -- they ask anew each Winter, and no one ventures to answer the question.
headline: {'main': 'The Natural Remedy of Poverty.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Natural Remedy of Poverty.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our South Caro  BEGINNING TO TALK OUT. Our South Carolina brethren are so elated with the prospect of their coming independence, that they are getting communicative. While they remained in the Union, their claims upon the Federal Government were stealthy and cautious. They pressed their demands softly, asking only their "plain, constitutional rights,"
lead_paragraph: Our South Carolina brethren are so elated with the prospect of their coming independence, that they are getting communicative. While they remained in the Union, their claims upon the Federal Government were stealthy and cautious. They pressed their demands softly, -- asking only their "plain, constitutional rights," -- merely insisting that we should protect them in the enjoyment of their property, and permit them to take it into the Federal Territories, which were bought by the "common blood and treasure" of all the States.

abstract: Should not one of those interpositions of Providence, such as let FREDERICKS, the mate of the Cora, out of a cabin window into an opportune boat, inscrutably occur in favor of Capt. LATHAM, of the same vessel, District Attorney ROOSEVELT may consider his case against these people as admirably complete. Capt. LATHAM is an old friend of the Marshal's Office.
lead_paragraph: Should not one of those interpositions of Providence, such as let FREDERICKS, the mate of the Cora, out of a cabin window into an opportune boat, inscrutably occur in favor of Capt. LATHAM, of the same vessel, District Attorney ROOSEVELT may consider his case against these people as admirably complete. Capt. LATHAM is an old friend of the Marshal's Office. It made his acquaintance last Spring, when he swore his vessel free from the suspicion of being a slaver, adding heavy security to strengthen his oath; and the Cora sailed for Congo and a cargo. It obtained the latter; At the end of six months, the Cora and its Captain are here again, in the grasp of the law; and all the profits of the adventure are yet to be divided between its survivors. The division is to be made by a jury of the United States Courts.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. DONIZETTI'S lively opera of the "Daughter of the Regiment," was played here on Wednesday night, and attracted a good house the best so far of the season, and a forerunner, we trust, of future success. The performance was, on the whole, a good one, and the applause sufficiently warm and frequent to justify the management in announcing the work for the Matinee an Saturday.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. DONIZETTI'S lively opera of the "Daughter of the Regiment," was played here on Wednesday night, and attracted a good house the best so far of the season, and a forerunner, we trust, of future success. The performance was, on the whole, a good one, and the applause sufficiently warm and frequent to justify the management in announcing the work for the Matinee an Saturday. Any one acquainted with the materiel of the present company, will see at a glance that an opera like the "Daughter of the Regiment," is more calculated to display its versatility than exhibit its real artistic capacity. It is remarkable, indeed, that performers, who have so recently electrified the public in a grandiose work like the "Jewess," and who contemplate to-night (Friday) giving MEYERBEER's "Robert le Diable," should be able to unbend themselves to the graceful elasticities of such a score, especially when it is remembered that neither Mme. FABRI, nor Signor STIGELLI possess the right character of voice for its comparative trivialities. FORMES, who, musically considered. Is equally good or bad in any part, never fails to give high dramatic interest to whatever he undertakes, and as the Sergeant, ha has rare opportunities, which we need only say he improves abundantly. Remembering these essential points, it is worthy to be put on honorable record that the opera was a success, and in many of its best known parts fairly brought down the house. The chorus and orchestra (under Mr. THOMAS' direction) were both thoroughly efficient. To-night MEYERBEER's opera of "Robert le Diable" will be given for the only time this season.

abstract: Both Houses of Congress, after a short and interesting session yesterday adjourned over until Monday. The Treasury Note bill was perfected and sent to the President for signature -- the House agreeing to the reduction of the minimum value from one hundred to fifty dollars, and the Senate agreeing that the pledge of public lands for their redemption should extend to the entire ten millions, instead of to only three millions, as proposed by the Senate Finance Committee. Mr. JOHSSON, of Tennessee, introduced in the Senate a series of resolutions proposing certain amendments to the Constitution looking to a permanent settlement of the pending difficulties in the country. Mr. IVERSON, of Georgia, called up the bill relative to our commission to Mexico, which was debated a short time without any definite result. The resolutions on the state of the Union were then taken up again, and Mr. WIGFALL, of Texas resumed his remarks on the subject of secession, commenced on Wednesday. He denied that the proposed action of South Carolina could be regarded as treason, and asserted his belief that she would be out of the Union in less than a week. In the House, the Speaker appointed Mr. HUGHES, of Maryland, as a member of the Committee on Military Affairs, in place of Mr. BONHAM, of South Carolina. Mr. MORRIS, of Illinois, then again endeavored to obtain leave to introduce his resolution pledging members to stand by the Union, but objection was made. The bill to grant lands to Kansas for the construction of railroads was referred to the Committee on Public Lands. Mr. HASKIN, of New-York, in view of the fact that Mr. FORD, the House printer, was absent, and that the sub-contractors decline executing the work at the price fixed upon at the last session, offered a resolution that the Superintendent of Public Printing be authorized to contract with other parties. Mr. MCCLERNAND, of Illinois, saw no necessity for passing the resolution, as Mr. Ford would soon be in Washington to attend to his duties, and the resolution, after some debate, was tabled.

Mr. MORRIS, of Illinois, then again endeavored to obtain leave to introduce his resolution pledging members to stand by the Union, but objection was made. abstract: The Lagrange, (Geo.) Reporter, which is published at the home of Hon. B.H. HILL, recently contained a well-considered article representing that the excitement in that State regarding secession, had passed its crisis; that the people were settling down to the conviction that the Constitution will secure them all their rights, and that they would make dissolution of the Union the last resort. Secession, the Reporter urges, is an unworthy refuge for the most timid, since the South will by it voluntarily relinquish to the Republicans all the advantages which they claim. This the people are realizing, and it urges them to send to the approaching State Convention men who will listen to reason, leaving them unpledged, however, so that they may act as the emergency may demand.
