abstract: FAIR OF THE WOMEN's PRISON ASSOCIATION. -- The Annual Fair of this excellent charity, for the benefit of the Isaac T. Hopper Home, opened at Clinton Hall, in Astor-place, on Wednesday evening, and closes to-night. The Institution was established fifteen years ago, and its object is to reclaim discharged female prisoners. It provides a home for the fallen ones in Tenth-avenue, near Twenty-second-street, where they are educated in the duties of the household, and whence they are sent forth to eligible situations in the City and country. The display this year is a very tempting one. All kinds of pretty and useful handiwork, much of it prepared by this inmates of the Home, and by the kind-hearted ladies by whose efforts it is supported, are exhibited and the purchasers have been plentiful. Yesterday 89 young ladies of Mrs. GIBSON's school, in Union-square, who had already contributed $100 worth of articles to the Fair, visited the rooms and bought many goods there. Great preparations have been made for the reception of Santa Claus, who is said to be in town on a shopping excursion, and is expected to visit the Fair to-day.

abstract: The Coroner's investigation in the case of Mrs. Sarah Shancks, who was murdered on Friday morning last at No. 22 East Twelfth-street, was concluded yesterday--resulting in a verdict against Alfred Buchanan, the young carpenter, who was arrested on suspicion of having committed the crime. The proceedings were conducted at the Fifteenth Ward Station-house, and the large number of persons in attendance attested the great interest which is felt in the case.

abstract: Detective Farley yesterday arrived in this City from St. Louis, Mo., having in custody Constantine Maugenet, a Frenchman, whom he had arrested in the latter city on a charge of larceny. It is said that about two months ago, from charitable motives, Rev. Father Lafonte, of the Twenty-third-street Catholic Church, took the prisoner into his service. Among the duties assigned him was that of cleaning the church, and in doing his work he ascertained where the plate, used in the sacramental rite, was kept. The temptation to steal it proved irresistible, and about four weeks since he packed it up and fled to St. Louis, taking in addition to the church property about $800 of his reverend benefactor's money. It is also said that before he left the City he procured several gold watches from dealers in William-street, upon the plea that Father Lafonte had sent for them. When Officer Farley reached St. Louis he had no difficulty in arresting Maugenet, whom he found clothed in rags, and representing to benevolent Catholics that he was desirous to obtain funds for the purpose of going to his friends in New-Orleans. In this way he had managed to collect a considerable sum of money. In the prisoner's possession was found six of the gold watches, and a portion of the money which is said to have been stolen from Father Lafonte. He is now locked up at Police Head-quarters.

abstract: The announcement that Rev. HENRY N. HUDSON, whose edition of Shakespeare has made a distinguished mark in the history of editions of the world's great poet, -- even at this time, when KNIGHT, DYCE, COLLIER, HALLIWELL, SINGER, and, though last not least, RICHARD GRANT WHITE, not to speak of Mr. HOWARD STAUNTON, are before the public as his expounders and commentators, was to commence a series of lectures on the principal plays of the "myriad-minded" Bard of Stratford, as COLERIDGE called him, filled Hope Chapel on Thursday evening, with an audience that would have pleased MILTON in being "fit," and which did honor to Mr. HUDSON, and sub voce to SHAKESPEARE in being not "few."

abstract: The audience which attended Rev. J.C. FLETCHER's last lecture the cap-sheaf of the Course, at Cooper Institute, last evening, was as large as those which the announcements of his previous public discourses have invariably called together the exceedingly cold weather to the contrary notwithstanding. Those who gave ear to the caution whispered by the icy Winter's wind, and stayed at home to keep them warm, reckoned without their host.
lead_paragraph: The audience which attended Rev. J.C. FLETCHER's last lecture the cap-sheaf of the Course, at Cooper Institute, last evening, was as large as those which the announcements of his previous public discourses have invariably called together the exceedingly cold weather to the contrary notwithstanding. Those who gave ear to the caution whispered by the icy Winter's wind, and stayed at home to keep them warm, reckoned without their host. The stirring theme and burning words of the lecturer were (better than a fire, and as he warmed to his subject, he kindled in the hearts of his hearers a more generous flame than that which blazed between the jambs of their own narrow firesides. For "Italy and GARIBALDI" was his theme -- the story of Liberty's release and the despot's overthrow. Mr. FLETCHER, after briefly expressing his thanks for the very cordial and gratifying reception which has been accorded to all that he has said by the many whom he has addressed, proceeded to deliver his lecture, of which, barring the pressure on our space, we should be happy to give a more extended report. Peninsulas, he said, had always been seats of power. The causes were evident, In them communication was easy and frequent -- everything tended to concentration. Athens, Rome, Granada thus became great peninsular seats of power. Italy had for ages been a giant crushed and held down by petty despots, as Gulliver was pinned down by the Lilliputians. The Peninsula had been distracted, divided, kept under the sway of petty tyrants. But though through long ages there had been no United Italy in politics, in language and in literature there had continued to be a United Italy. The strong Lombards, in the ancient time, had endeavored to make Italy a united kingdom, but had been overcome by the instrumentality of "the Papal king," as GARIBALDI termed the Pope. Then in the Fourteenth century RIENZI, "The Last of the Tribunes," had conceived the idea of a united Italy, but as soon as he touched the power of the "Papal King," so soon had he fallen. In the seventeenth century the Neapolitan. fisherman MASANTELLO -- one of the lowest class, the Lazzaroni -- aroused by the impositions of a foreign soldiery, struck, conquered, was crowned king, and -- beheaded. His name lived still. AUBER had embalmed it in music, and the people of Italy to-day united in singing the liberty hymns of his opera, the performance of which was interdicted in Russia and Austria, It was but a short time ago that VICTOR HUGO had exclaimed, "Oh, Italy, Italy, of all that is beautiful, thou art but the shadow of thy former self!" And, at another time, "Italy, that has taught the world how to read, to-day knows not how to read!" But that was changed. The Waldenses -- that people which had never been dignified by the name of Italy -- that people which had been hidden away among the Croatian Alps, and whose motto was "Lux lucet in tenebris" -- that despised and persecuted people, had been the feeble instrumentality by which a united Italy had been brought forth. Eighteen months ago the chances of Italian liberty had seemed dark indeed. How had this land rejoiced in seeing Italy united. Should that Italy now see us flying to pieces? There was quite as much prospect of it apparently as there was eighteen months ago that Italy would be united. But the same God who made it a united Italy could prevent us from becoming a dis-United States. [Applause.]

abstract: The sloop Jenny Lind, of and from Stamford, Conn., for this City, was capsized on Thursday night, at 10 o'clock, when off Sunken Marsh, above Hell Gate. Some men working at the Railroad depot, at Port Morris, heard them calling for assistance, and informed Mr. WM. KEES, who launched his boat, and succeeded in saving all hands, in a nearly exhausted state. One of the men was not fully resuscitated until this morning. Considering how cold the night was, they no doubt would have perished but for the intrepidity of Mr. KEES. The sloop has since been righted, and the water got out of her.

abstract: -- John Blake, a farmer in Saratoga County, has been fined $1,000 for cruel treatment of Conrad Floyd, a boy whom he adopted into his family from the Utica Orphan Asylum. It was proved that Blake had kicked the boy until he was deformed, that he had given him meals only when he felt inclined, and that he had actually compelled him to eat mice and squirrels raw and unskinned.

abstract: BUNSEN, the illustrious, critic, philologist, historian and diplomat, died at Bonn, on the 28th of November, in his seventieth year. There are many in America to whom this profound and hospitable spirit has long been dear for the noble freedom which he has carried into the treatment of the profoundest questions of History and Theology, and for the truth and piety that have pervaded his life and works. In England, with which he was long connected by many literary and social ties, (having been for near twenty years Prussian Ambassador to the Court of St. James,) he will be widely and sincerely regretted. His house in London was for many years the rendezvous of a very interesting and various society, including scholars, artists, literateurs and divines, as well as statesmen and diplomatists. He has, without doubt, deeply influenced modern speculative thought, and has planted things like to last.

abstract: From Rhinebeck to Albany the Hudson River is frozen over, rendering navigation between this City and Albany impossible. Between Rhinebeck and Poughkeepsie there are large quantities of floating ice; between Poughkeepsie and Newburgh, but little. A steam propeller, with barges in tow, on her way to Albany on Thursday, was unable to proceed beyond Poughkeepsie. The steamer Manhattan started from Poughkeepsie yesterday morning for Rondout, plowing her way through the ice. The weather during the past few days has been very cold. There has been very good sleighing at Poughkeepsie and above for nearly two weeks.

abstract: Perhaps the best idea of the comparative magnitude or value of the productions of Northern and Southern States is to be obtained by considering the relative degree of education, industry and training which prevails, and the amount of capital invested in the different branches of industry. Hardly any census will give the total value of articles produced. Such as enter into commerce from different communities are in every unequal...
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the best idea of the comparative magnitude or value of the productions of Northern and Southern States is to be obtained by considering the relative degree of education, industry and training which prevails, and the amount of capital invested in the different branches of industry. Hardly any census will give the total value of articles produced. Such as enter into commerce from different communities are in every unequal ratio to their total production. Some produce, in kind, nearly all the articles they consume; others only a very small percentage. But if we could get at the amount of capital, and the skill and industry of the laborers employed, we could form very satisfactory estimates of the comparative results.

abstract: There are few standard operas in the Italian or German repertoires more generally acceptable than MEYERBEER's "Robert le Diable." Without the pretence of the master's subsequent works, it possesses all the best characteristics of his genius, and is full of those unique fragments of melody which none but he -- who regards them as gems, and treats them, as such -- knows how to bring into prominence. The principal morceaux of the opera were excellently given last night, by the principal artists, who evidently felt themselves completely at home in their various roles. Thoroughly competent as we know Mme. FABBRI to be, and completely at ease as that knowledge never fails to put us, we were scarcely prepared for such a rendition of her part. It must be regarded as one of her greatest successes, and this we say the more unhesitatingly, in view of the slight vocal accident which marred the effect of the trio in the second act. Signor STIGELLI recovered himself completely as Robert, and sang with great spirit. Herr FORMES fully sustained his reputation as the best Bertram on the stage. Altogether, indeed, the performance was more than an average one. The attendance, we are sorry to say, was not what it should have been.

abstract: A German shoemaker, named GEORGE MERKELIN, who kept a shop in a temporary building in Garden-street, Hoboken, which was formerly used as a coal office, has been missing for the past two weeks, and his shop during that time has remained closed. Some of MERKELIN's friends, becoming alarmed at his unaccountable absence, applied to Constable HAYBECK, of Jersey City, to hunt up the man if possible, or to ascertain if any accident had befallen him, or if there had been any foul play.

abstract: By advertisement in another column it will be seen that a new military organization is about to be established in this City, under the auspices of Mr. JAMES E. KERRIGAN, member of Congress elect from the Fourth District of this City. The object of the proposed corps is of a character somewhat different from that of military companies in general, being nothing more nor less than the protection of the municipal rights of this metropolis from further Republican encroachments. It is believed that the next Legislature which is to meet at Albany intends to meddle still more with the affairs of this City by destroying certain of its constitutional rights, and by legislating certain officials elected by the people out of office, in the same way as was done in the case of Mayor WOOD. Such attempts Mr. Kerrigan's organization is determined to resist vi et armis; so that our Republican Solons had better attend to their manners this Winter, and look well ere they leap into a course which may have a very undesirable termination. The Kerrigan organization will, moreover, be Pro-Slavery in principle, and will take prompt action in case of secession. We understand that fifty volunteer companies, representing some three thousand members, have already responded favorably to the call. All captains of volunteer companies desirous of taking part in the movement are invited by the call to communicate with Mr. KERRIGAN, at 74 Mott-street.

abstract: Democratic institutions are now on their trial in America. It Would be a strange coincidence if the same year should witness the accomplishment of Italian unity under a constitutional monarchy and the disruption of a far mightier Union under the dislocating agency of Federal Republicanism. WASHINGTON, like ALEXANDER, troubled in his last days by misgivings as to the solidity of his own workmanship.
lead_paragraph: Democratic institutions are now on their trial in America. It Would be a strange coincidence if the same year should witness the accomplishment of Italian unity under a constitutional monarchy and the disruption of a far mightier Union under the dislocating agency of Federal Republicanism. WASHINGTON, like ALEXANDER, troubled in his last days by misgivings as to the solidity of his own workmanship. He had found American patriotism strong enough to brave in a good cause the armies of GEORGE III., but would it be proof against the selfishness of prosperity, the meanness of party and personal interests, the fierceness of provincial jealousies? Could the dignified and statesmanlike moderation of the founders of liberty be transmitted to their successors, or would later growth develop those harsher and vulgar qualities which too often appear in the Anglo-Saxon character? We dare not say that the experiment is yet complete. Two generations have amply sufficed to confirm and transcend the experience of antiquity as to the expansive energies of a Democracy, but its capability of cohesion still remains open to question. At a crisis like the present the centrifugal seems more than a counterpoise to the centripetal force, if we are to take the Southerners at their word. The proud traditions of the great Western Republic, the ties of laws, language, religion and national character, the dictates of a higher and more comprehensive self-respect, and the respect of European Powers, are to be cast to the winds when they conflict with local prejudices and the salaries of a class of gentlemen who took their appointments subject to this uncertainty. The enemies of Democracy have always asserted that it cannot rise to the conception of a great national idea, and that for want of this vivifying principle it carries in itself the germ of its own decay. The opponents of cotton have even denied the assumed liberality of the commercial spirit, and retorted that, if circumstances were changed, merchants and manufacturers would not show less blindness or selfishness than farmers and landlords. It has been reserved for the "fire-eating" slave owners of South Carolina and Georgia to verify this taunt, and to seek for precedents of party warfare, not in the history of the United States, but in the continental system of NAPOLEON, in the Berlin Decree, and the English Orders in Council.

abstract: The attempt to bring to justice in our City criminal courts, offenders possessing either money or political influence, has so often failed, as to have inspired the fear in many minds that crime among us would soon come to extend, until it could assume a position beyond all check or control. By way of encouragement against such despondency, we ....
lead_paragraph: The attempt to bring to justice in our City criminal courts, offenders possessing either money or political influence, has so often failed, as to have inspired the fear in many minds that crime among us would soon come to extend, until it could assume a position beyond all check or control. By way of encouragement against such despondency, we recently called attention to the rigorous enforcement of justice against the Worst class of offenders in community, at the hands of Judge GOULD, in the Oyer and Terminer. The recent reports of the business transacted in that tribunal, lead to the hope that it may be a permanent bulwark against the encroachments of corruption and negligence, which so often prevail at other shrines of criminal justice.

abstract: SUICIDE OF A SOUTHERNER. -- Coroner. JACKMAN was yesterday called upon to investigate the circumstances connected with the death, on Thursday evening last, of one of the guests of the Metropolitan Hotel. The testimony showed that deceased came to this City on the 19th of November last, and registered his name upon the hotel book as "F. GURDEN, Boston." At the expiration of a week he deposited $100 with the book-keeper of the establishment on account of his board, and since that time he had frequently absented himself for a day or two from the house. On Thursday, about 1 o'clock, he summoned one of the servants to his room, and represented that he was very sick. Mr. LELAND was informed of the fact, and he sent for Dr. QUACKENBOSS to visit him. The sufferer expressed an unwillingness to receive medical attention, stating that he had taken chloroform and a large quantity of arsenic for the purpose of ending his life. He also said that he had fully made up his mind to die, and that the reason why life had lost its charms was because a lady to whom he was engaged in marriage had discarded him. He positively refused to give her name, however. Deceased was about 30 years of age, and he had, on several occasions, represented to persons about the hotel that he came to this City from Alabama, but he told the physician that he was from New-Orleans. He died about 9 o'clock in the evening, having positively refused to take anything in the way of an antidote to the poison. Drs. JOHN BEACH and CHRISTOPHER WELTJE made a postmortem examination of the body, finding the internal organs much diseased, and in the stomach a large quantity of arsenic.

abstract: We fear our Southern friends will derive small comfort from the comments of English journals upon the Disunion movement. They seem to have very little sympathy with it or respect for it. The English mind seems not to be in the least degree excited by the brilliant prospect of free trade held out to it by the proposed Southern Confederacy, nor ...
lead_paragraph: We fear our Southern friends will derive small comfort from the comments of English journals upon the Disunion movement. They seem to have very little sympathy with it or respect for it. The English mind seems not to be in the least degree excited by the brilliant prospect of free trade held out to it by the proposed Southern Confederacy, nor alarmed at the threat of withholding Southern cotton. On the contrary, they give our Southern friends fair notice that all their respect for American history and achievement clusters around the Union which they are seeking to destroy, and that they have nothing but detestation and hatred for the Slavery which they are seeking to preserve and increase.

abstract: About 6 o'clock on Thursday night, as the steamer Clifton was on her way to the City, loaded with produce, and when near Rhinebeck, her upper deck was discovered in flames. All efforts to extinguish them proved of no avail, and in a short time, so rapidly did they spread, that the crew had to leave the vessel to her fate. She burned for nearly an hour and a half, and was completely destroyed to the water's edge. She was loaded very heavily and this was her last trip for the season. The fire broke out near the smoke-stack, and it is supposed that the hay on the upper deck caught fire from falling sparks. Everything on board was destroyed except eight live hogs, which were picked up by the crew of the Rhinebeck ferry-boat. All hands escaped without injury.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning are in the highest degree important. Gen. CASS, in despair at the condition of the country, has resigned his position as Secretary of State. Mr. TRESCOTT, the Assistant Secretary, as has already been announced, resigned on Thursday, -- consequently, the State Department is at the present time without any responsible head. A successor to Gen. CASS has not yet been decided upon by the President, but rumor points to Hon. DANIEL S. DICKINSON, of New-York, as likely to be called upon to assume the responsibilities. It is also positively, stated by our correspondent that Secretary THOMPSON will resign, probably on Monday; and it is believed that other members of the Cabinet will follow. It is even very strongly suggested that President BUCHANAN himself may retire, and leave the management of affairs between now and the 4th of March in the hands of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE. The House Special Committee had another meeting yesterday, but it does not appear that anything of special importance was effected. Mr. CORWIN, the Chairman, submitted a proposition giving the people of a Territory the exclusive right to elect their officers and to make their own laws, subject, of course, to the Constitution of the United States. This, however, was opposed by several of the Republican members, as carrying Slavery into all the Territories under the decision in the Dred Scott case, and, without voting on the proposition, the Committee adjourned until Monday. It is believed that a report will be made early in the coming week, probably on Tuesday. Meantime it is asserted, on what is considered reliable authority, that Senator DOUGLAS intends, on Tuesday, to deliver his expected speech, in which he will take strong ground in favor of coercing seceding States. Mr. WADE, of Ohio, it is known, will take that ground in the speech which he is to deliver on Monday. The effect to be produced by these speeches is a matter of grave speculation. The Secessionists, of course, contend that they will precipitate an immediate collision in South Carolina, and strengthen the disunion feeling throughout the South; but this view of the case is susceptible of some doubt. Advices received in Washington from the Cotton States are somewhat contradictory. Louisiana is represented to be ripe for secession; while in Alabama, which has been strongly counted on to follow South Carolina immediately, the conservatives think they will be able to carry the State. MILES, of South Carolina left for home last night, and the rest of the delegation from that State, it is understood, are to withdraw formally in a body.

abstract: The examination of the officers and crew of the slave-bark Cora, recently arrived at this port, was commenced yesterday, before United States Commissioner MORELL. Loretto Ruez, alias Latham, the reputed Captain of the Cora, together with her first and second officers, John Wilson and Hans Olsen, and eight of the crew of the slaver Bonita, who arrived here on Wednesday, were brought before the Commissioner, handcuffed, and drew after them a large crowd of people, who were anxious to get a sight of the slave-catchers. The Commissioner decided to first proceed with the examination of Wilson and Olsen. District-Attorney Roosevelt, assisted by J.B. Henry, Esq., appeared for the prosecution, and Chas. J. Donohue and W.R. Beebe, Esqs., for the prisoners.

abstract: -- Rev. J.R.S. Clark, of Lynchburgh, Virginia, apparently belongs to the church militant. At a recent meeting of the Virginia Conference of the M.E. Church great objection was made to Mr. Clark's receiving any appointment, as he had become Chaplain of the K.G.C.'s, and had been seen walking around Lynchburgh with his beard fully grown and a pair of revolvers in his pocket. The Bishop who presided was inclined to regard Mr. Clark's conduct leniently, and gave him his appointment.

abstract: The Cabinet has sustained another rupture. Gen. CASS has resigned his post as Secretary of State -- one of the reasons assigned therefor being the peremptory refusal, of the President to send to Fort Moultrie reinforcements, which the officer in command has declared to be necessary to its defence. Gen. CASS is reported to be of opinion that a compliance with this demand was a matter of duty -- that the honor and good faith of the Government are implicated in the refusal, and that he cannot consent to share the responsibility of such a proceeding. We have on high authority other and less creditable reasons for his withdrawal, -- but we are unwilling to believe that they have governed his action.

abstract: After a personal experience of (40) forty years, the same settled conviction remains, that if the BLOOD IS PURE THE HEALTH WILL BE GOOD. Pure gold cannot make base currency. Neither can pure blood make bad bone, bad heart, bad liver, bad lungs, bad teeth, bad flesh, or bad skin; all is beautiful, because perfected by healthy blood.

abstract: The only business transacted in this Court yesterday before Recorder BARNARD was the trial of two causes. The first was that of John C. Baillie, a police officer, indicted for assault and battery upon Mary George. It appeared by the evidence adduced that Mathew Powers, the brother of the complainant, had a difficulty in the house, when Mrs. Myers called in the prisoner, police officer. Mr. Baillie entered the house, followed by Powers, whom he proceeded to arrest, when the complainant interfered, hanging on her brother, and telling the officer he should not make the arrest without a warrant. Her resistance was so forcible as to require the aid of another officer. During the scuffle the complainant was struck over the head and on the arms with a club, and was several times knocked down.

abstract: About 7 o'clock yesterday morning a sloop was observed lying capsized in the Hudson River, near Irvington, about forty rods from the shore. She lay with her mast pointing down the river, a part of her stern being the only part out of water. Seated upon the stern were three men, huddled together and apparently frozen to death, as no movement was discernible. Clinging to the mast was another man, over whom the waves had washed all night. The weather was bitter cold, the thermometer ranging about eight degrees above zero. In many places on the mast the ice was two or three inches thick.

abstract: The Panama Railroad Company's mail steamship Guatemala, from Central American ports, arrived here this morning. She brings dates from Guatemala to Nov. 24, from Salvador to the 26th, Nicaragua to the 30th, and from Costa Rica to the 2d December. The news is unimportant. The Guatemala brings 1,464 ceroons indigo, 3,500 hides, $41,000 in specie, and 24 passengers.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA, Wednesday, Dec. 5, 1860.

abstract: This  action is brought for a limited divorce from bed and board. The parties are highly connected in the City, and possessed of some means. abstract: After a month's parturition the long-looked for and long promised change in the organic law of the Empire has been realized. The "crowning of the edifice," that vague maximum of political perfection so often promised by the Emperor in his moments of magnanimity, has arrived at "the commencement of the end." From the condition of the one-man power we have suddenly passed into, that of the semi-parliamentary.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Tuesday, Nov. 27, 1860.

abstract: A witty conversationist once, remarked of an English earthquake, that it was so "tame you might have stroked it." Without suggesting an unkind thought, may we not say the same of the last Academy season? And here let us be understood. We do not mean the last Ullman season, for that has been dead and buried and forgotten so long that a dim traditional glory begins to surround it. No, not that, but the bona fide last "season" which some of us talked about only a few hours ago, and which was really in existence up to Saturday at 3 1/2 o'clock. For, know all men by these presents, that the Temple of Song is once more tenantless. That rickety infant, called the "Artists' Combination," born of adversity and prematurely exposed to the bleak December winds, came to an untimely end on the day and hour mentioned above. A few -- very few -- persons were present at the dissolution. The event, however grievous to art, was witnessed with fortitude by the public. Is it not a comfort to know this?

abstract: There can be no doubt that the President has accomplished the object he had in view, in proposing the extraordinary terms of compromise which are contained in his annual message.
lead_paragraph: There can be no doubt that the President has accomplished the object he had in view, in proposing the extraordinary terms of compromise which are contained in his annual message. It is incredible that he could believe it possible to effect a change in the Constitution, by which Slavery is to be made the fundamental law for all the territories of the Union; and in urging such a proposition upon the attention of Congress and the country, he could only have been actuated by the desire to stimulate the Southern Ultraists to demand what he knew would never be conceded, and thus to increase the difficulty of harmonizing the country. He was aware that the Democratic Party of the nation, in convention at Charleston, in April last, though thoroughly Pro-Slavery, and ready to buy Cuba, or conquer Mexico, in order to extend the system, could not venture to incorporate this proposition of a Slave code for the territories in their platform of principles; and that the Northern delegation, rather than sanction a measure which they knew would overwhelm them with defeat at home, held out against it to the last, though the delegates from seven or eight Southern States seceded in a body. He was aware that this very issue caused the permanent dissolution of the party; that the two factions into which it was divided went into the Presidential canvass under different banners, and with opposing candidates; that a third candidate was before the people, who represented the Southern opposition; that Mr. LINCOLN beat them all by an overwhelming majority; and that Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, who alone was in favor of a Slave code for the Territories, was literally distanced in the race in the Free States by the least formidable of his competitors. So far as ascertained, we believe that his vote in these States was less than that cast for Mr. LINCOLN in the Slave States. All told, there was not one vote in fifty polled for the Slave code candidates in the Free States.

abstract: MORTALITY. -- There were 115 deaths in this city last week, classified as follows: Men, 12; women, 20; boys, 45; girls, 38; adults, 32; children, 83; males, 57; females, 58; colored persons, 2. There were 20 deaths by fevers, 17 of which were scarlet; 17 by consumption; 9 each by marasmus and inflammation of the lungs. Seventy of those who died were under 5 years of age. The deaths occured in the several Wards, as follows: First, 2; Second, 13; Third, 5; Fourth, 2; Fifth, 5; Sixth, 11; Seventh, 7; Eighth, 5; Ninth, 8; Tenth, 5; Eleventh, 16; Twelfth, 7; Thirteenth, 5; Fourteenth, 8; Fifteenth, 1; Sixteenth, 10; Seventeenth, 5; Eighteenth and Nineteenth, none. Ninety-nine of those who died were natives of the United States.

abstract: The Mayors of New-Orleans and Mobile have found it necessary to vindicate their positions, by issuing proclamations against Vigilance Committees, and other volunteers, who were disposed to assume the administration of the laws. For several weeks past, it has been more than ordinarily hazardous for Northern people to breathe the air of the South.
lead_paragraph: The Mayors of New-Orleans and Mobile have found it necessary to vindicate their positions, by issuing proclamations against Vigilance Committees, and other volunteers, who were disposed to assume the administration of the laws. For several weeks past, it has been more than ordinarily hazardous for Northern people to breathe the air of the South. In the provinces the danger is so well appreciated, that the stranger consults his safety by entire silence as to his local habitation. In the cities, where the presence of multitudes is usually secure shelter against suspicion and molestation, caution has not been deemed so absolutely necessary; and residents known to be of Northern origin have generally continued their avocations as in quieter times.

abstract: In this Court, on Saturday, Judge BALCOM passed sentence upon Constantine Mangenet, a Frenchman, indicted for grand larceny, in having stolen some $700 or $800 worth of plate and money. The prisoner had fled to Missouri, and was now brought in on a requisition. He pleaded guilty and put in a written confession, asking that he might be dealt with in mercy, and sent to some place where his time could be occupied with work. He was a carpenter, twenty-seven years of age, and was reported by the officer as a quiet and peaceable person. He was then sentenced to State Prisons for three years and six months, the Court expressing the hope that a short confinement might be effectual in producing a reform.

abstract: SKATING AT THE CENTRAL PARK. -- The Winter sports of the Central Park, which, for some years to come, are likely to be more popular than any that Summer affords in that locality, were thoroughly initiated on Saturday. The freezing weather of the last few days has given a wonderful impetus to the trade in skates, the prices gradually going up as the mercury went down, and on Saturday morning it reached its climax -- the red ball was "up" and the skating ball opened. From early morning till dusk the pond in the Central Park was alive with steel shoes, and nimble-footed lads and lasses, representing all grades of proficiency and verdancy in the skating art. It is estimated that upwards of 3,000 persons visited the Park on Saturday, and the number will, no doubt, increase daily as long as the skating weather continues. The Scotch game of "curling," which was so popular last winter, bids fair to be still more so this. The lower pond is reserved for this game, and a large number were engaged in practicing on Saturday. Refreshment saloons are soon to be opened in the Park, where hot coffee and other luxuries, not intoxicating, will be provided. It is also in contemplation to engage a band of music for the benefit of those who are proficient enough to dance on skates.

abstract: -- The Republican Party are indebted to an astute English journalist for the most rational explanation which has yet been given of their overwhelming, success in the recent national elections. The London Chronicle, which, we beg our readers to understand, is not at all a comic paper, but on the contrary the most serious and solemn of unreadable organs, gravely advances the theory that Mr. LINCOLN's triumph is the natural consequence of the Prince of Wales' visit to the United States.

abstract: The world must be fed and clothed, come what may of our political troubles. The material means of this country, in the present emergency of an agitated government at home, and deficient grain crops, but great manufacturing activity, abroad, were seldom so abundant -- never so in grain, and only once before in cotton. Let us, therefore, for the moment attempt, at least, to find some compensating good against the anxious political ills that beset this agitated land, in its superabundant supplies of food and raiment.
lead_paragraph: The world must be fed and clothed, come what may of our political troubles. The material means of this country, in the present emergency of an agitated government at home, and deficient grain crops, but great manufacturing activity, abroad, were seldom so abundant -- never so in grain, and only once before in cotton. Let us, therefore, for the moment attempt, at least, to find some compensating good against the anxious political ills that beset this agitated land, in its superabundant supplies of food and raiment.

abstract: In this Court, on Saturday, Justices KELLY, WELSH, and STEERS, disposed of seventy-six potty cases. Of twenty-six persons charged with assault and battery, four were discharged on account of no witnesses appearing against them, two were dischargedby request of complainant, four were dismissed under suspended sentence, one was allowed postponement, seven were fined, six were imprisoned, and two were acquitted. Of forty-eight persons charged with larceny, three were discharged, no witnesses appearing against them, seven were discharged under suspended sentence, four were granted an adjournment, five were remanded, twenty-eight were imprisoned, and one was acquitted. One person charged with keeping a disorderly house was remanded, and one charged with illegal voting had sentence suspended, and was discharged.

abstract: --From a report published in another column, it will be seen that WILLIAM MULLIGAN has at length been brought to realize that the way of the transgressor is hard, and that the laws, however tardy in their operation, are terrible in their penalties when provoked beyond a certain point.
lead_paragraph: -- From a report published in another column, it will be seen that WILLIAM MULLIGAN has at length been brought to realize that the way of the transgressor is hard, and that the laws, however tardy in their operation, are terrible in their penalties when provoked beyond a certain point. The stone walls, iron gratings, scanty diet, hard labor, rigorous discipline and perpetual silence of Sing Sing, must press with crushing force on all the faculties and habits of this fierce human animal, who has been accustomed for so many years to live as pleased himself, observing no rule, engaged in no regular occupation, and yet supplied with every enjoyment of the grosser senses -- perhaps as a tribute paid by the world to his high position and desperate renown amongst "the ruling classes" of our City. His fate should be a warning to the many hundreds of his class who still roam our streets unwhipped of justice. It is the first positive announcement made from the Bench in many years, that political services shall not suffice to screen the guilty from punishment, nor be held to justify the professional ruffian in the use of weapons against the lives of peaceful citizens, or officers in the discharge of their duty.

abstract: The intelligence from the Federal Capital which we publish this morning, will be read with a great deal of interest. Our dispatches indicate that the parting of the late Secretary of State with the President, was not quite so cordial as we were at first led to believe; -- that, in fact, there was a serious misunderstanding, which is to find ventilation" through the medium of a somewhat pungent correspondence, of which the first capter, emanating from Gen. CASS, has already been written. The difficulty, it is now definitely determined, grew put of the refusal of the President to reinforce the scanty garrison of Fort Moultrie, in the harbor of Charleston in accordance with the requisition of Maj. ANDERSON, the officer in command. That this reinforcement is needed, no one can doubt who reads the advices direct from the Fort, which we publish elsewhere. A successor of Gen. CASS has been found in the person of Attorney-General BLACK, who entered upon his new duties on Saturday. It is rumored that EDWIN STANTON, of Washington, will succeed to the Attorney-Generalship. With regard to the action of the House Special Committee, past and prospective, advices are somewhat contradictory. It is asserted, on the one hand, that REUBEN DAVIS of Mississippi, intends to-day to introduce a resolution of the ultra-Southern stamp, upon which he will insist on a test vote, and against which the Republican members of the Committee will vote in a body; whereupon the Southern members will all withdraw, and the Committee will be broken up without effecting anything. On the other hand, we are assured that there is a probability that some arrangement will he determined upon which will be satisfactory to everybody. Under these circumstances, it is probably best to await the developments of time. Meanwhile caucuses appear to be the order of the day. The delegation from this State, without; regard to politics, met last night at the room of JOHN COCHRANE, to deliberate upon the course proper to pursue in the future. Nearly all were present. Mr. REYNOLDS, elected as an Anti-Lecompton Democrat, offered a resolution affirming that the Union "must and shall be preserved," and pledging New-York to its support, which was adopted almost unanimously. The Pennsylvania and the Ohio delegations will hold caucuses to-day. Indications of a strong Union movement also, among the Southern members of Congress, are not wanting.

CASS, has already been written. The difficulty, it is now definitely determined, grew put of the refusal of the President to reinforce the scanty garrison of Fort Moultrie, in the harbor of Charleston in accordance with the requisition of Maj. ANDERSON, the officer in command. That this reinforcement is needed, no one can doubt who reads the advices direct from the Fort, which we publish elsewhere. A successor of Gen. CASS has been found in the person of Attorney-General BLACK, who entered upon his new duties on Saturday. It is rumored that EDWIN STANTON, of Washington, will succeed to the Attorney-Generalship. With regard to the action of the House Special Committee, past and prospective, advices are somewhat contradictory. It is asserted, on the one hand, that REUBEN DAVIS of Mississippi, intends to-day to introduce a resolution of the ultra-Southern stamp, upon which he will insist on a test vote, and against which the Republican members of the Committee will vote in a body; whereupon the Southern members will all withdraw, and the Committee will be broken up without effecting anything. On the other hand, we are assured that there is a probability that some arrangement will he determined upon which will be satisfactory to everybody. Under these circumstances, it is probably best to await the developments of time. Meanwhile caucuses appear to be the order of the day. The delegation from this State, without; regard to politics, met last night at the room of JOHN COCHRANE, to deliberate upon the course proper to pursue in the future. Nearly all were present. Mr. REYNOLDS, elected as an Anti-Lecompton Democrat, offered a resolution affirming that the Union "must and shall be preserved," and pledging New-York to its support, which was adopted almost unanimously. The Pennsylvania and the Ohio delegations will hold caucuses to-day. Indications of a strong Union movement also, among the Southern members of Congress, are not wanting.

abstract: We publish elsewhere a report of the proceedings of a meeting held in this City on Saturday, on the subject of Disunion. The meeting was strictly private, no person being admitted who had not received a special card of invitation. We give a list of those who were thus invited; it will readily be seen that they were in the main highly respectable, and that their proceedings are entitled to all the weight which their personal characters and positions in the community may secure for them.

abstract: Letters received at Salem, Massachusetts, announce that another slaver, with 846 negroes on board, has been captured near Mozambique, by the British steamer Brisk. The delinquent vessel is named the Sunny South, and was, of course, cleared from this City, some months ago, for Havana, where the usual pretended sale to a Spaniard was completed. Verily, however, there would seem some evil destiny hanging over the gentlemen engaged in this branch of importing, so many of their business ventures have, of late, been brought to an ill result; and in view of the continuous tide of negro labor which these developments prove to be constantly flowing towards the American continent from Africa, it may well be asked: Can Cuba possibly need so many field-hands for her own consumption? or are these captured Africans only used to replace the Spanish-speaking Cuban slaves smuggled over to Florida and Louisiana, where they will fetch nearly double the price paid for them in slave-importing Cuba?

abstract: The Trustees of Plymouth Church in Brooklyn, received notice from certain quarters that a mob of roughs from this City intended to interrupt the Sabbath evening service, and possibly demolish the building. The same reports has been industriously circulated throughout the cities of New-York and Brooklyn, and great excitement was caused thereby.
lead_paragraph: The Trustees of Plymouth Church in Brooklyn, received notice from certain quarters that a mob of roughs from this City intended to interrupt the Sabbath evening service, and possibly demolish the building. The same reports has been industriously circulated throughout the cities of New-York and Brooklyn, and great excitement was caused thereby. The universal sentiment seemed to be that the person of Mr. BEECHER and the property of the Society should at all hazards be defended, and that though opinion were divided as to the propriety and effects of Mr. BEECHER's teaching, there was but one feeling concerning the absolute right of free speech in the pulpit or on the rostrum.

abstract: On Saturday night a deliberate attempt was made to murder John Hughes, a laboring man, living at a tenement house in East Thirty-eighth-street, by one of his neighbors, a German, named John Ruyter. It appeared from what transpired yesterday betore Judge QUACKENBUSH at the Jefferson Market Police Court, that some time since, Ruyter, who is a carpenter, was engaged by Hughes to do some repairing at his house.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night a deliberate attempt was made to murder John Hughes, a laboring man, living at a tenement house in East Thirty-eighth-street, by one of his neighbors, a German, named John Ruyter. It appeared from what transpired yesterday betore Judge QUACKENBUSH at the Jefferson Market Police Court, that some time since, Ruyter, who is a carpenter, was engaged by Hughes to do some repairing at his house. The bill for doing this work amounted to $3, but Hughes said it was exorbitant and declined to pay it. This fact caused ill-feeling between the men and their respective families, and on Saturday evening Mrs. Ruyter and Mrs. Hughes fought together, the latter while the fray went on receiving assistance from her husband. At a later hour Ruyter heard of what had taken place, and to avenge his wife's black eye, he called at Hughes' house and commenced an attack upon him. Hughes defended himself with a small hammer, and having used the instrument several times upon the German's head, the latter was glad enough to escape the blows by running away. He, however, soon returned, bringing with him a gun, and having dared Hughes to come out of the house, the latter, after a time, presented himself. Ruyter at once fired, the ball taking effect in Hughes' thigh, inflicting a wound of a very serious character. The injured man was conveyed to the Twenty-first Ward Station-house, where Ex-Coroner CONNERY administered to his relief. Officer McBride had meanwhile taken Ruyter into custody, and Justice QUACKENBUSH yesterday sent him to prison.

abstract: Allerton,  c. vs. Delevan, City Inspector, et al. --This case was now argued, counsel contending in support of the motion, that previous to 1849 butchers licenses were issued by the Mayor to those butchers recommended by the Common Council. That consequently when a butcher purchased a stall it was necessary for him to apply to the Common Council for such recommendation.
lead_paragraph: Allerton, c. vs. Delevan, City Inspector, et al. --This case was now argued, counsel contending in support of the motion, that previous to 1849 butchers licenses were issued by the Mayor to those butchers recommended by the Common Council. That consequently when a butcher purchased a stall it was necessary for him to apply to the Common Council for such recommendation. That it was given by resolution sometimes that the stall be transferred to the applicant, sometimes that he be recommended to the Mayor for license -- but that the Common Council never claimed any right to refuse a proper applicant, or to prevent a transfer.

abstract: All other questions connected with secession become unimportant, in view of the position of Fort Moultrie, at Charleston. Sixtyfive men, under a gallant and loyal officer, constitute its only garrison, and are instructed to hold it against assault.
lead_paragraph: All other questions connected with secession become unimportant, in view of the position of Fort Moultrie, at Charleston. Sixtyfive men, under a gallant and loyal officer, constitute its only garrison, and are instructed to hold it against assault. South Carolina has for months threatened secession, in the event of LINCOLN's election, and the seizure of that fort is an indispensable incident of secession. Six weeks before the election a force of three hundred men was collected, for the purpose of being sent to reinforce that garrison; but just as they were ready to start, Secretary FLOYD, -- for reasons which he may possibly explain, -- countermanded the order, and they were sent to California. From that day to this nothing has been done to strengthen the garrison. A month ago Gen. SCOTT addressed directly to the President, an elaborate paper representing the absolute necessity of sending reinforcements to all the Southern forts, and designating the number needed for each, and the posts from which they could be obtained. No notice whatever has been taken of this urgent-recommendation. Col. ANDERSON, the officer in command, has asked for reinforcements, and his request has been refused.

abstract: A Joint Committee of the South Carolina Legislature has been discussing the best mode of supplying Postal facilities for the State after its secession. They object to employing ADAMS' Express, as inadequate to the purpose, -- and recommend the continuance of the present system. The Postmasters will of course resign, in order to be released from their oath to support the Federal Constitution; but they will immediately resume their functions and go on as if nothing had happened. The Committee state that they "have reason to believe the Federal Government will not be adverse to this plan."
lead_paragraph: A Joint Committee of the South Carolina Legislature has been discussing the best mode of supplying Postal facilities for the State after its secession. abstract: The South Carolina State Convention, called to consider the question of seceding from the Federal Union, assembled at Columbia yesterday. Four ballots were had for a permanent President, which resulted in the choice of Gen. D.F. JAMISON, who made a brief address on taking the chair. A resolution was then immediately offered, that when the Convention adjourned it should be to meet in Charleston this afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The South Carolina State Convention, called to consider the question of seceding from the Federal Union, assembled at Columbia yesterday. Four ballots were had for a permanent President, which resulted in the choice of Gen. D.F. JAMISON, who made a brief address on taking the chair. A resolution was then immediately offered, that when the Convention adjourned it should be to meet in Charleston this afternoon. This resolution, which was induced by the prevalence of small-pox in Columbia, caused considerable debate, the impression with some being that outsiders would regard such a proceeding as an evidence of timidity. Mr. MILES, especially, appealed to the Convention not to go to Charleston, but to remain in Columbia, regardless of the epidemic. This heroic counsel, however, was disregarded, and the Convention voted to go to Charleston by a large majority. Nothing else of importance was done. Mr. PICKENS, the new Governor of the State, was inaugurated yesterday by the Legislature, with the usual ceremonies. His address is represented to have been strong for secession. The late Secretary of the Treasury, Hon. HOWELL COBB, was present on the occasion, as were also Messrs. ELMORE and HASKEN, the Commissioners from Alabama and Mississippi.

abstract: Sarah M. Sandford vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This is a demurer to a complaint, on the ground that it does not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action. The plaintiff claims to have paid the sum of $2,782 30 for assessments on property in Seventy-ninth-street, in this City, lying between Fifth-avenue and the East River. The plaintiff claims that the assessment is irregular and void, and seeks to set it aside, and have the money refunded. The Court decided that if the assessment was void, it ought to appear in the complaint how and in what manner; that the plaintiff could not sustain the suit in an action at law after having voluntarily paid the money.
lead_paragraph: Sarah M. Sandford vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This is a demurer to a complaint, on the ground that it does not state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action. abstract: By reference to the proceedings had yesterday in reference to the Captain and mates of the slaver Cora, it will be seen that at least three high officers of the Custom-house at this port are either afflicted with shortness of memory to a degree incapacitating them for the due discharge of their duties; or that they discharge their duties with a haste, looseness and recklessness greatly tending to reconcile the public to the probable loss of their services after the 4th day of next March. Deputy-Collector MICHAEL HOFFMAN swore that he preserved no recollection whatever of the person who made oath before him to the outward manifest of the Cora, on the occasion of her clearing from New-York upon her African voyage. He administered the oath and attested the same by his signature; but when asked could he identify the person who made the oath, Deputy-Collector HOFFMAN responded that "his mind was wholly blank on the subject." This utter oblivion is the more remarkable as the witness had a sharply defined recollection of several minor circumstances connected with the taking of the oath -- such as that Capt. LATHAM's signature had been written before the document was handed to him for attestation upon the 19th day of last May.
lead_paragraph: By reference to the proceedings had yesterday in reference to the Captain and mates of the slaver Cora, it will be seen that at least three high officers of the Custom-house at this port are either afflicted with shortness of memory to a degree incapacitating them for the due discharge of their duties; or that they discharge their duties with a haste, looseness and recklessness greatly tending to reconcile the public to the probable loss of their services after the 4th day of next March. abstract: JOHN WILSON and HANS OLSEN, who stand charged with voluntarily serving on board of the slave bark Cora, underwent a further examination yesterday before United States Commissioner MORRELL. The "Spanish" Captain of the Cora, who is believed to be JOHN LATHAM, to whom the vessel was sold, and who cleared her from the Custom-house, was also present.
lead_paragraph: JOHN WILSON and HANS OLSEN, who stand charged with voluntarily serving on board of the slave bark Cora, underwent a further examination yesterday before United States Commissioner MORRELL. The "Spanish" Captain of the Cora, who is believed to be JOHN LATHAM, to whom the vessel was sold, and who cleared her from the Custom-house, was also present. Commander EASTMAN, who brought the Cora from the coast, was examined as to whether Capt. LATHAM was not the recognized captain of the the Cora, and admitted himself to be such. Witness stated that the individual present known as Capt. LATHAM told him on the African coast, that he was the Spanish Captain of the Cora, the mates of the vessel called him the Spanish Captain, and he spoke in Spanish. Afterwards, when witness boarded the Cora, he spoke English, but it was difficult to tell by his accent and pronunciation whether he was Spanish or not. OLSEN told him he had been employed to to clean the lower deck for the negroes when they were coming on board. On the outward voyage LATHAM ordered him to cut holes in the spar deck, aft, twelve by six inches, to ventilate the hold; the mates spoke of LATHAM as the Captain who had to take the vessel out. They called him LATHAM. The mates told witness the last they saw of the American Captain was at Maugue Grande.

abstract: Mr. CLARK's (of New-Hampshire, Rep.,) resolution of inquiry, requesting the President to inform the Senate what number of men were stationed at Forts Moultrie and Sumter; whether, in his opinion, the number was sufficient to defend those forts against any attack or domestic violence; whether additional men had been ordered to either of said forts, or any steps taken to put them in position to resist any attack; in whose custody the Arsenal at Charleston is placed; what arms and property are there kept, or if removed, by whom; and why said arms are not put in possession of officers of the United States upon a requisition, or if this has ever been refused; and further, what instructions have been given to the officers of said forts in case of a demand to surrender them by any person or authority made upon them; also the copies of any correspondence between the Commander-in-Chief of the American Army relative to the necessity of supplying the officers of said forts with protection, was taken up.

abstract: Supreme Court vs. The Superior Court. -- The Special Term of this Court and the Superior Court, MONCRIEF, J., yesterday came into collision, each, seeking possession of the same room. The room assigned by the Common Council for the use of the Superior Court, has been assigned by the Supervisors to the use of the Supreme Court. Justice LEONARD refuses to surrender, holding that the Supervisor can give the best title. Both Courts adjourned pending the contest.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. To a cold bachelor afflicted with midnight twitches of the crisis, and doomed to awaken to spasms of financial apprehension, there is something hardened and alarming, if not positively impertinent, in the title of Mr. WALLACK'S latest production, "To Marry or Not to Marry?" Without
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- To a cold bachelor afflicted with midnight twitches of the crisis, and doomed to awaken to spasms of financial apprehension, there is something hardened and alarming, if not positively impertinent, in the title of Mr. WALLACK's latest production, "To Marry or Not to Marry?" Without stopping to inquire by what right a manager dares thus propound to a rising and expectant community to monstrous a question, we will at once admit that, under ordinary circumstances, that same community would reply to it with what the French call effusion. But in times like these it is really not right to have a topic which so many ingenious youths are trying to dodge, blurted out in so abrupt a manner. Imagine the feelings of Adolphus as he leads forth the blushing Celestine to partake of a frugal, but emotional, ice-cream, when he perceives with horror that her lovely eyes are furtively, but suggestively, glancing at the monstrous placard containing Mr. WALLACK's indiscreet query. What agony must that gallant fellow endure in the interval which yawns like a century between that horrid "poster" and an easy change of the subject of conversation?

abstract: THE $800 ROBBERY. ALEXANDER SCHULTZ, the young man arrested last week on suspicion of having robbed an emigrant named JOHN GEISLER of $800, on the New-York and Erie ferry-boat, was discharged yesterday morning, upon giving bonds in $800 for his appearance at the January term of Court.
lead_paragraph: THE $800 ROBBERY.-- ALEXANDER SCHULTZ, the young man arrested last week on suspicion of having robbed an emigrant named JOHN GEISLER of $800, on the New-York and Erie ferry-boat, was discharged yesterday morning, upon giving bonds in $800 for his appearance at the January term of Court. Detective LAWSON, of New-York, came over in the forenoon to cause the arrest of SCHULTZ, on suspicion of having forged a mortgage for $3,500, upon which parties in Newark were swindled out of $2,800 worth of goods. A telegraph dispatch was sent to one of these gentlemen to identify the prisoner, but before his arrival SCHULTZ was bailed out. In passing down Montgomery-street, in company with a woman, SCHULTZ saw two officers ahead, when he turned and fled.

abstract: The People ex rel, John Green vs. Fernando Wood, Mayor,  This motion came on to be heard on the return of an order to show cause why the Mayor should not be compelled to countersign a warrant directed to the Chamberlain of this City directing him to pay the relator the sum of $1,000.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel, John Green vs. Fernando Wood, Mayor, &c. -- This motion came on to be heard on the return of an order to show cause why the Mayor should not be compelled to countersign a warrant directed to the Chamberlain of this City directing him to pay the relator the sum of $1,000. It appears from the affidavit of the relator that this sum is claimed by reason of his being the contractor to collect and remove the offal of the City. It appears also that this bill for such work has been presented to the City Inspector, and has been certified by him as well as all the other City officers who are required by law to sign such warrants. The defence is that Green has failed to perform his contract in accordance with its terms; that the offal in the district over which his contract extends has been left exposed in the streets so as to become a public nuisance to people residing in the vicinity; and on this ground the Mayor withholds his signature.

abstract: Finance are greatly depressed. KIRKLAND, CHASE  Co., the largest shipping-house in Baltimore, suspended payment to-day, caused by the decline in coffee, sugar and molasses, an immense amount of which they held. Their liabilities are supposed to be nearly a million of dollars, and the assets nearly equal. It is hoped they may be able to resume.

abstract: The Supervisors Committee of Inquiry in relation to the county deposits, held another meeting yesterday afternoon, when it was expected the Mayor would be present. After the Committee had been in session some time, Mr. J.B. AULD, the Mayor's Chief Clerk, appeared and stated that the Mayor was engaged presiding at meeting of the Commissioners of Health.
lead_paragraph: The Supervisors Committee of Inquiry in relation to the county deposits, held another meeting yesterday afternoon, when it was expected the Mayor would be present. After the Committee had been in session some time, Mr. J.B. AULD, the Mayor's Chief Clerk, appeared and stated that the Mayor was engaged presiding at meeting of the Commissioners of Health. Mr. PURDY advised that the Committee wait a while for the Mayor, and it was finally agreed to wait half-an-hour. When that time had elapsed, and the Mayor had not made his appearance, a motion was made to adjourn over for a day, and then to send another messenger. Another messenger was sent, and he met still another messenger from the Mayor, with the information that he (the Mayor) would be with the Committee very soon. The Committee waited, and finally the Mayor appeared, with an apology for having kept the Committee waiting.

abstract: "From early dawn to set of sun," and many hours after the departure of that luminary from this particular portion of the continent, the "tide" of pleasure "takes its way" to the Central Park. The rush of people thitherward commenced last week, and has diurnally increased in a compound ratio. Of course the Park itself is hardly the attraction, but the vast pond of ice, the skating and the skaters. And we are glad to say that these form an attraction that we have never seen excelled, with the additional advantages of giving that exuberance of spirits, and ruddiness of cheeks, which characterize moral, mental, and physical health, to all who, whether as agents or spectators, participate therein.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- In accordance with the custom which prevails among tragedians, Mr. BOOTH appeared last night as Othello, thus exchanging parts with Mr. DYOTT, who, it will be remembered, played the character on Saturday night to Mr. BOOTH's Iago. To an audience watchful of the snares by which an intellectual nature gains its inevitable ascendancy over a merely passional one, the character of the lieutenant is always preferable to that of the Moor, but the latter in its turn has all the advantages of a love vehement, absorbing, destructive in its kind.

abstract: In this Court yesterday the ordinary number of petty cases were disposed of in the following manner: Of nine persons charged with assault and battery, one was discharged, no witness appearing against him, three were remanded, four were imprisoned, and one was, acquitted. Of thirty-five persons charged with petty largely, two were discharged by request of com,
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday the ordinary number of petty cases were disposed of in the following manner: Of nine persons charged with assault and battery, one was discharged, no witness appearing against him, three were remanded, four were imprisoned, and one was, acquitted. Of thirty-five persons charged with petty largely, two were discharged by request of complainant, two had sentence suspended, eleven were remanded, one was fined, eighteen were imprisoned, and one was acquitted. One prisoner charged with embezzlement, was discharged by request of complainant; one person charged with malicious mischief, was remanded.

abstract: As the James Adger, Capt. PHILLIPS, from Charleston, was nearing her pier at about 2 o'clock this morning, and while making fast her lines was [???] into by the propeller R.R. Cuyler, Capt. CROCKER, from Savannah. At the time of the collision the Adger was about twenty feet distant from her pier. Her second Officer stood on her upper deck and made signals for the propeller to stop, but the men on board the propeller took no notice of the lights, and as a consequence the bow of the Cuyler was driven with terrible force into the stern of the Adger. The Adger had her stern stove in, and sustained much damage in her cabins. The propeller proceeded to her berth several piers above.

abstract: We have shown the value, per head, of the products of the industry of Massachusetts entering into consumption, to exceed four-fold that of the same number in South. Carolina. A mere description of the agencies employed in the two States will compel to such a conclusion, without the support of a voucher or a figure. Within the compass of one hundred acres in the City of Lowell are agencies at work which, assisted by 15,000 laborers, more than one-half females, produce for general consumption fabrics exceeding in value more than one-half the whole exports of South Carolina. Two Lowells, consequently, are of greater moment than this State, in commercial affairs. Philadelphia is a dozen South Carolinas rolled into one.

abstract: Senator WADE's speech, on Monday, was a timely and an admirable statement of the disunion issue. It suits the purposes of a portion of the Press to style it a war manifesto, and to speak of it as marked by vehemence of manner, and by hostility to the South in its tone. Nothing could be more unjust, as those who read it in the TIMES of yesterday have seen. It was a plain, temperate and truthful statement of the position of the North, and of the foolish madness and absurdity of the disunion movement. It was in admirable contrast, in every respect, with the vulgar, insolent and disgraceful speeches of IVERSON and others, who have professed to speak for the disunion States in this controversy.
lead_paragraph: Senator WADE's speech, on Monday, was a timely and an admirable statement of the disunion issue. abstract: -THE TRUE POLICY OF THE REPUBLICANS. -- The hasty declaration of the Secessionists in Congress to their constituents, that 'argument is exhausted," and that "the honor, safety and independence of the Southern people require the organization of a Southern Confederacy," will not be regarded as the honest convictions of those whose names are signed to it so long as they retain their seats in Congress. If they had followed up this apparently desperate and determined resolve by the resignation of their offices and the renunciation of their oaths of allegiance, we could not withhold from them the tribute of respect which is always due to an honorable and self-sacrificing course of conduct, however mistaken it may be in its objects. But so long as these men continue to sit in council with those whom they declare to be the implacable foes of their country, and draw their salaries from the National Treasury, they must excuse us if we indulge the suspicion that they are only playing at the political game of "brag." Nothing could be better calculated to frighten timid Northern politicians into disgraceful concessions of principle than this apparently firm and uncompromising manifesto; and it is impossible not to believe that this effect was contemplated and intended by those who have set it forth.
lead_paragraph: -THE TRUE POLICY OF THE REPUBLICANS. -- The hasty declaration of the Secessionists in Congress to their constituents, that 'argument is exhausted," and that "the honor, safety and independence of the Southern people require the organization of a Southern Confederacy," will not be regarded as the honest convictions of those whose names are signed to it so long as they retain their seats in Congress. If they had followed up this apparently desperate and determined resolve by the resignation of their offices and the renunciation of their oaths of allegiance, we could not withhold from them the tribute of respect which is always due to an honorable and self-sacrificing course of conduct, however mistaken it may be in its objects. But so long as these men continue to sit in council with those whom they declare to be the implacable foes of their country, and draw their salaries from the National Treasury, they must excuse us if we indulge the suspicion that they are only playing at the political game of "brag." Nothing could be better calculated to frighten timid Northern politicians into disgraceful concessions of principle than this apparently firm and uncompromising manifesto; and it is impossible not to believe that this effect was contemplated and intended by those who have set it forth.

abstract: -- The shameful insufficiency of accommodation for our Courts of law, has at length produced a collision between the Supreme and Superior Courts, not creditable, we may say, to either, nor tending to elevate their dignity in the eyes of the people. The Superior Court, part second, finding itself without any room or hall in which to hold Trial Term, procured the passage through the Common Council of a resolution granting to it for use the General Term room of the Supreme Court, in which Judge LEONARD, of the latter Court, is at present presiding. No provision whatever was made by the resolution for the accommodation of the Court thus ejected out of its own room; and as Judge LEONARD, on behalf of the Supreme Court, questioned the right of the Common Council to overrule the action of the Board of Supervisors in the original assignment of this room, the pleasing and dignified spectacle was presented last Monday morning of a scramble between the dignitaries and officers of two of our highest judicial tribunals as to which could first seize the doors of the Court-room and take possession of the Bench.

abstract: -We regret to learn that ALEXANDER MANN, Esq., formerly of this State, died suddenly of apoplexy on the 6th inst., at St. Augustine, Florida, where he had been living for some months. He was a native of Scottsville, Monroe County, in this State, where his parents still reside, and graduated at the University of Vermont in 1838. He studied law and practiced that profession in Rochester until 1843, when he took charge of the American, a daily Whig paper, established by the brothers JEROME now of this City, and edited it with ability and success until it was merged into the Democrat. He afterwards came to this City, and was connected for a short time with the editorial department of the TIMES, -- but failing health compelled him to seek a milder climate, and nearly a year ago he took up his residence in St. Augustine. He leaves a wife and two children, besides a large circle of relatives and friends, to mourn his loss.
lead_paragraph: -We regret to learn that ALEXANDER MANN, Esq., formerly of this State, died suddenly of apoplexy on the 6th inst., at St. Augustine, Florida, where he had been living for some months. He was a native of Scottsville, Monroe County, in this State, where his parents still reside, and graduated at the University of Vermont in 1838. He studied law and practiced that profession in Rochester until 1843, when he took charge of the American, a daily Whig paper, established by the brothers JEROME now of this City, and edited it with ability and success until it was merged into the Democrat. He afterwards came to this City, and was connected for a short time with the editorial department of the TIMES, -- but failing health compelled him to seek a milder climate, and nearly a year ago he took up his residence in St. Augustine. He leaves a wife and two children, besides a large circle of relatives and friends, to mourn his loss.

abstract: Peter Lynch vs. John Kennedy and Patrick Hogarty. -- This is an appeal on the part of defendants from a judgment rendered at a trial term of this Court, on the 9th day of December, 1859. The action was founded on a promissory note, alleged to have been made by Kennedy for $2,000, to the order of Hogarty, who, it is alleged, endorsed the note and delivered it to the plaintiff. The answer sets up that the note in question was a second renewal of one made between the same parties, and that it was secured and eventually paid out of the avails of property transferred from Hogarty to James Lynch, the plaintiff's brother, who, as alleged, after payment, transferred the note to plaintiff to be recovered for his brother. It is alleged that the previous notes of Kennedy were business notes; that the note in suit was an accommodation note on the part of Kennedy. It appears from the evidence that Jas. Lynch went with Hogarty to the plaintiff's store to have the note discounted; that the note was produced, and Hogarty indorsed it. It further appears that James Lynch then gave his brother a certificate, signed by Kennedy, that the note was a business note and would be paid at maturity. It further appears that some conversation relative to this note occuried some two months before the suit was brought, as fallows: Plaintiff met Kennedy in the street, and wished to know from him when he was coming to pay that note. Plaintiff then told him that he held a note of his with Hoggarty's endorsement upon it. which was the past due. Defendant then told plaintiff, "Your brother will pay that; see him and he will pay it."

abstract: As many of the people of New-York as the large hell of Cooper Institute would hold, gathered there, last evening, and gave a hearty expression to their sympathy with Italian Freedom and Nationality. About the platform hung many flags -- upon it were a bust of GARIBALDI and many distinguished gentlemen, and suspended in front of it was ORSINI's splendid painting of the Italian hero, placed there through the kindness of Mr. W.H. DERBY, of the Institute of Fine Arts, where it is on exhibition. The Navy-yard Band furnished the instrumental music of the occasion, and during the evening Dr. GUILMETTE sung exceedingly well "The Triumph of Italian Freedom," an ode set to the music of the "Marseilles Hymn," composed for the occasion by WILLIAM ROSS WALLACE. The audience joined in the chorus.

abstract: On Sunday last a letter from Bishop POTTER to the clergy and laity of the diocese of New-York, was read in the Episcopal churches. The document, which is quite long, alludes to the troubles which are upon us, and to the greatness which the Confederacy has achieved under the Federal Constitution: Members of the same political family have became so absorbed in the contemplation on one point of difference, that they have lost sight of all that is excellent Bishop knows that there are [???] exceptions to this in each other's character and have become incompatible of doing justice to each other's feelings, principles and conduct. The assertions, and that the church of his affections has been honorably distinguished by exemption from all sectional disputes and divisions. For this reason he appeals to each individual in his flock to do all that lies in his power to carry out the principles of compromise in which the Government was founded. It is useless to stop and ask who is to blame for the present state of affairs. The evil is upon us, and is every day becoming greater. None can tell what the future may have in store if it is not at once checked. The Bishop therefore urges all to use with greater fervency and frequency the prayers in the Litany for Congress and for those in authority. He concludes with an ardent in location that we may be rescued from present and impending perils.
