abstract: The Medical Department of the New-York University has for the last few days been the scene of some excitement, originating in a personal difficulty or misunderstanding between two of its Professors, of no especial interest to the rest of mankind, and which might better have been kept private, but which having been made public, demands a passing notice, if for no other reason than to correct the misrepresentation, and exaggerations of the affair that have appeared in some of the City papers. It is in no sense a political difficulty, as has been made to appear by some sensation papers, nor is it true that fifty Southern students, or even one-fourth of that number, are about to sail in the Marion to-day for the sunny South in consequence of the affair.

abstract: After the steady receipts of generally common grade cattle that have been pouring into the market for a number of weeks past, it was refreshing to see the fine display that the yards at Forty-fourth-street presented yesterday, Cattle producers seem determined that there shall be no lack of choice cuts for the coming Christmas. Fat, handsome, premium steers and bullocks could he counted by the dozen, while from almost every drove could be singled equally as rich, if not such heavy animals. In fact, nearly every one had prime stock to offer, and butchers, finding that they could suit themselves at nearly every turn, were inclined to be a little independent. This made the trade drag considerably during the latter part of the day, but brokers knowing that the moderate supply of last week allowed very little reserved stick to remain in butchers' hands, refused to recede a fraction from the figures of last market day. About 3,100 head were yarded by noon, and some 500 head of State cattle were expected by the Harlem Railroad. This total is not excessively large, but even without the addition of those due, so great is the increase of average weight in Western and other droves, that our market will be liberally supplied with beef for the coming week. Some of the Christmas stock brought 12.@12 1/2c., and 10c., was frequently paid for the greater part of some pretty large lots. In thin cattle there were few if any transactions. The closing up of yesterday's trade left a very fair complement for to-day.

abstract: -The new line of steamers between Boston and Charleston was withdrawn last week, the enterprise in the present paralysis of trade, involving a less Causes of a different nature threaten to embarrass the intercourse between this City and Southern ports. The discouragement of steerage travel by the uniform  return of the emigrants is not calculated to enlarge receipts from the transportation of that class of passengers. First class travelers, in the present exasperated condition of Southern feeling; are also rare; the usual pleasure and health seeking population, who follow the retreating summer Southward, postponing this season, for wholesome reasons, their annual migration. Freights in the present state of trade are of course extremely light. Every commercial influence is thus adverse to the prosecution of a successful business in transportation; and but for the mail contracts it is quite possible the frequency of communication would be temporarily reduced.

abstract: CITY OFFICIALS AT LOGGERHEADS -- ALMOST AN AFFRAY. -- The vicinity of the TIMES Office came near, yesterday, being the scene of a bloody, affray, which was, however, prevented by the intervention of friends. The parties were Ald. PLATT, and Superintendent of Markets, JAS. IRVING. The trouble between them having grown out of some remarks (as alleged) made by Mr. PLATT, which were not specially acceptable to the Superintendent, and hence the collision. Mr. PLATT having found a secure spot where he could not be attacked in flank or rear, maintained his position with unflinching steadiness, refusing all invitations to come out and be thrashed, which, considering that he measures about five feet two, and weighs at least 120 pounds; whereas his challenger foots up five feet six, and weighs at least 160 pound. -- was an act of commendable discretion, A long war of words ensued, the Alderman refusing to reply to the attacks and insinuations of the Superintendent, but the latter was at length aroused to a state of phrenzy by the Alderman's placing his hand in his pocket. Of course this was assumed as being in readiness to draw and fire, but his wrath was quelled by the assurance that the Alderman had only searched for a paper of tobacco which was in his pocket. The emeule was, quelled without bloodshed, but the quantity of oaths and threats uttered, quite atoned for such a deplorable termination to that which at first bid fair to terminate in a really respectable row.

abstract: AS THIS question is frequently asked, we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upwards of thirty years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a Female Physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class; and, as a result of this effort and practical knowledge, obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health; and is, moreover, rare to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children certainly do RISE UP and bless her; especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an untimely grave by its timely use, and that millions, yet unborn will share its benefits, and unite in calling her blessed. He MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of Mrs. Winslow's Soothing Syrup. Try it mothers. TRY NOW. -- Ladies Visitor, New-York City.

Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an untimely grave by its timely use, and that millions, yet unborn will share its benefits, and unite in calling her blessed. He MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of Mrs. Winslow's Soothing Syrup. Try it mothers. TRY NOW. -- Ladies Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: The splendid new steamer John P. King, which had just been completed for Messrs. SPOFFORD & TILESTON's Charleston line, made a most successful trial-trip on Monday, preparatory to her going upon the line. She returned from the trip down the Bay at 4 o'clock P.M., and came to at pier No. 4 North River. The peformances of the King gave the highest satisfaction to all who were on board, including her builders, the constructors of her engines and machinery, her New-York owners, and a large number of merchants. Having landed her guests, the vessel was surrendered to the custody of her officers and a watchman for the night, the Captain going to his residence in Brooklyn. At half-past 4 o'clock yesterday morning, the attention of the police on West street was attracted by smoke which was seen issuing from the funnel of the new steamer. The alarm was immediately given, and the persons on board of the King called up. A slight inspection below revealed the fact that the wood-work surrounding the engine-room was in a blaze, the fire having already made considerable headway, and the flames mounting from the forward hatch of the engine-room. The cause of the fire was unknown, but was supposed to have resulted from the over-heated wood-work around the boilers. The nearest hydrant was unscrewed, and by the aid of the steamer's hose a stream of water was poured below, and upon the fire. In a short time the firemen arrived, and brought powerful streams to bear upon it from their several machines. It was soon apparent, however, that the fire was beyond control, and efforts were made to scuttle the vessel. The flames now had gamed fearful headway, and messengers were dispatched to the Union Ferry Company for the assistance of the ferry-boats with their Worthington pumps to aid in extinguishing the fire. The ferry-boat Whitehall was soon alongside, having the steam-engines J.G. Storm and Mary Ann, No. 8, which did good service, the Worthington force-pump from the ferry-boat throwing a continuous and powerful stream into the hatchways of the burning steamer. The impossibility of getting below so as to direct the streams upon the flames, rendered all efforts abortive.

abstract: There is a woman in the public eye, whose name had all along been associated, in our mind, with the "Yankee," "Quack," and "Humbug." But it is so no longer, and we desire to wrest her name from all such suspicious association in all other minds. Whatever notions we may have of womanly delicacy and propriety, we will all admit that woman alone is the Nurse -- the GOOD Nurse -- the BEST Nurse. Whether we shall have Female Physicians or not, is a question which must be decided by time and principle, and not as a matter of taste. Pride, prejudice, caprice and custom, may as well behave themselves, for if there is really a want, there will also be a supply -- if there be a "calling," there will be a COMING. Nature and human society are always self-applying, and though Art and Fashion may hinder, they cannot prevent.

abstract: The house of W.L. Ormsby, Jr., No. 556 Broomestreet, was broken into about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, the burglar having effected an entrance by removing a cellar-door from its hinges-after which he pried open an inside door and ransacked the lower part of the premises without attracting the attention of the occupants. A quantity of clothing and other artieles of considerable value were carried away, but the
lead_paragraph: The house of W.L. Ormsby, Jr., No. 556 Broomestreet, was broken into about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, the burglar having effected an entrance by removing a cellar-door from its hinges-after which he pried open an inside door and ransacked the lower part of the premises without attracting the attention of the occupants. A quantity of clothing and other artieles of considerable value were carried away, but the thief did not escape with his booty. While passing through Clarke-street, with a bundle of garments in his possession, he was seen by officer Rogers, of the Eighth Precinct, who knew him to be a reputed thief, and his arrest was effected on suspicion. It subsequently transpired that the burglary had been committed, and Mr. Ormsby fully identified the property found upon the prisoner as that which had been stolen from him. The accused, who is said to be named John Gordon, was committed for trial by Justice CONNOLLY.

abstract: The members of the South Caroline State Convention reached Charleston at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and were received by the citizens and military, and with a salute of fifteen guns. The Convention met at 4 o'clock, and immediately proceeded to business. A Committee of seven was appointed to prepare an address to the people of the Southern States. Committees were also appointed "On relations with the Slaveholding States," On Foreign Relations," On Commercial relations," and "on the Constitution of the State." Judge MAGRATH offered a resolution, which was made the special order for to-day relative to that part of the President's Message, which treats of the Federal property in South Carolina. He desired that it should be referred to a Committee, to inquire whether the United States, after South Carolina shall have seceded, can enjoy such property consistently with the dignity and safety of the State. The resolution also proposed an inquiry as to the value of the property of the United States not in South Carolina, and the share to which that State would be entitled upon a division among the States. A document, purporting to be an address from a portion of the Georgia Legislature, was received and laid oh the table, without reading. After some other business of no special importance, the Convention adjourned until 11 o'clock to-day.

abstract: The New-Orleans Delta has extracts from letters written in Nicaragua, in regard to the expedition and death of WALKER. They state that the news of the landing of the Fillibusters at Truxillo was the signal of the most enthusiastic demonstrations among the Nicaraguan Liberals. Parties of them paraded the streets cheering the name of WALKER, and crying death to the Government, and in some instances filing upon the guard-houses. These exhibitions of sympathy the Government is said to have been powerless to repress or punish; and when, after the news of the great Fillibuster's execution had been received, attempts were made to stimulate a general popular rejoicing over the event, they proved, so far as Nicaragua was concerned, to be "dead failures." These same correspondents assert that the dying words put in the mouth of WALKER by the Hondurians, were fabrications; that what the chief really did say, was to promise other Walkers to arise from his blood. On this hope the popular party in Nicaragua are said to be relying.

These same correspondents assert that the dying words put in the mouth of WALKER by the Hondurians, were fabrications; that what the chief really did say, was to promise other Walkers to arise from his blood. abstract: The Senate has entered upon the task of devising a compromise for the settlement of the Slavery question. A Select Committee on the subject was ordered in that body yesterday, and Mr. CRITTENDEN submitted a series of amendments to the Constitution, of which the leading feature was the adoption of the Missouri Compromise line extended to the Pacific. North of that line Slavery is to be prohibited -- South of it slaves are to be protected by authority of the Federal Government as property. Fugitive slaves are to be paid for if rescued -- Congress to reimburse the owner, and look to the county where the rescue occurs for reimbursement. And sundry fresh guarantees are to be given for the security of Slavery in the States, and in the District of Columbia, and for the immunity of the domestic Slave-trade from interference.
lead_paragraph: The Senate has entered upon the task of devising a compromise for the settlement of the Slavery question. A Select Committee on the subject was ordered in that body yesterday, and Mr. CRITTENDEN submitted a series of amendments to the Constitution, of which the leading feature was the adoption of the Missouri Compromise line extended to the Pacific. North of that line Slavery is to be prohibited -- South of it slaves are to be protected by authority of the Federal Government as property. Fugitive slaves are to be paid for if rescued -- Congress to reimburse the owner, and look to the county where the rescue occurs for reimbursement. And sundry fresh guarantees are to be given for the security of Slavery in the States, and in the District of Columbia, and for the immunity of the domestic Slave-trade from interference.
headline: {'main': 'The New Compromise.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Compromise.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An important caucus was held yesterday afternoon at Delmonico's, the Mayor presiding, and a majority (as it is claimed,) of the City Fathers being in attendance. If so, there must be "big cheating" round the board, and nothing that may occur this evening should astonish us. The Mayor is anxious to have his brother, Mr. HENRY WOOD, confirmed as Street Commissioner, and it is believed that the caucus of yesterday was called to hear, see and feel arguments in regard to the propriety of such a change. Those who profess to be posted in Aldermanic secrets, openly ridicule the attempt as an absurd and impossible one. The Mayor, they say, cannot get more than four out of the seventeen votes requisite for the removal of Capt. G.W. SMITH; and no matter how many Aldermen may enter his caucus, when it comes to the sharp push of voting, there will be found a solid phalanx of thirteen in favor of allowing things to remain as they are in the Street and City Inspector's Departments, until after the 7th of next month. When the new Board comes into power, they think, will be time enough for the Mayor to look after the removal of Messrs. SMITH and DELAVAN. There was intense excitement yesterday upon the subject, and doubtless the proceedings of the Board this evening will be attended by large outside delegations from the threatened Departments. There is not much immediate fear that the Charley Devlin regime can be restored to power. Those favorable to such a proposition, will (as Ald. BOOLE says,) "have to watch long before they can prey."

abstract: The numerous ladies and gentlemen who attended the grand concert at Cooper Institute, last evening, for the benefit of the Five Points Gospel Union Mission, were certainly not fair-weather Christians. It was a most disagreeable night without, but within the hall, which was nearly half full, it was an exceedingly pleasant one. The musical entertainment, in which six celebrated Sunday-school vocalists, assisted by Mr. ROBERT CHAPMAN and twenty young ladies and gentlemen of New-York and Brooklyn, took part, was a very fine one. It was under the direction of Mr. HORACE WATERS, and Mrs. E.A. PARKHURST presided at the piano forte. The vocal performances of little Miss MARTHA DAVIES deserved and drew forth repeated plaudits. During the evening Rev. RUFUS W.M. CLARK, delivered an address, in which he stated that in 1830 the first efforts for the regeneration of The Five Points were made; told amid what drawbacks the first Sunday School was established in that section of the City, and endeavored, apparently with great success, to awaken among the audience a lively interest in the objects of the Mission. He gave some interesting reminiscences of his own early efforts in its behalf: from them deducing the moral that young men might accomplish much in the cause of Christianity.

abstract: Mr. Secretary THOMPSON, of the Department of the Interior, has left Washington for Raleigh. He goes as Commissioner from the State of Mississippi to the State of North Carolina, to consult with the authorities of that State in regard to Southern cooperation in the event of secession. He still holds his office under the Federal Government, and is expected to return within a few days.

abstract: The Fire Department of our City, while claiming much credit as a volunteer organization, rendering its services gratuitously in behalf of property and life, is rapidly becoming a heavy burden on the City Treasury; and it may to-day be justly questioned, whether a paid Department, with every man in the force drawing salary and liable to lose his place for misconduct, would not be a measure as promotive of public economy as it would certainly be conducive to the public peace, comfort and morals. This experiment has been tried elsewhere, and in every instance the results have been satisfactory and encouraging. The change from a volunteer to the paid system of Fire Companies, has certainly contributed its full share to the redemption of Baltimore from the sway of rowdies; and if the interesting class of those who now "bunk" in our engine houses, could be made to sleep at home o' nights, and spend less time in association with similar youths similarly situated, we make no doubt that there would soon be perceptible diminution in the assault and battery cases to be tried at the Court of Special Sessions.

abstract: Public attention has, of late years, been directed to the obvious advantages arising from the entrance of woman into the profession of medicine, and every day increases the number among us of those who wish to devote themselves to this department of science. The tide which they have so long been obliged to stem, now sets in their favor. We rejoice in the increasing popularity of this noble work, as a token of the world's progress; but while we do so, we should not forget the pioneers in the field, who have struggled in the past untiringly, through the obstacles which prejudice has thrown in their way, and whose heroic exertions have effected the change in public opinion. Conspicuous among the number stands Mrs. WINSLOW, who for more than thirty years as nurse and physician, has followed her profession with unflagging application and industry. During this time she has compounded a Soothing Syrup, for children teething, which ought to immortalize her name. It is the most perfect thing of the kind, in our opinion, ever compounded, and one of the greatest discoveries in medicine of the age; it is of more importance to the human family than any other discovery made by the profession in the last hundred years. Common observation cannot fail to satisfy all who will take the trouble to look into the bills of mortality for any one year, that a very large percentage of children annually die during the process of teething, and a very much larger number of those who survive are greatly debilitated or diseased, so that they grow up weak both physically and mentally, and incapacitated both for study and labor. Now, we appeal with perfect confidence to thousands of mothers who will read this article, to corroborate our statement when we say that no such fatal consequences as those we have alluded to, ever occur from teething, when Mrs. WINSLOW's Soothing syrup is used is TIME. That it is just the article needed is the testimony which reaches us daily from those who have tried it, and until some member of the Faculty can produce an article which shall equal in excellence the result of the long experience of a Female Physician, we hope we shall hear no more of woman's overstepping her sphere in entering the medical profession. -- Drawing-room Companion, N.Y.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Recorder BARNARD, William B. Lilley, indicted for forgery, in passing an altered $1 note, was first tried. The jury, after a long absence, returned and stated that they were unable to agree. They were thereupon discharged, and the prisoner then pleading guilty to forgery in the fourth degree, was discharged under suspended sentence.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- "Romeo and Juliet" was played here last night, Mr. BOOTH sustaining the part of the hero, and a "young lady of this City," that of the heroine. The interest of the occasion centred, of course, upon the latter. Miss ELLIOTT, the debutante, possesses a good figure, fine eyes and a pleasing stage presence; her movements are unembarrassed and graceful. Beyond these requisites, which she brings to a profession demanding these and many others, we noticed much quiet and thoughtful purpose, and a meritorious modesty, which, while it was embarrassing to the lady herself, was not the less her friend with the audience. There is no royal road to acting, and the future excellence which is promised by this initial performance must depend on patient heroism, willing drudgery, tedious minuteness of study, and unflinching strength of purpose. The first triumph has been gained, but scarcely the first victory, for Miss ELLIOTT has yet everything to learn. It is pleasant, however, to be able to assure her at the start that to a miscellaneous audience, (the truest and sometimes severest critic,) as well as to the mere reporter, she seems to possess every graceful requisite for distinction in the profession she has espoused.

abstract: We publish, in another column, rather an extraordinary document, purporting to come from the hands of President BUCHANAN. It is a political letter, -- addressed to a gentleman in Philadelphia who had expressed a fear, shared by many of their party friends, lest the "remaining vitality" of the Democratic Party might be "still further lessened" by the course of action the President was pursuing in regard to secession. It was designed to be confidential, -- but that purpose has been frustrated and the world is permitted to share the wisdom originally intended for the use of the much more limited circle of Mr. BUCHANAN's political "friends." We should be glad if we were at liberty to consider it spurious, -- but we fear the intrinsic evidence of its genuineness deprives us of this consolation. It must certainly be humilating to find the President of the Republic, in this supreme crisis of its history, extending a degree of anxious consideration to a small party clique in Philadelphia which he denies to the gallant little garrison of Fort Moultrie.

abstract: This case was resumed yesterday before United States Commissioner MORELL. The prisoners were not present, and Capt. LATHAM was reported to be quite ill. The only witness examined was Mr. SOLON HUMPHREY, a member of the firm of E.D. MORGAN & CO., who testified that he executed a bill of sale of the bark Cora on or about the 11th April last. The signature was in his handwriting. The bill of sale was identified, counsel for the defence objecting to the introduction of the paper. A ship-broker, calling his name FREDERICKS, and hailing from South-street, applied to purchase the vessel; some half-a-dozen brokers were about it, but FREDERICKS was accepted as the buyer. He gave JOHN LATHAM as his principal. The sale note was drawn by witness, and FREDERICKS signed it at their office. He took the note away, and returned it the next business day, signed and accepted. [The bill of sale and broker's note were offered as evidence and accepted, subject to objection.] The purchase money was paid on the 11th of April.

abstract: The Romney (Va.) Argus, lamenting the decline in the value of slaves, reports the sale at $800 of a valuable mechanic, who last year would readily have brought $1,500. Everywhere in the South at the present moment the quotations for such merchandise arc merely nominal. The transactions are extremely few, and uniformly at prices which a twelve-month since would have been considered ridiculously inadequate. In the Frontier States rates are better maintained than further southward, for the reason that there is less danger of servile revolt there than in the Cotton States. In South Carolina, for instance, the perilous aspect of the social question absolutely prevents the sale or exchange of slaves; and while the nominal rates have declined at least thirty per cent., there are no sales to test the decline. It may be safe, however, to estimate that if the involuntary labor of the South was in 1859 worth $1200,000,000, in 1860 it is worth less than $800,000,000 -- a sudden depreciation for which the capital of no country in the world has ever, perhaps, furnished a precedent.

abstract: FREE CHURCH OF THE EPIPHANY -- LADIES' FAIR. -- The ladies of the Free Church of the Epiphany are now holding their annual Fair in aid of the Church funds, in the church in Stanton-street, near Essex, where they offer for sale Christmas toys and the extensive assortment of articles usually displayed on like occasions. As they charge no admission fee, and eschew the conventional lottery and raffle features, it is fair to presume they will do as well as they did last year, when, under similar circumstances, they realized about $700. The rapid up town movement of the congregation necessitates these Fairs to sustain the church. The present esteemed pastor, Mr. JONES, has officiated as minister of this church about twenty-eight years, and his old parishioners flock to these Fairs to greet their old pastor and his estimable lady.

abstract: The fact that Illinois and her noble sister States of the West have opened their granaries in a flooding stream for the starving thousands of Kansas is widely known. But it is not so generally known, that for several weeks past some thirty thousand bushels of this generously contributed grain have been lying in the hands of Committees and at depots of railroads through the West, for want of sacks in which to transport it.

abstract: We must crave the indulgence of correspondents for any apparent neglect of their favors. We have an immense accumulation of manuscript -- especially of communications on the subject of our political troubles, many of which are valuable and would be cheerfully published at once if the pressure of news, advertisements, &c., upon our columns, did not render it impossible. In due time we hope to be able to make room for some of them, -- but we must bespeak the forbearance of their authors.

abstract: KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- UNITED STATES DEPOSIT FUND. -- An adjourned meeting of this Board was held yesterday afternoon, in the County Jail Court-room, Raymond-street, President CROWELL in the chair. After the usual preliminary business had been disposed of, and bills had been presented and referred; a communication was read from Mr. CAMPBELL, Sheriff elect of the county, asking for a new safe for the Sheriff's office. The communication was referred to the Committee on Accounts. The Committee on the United States Deposit Fund presented a report, showing that at the date of the last annual report there was loaned $7,070; amount now on loan, $6,500, on mortgages, as follows:

abstract: The course of Prof. DRAPER in the unpleasant difficulty between him and Dr. AYLETTE having been indorsed by nearly all the students from both sections of the country, it is confidently stated that he will reconsider his resignation and resume his lectures after the holidays. Dr. AYLETTE has ceased his connection with the University. Out of forty-seven Southern medical students, who signed the agreement to leave this City for the South, and who, it was understood, would go in the steamer Marion, yesterday, an inducement being a reduction of $2 each for tickets, only three actually took leave by that conveyance. Their names were registered as follows: C.C. WELSH. Lancaster District, S.C.; J.R. EVANS, Chesterfield District; S.C.; J.W. GLOVER, Newburg, S. C. It was stated that others would probably leave by the railroad, and still others would follow in a few days. There was no demonstration made.

abstract: The most important feature in the proceedings of Congress yesterday was the speech of Mr. JOHNSON, of Tennessee, in the Senate, continued from Tuesday. He made a strong appeal for the Union, and declared that Tennessee would stand by it to the last. Alluding to the expressed intention of South Carolina to compel the other Southern States to follow her in her scheme of secession, he said that Tennessee would not be dragged into a Southern or any other Confederacy until she had time to consider about it. He was followed by Mr. LASS, of Oregon. Mr. TOOMBS, of Georgia, made his appearance in the Senate yesterday for the first time during the present session. The Pension and the Military Academy bills were passed In the House, the day was principally occupied in the consideration of the Deficiency Appropriation bill, the item under discussion being an appropriation of $900,000 for the return and maintenance of the recaptured Africans. The bill finally passed as reported from the Committee of Ways and Means. An effort was made to adjourn over until the 7th of January, but it failed -- 94 to 82.

abstract: As the Cotton States are placing great dependence upon England as their future customer for their "Great Staple," it may be well for them to read the third annual report of the "British Cotton-Supply Association," from which some extraordinary facts may be learned, showing the great energy and research of that Association, acting under the determination to obtain a full supply of cotton in the future, without dependence upon the product of slave labor.

abstract: Senator JOHNSON'S speech to-day was a strong vindication of the supremacy of the Constitution, and a refutation of the asserted right of any State to secede. It was able and impressive, and was listened to with interest. Naturally enough the ultra Southern Senators are dissatisfied with it, as it was severe in its denunciation of Southern ultraism, and left little hope that Tennessee would yield to it. Gen. LANE made a brief reply.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 19.

abstract: Amable Lafevre vs. Henry H. Morange. -- This was an action in the nature of trespass, brought to recover damages of the defendant for an alleged wrongful seizure of the plaintiff's property. The seizure was shown on the trial below, but the defendant justified under process of attachment issued out of the District Court, and claimed that the property was lawfully taken, he being the plaintiff in the action had in the District Court. The plaintiff in this case, on the trial below, contended that the attachment issued by the District Court, although regular on its face, was really void, because certain statutory conditions had not been complied with.
lead_paragraph: Amable Lafevre vs. Henry H. abstract: Cecelia A. Howell, vs. The Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company. -- This was an action to recover the sum of $2,500, covered by a policy of insurance on the life of the plaintiff's husband. The facts of the case appear to be these: The policy was taken out in July, 1855. On the 19th of October, 1857, deceased, E.H. Howell, left his residence at Mamaroneck, and was never seen afterwards until found on the 15th of March, 1858, dead, in the woods near Fort Hamilton, L.I., with a ball-hole through his head and a pistol by him. From the appearance of the body, he had been dead several months.

abstract: Many members of the legal profession, and nearly all who have the misfortune to be litigants in support of their rights, are beginning to make serious complaints of the unnecessary and prejudicial delays of the Judiciary in rendering their decisions on cases argued in our Courts of Record. It is alleged that one Judge of the Supreme Court rarely decides a case within a year after the hearing; while another Judge of the Common Pleas has been known, in many instances, to take from eighteen months to three years before delivering his opinion on cases taken home for examination.
lead_paragraph: Many members of the legal profession, and nearly all who have the misfortune to be litigants in support of their rights, are beginning to make serious complaints of the unnecessary and prejudicial delays of the Judiciary in rendering their decisions on cases argued in our Courts of Record. It is alleged that one Judge of the Supreme Court rarely decides a case within a year after the hearing; while another Judge of the Common Pleas has been known, in many instances, to take from eighteen months to three years before delivering his opinion on cases taken home for examination.

abstract: Yesterday evening about 5 o'clock, a fire broke out in the seven-story building Nos. 26 and 28 Frankfort-street. The fire originated in the fifth door of the building occupied by BARNETT & CO., manufacturers of daguerreotype cases. The fire was first discovered in the shelving, but spread with such rapidity that the employes of Mr. E.O. JENKINS, the printer, who occupied the upper stories, were obliged to escape through the scuttle. The building was occupied entirely for manufacturing purposes; it was owned by CHARLES JENKINS, and was seven stories high in front, with a height of nine stories in the rear. The building occupied a frontage of 50 feet, and a depth of 100 feet. For a short time the flames raged with the greatest fury, threatening total destruction to several neighboring buildings. The large tenement house Nos. 35 and 37 Frankfort-street, caught on fire several times, especially the roof and fourth story. The firemen saved the adjoining building Nos. 22 and 24 Frankfort-street. However, when the last wall of the burning building fell, it crushed in its fall the roofs of the buildings Nos. 30 and 32, owned by JAMES SULLIVAN, and occupied by JANE DESMOND and WILLIAM MARTIN. The fire was not extinguished until the building was entirely destroyed.

abstract: An accident of quite a serious character occurred yesterday morning on board of the steamer Commonwealth, which resulted in the scalding of several persons -- one of them, a waiter on board, fatally The steamer had reached a point above Throgg' Neck, about 5 o'clock in the morning, where it is customary, at this season, to wait for daylight, in order to safely pass through the Gate. While lying there with the furnace-doors, open, as usual, and only a moderate head of steam on, a defective plate in the steam-chimney, near the edge of one of the joints, gave-way, making an opening two inches wide, from which the steam; escaped into the chimney, and through the front connections into the starboard fireroom. The fireman rushed out upon the deck to escape the steam, and as the door was opened, a strong wind, coming in from the side opening on the guard, swept the steam out among the deck passengers, who, fortunately but few in number, were seated around the sove on the main deck. Seven or eight persons were considerably scalded, but only two or three seriously. JAS. MYERS, a colored lad, employed as a waiter for the officers, who was in the waiters' room with others, and who would have been safe if he had remained there, rushed out and inhaled the hot steam, fatally scalding him. An Irish family, named BLAKE, from Dublin, consisting of four persons, were also badly burnt, Mrs. BLAKE and her daughter CHARLOTTE seriously. One other person, named CHARLES HODSFELTER, was badly scalded. Luckily, none of the cabin passengers had risen, else there would probably have been many more persons injured. The steam was immediately blown off, the starboard connection was closed, and then steam was again raised on the larboard boiler, by which the steamer proceeded to the City. The officers of the steamer took prompt measures to relieve the sufferings of the injured persons, and the passengers made up a purse of $70 for their benefit. The following persons were conveyed to the New-York Hospital, on the arrival of the steamer, and placed under the charge of Drs. TUTHILL and Ward:

abstract: The House yesterday passed a bill for the construction of two railroads to the Pacific, -- a Northern and a Southern road, -- the former starting from two points on the western borders of Iowa and Missouri, by two lines converging to a point 200 miles west of the Missouri River, and proceeding thence via Salt Lake to San Francisco; -- the latter starting at two points from the western borders of Arkansas and Louisiana, by two lines converging until they meet the line of the road chartered by the State of Texas.
lead_paragraph: The House yesterday passed a bill for the construction of two railroads to the Pacific, -- a Northern and a Southern road, -- the former starting from two points on the western borders of Iowa and Missouri, by two lines converging to a point 200 miles west of the Missouri River, and proceeding thence via Salt Lake to San Francisco; -- the latter starting at two points from the western borders of Arkansas and Louisiana, by two lines converging until they meet the line of the road chartered by the State of Texas.

abstract: Our Washington Correspondent reports that orders have been sent to Maj. ANDERSON to surrender the Charleston Forts if they are attacked. We shall await confirmation of this intelligence before we give it full credit. We concede its probabilty. Every thing in the recent conduct of JAMES BUCHANAN has indicated that he was in close alliance with the Conspirators against the Union. All his official arrangements have looked towards this end. While we hesitate as yet to yield full credence to the reported consummation of his treason, we shall not be at all surprised to find that for weeks before the election, he has been pledged to aid in the achievement of these schemes. We do not forget that two months before the election, the Charleston Mercury, the accredited Disunion organ, assorted that if South Carolina would secede before the 4th of March, she would meet with no resistance, -- adding, with a significance which is now explained, "We know what we say." As long ago as in September last three hundred troops were collected here for the purpose of being sent to Charleston under Lieut. DAVIS to reinforce Fort Moultrie. Just as they were ready to start, the orders were countermanded from Washington and the troops were sent to California. Why this sudden change in their destination?

abstract: Public attention has of late years, been directed to the obvious advantages arising from the entrance of woman into the profession of medicine, and every day increases the number among us of those who wish to devote themselves to this department of science. The tide which they have so long been obliged to stem, now sets in their favor. We rejoice in the increasing popularity of this noble work, as a token of the world's progress; bu while we do so, we should not forget the pioneers in the field, who have struggled in the past untiringly, through the obstacles which prejudice has thrown in their way, and whose heroic exertions have effected the change in public opinion. Conspicuous among the number stands Mrs. WINSLOW, who for more than thirty years as nurse and physician, has followed her profession with unflagging application and industry. During this time she has compounded a Soothing Syrup, for children, teething, which ought to immortalize her name. It is the most perfect thing of the kind, in our opinion, ever compounded; and one of the greatest discoveries in medicine of the age; it is of more importance to the human family than any other discovery made by the profession in the last hundred years. Common observation cannot fail to satisfy all who will take the trouble to look into the bills of mortality for any one year, that a very large percentage of children annually die during the process of teething, and a very much larger number of those who survive are greatly debilitated or diseased, so that they grow up weak both physically and mentally, and incapacitated both for study and labor. Now, we appeal with perfect confidence to thousands of mothers who will read this article, to corroborate our statement when we say that no such fatal consequences as those we have alluded to, ever occur from teething, when Mrs. WINSLOW'S Soothing syrup is used IN TIME. That it is just the article needed is the testimony which reaches us daily from those who have tried it, and until some member of the Faculty can produce an article which shall equal in excellence the result of the long experience of a Female Physician, we hope we shall hear no more of woman's overstepping her sphere in entering the medical profession. -- Drawing-room Companion, N.Y.

That it is just the article needed is the testimony which reaches us daily from those who have tried it, and until some member of the Faculty can produce an article which shall equal in excellence the result of the long experience of a Female Physician, we hope we shall hear no more of woman's overstepping her sphere in entering the medical profession. -- Drawing-room Companion, N.Y.

abstract: South Carolina yesterday, by solemn ordinance declared the connection with the Confederacy of the United States dissolved. The instrument by which this desperate act was consummated declares that the ordinance adopted by the State, in Convention, on the 23d of May, 1788, whereby the Constitution of the United States was ratified, and all acts and parts of acts passed by the Legislature of the State ratifying amendments to the Constitution, are repealed, and that union subsisting between South Carolina and the other States, under the name of the United States of America, is at an end. The ordinance was engrossed on parchment, and the members of the Convention signed it at 6 1/2 o'clock last evening. Considerable discussion took place as to the immediate effect of this action on business and other relations; on the collection of revenue at Charleston by the Federal authorities; on the distribution of mail matter, etc.; but no definite idea seemed to be entertained by any one as to what was necessary or proper to be done. Some were in favor of continuing certain relations with the "foreign" Government of the United States, while others were opposed to any such arrangement, and for striking out at once into the labyrinths of separate sovereignty. These matters will probably be discussed by the Convention to-day.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina yesterday, by solemn ordinance declared the connection with the Confederacy of the United States dissolved. The instrument by which this desperate act was consummated declares that the ordinance adopted by the State, in Convention, on the 23d of May, 1788, whereby the Constitution of the United States was ratified, and all acts and parts of acts passed by the Legislature of the State ratifying amendments to the Constitution, are repealed, and that union subsisting between South Carolina and the other States, under the name of the United States of America, is at an end. The ordinance was engrossed on parchment, and the members of the Convention signed it at 6 1/2 o'clock last evening. Considerable discussion took place as to the immediate effect of this action on business and other relations; on the collection of revenue at Charleston by the Federal authorities; on the distribution of mail matter, etc.; but no definite idea seemed to be entertained by any one as to what was necessary or proper to be done. Some were in favor of continuing certain relations with the "foreign" Government of the United States, while others were opposed to any such arrangement, and for striking out at once into the labyrinths of separate sovereignty. These matters will probably be discussed by the Convention to-day.

abstract: The burning of the John P. King, at her dock, rather than at sea, with a complement of passengers; the comparatively harmless rupture of the Commonwealth's steam-chimney, under low steam and fires, rather than an explosion, of which, under higher pressure, this very rupture would have been the first step; the burning and tumbling to pieces of the Connaught -- to go back a little further -- under circumstances of the most frightful carelessness and guilt on the part of her builders, at a time when there was, singularly enough, a vessel at hand to save the victims; -- all these fearful warnings should be instantly heeded. We had better not tempt Providence much longer with our rotten boiler-plate and cheap construction. Let Congress spare one half hour to defend the public against a destroyer which menaces, its safety quite as decidedly, in the long run, as sectional and party strife.
lead_paragraph: The burning of the John P. We had better not tempt Providence much longer with our rotten boiler-plate and cheap construction. Let Congress spare one half hour to defend the public against a destroyer which menaces, its safety quite as decidedly, in the long run, as sectional and party strife.

abstract: Cecilia A. Howell vs. The Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company. -- This case was stated in yesterday's TIMES. The Justice left it with the jury to say whether or not the husband of the plaintiff, whose life was insured for her benefit by the defendant, came to his death by his own hand. After being out a number of hours, the jury returned and stated that they were unable to agree. They were accordingly discharged.

abstract: HOP OF THE "CITY WIDE-AWAKES." -- The "City Wide-Awakes," last evening, fairly danced for joy at the Republican victory. It was the first public demonstration in honor of Mr. LINCOLN's election that has taken place in the City. It seems the harbinger of a gentle regime that the republican rejoicings in the Metropolis are thus inaugurated under the benign auspices of Terpsichore rather than by marshalled hosts marching to martial music through the streets. Irving Hall, on Irving-place, corner of Fifteenth-street -- a new and elegant temple of the light fantastic toe, -- was the scene of the evening's festivities. There a gay throng assembled in good season. The members of the elite Corps of the Wide-Awarkes of New-York, led by their gallant Capt. BUNCE, dashed boldly into the thickest of the dance and stormed the hearts of the loveliest. The only ornaments of the dancing-hall were thefair; ball-rooms when adorned by them are adorned the most. The music was divine, the dancing delectable, and all night long all went merry as a marriage bell. It was not till long after the sheets of the present edition of the TIMES were put to press that the dancers thought of pressing theirs.

There a gay throng assembled in good season. The members of the elite Corps of the Wide-Awarkes of New-York, led by their gallant Capt. abstract: The Alabama Whig publishes an address made at Eutaw, on Dec. 6, by Hon. JOSEPH W. TAYLOR. He argues, in the first place, that the election of Mr. LINCOLN is constitutional, and should be acquiesced in. He can do the Southern States no harm. Separate State secession he condemns in general, because it is disunion of the South, and in the case of Alabama particularly, because, if it were peaceable, the State could not maintain its position as an independent nation. She could set herself up as champion of the peculiar institution, and would draw upon herself the hostility of the nations who are opposed to it. Such a course would furnisn no remedy for the grievances of which she complains; neither would it give her security for the future, or be making resistance to the election of Mr. LINCOLN, or to the aggressions of the Republicans. To speak plainly, such action would be submission, but in a new form, to most grievous wrong and injustice, for she would be giving up, voluntarily, all light and light to her possessions in the Union. These objections apply equally to the secession of a few States. Mr. TAYLOR then proceeds to the consideration of the remedy which is to be found for the grievances of Alabama in the cooperative action of the Southern States. He defines this as "joint conference and joint action by the Southern States within the limits prescribed by the Constitution." The first great argument in favor of this is that it seeks a union of the South for the protection of the South. By it all wrongs may be redressed in the Union; or, if it should be refused, the Southern States would occupy a favorable position from which to appeal to the world. Then he thinks that an overwhelming majority of the Southern States and of the Southern people prefer the cooperative policy. Then Mr. TAYLOR demonstrates that this course is not too dilatory, and that it is not submission in disguise. He acknowledges that it may preserve the Federal Union, and this is his reason for urging it. In conclusion, he suggests the following as the basis upon which an effort should be made to settle present dificulties:

abstract: South Carolina passed the ordinance of secession yesterday at 1 o'clock P.M., by the unanimous vote of the Convention; and her action was greeted with a salvo of a hundred guns. As this step was universally anticipated, it will create no special uneasiness. It does not change the relations of South Carolina to the Union in the slightest degree, though it will very possibly be followed by acts that will have that effect. It is not easy to see how she can avoid refusing to pay duties at once, as her continuance in paying, upon her own theory, becomes now an act of gratuitous subjection and tribute to a foreign State.

abstract: Another protest by FRANCIS the Second, in the shape of a circular to his Ambassadors at foreign Courts, had been issued. It is dated Gaeta, Nov. 12. The circular, while admitting that the King's army was demoralized by pernicious doctrines, and that treason had penetrated even to the Court and Council, contends that the King would have achieved a triumphal return to his capitol had not "a perjured and disloyal sovereign interfered to prevent it." The King complains of the apathy of European sovereigns, but pays a compliment to the Emperor NAPOLEON, who showed a generous disposition, for which loyal and monarchial England reproached him bitterly. Till lately the King cherished a hope that the Conferences at Warsaw would have led to a European Congress, but the Powers think more of their private animosities than of the great principles of order, and the security of thrones. The tone of the dispatch does not indicate a prolonged occupation of Gaeta.

abstract: George Law et al. vs. The United States. -- The counsel for the complainants in this action applied, this morning, to the Court for an order directing the District-Attorney to furnish to them copies of all letters on file in the Post-office Department between the Postmaster-General and Isaac V. Fowler, between the date of his appointment and the date of the official bond given by him. The application was founded on a petition of the complainant, George Law, setting out the facts of the case, and that the plaintiffs were first informed on Dec. 14, that between the 1st and 20th of September, 1858, Hon. A.V. Brown, then Postmaster-General, wrote a letter to Fowler urging the execution of the official bond, and that in said letter allusion was made to the existing defalcation or indebtedness of Fowler as Deputy Postmaster. The petition and affidavits showed further, that the complainants had made application for copies of the correspondence, but had been refused.

abstract: Gov. HOUSTON has addressed the people of Texas in a manifesto dated at Austin on Dec. 3. He repudiates the idea which he says has been industriously propagated, that he would submit to the violation of the rights of the people of the State by the Federal Government Because he would not urge a resort to revolution without a cause, he is not to be charged with advising submission to wrong. The people have the Constitution to maintain; and when that fails to give them their rights they may resort to revolution. The fearful calamity of disunion, now impending, calls for the united action of the Southern States, and, in this emergency, the rights of the Border States, which have so long stood as a bulwark against Abolitionism, should be regarded. They claim, and the Governor thinks not without reason, that their rights may be maintained in the Union. He then alludes to the action which he has taken towards the election, of delegates to a Southern Convention, and gives as his reasons for refusing to call the Legislature that such a step would involve a large expense which the State, is now unable to meet; that the members of the body were elected on a different issue, and do not now represent the sentiment of the State, and that he is far from satisfied that the people generally desire that the Legislature should be convened. He reaffirms his views regarding the propriety of a Southern Convention and concludes with this appeal:

abstract: COTTON The Broker's Circular says: "The advices received on Monday, of the heavy money pressure in the United States, caused great dullness here and the demand, for several days, was very limited. Although there was some little revival of inquiry, yesterday, the market was so freely supplied that a decline in nearly all classes of American, of 1/8d, lb., was submitted to." Other descriptions of Cotton are dull, and generally rather easier.

abstract: Loomis Bullard et als., plaintiffs and respondents, vs. Ezekiel S. Lockwood, impleaded with Alexander Lockwood and Thomas Gill, defendants and appellants. -- This action was brought to recover damages for the loss of certain straw goods alleged to have been sold to Gill upon the fraudulent representations of himself and the Lockwoods. The defendant, Gill, was not served in this suit. It appears that Gill's place of business was in the same building with the Lockwoods, who were his references. Thus, it is alleged, that through the representations of one of the defendants to the plaintiffs, that Gill was a man up-stairs, who bought goods at auction on short credit, and sold them for cash to the country trade. That they, (the Lockwoods,) sold him on credit, and that he then owed them $3,000, and had always paid them at maturity. It seems to appear from the evidence on the trial of this cause, that the Lockwoods, as auction and commission merchants, were in the habit of advancing Gill money on his promise to return it or send in goods to cover it, but told him they would rather have the goods, as that was their business. The plaintiff's sale on Lockwood's recommendation was shortly after their reference to him, and the next day their straw goods were in Lockwood's catalogue. Their advances to Gill were all made on goods to be sold by them at auction, and with a margin of from 40 to 50 per cent. It appears that, after this transaction, Gill failed, and this action was brought against the Lockwoods for the causes as set forth above. On the trial a verdict was rendered for the plaintiffs against the defendants, who now appeal to the General Term of this Court for a new trial, on the ground of alleged technical defects in the pleadings, -- a defect of parties, -- and that false representations cannot be properly alleged to be made by a firm. The main point, however, appears to be upon a question propounded on the trial to one of the defendants. "State whether, or not, in the conversation you had with one. Williams in regard to Gill's affairs, you had any intent to deceive." This was overruled on the trial as inadmissible evidence. The recommendation having been (positive and emphatic, and the plaintiffs having acted on it to their damage, it was irrelevant what their intent was; and the point is further taken by the counsel for plaintiffs, that one who, without knowledge of its truth or falsity makes a material misrepresentation of this kind; is guilty of fraud as much as if he knew it to be untrue.

abstract: The Newsboys' Lodging-house has become a harbor for all kinds of pour boys, and nearly 160 take shelter there every night. Some are not so sharp as the others, and, perhaps, being lately cast adrift, are exposed to considerable suffering from cold and hunger. Two have been taken lately to the Hospital, who had caught chills and fever from their exposure, with bare feet and ragged clothes, to the cold season. One ragged little fellow came in lately, and was provided with a, warm bed after being well cleaned. The Superintendent had occasion to go into the sleeping-room about 2 o'clock in the morning, and found the boy wide awake. He asked him if he was sick. "No, sir," said he, "but I can't sleep, 'cause the bed is so good. I havn't slept in a bed for three months!" The best time to see the boys together is in the evenings.

The Superintendent had occasion to go into the sleeping-room about 2 o'clock in the morning, and found the boy wide awake. He asked him if he was sick. "No, sir," said he, "but I can't sleep, 'cause the bed is so good. I havn't slept in a bed for three months!" The best time to see the boys together is in the evenings.

abstract: THE ACCIDENT ON THE STEAMER COMMONWEALTH.--Coroner SCHIEMER yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of JAMES MEYERS, a colored youth, employed as a waiter on board the steamer Commonwealth, who died in consequence of scalds received on Wednesday morning last by the explosion on board that vessel.
lead_paragraph: THE ACCIDENT ON THE STEAMER COMMONWEALTH. -- Coroner SCHIEMER yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the death of JAMES MEYERS, a colored youth, employed as a waiter on board the steamer Commonwealth, who died in consequence of scalds received on Wednesday morning last by the explosion on board that vessel. It was shown by the testimony of R.C. JAMES, second engineer of the steamer, that while the boat was lying to just above Hell Gate, waiting for daylight on Wednesday morning last, the steam chamber of the starboard boiler exploded. Witness was in the engine-room and heard the noise, but not being aware of its cause, he was impressed with the idea that the vessel had run on the rocks. As nearly as he could recollect there were 16 inches of steam on at the time of the explosion. The boilers were inspected on the 2d of May, when a certificate was given that they were capable of carrying 35 lbs. The steam chamber he found, by examination, had burst at one of the caps in the lining of the steam chimney, and the weakness he believed had been caused by corrosion, JOHN FAULKNER, fireman, testified that he had found the deceased, shortly after the explosion, lying, near the galley on the larboard side of the steamer's deck. Deceased was asleep in his room near the exploded steam chamber when the accident occurred. Two other servants were with him, but they escaped uninjured. Witness also picked up several females who were scalded, and conveyed them to the ladies' cabin. On the arrival of the Commonwealth at this City deceased and seven other persons were conveyed to the New-York Hospital. Dr. TUTHILL, resident physician of the institution, testified that deceased had been under his care, and that he died from the effects of scalds, at 3 1/2 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon. The jury declared the explosion to have been accidental.

abstract: Henry C. Bowers vs. James C. Willets, Sheriff,  action was brought to recover $7,200 damages, alleged to have been sustained by reason of the defendant entering in and upon,the store on the corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street and Fourth-avenue, in this City, and taking therefrom, detaining, and converting to his own use, a large quantity of groceries.
lead_paragraph: Henry C. Bowers vs. James C. Willets, Sheriff, &c. -- This action was brought to recover $7,200 damages, alleged to have been sustained by reason of the defendant entering in and upon the store on the corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street and Fourth-avenue, in this City, and taking therefrom, detaining, and converting to his own use, a large quantity of groceries. The levy upon these goods was made by the Sheriff under attachments against the firm of Colgrove & Co., some time in February, 1856. It appears from the evidence in the case that Colgrove & Co. had bought this store something like a month before the levy, under the following circumstances: A person of the name of Lock, who was engaged in the vending of patent medicines, occupied desk-room with the plaintiff Bowers during the month of September, 1855. During the same month, Colgrove & Co. purchased of a Mr. Walters the store at the corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street and Eighth-avenue, for about $2,000 -- $500 of which was paid in cash, and the balance in Lock's notes, at from three to twelve months, with Colgrove's indorsement upon them. About two months after this transaction Colgrove & Co. bought another store from Mr. Gibbs, on the corner of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street and Fourth-avenue, which is the store in question, paying Gibbs $400 in cash at the time of the purchase, and their notes for the balance at thirty, sixty and ninety days. None of these notes, it appears, given for these purchases, were ever paid, except that Walters collected the amount due him on the first note out of the proceeds of the Eighth-avenue store, after its sale to the plaintiff.

abstract: The Boston papers bring us the address to the citizens of Massachusetts regarding the Personal Liberty bill in that State, to which reference has been made by telegraph. After a few introductory remarks, the document asserts, that by the statute in question, Massachusetts has violated the great national compact. This law, and others of similar import, which have in view the obstruction of the Fugitive Slave law, are analyzed at length, and their unconstitutional provisions are pointed out. Is it consistent with the honor of the State that these laws should be permitted to exist any longer? Some say that they should not be repealed under threats. This the address admits -- but they should be repealed under a love of right. Then, what meaning is there in the statement that there are threats made concerning them? None at all, for those who use them to further their ends do not desire their repeal; on the contrary, they wish them to stand, while those who truly love their country and are struggling to preserve its integrity, ask that they should be erased from the statute-books, that the South may no longer allege this injustice against the North. The address appeals to the integrity, the intelligence, the magnanimity and the patriotism of the citizens of Massachusetts to secure the repeal of these measures.

abstract: The Philadelphia Press publishes a letter from Hon. WILLIAM WILKINS, of Pittsburgh, Penn., formerly United States Senator, member of the Cabinet, Minister to Russia, and Representative in the State Legislature. He frankly declares that his sympathies are with the South, and says that she has much to complain of in this incessant Anti-Slavery agitation and the passage of laws nullifying the Fugitive Slave law. These obnoxious measures, he urges, should be repealed at once, that the South may be reassured; but she should not condemn Mr. LINCOLN without a hearing. She should wait for some open declaration of principles -- for some overt act of administration. If resistance is to be made at all, it should be against the States which have legislated in a hostile manner towards the South, and not against the General Government, which has given her no cause of complaint. In conclusion, Mr. WILKINS says:

abstract: Ferdon vs. Cunningham. -- This was an appeal from the General Term of the Marine Court affirming a judgment recovered by the plaintiff in an action against the defendant for services rendered in carting in the City of New-York. The defence set up on the trial in the Court below was that the plaintiff had no license either for himself or his cart; that he services being rendered in violation of the City ordinance prohibiting any person except a licensed cartman, he could not recover. The only question raised oh the appeal was whether a person unlicensed as a public cartman and driving an unlicensed cart in the City of New-York can make a valid contract for transportation or carting for anything whatever within this City for hire or pay. Held by the Court that such a contract was illegal and void and that the judgment of the Marine Court must be reversed. Ordered accordingly.
lead_paragraph: Ferdon vs. Cunningham. -- This was an appeal from the General Term of the Marine Court affirming a judgment recovered by the plaintiff in an action against the defendant for services rendered in carting in the City of New-York. lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN feels or affects very great horror at the idea of coercing citizens of South Carolina to obey the Federal laws, against the will of the State authorities. And the sympathizers with secession in general fall into the same tone, and speak of coercion as if it involved civil war and all the nameless horrors which follow in its train. The President seems, inclined to find no alternative between permitting South Carolina to do just as she pleases about obeying the laws, and sending an army to overrun her soil.

abstract: In his Message Mr. BUCHANAN urges the necessity of making certain specified amendments to the Constitution. He believes them necessary to secure the rights of the Southern States.
lead_paragraph: In his Message Mr. BUCHANAN urges the necessity of making certain specified amendments to the Constitution. He believes them necessary to secure the rights of the Southern States. He does not believe that Congress or the country is prepared to concede them now, -- or that they would have any chance of success if presented and urged in the ordiaryway, and on the ordinary motives which govern public action. But he does believe that if the Southern States, or any considerable number of them, were to withdraw from the Union, -- organize themselves into a new Confederacy for the purpose of negotiation and then offer to come back on condition that these amendments should be made, -- the North would assent at once, and thus secure the end desired.

abstract: The Milledgeville Recorder brings a full report of the meeting held in the Senate Chamber, on Dec. 14, by those members of the General Assembly favorable to cooperation. Hon. JOHN BILLUPS, of Clark, presided, and a Committee of twenty-two, having Mr. QUILLIAN, of Gilmer, as Chairman, was appointed to prepare business for the meeting.
lead_paragraph: The Milledgeville Recorder brings a full report of the meeting held in the Senate Chamber, on Dec. 14, by those members of the General Assembly favorable to cooperation. Hon. JOHN BILLUPS, of Clark, presided, and a Committee of twenty-two, having Mr. QUILLIAN, of Gilmer, as Chairman, was appointed to prepare business for the meeting. After consultation, the Committee presented a series of resolutions with an address "to the people of South Carolina, Alabama, Mississippi and Florida, in delegate Conventions assembled, and to such other Southern States as may assemble before the meeting of the Georgia Convention." These documents were signed by fifty-two members of the Legislature who were in attendance at the meeting. The preamble acknowledges the importance of the crisis, and the resolutions repudiate the idea that either of the Slaveholding States will prove untrue to her own interests or the common cause, condemn the plan of secession first and cooperation afterwards, since it would inevitably create domestic dissension and strife, while consultation would insure the success of whatever plan of redress may be agreed on. The address urges these same views at greater length, and invites the appointment of delegates to a Southern Convention. "Our people," it says, "must be united. Our common interest must be preserved. Our common movement must be successful. Common dangers must be avoided. Our equality, our honor shall be preserved. All these can devise a cooperation. Not for our enemies, but for ourselves, our safety, our children, our peace, our necessities, we beseech you so to order your action as that consultation and cooperation shall not be defeated, but secured."

abstract: * * * * France cannot be otherwise than proud to find her protection claimed or her alliance sought by all oppressed nationalities, and it is her interest and her glory not to fail in any of the obligations that her high position imposes upon her. abstract: We see it stated that Mr. CONKLE, of Philadelphia has not yet received the letter addressed to him from President BUCHANAN, which we published on Thursday. Whether this default is owing to a delay of the mails, or to the fact that Mr. B. has never sent him a copy, Mr. CONKLE, of course, not knowing cannot say. As he has had an opportunity, however, of reading it in the TIMES, the failure to receive the manuscript copy is a matter of comparatively little consequence.

abstract: There is something about childish poverty that touches the heart of every true man. We have no right to assume that a poor child is necessarily lazy or vicious, and the youthful sufferer seems to represent to us, for the time, social evils of whose distant influence it is the innocent victim.
lead_paragraph: There is something about childish poverty that touches the heart of every true man. We have no right to assume that a poor child is necessarily lazy or vicious, and the youthful sufferer seems to represent to us, for the time, social evils of whose distant influence it is the innocent victim. In this City there are thousands of children who are homeless, destitute of clothing and of money, beyond the reach of the older means of Christian influence, and fast drifting way towards that dismal swamp from whence come the robbers, the prostitutes, the murderers of society.

abstract: Books are generally as plentiful after a Presidential election as toads are after a shower. The present clouded condition of the political sky has had a rather retarding influence on the crop, but has by no means killed it; we have books to the right of us, books to the left of us, and books all around us.

abstract: THE VALUE OF  PROCRASTINATION.--If GOV. MOORE, of Ala  bama, be accepted as a genuine guage and measure of the sentiment of that State it will be advisable to stake no very formidable risks upon the ultimate course Alabama is likely to take in the crisis.
lead_paragraph: -THE VALUE OF PROCRASTINATION. -- If GOV. MOORE, of Ala bama, be accepted as a genuine guage and measure of the sentiment of that State it will be advisable to stake no very formidable risks upon the ultimate course Alabama is likely to take in the crisis. At the outset of the movement the Governor gave himself out as a conservative, and scrupled about calling a Convention until February. Two days after be arrived at Montgomery, and the proclamation summoning the Convention for January appeared. The business of appointing Commissioners to confer with other Southern States immediately devolved upon the State Executive; and, as if to check the too rapid growth of ultraism, the Governor selected three gentlemen for the duty, whose Yanceyism is far below the requirements of the occasion. Messrs. WINSTON, HOPKINS and SMITH have heretofore declined to identify themselves with the radicals. The two former were active throughout the recent Presidential conflict in their endeavors to defeat the secession faction. The latter has just offered to the people of Alabama, and to the rest of the Gulf States, the most able and sensible argument against the expediency of secession which has thus far been submitted to them.

abstract: Under date of Dec. 17, Ex-Gov. WICKLIFFE, of Kentucky, writes to the Louisville Democrat, giving his views of the course which should be pursued toward South Carolina. In the event of declaring herself out of the Union, which she has now done, he recommends that the law establishing her ports of entry should be repealed, and that the revenue laws of the ...
lead_paragraph: Under date of Dec. 17, Ex-Gov. WICKLIFFE, of Kentucky, writes to the Louisville Democrat, giving his views of the course which should be pursued toward South Carolina. In the event of declaring herself out of the Union, which she has now done, he recommends that the law establishing her ports of entry should be repealed, and that the revenue laws of the United States should still be vigilantly exercised -- no vessel, foreign or domestic, being allowed to enter or depart from her ports. Then, if she opposes Congress in establishing judicial districts in the State and her citizens refuse to fill the offices of judge and marshal, abolish the district by law, and attach the territory to some other neighboring judicial, district. If she desires no postal facilities of the United States, abolish the post-offices and withdraw the service. If he will send no Senators or Representatives to Congress, let her alone -- the Government can get along without their services in Congress. Apply these same remedies to each seceding State. This is making no war upon a State or upon its citizens -- it necessarily does not involve the shedding of human blood.

abstract: FORT SCOTT, Tuesday, Dec. 4, 1860. The saying is an old one, that man is the crea  ture of circumstances. Never was that fact made more clear and emphatic, than it now is, by changing my position from Linn County to Fort Scott. I here inhale a different atmosphere, and find the public  sentiment in a great degree changed.
lead_paragraph: FORT SCOTT, Tuesday, Dec. 4, 1860.

abstract: For nearly four  months, tragedy, which it was supposed had no more interest for the New-York public, has reigned triumphant in the New-York theatres. The opera, the pet amusement of the Metropolis, hides its diminished head, and the town goes to Niblo's and the Winter Garden.
lead_paragraph: For nearly four months, tragedy, which it was supposed had no more interest for the New-York public, has reigned triumphant in the New-York theatres. The opera, the pet amusement of the Metropolis, hides its diminished head, and the town goes to Niblo's and the Winter Garden. Mr. FORREST begun to play in September, and has not got done yet; his houses have frequently been large, and his audiences appreciative; at times people of Catholic taste have mingled with the spectators, and acknowledged what of good they discerned amid a mass of faults. For two months Miss CUSHMAN attracted people to the Winter Garden by her intellectual and artistic personations of Shakespearean characters, and her wonderful performance of Meg Merrilies. And now, the entire educated and fashionable circles of the Metropolis are sounding the praises of EDWIN BOOTH, who has won a more brilliant and more legitimate dramatic success than any actor on the New-York stage for years.

abstract: Among things that may be fitly and agreeably given, especially in Holiday times, books are the best. A book may express, as the giver desires, the most delicate shade of sentiment, the highest esteem, the kindliest wish, or the warmest hope, and in point of expense there is scarcely a limit in either direction; and, of course, booksellers ...
lead_paragraph: Among things that may be fitly and agreeably given, especially in Holiday times, books are the best. A book may express, as the giver desires, the most delicate shade of sentiment, the highest esteem, the kindliest wish, or the warmest hope, and in point of expense there is scarcely a limit in either direction; and, of course, booksellers are all awake to the fact that the Christmas time, the great opener of hearts, is also a loosener of purse-strings.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 21. The TIMES dispatch stating that if the Forts  at Charleston should be attacked, they would be surrendered under the orders of the Government, created a good deal of interest here. That such orders have been issued cannot, of course, be positively known,-- but I have a good grounds for believing that they have, and I am quite willing to rely upon the event to bear me out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Friday, Dec. 21.

abstract: James Dillon, one of the crew of the ship Wm. F. Storer, who, with several others, was convicted of a violent revolt on board her in the harbor of NewYork, but who was not sentenced with the rest, he being at the time in the hospital from the effect of wounds received in the affray, having now recovered, was brought up for sentence.
lead_paragraph: James Dillon, one of the crew of the ship Wm.F. Storer, who, with several others, was convicted of a violent revolt on board her in the harbor of New-York, but who was not sentenced with the rest, he being at the time in the hospital from the effect of wounds received in the affray, having now recovered, was brought up for sentence. The prisoner was asked if he had anything to say why he should not be sentenced. He spoke of his having been severely injured in the affray and his sufferings, as a reason why he should be treated with some leniency.
