abstract: A venerable and well-known citizen of Virginia, residing in the county of Ritchie, has written to apprize us of a movement which, he says, is already set on foot in the northwestern part of that State, for the purpose of calling a Convention of the people to take into consideration the expediency of separating from Virginia in case of her withdrawing from the Union to join in the formation of a Southern Confederacy. Our informant adds that the leaders in this revolutionary scheme contemplate the erection of a new State, embracing that portion of Virginia lying west of the Blue Ridge, and destined to include as many counties east of said line, along the upper Potomac and near it, as may be induced, by identity of interest, to cooperate in the project. Considerations of an economical character, determined partly by the arrangements of the present Constitution of Virginia, (deemed by many in the western part of the State to be unequal in respect to the rates and objects of taxation,) are represented to be at the bottom of this popular movement, which, in the opinion of our correspondent, awaits only the opportunity and the pretext to assume formidable proportions.
lead_paragraph: A venerable and well-known citizen of Virginia, residing in the county of Ritchie, has written to apprize us of a movement which, he says, is already set on foot in the northwestern part of that State, for the purpose of calling a Convention of the people to take into consideration the expediency of separating from Virginia in case of her withdrawing from the Union to join in the formation of a Southern Confederacy. Considerations of an economical character, determined partly by the arrangements of the present Constitution of Virginia, (deemed by many in the western part of the State to be unequal in respect to the rates and objects of taxation,) are represented to be at the bottom of this popular movement, which, in the opinion of our correspondent, awaits only the opportunity and the pretext to assume formidable proportions.

abstract: A story had currency on 'Change yesterday, that South Carolina had not only set up as a sovereign but had gone into business as a Cotton broker. Eager to carry her planters through the crisis with safety to them and profit to herself, the Government, it was stated, entertained a plan for issuing bonds to a fabulous extent, with which to buy up the entire crop of Cotton in the State, paying for it at the market rate, less fifteen per cent. on the face of security. This fifteen per cent., it is said to have been argued, would enable the State to store the Cotton, augment the price by controlling the supply, and select, which is the important point, an unoffending customer. A margin would also be left for profit.
lead_paragraph: A story had currency on 'Change yesterday, that South Carolina had not only set up as a sovereign but had gone into business as a Cotton broker. abstract: The following promotions have been made to date, from Oct. 17, 1860, the date of Gen. CLARKE's death: Lieut-Col. Washington Seawell, Eighth Infantry, to be Colonel Sixth Infantry; First-Lieut. Edward D. Blake, Eighth Infantry, to be Captain; Second-Lieut. Zenas R. Bliss, Eighth Infantry, to be First-Lieutenant; Capt. James V. Bomford, Eighth Infantry, to be Major Sixth Infantry; Major William Hoffman, Sixth Infantry, to be Lieutenant-Colonel Eighth Infantry. And to date from Oct. 30, 1860 Brevet-Second-Lieut John R.B. Burtwell, First Cavalry, to be Second-Lieutenant, vice Church, resigned.

abstract: The announcement that the Allied army has entered Peking, realizes the expectation of all who have watched the progress of the present China war. We have not yet received any particulars of this important event. A telegram briefly and simply states that the city was captured--that the Emperor fled--and that his palace was sacked; and from these ...
lead_paragraph: The announcement that the Allied army has entered Peking, realizes the expectation of all who have watched the progress of the present China war. We have not yet received any particulars of this important event. A telegram briefly and simply states that the city was captured--that the Emperor fled--and that his palace was sacked; and from these facts we infer that the Chinese did not abandon their Capital without a struggle. There is no probability, however, that the resistance was a desperate or a bloody one. The Tartar cavalry have demonstrated their utter inability, though ten times superior in numbers, to stand before European troops. At Taku only the Chinese made even a respectable resistance, and after that defeat, knowing well that Peking was in a defenceless condition, they should have accepted the terms of their conquerors.

abstract: Public attention has, of late years, been directed to the obvious advantages arising from the entrance of woman into the profession of medicine, and every day increases the number among us of those who wish to devote themselves to this department of science. The tide which they have so long been obliged to stem, now sets in their favor.
lead_paragraph: Public attention has, of late years, been directed to the obvious advantages arising from the entrance of woman into the profession of medicine, and every day increases the number among us of those who wish to devote themselves to this department of science. The tide which they have so long been obliged to stem, now sets in their favor. We rejoice in the increasing popularity of this noble work, as a token of the world's progress; but while we do so, we should not forget the pioneers in the field, who have struggled in the past untiringly, through the obstacles which prejudice has thrown in their way, and whose heroic exertions have effected the change fat public opinion. Conspicuous among the number stands Mrs. WINSLOW, who for more than thirty years as nurse and physician, has followed her profession with unflagging application and industry. During this time she has compounded a Soothing Syrup, for children teething, which ought to immortalize her name. It is the most perfect thing of the kind, in our opinion, ever compounded, and one of the greatest discoveries in medicine of the age; it is of more importance to the human family than any other discovery made by the profession in the last hundred years. Common observation cannot fail to satisfy all who will take the trouble to look into the bills of mortality for any one year, that a very large percentage of children annually die during the process of teething, and a very much larger number of those who survive are greatly debilitated or diseased, so that they grow up weak both physically and mentally, and incapacitated both for study and labor. Now, we appeal with perfect confidence to thousands of mothers who will read this article, to corroborate our statement when we say that no such fatal consequences as those we have alluded to, ever occur from teething, when Mrs. WINSLOW's Soothing syrup is used IN TIME. That it is just the article needed is the testimony which reaches us daily from those who have tried it, and until some member of the Faculty can produce an article which shall equal in excellence the result of the long experience of a Female Physician, we hope we shall hear no more of woman's overstepping her sphere in entering the medical profession. -- Drawing-room Companion, N.Y.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge BALCOM, counsel for James Massy, indicted for felonious assault on a Police Officer, stated that his client had not left the country permanently, but had only gone to New-Jersey to attend a prize fight. He did not intend to shrink from a trial, and would be ready on Monday, for which day the case was therefore set down.
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Judge BALCOM, counsel for James Massy, indicted for felonious assault on a Police Officer, stated that his client had not left the country permanently, but had only gone to New-Jersey to attend a prize fight. He did not intend to shrink from a trial, and would be ready on Monday, for which day the case was therefore set down. In the event of his appearance at that time the forfeiture of his ball, which was entered on his default a few days since, will probably be reversed.

abstract: In common with many lovers of the beautiful and masterly in Art, we have been charmed with the exquhite picture of "Cinderella" and her scornful sisters by VAN LERIUS, which is now on exhibition at the rooms of SCHAUS, on Broadway. The old story, in which our youthful imagination used to revel, and which inspired in us an early love for poor shoeless maidens, and a hearty contempt for haughty unkind sisters, is faithfully depicted by the artist, who wields a master's pencil, and who, for boldness of touch, elaboration of detail, felicitous blending of positive color and judicious use of natural tints, is deserving of the highest commendation. No picture has been for a long time exhibited in New-York which is so admirably adapted to please the public artistic eye as this, and we are glad to learn that Mr. SCHATUS declines to sell it, preferring to retain it, as a permanent and atractive feature to his already popular gallery.

abstract: It will be seen by our telegraphic dispatches that another slaver, the Bonita, has been captured by the San Jacinto frigate, and taken into Charleston. Under any circumstances Charleston does not seem to be just the place to take persons for trial charged with Slave-trading. But now that South Carolina considers herself out of the Union, she will not be very likely to enforce the Federal laws which prohibit the importation of negroes. We suggest to the President that if he desires the law enforced, he would do well to send the slaver to Boston. If he wishes it evaded, send her here; if defied, leave her at Charleston.

abstract: THE COURTS. -- In the Kings County Court of Sessions, on Thursday, Judge GARRISON sentenced FRANK DAILEY and BARNEY VICTORY, convicted of highway robbery, each to ten years and four months' imprisonment in the State Prison at Sing Sing. DAILEY is 21 years old, a native of New-York City, and never had any regular legitimate occupation. VICTORY is 21 years old, native of Ireland, and a cooper by trade. Both are single. RICHARD SHORTALL, convicted of forgery in the second degree, was sentenced to five years and four months' imprisonment in the State Prison at Sing Sing. EDWARD TRACEY and OLIVER MCGUIRE, who were to have been tried yesterday for a similar offence, absented themselves and forfeited their bail.

abstract: Yesterday the new crew and officers for the United States corvette St. Marys, of the Pacific Squadron, left in the California steamer. The St. Marys has been about two years in commission. She is a first-class corvette, 958 tons burthen, and carries 22 guns. At last advices she had arrived at Panama. Her old officers and crew will return in a few weeks, but the exciting state of political affairs renders their discharge improbable. At present tried men seem to be in demand.

abstract: We translate and publish else  where, from the Paris journal La Presse, an article on the political troubles in the United States, which all who are committed to disunion would do well to read and consider.
lead_paragraph: We translate and publish elsewhere, from the Paris journal La Presse, an article on the political troubles in the United States, which all who are committed to disunion would do well to read and consider. The article contains many truths, and evinces a perception of the danger and ruin into which the Secessionists are hurrying the country, that they themselves have utterly failed to realize.

abstract: The South Carolina Convention spent most of their time yesterday in secret session, one of the matters under consideration being the appointment of three Commissioners to proceed to Washington to negotiate an arrangement of postal affairs and other essential points with the Administration.
lead_paragraph: The South Carolina Convention spent most of their time yesterday in secret session, one of the matters under consideration being the appointment of three Commissioners to proceed to Washington to negotiate an arrangement of postal affairs and other essential points with the Administration. It was understood, that R.W. BARNWELL was elected on the first ballot, and that Messrs. MAGRATH and ORE stood the best chance for the other two places. Mr. RHETT, from the Committee appointed to prepare an address to the Southern people, made a report, which was ordered to be printed, and it was made the special order for to-day. The fourth article of the Constitution of South Carolina, which embodies the form of oath to be taken by all officials in the State, was amended by an ordinance reported from the Committee appointed for the purpose, so as to exclude all allusion to the Government of the United States. The Legislature, which is also in session at Charleston, yesterday changed the name of the Committee on Federal Relations to the "Committee on Foreign Relations," and appointed a Committee to report a style of National flag. Gen. CUSHING is reported to have arrived in Charleston on Thursday night, and to have remained five hours, when he started on his return to Washington. The nature of his mission is a matter of considerable speculation.

abstract: -- On Saturday last the Court of General Sessions reached the end of the final term in the year, and adjourned without day. The presence of a very full bar, in attendance for arguing motions, presented a provoking opportunity for a somewhat formal leave-taking by the retiring Castor and Pollux of our criminal Judiciary. The City Recorder and the City Judge were both upon the Bench; before leaving which, the former, acting as common spokesman, after alluding to the kindly relations that had existed between the occupants of the Bench and the other officers of the Court, declared that although both of their retiring Honors had administered justice impartially, and tempered it with precisely the proper alloy of mercy, there had not been wanting those who imputed many of their acts to motives of dishonesty and corruption; while to such a pass of insolence had the public Press arrived, that it had so far doubted the profound learning and integrity of the upright Court as to venture criticism upon its acts from time to time, or, as the learned Recorder expressed it, "the Press had re-tried and re-sentenced prisoners whese cases he had already disposed of."
lead_paragraph: -- On Saturday last the Court of General Sessions reached the end of the final term in the year, and adjourned without day. abstract: His Honor the Mayor was on Saturday united to Miss MILLS in the bonds of matrimony, and immediately after the ceremony started on a Southern tour. Mr. PECK will act as his locum tenens during his absence, and in case he should not return before New-Year's. The official seat will be temporarily filled by Alderman H.W. GENET, who has been selected as the successor of Mr. PECK, the present presiding officer of the Board of Aldermen.

abstract: Mrs. Jane Sparks, a widow, residing at No. 645 Greenwich-st., presented herself at the Jefferson Market Police Court, on Saturday, and acknowledged herself the unfortunate loser of $1,500 in bank notes, adding her suspicion that Mary Moran, her maid of all work had stolen the money. The fair complainant was told by Justice DUSENBERRY to make an affidavit of the circumstances connected with the loss, and if her suspicions against Miss Moran seemed well-founded, a warrant should be issued for her arrest. With many blushes, much hesitation, and becoming modesty, the widow confessed to a weakness she had of concealing her money in out-of the-way places, with the object of securing it from thieves. In the instance under consideration the missing bank notes -being a $1,00 and $500 bill on the Chemical Bank. this City -- had been sewed fast by her own hand to the innermost of all the garments that she wore, where it remained for days untouched by the light fingers of dexterous pickpockets. Finally, however, that quality which the widow had been taught was next to godliness demanded that the garment should be placed in the hands of the laundress, and it was thrown carelessly into the clothes basket, without a thought having been given to the removal of the money. When next the complainant saw the linen it was drily flaunting upon a line in the yard, and as soon as she had seen it, her carelessness flashed upon her mind. An examination showed, however, that both bank notes were missing, and as Mary was the only person who had handled the garment suspicion naturally attached to her. The magistrate thought there was ground for the suspicion, and issued a warrant for the arrest of the accused, who was held for trial, notwithstanding her protestations of innocence.

abstract: MORTALITY. There were 110 deaths in this City last week, classified as follows: Men, 13; women, 48; boys, 41; girls, 38; adults, 31; children,  79. Males, 54; females, 56; colored persons, 1. There were 24 deaths by fever, 19 of which were scarlet; 14 by consumption; 10 by inflammation of the lungs; croup and convulsions, 6 each, 61 were under 5 years ...
lead_paragraph: MORTALITY. -- There were 110 deaths in this City last week, classified as follows: Men, 13; women, 48; boys, 41; girls, 38; adults, 31; children, 79. Males, 54; females, 56; colored persons, 1. There were 24 deaths by fever, 19 of which were scarlet; 14 by consumption; 10 by inflammation of the lungs; croup and convulsions, 6 each, 61 were under 5 years of age, and 89 were natives of the United States. The deaths occurred in the several Wards as follows: First Ward, 2; Second Ward, 7; Third Ward, 3; Fourth Ward, [???]; Fifth Ward, 7; Sixth Ward, 17; Seventh Ward, 7; Eighth Ward, 2; Ninth Ward, 7; Tenth Ward, 13; Eleventh Ward, 9; Twelfth Ward, 8; Thirteenth Ward, 3; Fourteenth Ward, 8; Fifteenth Ward, 2; Sixteenth Ward, 9; Seventeenth Ward, 2; Eighteenth Ward, none; Nineteenth Ward, 3.

abstract: Last night, about 10 o'clock, Capt. HELME, of the Eighth Ward Police, supported by a strong force of patrolmen, went to the lager-beer saloon No. 5 Macdougal-street, kept by ANTONIO D. GILL, and effected the arrest of thirty-six Italians, men and women, whose offence consisted in dancing, wine-drinking and acting otherwise in a manner subversive of public morality. The sudden irruption of the Police afforded no opportunity for the male prisoners, all of whom were armed with knives, to resist the attack. Having been led into the street, all the offenders were marched to the Station-house between a double file of officers, and locked up for the night. A large number of women, who also were found in the saloon, were permitted, by the Police, to go home, in pity for the little children who were with them. The adjoining saloon No. 7 Macdugal-st. was also visited, and when the officers entered. they caught seven men engaged in gambling with dice. They were all apprehended, and with GIO BATTA BARCIGALOGO, the bar-keeper, conducted to the lock-up. The large number of arrests drew a large crowd about the Police Station, and occasioned much excitement in the Ward. JOHN HOWE and PATER DUMAS, respectively, bar-keepers at Lafayette Hall and the Mercer House, were likewise taken into custody for violating the Sunday Liquor Law. While the Eighth Ward Police were thus engaged, their colleagues in the Fourth Ward were not idle. Captain PALMER invaded the noisy precincts of William-street with a brave little army, and first paid his respects to the persons in the billiard, been, and dance saloon Nos. 123 and 125 William street, where L. PERJER, M. NICHT, G.C. HART. GEORGE DEDART, and J. HOLLACHER were caught in unlawful acts and taken in. A number of similar places in the neighborhood were also open for the dance, but as soon as the proprietors learned what the police were doing at their neighbors, they put out their lights and shut up in a hurry. The total number of arrests yesterday for selling liquors was 28, and of intoxicated persons 29 -- being about the average number since the attempt at enforcing the law was inaugurated.

abstract: -- The President's Washington organ pronounces the Conkle letter a forgery. We presume that settles the matter. But the Constitution is very much mistaken in saying that we indorsed the letter as genuine. We did nothing of the sort. We only said that it read like a genuine, -- that its sentiments were precisely the same as Mr. BUCHANAN had expressed in his Message, and that if intrinsic evidence alone were to be relied on, it would be pronounced genuine: and we say so now. We defy the Constitution to point out a sentiment or an opinion in it, which is not also fairly expressed or implied in the Message.
lead_paragraph: -- The President's Washington organ pronounces the Conkle letter a forgery. We presume that settles the matter. But the Constitution is very much mistaken in saying that we indorsed the letter as genuine. We did nothing of the sort. We only said that it read like a genuine, -- that its sentiments were precisely the same as Mr. BUCHANAN had expressed in his Message, and that if intrinsic evidence alone were to be relied on, it would be pronounced genuine: and we say so now. We defy the Constitution to point out a sentiment or an opinion in it, which is not also fairly expressed or implied in the Message.

abstract: The discussions in the Charleston Convention, subsequent to the adoption of the secession ordinance, as well as those which immediately preceded that event, show that the leaders of that movement are at last beginning to appreciate the difficulties into which they have precipitated the State. The speech of Chancellor DUNKIN on Wednesday shows that one man at least saw the yawning gulf before the fatal plunge was made, but, swept ...
lead_paragraph: The discussions in the Charleston Convention, subsequent to the adoption of the secession ordinance, as well as those which immediately preceded that event, show that the leaders of that movement are at last beginning to appreciate the difficulties into which they have precipitated the State. The speech of Chancellor DUNKIN on Wednesday shows that one man at least saw the yawning gulf before the fatal plunge was made, but, swept on by the rushing tide, he made no effort to avert the impending catastrophe. He nevertheless told some wholesome truths to his colleagues of the Convention, the echoes of which seem to have made an impression -when it was too late. He told that body that, if the act of secession were to have the effect of turning the Collector of the Customs out of office, no vessel could leave Charleston freighted with Cotton or other products of the State, except at the risk of being seized as a pirate by the navies of the world; and hence, the commerce and business of the State would be paralyzed, and the people ruined. The resignation of the Postmasters, or the annullment of their official power by the act of secession, would in like manner, he said, seriously derange business by destroying the postal system. In this connection he aptly quoted a saying of MIRABEAU, that "the fiercest insurrections were those which arose from the stomach." "People without bread," he continued, "won't hear reason; their patriotism is dead. And he thus spoke of the effect of such a state of things on the public in South Carolina and other States:

abstract: An entertainment of an entirely novel character is a thing so seldom enjoyed in New-York, that we feel much pleasure in calling attention to the debuts of the "Zouaves" on Saturday night at Niblo's Garden. The Zouaves it must be premised are veritable braves of the French army, and owe their present positions to an accidental talent discovered before the walls of Sebastopol, and since cultivated to a point of great excellence. Their piece, the "Fille Terrible" was first acted in the Crimea, and during the performance the Russians it is said made a sortie which compelled actors and audience to take to their arms. One of the former dressed in female attire was killed, and others, including some members of the present company, severely wounded. Incidents of this exciting kind brought the Theatre d'Inkerman prominently before the public, and when the war terminated there was a natural desire among civilians to see the men who could thus amuse others in the face of death. A prosperous career in France, and a repetition of the same in London, have brought the Zouaves to our shores, where the name, at least, is popular at this moment; whether the entertainment will be equally so, remains to be seen. The pieces played by our French friends are of the slightest possible character, and for that reason are eminently amusing and laughable. It is known, of course, that the female parts are played by men, but without witnessing a performance, it is impossible to believe how well and ludicrously the external characteristics of the sex are mimicked. The entertainment, indeed, is of so peculiar a kind, that we feel no disposition to indulge in critical elucidation, but simply to direct the attention of the public to its abundant novelty and agreeableness. The Zouaves will play to-morrow. To-night Mr. FORREST repeats his performance of "Richard the Third."

abstract: The President's proclamation, recommending a day of fasting and humiliation in view of the National crisis, has not met with that ready and universal response from State and Municipal authorities which such invocations are accustomed to receive. Even Mayor WOOD, who, with his usual perspicacity, ...
lead_paragraph: The President's proclamation, recommending a day of fasting and humiliation in view of the National crisis, has not met with that ready and universal response from State and Municipal authorities which such invocations are accustomed to receive. Even Mayor WOOD, who, with his usual perspicacity, might have been expected to find some ground of thankfulness in this dispensation, as he found tears for the season of thanksgiving, has furnished no recognition of the National Fast; and there is much reason to fear that so much of our population as are known to net only on the promptings of his Honor, may inadvertently extend the festivities of the New Year even to the day consecrated to mortification. It is not too late, perhaps, to invite the attention of the Mayor to the subject.

abstract: Mr. SEWARD happened to drop in at the New-England dinner on Saturday night, and was of course called on for a speech. He made one -- and in the course of it touched at length on the subject of secession -- without, however, throwing much light on the present state of that rather complicated question. He did say that he was opposed to any compromises on which New-York and Pennsylvania could not stand together -- and he also expressed the opinion that there would be no secession, because no State could be so well off out of the Union as she is in it. And he thought also that the secession feeling in the South was less marked and decided now than it was a month ago.
lead_paragraph: Mr. SEWARD happened to drop in at the New-England dinner on Saturday night, and was of course called on for a speech. He did say that he was opposed to any compromises on which New-York and Pennsylvania could not stand together -- and he also expressed the opinion that there would be no secession, because no State could be so well off out of the Union as she is in it. And he thought also that the secession feeling in the South was less marked and decided now than it was a month ago.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington indicate very little progress towards an understanding among the members of the Senate Special Committee, which would be likely to lead to an amicable arrangement of the pending difficulties. The Committee had a meeting on Saturday, at which various propositions offered by Senator CRITTENDEN were discussed and rejected.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington indicate very little progress towards an understanding among the members of the Senate Special Committee, which would be likely to lead to an amicable arrangement of the pending difficulties. The Committee had a meeting on Saturday, at which various propositions offered by Senator CRITTENDEN were discussed and rejected. The Democratic members of the Committee being in a majority, it was agreed that no project should be adopted and reported which did not receive the unanimous sanction of the Republican members, -- consequently, although another meeting will be held to-day, there is very little likelihood that anything will be agreed upon. The failure of the Committee to agree will probably be reported to the Senate to-day, when Mr. TOOMBS, it is understood, will make a speech in violent denunciation of the Republican Party, and repudiating any further efforts at reconciliation. He last night telegraphed to his constituents that he considered further attempts to arrive at an amicable understanding useless, and advising secession certainly by the 4th of March.

abstract: A few years ago the only mode of getting the produce of the Western States to market was to float it by its own gravity down the Mississippi. To give us the free use of this river and its outlet, and to avoid a constant source of bickering and quarrel with a foreign Power, the territory of Louisiana was purchased. But this did not accomplish all that was needed.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago the only mode of getting the produce of the Western States to market was to float it by its own gravity down the Mississippi. To give us the free use of this river and its outlet, and to avoid a constant source of bickering and quarrel with a foreign Power, the territory of Louisiana was purchased. But this did not accomplish all that was needed. The consumers of this produce lay to the northeast, rendering necessary a circuit of some four thousand miles to reach districts separated only by as many hundreds. The people of our own State, consequently, set to work to open another outlet for the great valley -- in effect to turn its great river into their own magnificent harbor. With this view the Erie Canal was constructed; a work of small capacity in the outset, but still sufficient to accomplish vast results, instantly reducing the cost of transporting a ton of merchandise from Buffalo to New-York from $100 to $15.

abstract: State Bank of New-Brunswick vs. Mettler et al. -- This cause was referred by consent of parties. The cause was tried before a Referee in 1854, and decided in favor of the plaintiff. An appeal from his decision was taken to the General Term of this Court and reversed. It was then sent back to him for a new trial, and under the decision of the Court he found for the defendants. The Court of Appeals reversed the decision eventually, and the plaintiffs now appeal from the order of the Special Term, referring the case. The respondents move to dismiss this appeal, on the ground that such an order is not appealable, and in support of the motion counsel cites section 349 of the Code; Perry vs. Moore, 2 E.D. Smith, 32; 3d Code R., 221. Decision reserved.
lead_paragraph: State Bank of New-Brunswick vs. Mettler et al. -- This cause was referred by consent of parties. The cause was tried before a Referee in 1854, and decided in favor of the plaintiff. Smith, 32; 3d Code R., 221. Decision reserved.

abstract: The United States brig-of-war Dolphin, as announced by telegraph, arrived at Norfolk on Sunday, from the coast of Brazil. The Dolphin is the last vessel of the Paraguay Expedition to go out of commission. She left Norfolk in the Winter of 1858, and in a week after joined Com. SHUBRICK's fleet in La Plata, where she has spent the greater part of her cruise. Her service in South America was not characterized by any extraordinary circumstance. When the St. Lawrence returned to the United States she had the wide flag of the squadron, which was subsequently turned over to the Congress. The Dolphin is the smallest vessel in the regular Navy, being only 224 tons burden, and carrying four guns. She will probably be retained in service condition, until political matters begin to look brighter. Her Commander, CHAS. STEDMAN, may be superseded, in deference to his South Carolinian origin. He is known to be a Union man, however, and no one expects that he will resign. There are about 100 men on board the Dolphin. Her officers are as follows: Cum. C.H. Stedman; Lieuts. L. Paulding, E.P. Williams and C.W. Fluper: Passed Assistant-Surgeon, John Y. Taylor.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution was adopted authorizing John T. Mills, proprietor of the Bull's Head line of stages, to terminate his route down town at the lower end of the Park, instead of at Fulton Ferry, as at present. Alderman STARR stated that this would be a great accommodation to the working classes, as the fare in these stages is but three cents, and few passengers desired to ride in them to or from Fulton Ferry.

abstract: We regret to announce that the Supreme Court has determined to inflict the penalty of death upon the Judges of the Superior Court. Hopes of some mitigation of this dreadful sentence have been entertained. Application was made, a fortnight since, to the Common Council, that it should interpose to save these innocent gentlemen, and it is due to the Corporation to say that it made some, though no very strenuous effort, to defeat, the design of the sanguinary tribunal. But the sanguinary tribunal defied the Common Council, and shut a metaphorical door of escape in the very faces of its victims, and there now seems to be no outlet for the unhappy condemned. They are to perish by suffocation and poison.

abstract: Edward H. Maxwell vs. Ben. Wood. -- This is the action growing out of the alleged sale of the one-half interest in the Daily News of this City to the Hon. Benjamin Wood. The particulars of the action were stated at length in the TIMES of Saturday, at which time it was set down for trial on Monday. Upon calling the case, however, the Court suggested that as its trial involved the adjustment of a long and complicated account, it was a proper case for reference, which was ordered.

abstract: -- The January number of this periodical maintains its excellent character. The leading article on Washoe -- second of the series -- is by Mr. J. ROSS BROWNZ, and describes Life in California. and Oregon: The illustrations are lively and characteristic and display decided force and talent, as do also those in the article on Jamaica. This number of Harper is prolific in good pictures, for there is an average of a wood-cut to each of its first forty pages. In the way of travels we have, besides the paper on Washoe a fresh article on Jamaica, and Mr. MEACH[???]'s "New Route through Chiriqui" -- a subject of much interest at the present time. Poesy is fairly represented, particularly in the "Battle of the Cowpens," and there are the usual number of readable stories and condensations of new books. The last is an important feature in Harper. There are many books that contain considerable information, but are too prolix for popular reading. The condenser performs the arduous duty of transforming an unreadable volume into an inviting article, and the manufacturing process is very successfully performed for the pages of Harper's Magazine. The regular departments of the Magazine -- the "Monthly Record," the "Editor's Table," the "Editor's Easy Chair," "Our Foreign Bureau," and "the Drawer" -- are conducted with judgment and ability, and aid in making this periodical most popular among the masses of the American people of all sections of the country.

abstract: It is a fact perhaps not often considered, that nearly all of the world's capital is being expended in facilitating locomotion. If we think of the immense amounts all the time spent in the improvements of rivers; harbors, canals, docks, shipping, bridges, roads, railways, vehicles and the like, we readily see what at first would not seem true. Nearly all the public (and much of the private) money of the world goes to locomotion.

abstract: On Saturday  last the body of a peddler, named "JAKE," was found in the woods, near the Calvary Cemetery, in Queens County. The skull of deceased was fractured, and there were other injuries about the body indicating that a murder had been committed. Coroner HIGBIE, of Astoria, took possession of the body, and will hold an inquest on Friday next.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge BALCOM, Morlinier Shay, indicted for the murder of John Leary, pleaded guilty of manslaughter in the first degree. The prisoner was convicted of murder several months ago, and subsequently obtained from the Court of Appeals a new trial, upon the same ground as that on which a like action in the Hartung case was had, which was the retroactive force of the statute of last Winter. The prisoner, on pleading as above, was remanded till Wednesday for sentence.

abstract: -- At 8 1/2 o'clock last evening, a fire was discovered on the premises of E. DREW, dealer in variety goods, on the third floor of No. 327 Broadway. By the prompt action of the firemen, the flames were prevented from extending much beyond the place of their origin, though considerable damage was done by water. The loss upon Mr. DREW's stock is about $500; insured. Mr. MCDONALD, dealer in fancy goods, who occupied the rear part of the third floor, suffered a loss of $300; insured. The second floor was occupied by RYDER & DITTENHOETER, dealers in silks, and their stock was damaged to the extent of about $800: insured. The stock in the tailor's store on the first floor was slightly damaged by water. It will require about $300 to repair the building. The fire was evidently the work of an incendiary -- the Fire Marshal having discovered two places which exhibited undoubted proof that the fire had been designedly kindled.

By the prompt action of the firemen, the flames were prevented from extending much beyond the place of their origin, though considerable damage was done by water. The loss upon Mr. DREW's stock is about $500; insured. Mr. MCDONALD, dealer in fancy goods, who occupied the rear part of the third floor, suffered a loss of $300; insured. The second floor was occupied by RYDER & DITTENHOETER, dealers in silks, and their stock was damaged to the extent of about $800: insured. The stock in the tailor's store on the first floor was slightly damaged by water. It will require about $300 to repair the building. The fire was evidently the work of an incendiary -- the Fire Marshal having discovered two places which exhibited undoubted proof that the fire had been designedly kindled.

abstract: -- Our neighbors of England are not fortunate in the matter of their coinage. It is but a few years since an immense issue of two-shilling pieces had to be recalled from circulation in consequence of the Mint-master's having omitted the letters "D.G." between the words "Victoria" and "Regina." The religious portion of the community became extremely excited upon the point, attributing the absence of any reference to the "Grace of God," in connection with the Queen's titles, to a deliberate purpose of infidelity -- a design to ignore Divine Providence as the fountain-head of all royal rights. The high-tory party took high ground against the continued issue of any such heathen circulating medium; and finally, after a protracted struggle, is which Punch and Parliament bore the most prominent parts, the new florins were recalled for a fresh mintage, and reissued with the letters "D.G." duly embossed on their shining and two-shilling faces.

abstract: In consequence of information elicited in Washington, Officer ALLEN came on to this City on Sunday in pursuit of the person alleged to be implicated in the wholesale plunder of the public funds. On his arrival he immediately communicated with the United States Marshal, exhibiting a requisition from the authorities of the District of Columbia. Steps were immediately taken to secure the arrest of the accused, who, it was ascertained, was stopping at the Everett House. United States Commissioner BETTS issued his warrant, and early yesterday morning the officers found the person they were in pursuit of. Mr. WM.H. RUSSELL, who was about leaving his hotel. He was conveyed to the Marshal's office in a carriage, and on application Judge BETTS signed the order for the delivery of the accused to the authorities of the District of Columbia. He was conveyed to Washington yesterday afternoon, in the custody of Mr. ALLEN, and one of the Assistant United States Marshals. Mr. RUSSELL, it is well known, has been a large contractor for conveying Indian supplies across the plains. He says he knows nothing about the defalcation.

abstract: WINTER-GARDEN. -- A new version of the immortal "Rip Van Winkle" was produced here last evening, and introduced Mr. JEFFERSON in the questionable character of "a star." It seems but the other day that we gave welcome to this gentleman as a desirable addition to Miss LAURA KEENE's Theatre, and now we find him alone and cold, and over-wrought, going through, the egotisms of a star engagement. He who was the spice of an evening's entertainment, has thus become the solid meat thereof, and is, we are bound to add, a little tough. Comedians seldom succeed as stars, and the reason is found not in the want of appreciation of fun on the part of the audience, but in the fact that the situations which cause that fun cannot be piled on one man's shoulders. A moment's reflection will convince us that in his new character Mr. JEFFERSON is incapable of reviving any pleasant souvenirs of his former triumphs; hence the necessity for a piece like "Rip Van Winkle," which is in a way now, and demands but a single actor and a variety of supernumeraries. Of its kind it is good enough, but we object to its kind, and regret the occasion which has brought Mr. JEFFERSON from the enviable position of the first stock actor of the Metropolis to the "lower range of feeling" of a more comic star. His performance last evening was as good as any man could make it, but the applause was hollow, and will not, we fear, contribute to the fortunes of the engagement. The piece is well put on the stage, and whatever the result, no one can question Mr. JACKSON's judgment in giving us a short holiday taste of merriment after so long a supper of tragic horrors.

abstract: We are now trying the strength of our Government in its weakest point the Federal Executive. All the Republics of North and South America, based on the model of our own, have, for want of an efficient central power to command respect and enforce obedience, sunk into anarchy, and become a prey to civil wars with no prospect of termination but the extinction of the race. They com- ...
lead_paragraph: We are now trying the strength of our Government in its weakest point -- the Federal Executive. All the Republics of North and South America, based on the model of our own, have, for want of an efficient central power to command respect and enforce obedience, sunk into anarchy, and become a prey to civil wars with no prospect of termination but the extinction of the race. They commenced their career by the refusal of the States to respect and obey the organic law for the whole country. One step was followed by another till, at last, all ties of social organization has become dissolved. The person is no longer protected. Property is seized with impunity by the strongest. Even those who by lucky accident happen to wield the little central power remaining, and who should vindicate and maintain the laws, subsist upon spoliation and plunder. Neither individuals nor communities can be relied on for the discharge of any duty. The sense of common danger or of present or prospective advantage is no longer a motive to action. In fine, in our sister Republics, society seems to be reduced to its chaotic state, without the power of reconstruction, save under the hand of a skillful and energetic despot, who can make his own will the law and rule for the people.

abstract: Our readers probably remember the general interest excited three years ago by the mysterious disappearance of young DE FORREST from the Metropolital Hotel, -- and the utter failure of all endeavors to detect any trace of him. He had very respectable connections, was of good habits, and it was impossible to account for his sudden absence. The general belief was that he had been murdered, -- or had fallen into the river during some momentary attack of insanity. The last Australian mail, however, has brought letters which place beyond doubt the fact that he is alive, and in his right mind. His experience, as related by himself, is most interesting, and in a condensed form we present it to our readers. Coming to this City he put up at the Metropolitan Hotel. While there he became oppressed with the feeling that his friends no longer loved him or cared for him, and that they would be glad to know of his death. Having ample means with him he procured a passage to San Francisco under an assumed name, and departed thither, leaving behind him his entire wardrobe and all the money he had over, to the amount of $500. While on the passage, he found to his infinite terror that he was an object of notice from several persons whom he had known in early life as factory hands in his native village, and deeming that he had been discovered, he reassumed his own name and ever after retained it. He landed at San Francisco with nothing to do, with no friends, and without money. Consequently he suffered much, not only from privation, but from the inclemency of the weather, and was heartily glad of an opportunity to earn his board and lodging on a ranch at some distance from the city. Not content, however, with this life, he made a successful attempt at teaching school, and as he was a graduate of Yale College, it is fair to presume he found the employment more congenial. At that he continued a year, by which time he had saved sufficient to enable him to buy a passage ticket for Australia, to which point he had determined at the outset to go. He at once found employment in the High School at Melbourne as a Professor, referring the Trustees to Yale College for his identification. During all this time his mind was terribly exercised and his heart most keenly lacerated by the thought that his friends rejoiced in his departure. Supposing that those who had recognized him on the steamer would have written home, he watched carefully the Eastern papers for advertisements, but seeing none, concluded that he was indeed forsaken by all whose affection he prized.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, President KALEFLEISCH in the chair. A communication was received from the Corporation Counselor, in reply to a resolution of the Board, adopted at the last meeting, to the effect that at the present time it is inexpedient to commence a suit to recover possession of Furman-street, but recommending that application be made to the Legislature for the passage of an act adjusting the interests of the rival Railroad Companies. The original resolution was reconsidered and another adopted, revoking all grants hitherto made to any persons, of a right to lay rail tracks and run cars on Furman or Columbia street. A motion to reconsider this resolution was lost. A communication was received from the Street Commissioner, calling attention to the almost impassable condition of Furman-street, occasioned by the attempt of the Central Railroad Company to lay a rail track there. The matter was referred to the Law Committee.

abstract: The eighteen hundred and sixtieth anniversary of the Birth of Christ! Yet, like Christianity itself, of whose vitality it partakes, Christmas never grows old. Who looks upon it as antiquated or worn out? It lives with a stronger pulse in the world's heart to-day than any other historic epoch; and, after sixty generations, we still read afresh its poetic story as it echoes along the centuries and spreads ever wider over the globe. The vision of its coming was revealed to the first man, and its commemoration will last out the world. It signalizes the event that lies at the foundation of our modern life, and is the vital spring of our social and political existence. It is the high festival of universal Christendom. The bells of St. Paul's, St. Peters and St. Sophia, as well as of old Trinity, ring in the morning of the nativity of the Divine Child, and the incense of general joy ascends to Heaven from the uttermost corners of the world. Innocent frolic and universal fraternity -- the smiling face and the generous hand -- children, dancing with glee, and patriarchs renewing again the days of their youth -- yule logs and Christmas candles -- carols -- churches decorated with evergreens -- merry chimes, music, processions and banners -- lords of unreason, chaplets of mistletoe, and kisses under the rose -- feasting among the poor and freedom even to the slave -- these are among the clustering souvenirs of Christmas.
lead_paragraph: The eighteen hundred and sixtieth anniversary of the Birth of Christ! Yet, like Christianity itself, of whose vitality it partakes, Christmas never grows old. abstract: Now, if ever, is the time for youthful lovers and elderly admirers to go to housekeeping. If we may judge from the advertisements that crowd our columns, everything is cheap all things are being sacrificed. Holders of desirable personal property seem determined and "contarmed" to almost give it away, and we are really encouraged to believe that the millenial days are approaching, when generosity and unselfishness shall reign in the hearts of all men.

abstract: Intense excitement exists here to-day, in consequence of its being made public that United States Quartermaster TALIAFERO was negotiating for the shipment from the Alleghany Arsenal of seventyeight guns to Newport, near Galveston Island, Texas, and forty-six more to Ship Island, near Balize, at the mouth of the Mississippi River the apparent object being to strip the Alleghany Arsenal, and place the guns where the Secessionists could get them.

abstract: We have accidentally neglected to notice among the elegant minor gift-books of the season, the fine edition of that famous and magnificent canticle of the Middle Ages, the Dies frae, edited by ABRAHAM COLES, and published by the APPLETONS. With a history of the hymn and also of its various translations, are given seven of the finest English versions in connection with the original. The style of the volume is very neat, and the book forms a most appropriate Christmas gift.

abstract: The case of Capt. Latham and others, involved in the slave case of the Cora, was called yesterday by U.S. Commissioner MORELL, but owing to the alleged continued illness of Capt. abstract: The Boston Traveller has been investigating the effect which the political panic has had upon the shoe trade. At Natick the depression is most serious. 1,000 workmen, out of 1,200 have been discharged, and 600 of these remain at Natick doing nothing, while the rest have gone to their homes in different parts of New-England. In South Natick four manufacturing firms, S. WALCOTT & CO., D.D. MOODY & BROTHER, JOHN W. COTTON & CO., and CROSBY & WOODBURY, have all failed, their aggregate liabilities being nearly $300,000. These failures have all taken place within a few weeks, have thrown about 300 men out of employ, and stopped the manufacture of about 225 cases per week. Shoes which were made for 17 to 20 cents per pair are now made for 16 cents. In Lynn, where ladies' and misses' shoes are manufactured, of the 3,000 workmen employed in the busiest seasons 1,000 are out of employment altogether, while 1,200 are working only part of the time. At Marblehead, Danvers and Haverhill the same stagnation prevails. To speak generally of the trade in these prominent places, (says the Traviller,) we remark that orders from the South and West come in occasionally, but the manufacturers are generally afraid to fill them during the present crisis. There seems to be no disposition on the part of Southern customers to repudiate de[???]ts, though some have failed and others asked for extensions.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Traveller has been investigating the effect which the political panic has had upon the shoe trade. To speak generally of the trade in these prominent places, (says the Traviller,) we remark that orders from the South and West come in occasionally, but the manufacturers are generally afraid to fill them during the present crisis. There seems to be no disposition on the part of Southern customers to repudiate de[???]ts, though some have failed and others asked for extensions.

abstract: The people of Pittsburgh and vicinity were thrown into a state of the greatest excitement yesterday by a revelation of the fact that U.S. Quartermaster TALIAFERO was arranging for the shipment of seventy-eight heavy guns to Newport, Texas, and forty-six more to Ship Island, near the Balize, from the Alleghany Arsenal the apparent object being to place them in a position where they could be seized by the Secessionists. It ap- ...
lead_paragraph: The people of Pittsburgh and vicinity were thrown into a state of the greatest excitement yesterday by a revelation of the fact that U.S. Quartermaster TALIAFERO was arranging for the shipment of seventy-eight heavy guns to Newport, Texas, and forty-six more to Ship Island, near the Balize, from the Alleghany Arsenal -- the apparent object being to place them in a position where they could be seized by the Secessionists. It appears that the forts at the points designated are new, and have never had any guns, and that those in question were originally designed for them. In the present condition of affairs, however, the citizens of Pittsburgh think it better that the guns should remain where they are, and measures are being taken to retain them.

abstract: Henry Hoyt, an old man, respectable in appearance, was yesterday arrested and taken to the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged with having defrauded Mrs. Emily Wallace, residing at Orange, N.J., to the extent of $200, under the following circumstances: The complainant recently advertised in one of the City papers for a situation as housekeeper, and the accused called upon her, representing that he was a physician living at Richmond, Va., who desired to employ such a person as herself. The interview resulting in her engagement, and the next day she came down from Orange, bringing with her three trunks, containing clothing and other property. At the depot of the Morris and Essex Railroad, Jersey City, the complainant was met by the prisoner who took charge of her trunks and conducted her to the St. Nicholas Hotel. There she remained some time, but her trunks did not follow her, and her employer also gave her the slip. In her trouble she applied to Capt. Helme, of the Eighth Ward Police, who prosecuted a search for the missing trunks, and yesterday found them at Sweeney's Hotel with most of their contents gone. The prisoner was soon afterwards found, and Justice QUACKENBUSH held him, pending an examination.

abstract: The election is passing off quietly in this city, there being no opposition to the Secession ticket. The most reliable information that I can obtain leads me to believe that the separate Secessionists will elect seventy-five delegates out of one hundred. The ordi  nance will probably be passed on the 9th of January. It is thought that Mississippi will secede on the same day.

abstract: It is evident, from the present state of Italy, that to realize profitable results from a victory indicates more ability than to gain it. It is a fine thing to become "master of the situation," but a much finer to turn it to account. And it is precisely in the delicate turn of application -- in the transition from the dramatic to the profitable -- that the entire strength of a reform or of a character, of a State or of an individual, is most clearly shown. The Union Party in Italy has passed through the first struggle triumphantly. It is decidedly master of the situation. It has now well-high again realized its own proverb of classic times, "one ruler, one tongue, one nation;" it will, probably, ere long, accomplish its prophecy of the Middle Ages expressed by MACHIAVELLI, and "hunt out the last barbarian."

abstract: His Honor the Mayor will be disagreeably surprised this morning, to hear that the Board of Aldermen, at their meeting yesterday afternoon, removed Mr. NATKAN C. PLATT from the office of Chamberlain, appointing Mr. DANIEL DEVLIN in his place. The reasons assigned by Acting-Mayor PECK, for the removal, appear cogent and satisfactory. Mr. PLATT having in the first place deposited the City Funds in an unsafe Bank; secondly, having denied, the authority of the Board of Aldermen to inquire as to the amount, condition and safe-keeping of the public money under his charge; and finally, having refused to give the bonds demanded of him by the Board of Supervisors, for the security of the vast amounts lodged in his hands as County Treasurer. Behind these official reasons, however, rumor has for some time asserted that Mr. PLATT, under the advice of his physicians, intended to resign early next January, so that the Mayor might then have the nomination of his successor. This was not a pleasant prospect to the Alderinanic mind, and hence the Acting Mayor seized the golden opportunity of Mr. WOOD's absence from the City, to place the office of Chamberlain and County Treasurer beyond the further reach of our Municipal Chief Magistrate during the balance of his term.
lead_paragraph: His Honor the Mayor will be disagreeably surprised this morning, to hear that the Board of Aldermen, at their meeting yesterday afternoon, removed Mr. NATKAN C. abstract: The discovery of a defalcation, amounting, so far as known, to $870,000 in the office of the Secretary of the Interior, at Washington, may be taken as the avant courrier of a long line of similar revelations which may be expected to follow within the next few weeks or months. The statement implicating Secretary FLOYD, made by the embezzling clerk, and the arrest, as a suspected accomplice, in this City, of a speculator who is known to have had most dangerously intimate relations with the Secretary of War, indicate only too clearly that we may expect some most painful and astounding disclosures should the authorities at Washington fail to have power to arrest the investigation in its very earliest stages. No men of ordinary intelligence, who have watched the official course and known the antecedents of some of the men in Mr. BUCHANAN's Cabinet, can ever he persuaded that a mere clerk in the office of the Secretary of the Interior would have been allowed to plunder in this wholesale fashion, for so long a period, if he and his accomplices outside the official circle had been the only participants in the profits.

abstract: One of the glories which the Southern Confederacy pictures to itself is the millenium of free trade. Its ideas upon this subject were first developed by Mr. McDUFFIE in his famous "forty bale" theory. They took fast hold of South Carolina, and constitute one of the leading motives to secession, under which the State is to reach the very acme of wealth and power.

abstract: News has arrived of the arrival of the King in Palermo, on Saturday morning, at 9:15 A.M. He was received with indescribable enthusiasm. The people insisted on taking the horses out of the carriage and drawing him in. It is calculated that upwards of 400,000 persons had assembled in Palermo. His Majesty went first to the cathedral, where he was received by the Archbishop. On arriving at the palace he received immediately the constituted authorities, and afterwards the deputations from the various municipalities of the island.

abstract: Christmas is me again. It seems rather twelve weeks, than twelve months ago, since we last said the same thing. Come again, with its good luck and bad luck, its joys and forebodings, weather the latter be for good or for evil -- come again, with large stockings, and the gifts of Santa Claus, to fill them -- come again with chairs round the festive table, for the annual gathering of scattered friends, -- in many instances with a vacant chair in which only a dearly cherished memory sits, but whose real occupant is with Him for whose birth the day is celebrated.

abstract: Hon. W.L. YANCEY Sir: In my last letter I gave you my reasons for regarding Secession as simply Revolution, and for believing that it canneither be peaceful nor successful. I propose now to state my understanding of the nature of the contest, and my reasons for hoping that it will not be compromised nor postponed, but finally settled, by whatever process and through whatever tribulations may be necessary.

abstract: Christmas Day was celebrated yesterday with all the appropriate festivities of the season, the good cheer suffering as much as if Secession had never been heard of, and the richer classes, apparently coming handsomely to the rescue and gratification of their poorer brethren. It was a beautiful Christmas Day, cold but bright, and with not so much wind out as to render skating disagreeable. At all the churches the occasion was celebrated with more than usual devoutness, and the Public Charities disbursed an active and bountiful benevolence to all who came within their sphere. It was a common remark in almost all circles, that a more thoroughly cheerful Christmas has rarely been witnessed in this City.
lead_paragraph: Christmas Day was celebrated yesterday with all the appropriate festivities of the season, the good cheer suffering as much as if Secession had never been heard of, and the richer classes, apparently coming handsomely to the rescue and gratification of their poorer brethren. abstract: FIRE IN FULTON-STREET. -- Between nine and ten o'clock last night a fire broke out in the brick building No. 77 Fulton-street, occupied by JNO. M. WHITFIELD, plumber, on the first floor, HAFFERTY & MCCUE, manufacturers of corks, on the second and third floors, and H.W. KING, manufacturer of leather belts, on the fourth floor. The fire originated on the second floor, and thence extending to the roof, communicated with the adjoining building No. 75, the two upper stories of which were burned out. No. 75 was occupied by DECORI & MANUERA, importers of Italian prints. The building in which the fire originated was all destroyed, save the first floor. Owing to the confusion and the absence of the occupants, we were unable to obtain an account of the losses or insurances. The total loss will not fall short of $15,000.

abstract: A few days ago Brig.-Gen. FROST, commander of the forces which went from St. Louis in pursuit of Capt. MONTGOMERY, and which returned without catching him, revenged himself for reflections cast upon his official conduct by one of his Quartermasters, E. B. SAYERS, by administering him a flogging. The latter could devise no way of healing his wounded honor but by challenging Gen. FROST to a duel, so a cartel was sent in due form, and received a prompt response. Mr. JAMES R. SHALER and Capt. WADE, acting for Messrs. SAYERS and FROST, respectively, arranged the following preliminaries:

abstract: In view of the threatened dissolution of the Union, and the consequent derangement of commercial and business enterprises, we are gratified to learn from Washington that leading members of the Republican Party, are already beginning to look forward to the acquisition or annexation of Mexico, as already means of at once indemnifying the North for the partial loss of Southern trade, and of marring the schemes of Slavery propagandism, which is one great incentive to disunion. This policy has been heretofore hinted at by the Press, but was formally foreshadowed in the recent speech of Mr. WADE in the Senate. We happen to know that this idea of acquiring Mexico, first under the forms of a protectorate, but eventually as a component part of the Confederacy, is no merely casual suggestion of an individual senator, but that it has been seriously and favorably considered by leading minds, which will, exercise an important influence upon the incoming Administration.

abstract: -- At about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a fight occurred between a party of men, who were intoxicated, in a building known as the "Barracks," on North Fifth, near First-street, E.D. LOUIS HURSCH stabbed, and killed almost instantly, a man named JOSEPH O'NEIL, and seriously, if not fatally wounded another man pained JOHN KENNEDY, with the same weapon. The "Barracks" is a tenement house, occupied by a large number of German and Irish [???]lics, and the quarrells there among the inmates have frequently attracted the attention of the Police. HURSCH, after committing the deal, attempted to escape, but was arrested and committed to jail. Coroner MURPHY will investigate the case to-day.

abstract: We ventured some days since to express the opinion that Secession was a political movement, -- intended to secure certain political results: -- that the seceding States were going out of the Union not with any intent to stay out, -- but for the purpose of gaining a position from which they could press their demands upon the Federal Government with greater effect. We thought we detected signs of this in certain movements of the Southern States, and in declarations of some of the most prominent Cooperationists; -- and it afforded, moreover, the only explanation of Mr. BUCHANAN's remarkable official action, consistent with his sanity and his loyalty to the Union.
lead_paragraph: We ventured some days since to express the opinion that Secession was a political movement, -- intended to secure certain political results: -- that the seceding States were going out of the Union not with any intent to stay out, -- but for the purpose of gaining a position from which they could press their demands upon the Federal Government with greater effect. We thought we detected signs of this in certain movements of the Southern States, and in declarations of some of the most prominent Cooperationists; -- and it afforded, moreover, the only explanation of Mr. BUCHANAN's remarkable official action, consistent with his sanity and his loyalty to the Union.

abstract: Christmas was more generally observed in Brooklyn yesterday than ever before. Nearly all places of business were closed and the people generally, old and young, devoted themselves to holiday amusements. The Roman Catholic and Episcopal Churches ...
lead_paragraph: Christmas was more generally observed in Brooklyn yesterday than ever before. Nearly all places of business were closed and the people generally, old and young, devoted themselves to holiday amusements. The Roman Catholic and Episcopal Churches made the occasion one of special interest by imposing ceremonies in their several churches. In some of the churches services were commenced as early as 12 o'clock on Monday night, but in most of them at 5 o'clock yesterday morning, and continued at intervals until 10 1/2 o'clock A.M., when High Mass was celebrated at the Church of the Assumption, corner of York and Jay streets. MOZART's Twelfth Mass was performed with great effect by Mrs. CLARK, soprano; E.B. CADLEY, tenor; Mr. ZUNGFREY, bass; Miss CLARK, alto; assisted by a heavy chorus. At St. Peter's Church, in Hicks near Degraw street, Generalis Mass was performed under the direction of Mr. MELVILLE. HAYDEN's No. 2 was performed at the Debevoise-street Church, under the direction of Mr. HOFFMAN. The ceremonies in these churches were witnessed by a large number of people belonging to other religious denominations, attracted thither by the imposing character of the exercises.

abstract: It has for thirty years been the steady and fixed policy of South Carolina to construe away  the authority and power of the General Government, and thus to restore, practically, the, old, exploded, and abandoned Confederation,  which existed before the Constitution was formed. This idea was originally conceived
lead_paragraph: It has for thirty years been the steady and fixed policy of South Carolina to construe away the authority and power of the General Government, and thus to restore, practically, the, old, exploded, and abandoned Confederation, which existed before the Constitution was formed. This idea was originally conceived by Mr. CALHOUN, and by availing himself first of the tariff and then of the negro, he managed to play so successfully upon Southern passions as at length to imbue the Southern mind with his theories. According to Mr. CALHOUN and his disciples of the present day, the framers of the Constitution utterly failed in their efforts to remedy the defects of the old articles of confederation; and in spite of the fact, which stands out so conspicuously upon the page of history, that that confederation or league was abandoned because it had no power of enforcing its decrees, because its inefficiency had reduced the country to bankruptcy, and because disunion and anarchy stared our forefathers in the face; in spite of the fact that a "more perfect Union" was formed, under a Constitution of Government, having sanctions and clothed with power to enforce its laws upon individuals, we are still told that we have a mere voluntary Union of Sovereign States, each of which may at pleasure retire from the league.
headline: {'main': 'The South Carolina Perversion of the Constitution.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The South Carolina Perversion of the Constitution.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is stated that the French Government is about to bring into France for interment the remains of the Empress MARIA LOUISE. The whirligig of time will never have done working its strange revenges. One would suppose that the vicissitudes of fortune ceased when humanity succumbed to the last enemy.
lead_paragraph: It is stated that the French Government is about to bring into France for interment the remains of the Empress MARIA LOUISE. The whirligig of time will never have done working its strange revenges. One would suppose that the vicissitudes of fortune ceased when humanity succumbed to the last enemy. But even alter life's fitful fever, the great are not always allowed to sleep undisturbed. She who was born an Austrian Princess and married to the man who had done most injury to her country and family; she whose train was held by four unwilling Queens, who was mother of NAPOLEON's son, who lived to see that son a prisoner in the city and custody of his own ancestors, his father in exile, and herself reduced to less than her original state; she who, after having been Empress of France and successor of JOSEPHINE, forgot this greatness ness to become the wife of a miserable Italian; who was even, said to have received illicit advances, and who died in merited obscurity -- she is now to be disturbed in her grave, and her ashes transported with Imperial honors to be laid by the side of the great man whose memory she had insulted.

abstract: Christmas-day was commemorated in Jersey City in the usual manner. Services were held in most of the churches in the morning, and many of the Sabbath Schools held their anniversary meetings. The children and other inmates of the Almshouse were provided with a bountiful dinner of turkeys, chickens aod other good things, the contributions of the citizens, who were present in large numbers to witness the enjoyment produced by their generous donations. The Hudson Guard partook of a company dinner, -- as is their custom on this day, -- which was participated in by many City officals and other invited guests.

abstract: The suspicion everywhere prevalent that the President and his Cabinet advisers are in secret league with the Secessionists, and working for the overthrow of the National Government, has at length produced its natural fruit at Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where the people have all but risen in organized resistance to the proposed transfer of one hundred and twenty-four new pieces of artillery from the Alleghany Arsenal to two Southern fortifications within reach of the Secessionists.
lead_paragraph: The suspicion everywhere prevalent that the President and his Cabinet advisers are in secret league with the Secessionists, and working for the overthrow of the National Government, has at length produced its natural fruit at Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where the people have all but risen in organized resistance to the proposed transfer of one hundred and twenty-four new pieces of artillery from the Alleghany Arsenal to two Southern fortifications within reach of the Secessionists. As Mr. BUCHANAN has declared substantially by his acts, that forts of the United States are not to be held at the cost of bloodshed, if attacked by the Pro-Slavery Revolutionists -- and as, in the case of Fort Moultrie, he has even abstained from sending the necessary munitions of war, lest by so doing he should "irritate" still further the people of South Carolina, -- for what good purpose we may well ask, could he now be so anxious to dismantle one of the most important military depots in a State bordering on the South, if he had not first received notice from the Secessionists that the "ten-inch Columbiad guns" in question would be accepted as a favor, and duly turned against the United States if placed within reach of the revolutionary element?

abstract: If Christmas "only comes but once a year," it is certainly one of the most eventful festivals of the year, viewed in a secular light only, and without reference to its high origin. Members of scattered families who do not meet on the Fourth, or at New-Year's, manage, if it be at all practicable, to come together on this occasion. It seems, indeed, to be everybody's birthday, and that each and all of them had called to wish the customary "happy returns."

abstract: JOHN L. HAYNAS publishes a long letter in the Texas journals setting forth the advantages which have accrued to that State since her connection with the Union. In 1848 her population was 155,292 (an annual average ...
lead_paragraph: JOHN L. HAYNAS publishes a long letter in the Texas journals setting forth the advantages which have accrued to that State since her connection with the Union. In 1845 he says the population of Texas was 50,940; in 1836 it was only 38,470, showing an increase of 42,470, which was doubtless due largely to the donations of public lands made to actual settlers. In 1848 her population was 155,292 (an annual average increase of 24,784) and in 1850 it was 212,543, which showed an increase in two years of 28,650 per annum. The next enumeration was made in 1858, when her population had reached 482,097, showing an increase since 1850 of 212,592. The domestic debt of Texas at the time of annexation was $8 909,146; the foreign debt, $4,144 955 -- total, $13,051,101: and at this time she could not make good her expenditures by an annual average of $1,227,800. In 1850 she received $10,000,000 from the General Government for her Santa Fe Territory, and by its aid she inaugurated a great system of public improvements and paid her revolutionary debt.

abstract: -John Bull is always in the right. This is the first article of his national faith. Nor is there anything very singular about it, for every nation has a comfortable fashion of relying on its own infallibility. But Bull carries the matter a good deal further than his neighbors. He not only considers himself right, but he regards every nation that differs from him and adopts a different policy from that which would best promote his interest, as not only wrong, but as wickedly and hopelessly perverse.

abstract: You are in the habit of charging the North with having produced all the sectional discontent that now prevails by departing from the Constitution. I will not say that there is no truth in the allegation. Possibly we have, in some particulars, beon less rigid in adhering to that instrument than we should have been. But none of these deviations
lead_paragraph: You are in the habit of charging the North with having produced all the sectional discontent that now prevails by departing from the Constitution. I will not say that there is no truth in the allegation. Possibly we have, in some particulars, beon less rigid in adhering to that instrument than we should have been. But none of these deviations on our part will compare with that great change which you demand in its essential elements and character. Nor have they caused your discontent As I have already shown in these letters, it is not our Personal Liberty bills, nor our failure to surrender fugitives, nor the practical inability of slaveholders to take their slaves into the Territories, that creates the difficulty. That difficulty has grown out of your determination to make a new Constitution. It is due primarily, and therefore entirely, to your departure from the policy of the Fathers of the Republic, as that policy was embodied in the Constitution, -- as it stands revealed in the language of that instrument, and interpreted by the opinions and sentiments of the men who made it. You demand that principles shall be engrafted upon it which they carefully and intentionally excluded from it. As you stated in your Montgomery speech "an entirely new idea has sprung up in the South" on the subject of Slavery, -- and you demand that this new idea shall be embodied in the Constitution. Hitherto, to be sure, you have sought this end by construction, -- by legislation, -- by the language of party platforms, -- by decrees of the Supreme Court, rather than by open and direct amendments. But now you insist upon the reconstruction of the Constitution itself, and the adoption into its language of the ideas and principles for which you contend. The "irrepressible conflict" is, therefore, not between the North and the South, -- but between the South and the Constitution. You have found the present Constitution, so far as your purposes are concerned, a failure. Unless, therefore, it can be overthrown by amendments, you are determined to overthrow it by force. I do not think you will succeed in either.

abstract: -- The Hartford (Conn.) Post tells a pleasant and romantic story of a young man who came to this country from England 25 years ago, in a fit of desperation caused by the refusal of the parents of the young lady whom he loved to sanction a marriage. He settled down at Cleveland, Ohio, and having accumulated a fortune, was about returning to his fatherland to hunt up his long lost love, when, during a brief stay in Hartford, chancing to call at the house of a friend, he met a lady toward whom he felt an irresistible attraction. What was his astonishment on inquiry at ascertaining that she was the girl he left behind him. Of course, the two were married forthwith, and will now make their trip home in company.
lead_paragraph: -- The Hartford (Conn.)
