abstract: Our South Carolina cousins -- or cousins-german we suppose we must call them, since their alien-ation -- are waxing magnificent already, on the strength of being "foreigners." Their newspapers head their extracts from New-York journals "The Foreign Press." If there was any reason to suppose they meant to be jocose, they would establish quite a reputation for humor in this way. But they are as serious and grave about it as undertakers at a funeral. We have tried to be as melancholy over the whole matter as the solemnity of the performers seems to call for, but the effort is becoming painful.

abstract: On Saturday the Extradition case was again before the Court of Queen's Bench, in Toronto, Mr. FREEMAN, counsel for the prisoner, announced that it had been determined to carry the case to the Court of Error and Appeal. Some discussion followed as to whether an appeal would he, but Chief-Justice ROBINSON finally said that he would interpose no objection to the matter being brought before the Court of Appeal if that tribunal thought it best to consider it, and it was determined that the case should take this course.

abstract: Our foreign telegrams contain information of the close of the war in China, and the return of the Emperor to Peking. As in the case of the negotiations at Tien-tsia, the news reaches us through Russian channels, in  advance of the usual Overland mail and telegraph a circumstance illustrating the sensitiveness and attention with which Russia  watches the development of the Western European influence in Eastern Asia.
lead_paragraph: Our foreign telegrams contain information of the close of the war in China, and the return of the Emperor to Peking. As in the case of the negotiations at Tien-tsia, the news reaches us through Russian channels, in advance of the usual Overland mail and telegraph -- a circumstance illustrating the sensitiveness and attention with which Russia watches the development of the Western European influence in Eastern Asia. No phenomenon in the recent course; of the Muscovite Government is, more striking than its abandonment of a comprehensive and ambitious European policy, and the concentration of its views upon Asia. And this is the reason was Russian agents have waited upon the steps of the Allies, and surrounded the Chinese Imperial Court, ready to forward to Europe the earliest advices of what might be achieved or intended by either.

abstract: At this Court yesterday, Justices KELLY, WELSH and BROWNELL disposed of the Calendar as follows: Of eighteen persons charged with assault and battery, eight persons were discharged; two by non-appearance of witnesses, two by request of complainant, two by suspension of sentence, and two by acquittal; three were fined, three imprisoned, and four were allowed postponement. Of thirty-one persons charged with petty larceny, twenty were discharged; one by request or complainant, three by suspension of sentence, and seven by acquittal; nine were remanded and eleven were imprisoned. One person charged with keeping a disorderly house was acquitted; one charged with embezzlement was imprisoned, as was also one charged with riotous conduct.

Of thirty-one persons charged with petty larceny, twenty were discharged; one by request or complainant, three by suspension of sentence, and seven by acquittal; nine were remanded and eleven were imprisoned. One person charged with keeping a disorderly house was acquitted; one charged with embezzlement was imprisoned, as was also one charged with riotous conduct.

abstract: George Law et al. vs. The United States. -- The plaintiffs' counsel moved this case, at the opening of Court this morning. The District-Attorney said that he had expected to try the case this morning, but must ask a postponement; that in view of the number of counsel opposed to him. he had written to the Government in relation to having associate counsel himself, and the gentleman to whom he had spoken to act with him could not attend till Friday; that a witness, moreover, for the Government was unable to be in Court this morning, and that he himself had a cold which made it difficult for him to talk much, and had a very important piece of business now pending for the Government involving some $870,000.

abstract: FRANCIS II. still stubbornly resists at Gaeta, and no one knows whether it will be days, or weeks, or even months, before he is dislodged. Gen. CIALDINI is pushing forward as rapidly as circumstances will permit his seige works, and will before long be prepared to strike his hardest blows. The young King has been hunted like a beast of prey all the way from his capital to what..

abstract: INSULTING FEMALES AND BRUTAL ASSAULT.  On Tuesday night, about 11  o'clock, as Mr. THOMAS TAILOR, of Hudson City, accompanied by his wife and two young ladies, were in the waiting-room of the Horse-car Railroad Company at Jersey City, a young man named EDWARD DAVIS, as is alleged, while intoxicated, entered the room and grossly insulted the ladies by the use of foul language and indecent proposals to them. Mr. TAYLOR, noticing the condition of...
lead_paragraph: INSULTING FEMALES AND BRUTAL ASSAULT. -- On Tuesday night, about 11 1/2 o'clock, as Mr. THOMAS TAILOR, of Hudson City, accompanied by his wife and two young ladies, were in the waiting-room of the Horse-car Railroad Company at Jersey City, a young man named EDWARD DAVIS, as is alleged, while intoxicated, entered the room and grossly insulted the ladies by the use of foul language and indecent proposals to them. Mr. TAYLOR, noticing the condition of DAVIS, shoved him out of the room. The latter immediately returned, however, and commenced a violent attack, and succeeded in striking TAYLOR several blows in the face, as is supposed with a slung-shot or some other instrument, before any one could interfere. As Mr. TAYLOR had received a very bad cut across his left check, and was otherwise injured, Dr. QUIDOR was called in, and on examination found the lower jaw fractured and a double tooth knocked out. DAVIS was arrested yesterday forenoon, and upon being taken before Justice COWAN, was held in $200 bonds to answer at the January term of Court.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning are important. The two Select Committees on the State of the Union held meetings yesterday, and the results arrived at is the House Committee will probably have an important bearing on the ques  tions at issue between the two sections of the country.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington this morning are important. The two Select Committees on the State of the Union held meetings yesterday, and the results arrived at is the House Committee will probably have an important bearing on the ques tions at issue between the two sections of the country. An "Enabling Act" for the Territory of New-Mexico was proposed by Mr. ADAMS, of Massachusetts, and will be adopted, which allows, by express provision, the establishment of the institution of Slavery, provided the people desire it. In the Senate Committee no conclusions were arrived at. An inquiry was made of the Southern members as to whether Mr. TOOMBS' proposition, that the Constitution should recognize the right of property, in man, was to be considered as the Southern ultimatum, but a satisfactory answer could not be obtained. The Commissioners from South Carolina have arrived in Washington, and taken private quarters. It is expected that they will communicate with the President to-day, either verbally or in writing when a message will be sent to Congress, giving the purport of the communication, whatever it may be. The trouble at the Alleghany Arsenal at Pittsburgh, it is understood, is giving the Administration a great deal of uneasiness, and messengers have been sent there, to see what can be done to prevail upon the people to allow the guns to be forwarded to their destination without molestation. The proceedings in open session of the South Carolina "Sovereign" Convention were somewhat interesting yesterday. A resolution was offered requesting the Governor to communicate to the Convention all the information in his possession relative to the condition of the fortifications in the harbor of Charleston. It was laid on the table for consideration in secret session. A resolution was offered -- what disposition was made of it is not stated -- that all citizens of the United States living in the State of South Carolina when the ordinance of secession was adopted, be declared citizens of that State. The gentleman who offered the resolution gave assurances that he did not contemplate making involuntary citizens of those who happened to be residing in the State at the time referred to. An attempt was made, to adjourn over until the 18th of January, or subject to the call of the President, but it failed. Mr. RHET[???] offered an ordinance providing for the holding of a Convention of the Slaveholding States, to form a Southern Confederation and frame a Constitution for its government, which he desired to have laid on the table without reading, It was decided, however, that this could not be done, as it would be against parliamentary usages, and it was accordingly read. It provides for a Convention to be held at Montgomery, to be attended by delegates from all seceding States, and recommends the adoption of the Constitution of the United States as a suitable basis on which to form the proposed new Government. The Convention then went into secret session and adopted an ordinance on the subject of Commercial Facilities.

abstract: It is not many weeks since the moral sense of the community was started by the formal enunciation of an opinion on the part of Judge ROOSEVELT, acting as prosecuting officer of the United States for this district, to the effect that public sentiment had recently undergone a change of view in regard to the Stave-trade, no longer regarding the purchase of negroes in Africa and their transit across the seas to ...
lead_paragraph: It is not many weeks since the moral sense of the community was started by the formal enunciation of an opinion on the part of Judge ROOSEVELT, acting as prosecuting officer of the United States for this district, to the effect that public sentiment had recently undergone a change of view in regard to the Stave-trade, no longer regarding the purchase of negroes in Africa and their transit across the seas to Cuban, Brazilian or American markets, as a crime amounting to piracy. It was further stated by the eccentric prosecuting officer, that at President BUCHANAN so completely shares this change of sentiment, whereby a felony of the gravest nature is sought to be reduced to the level of a mere commercial peccadillo, that under no possible circumstances wouldthe National Executive permit a conviction. for this, offence in the first degree, to be followed by the punishment prescribed by those laws which the President, something less than four short years ago, made oath to support and execute.

abstract: The Havana Diario de la Marina is at great pains to deny the statements of the Cuban correspondent of the TIMES in regard to the number of slave-cargoes landed on the island. The denial, it may be remarked, applies not to the absolute existence of the traffic, but to the extent of its prosecution. It admits that slaves are landed, but denies that the number of landings reported is authentic; and for actual delinquencies it has the audacity to hold the Government of which it is the organ entirely guiltless, asserting that England and the United States having undertaken to suppress the traffic, any cases of successful evasion must be charged to the negligence of those two Powers.

abstract: We see it announced that Mr. TRESCOTT, the Assistant Secretary of State, is to act as Secretary to the Commission from South Carolina to Washington. Our "foreign" friends, it strikes us, are drawing rather largely on the Government at Washington for their working force. They have stripped the Cabinet pretty clean already. COBB, of Georgia, after serving the cause of secession, by spending three hundred millions of the federal money, and plunging the Federal Treasury into bankruptcy, ran away, like a midnight incendiary, from the ruin he had caused. THOMPSON, another Cabinet officer, was selected as Secession Commissioner from Mississippi to North Carolina, -- while holding office and drawing pay from the Federal Government, -- and was only interrupted in his task by the necessity of returning to look after some of his underlings and accomplices in the Department over which he presides. FLOYD stays in the War Department to provide Federal arms for the Disunionists -- and see that the power of the Federal Government is not used against them. HEARTT superintends the Public Printing of the Executive Department for the purpose of circulating secession documents. And so in every Department of the General Government the agents of secession are busy in destroying the Union they have sworn to support, and which pays them for their services.

abstract: "History marches rapidly in these days," says the Russian Journalist HERZEN; and it cannot be denied that his own country has given the world, during the past decade, a stupendous example in the records of industrial progress. But all historical movements are not invariably forwards. Like storms, they move in circles and, like storms, they knock down many an old tree while fulfilling their grand mission of purification and fertilization.

abstract: The South pays but once a year, because Southern industry produces, annually, but one crop and one staple. When this is sold, the proceeds, so far as they will go, pay off debts contracted 12, 18 and 24 months previous. A New-York merchant in the Southern dry goods trade regularly draws his notes for his sales on 12 months -- virtually upon the next crop -- the proceeds of the past having all gone to pay debts previously contracted.

abstract: The weekly meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration was held yesterday. The weekly statement shows that there have been 1,339 arrivals of emigrants since the last report. Amount received for commutation of passengers, $3,480; disbursements, as per previous account, to Dec. 19, $254,130; current expenses, $3,005 11. Total, $257,141 11. Balance, $7,448 76. Mr. ELLINGWOOD, member elect of the State Assembly, was present, and had some conference with the Board upon the subject of the sale of the old Quarantine property. The following resolution was adopted:

abstract: The task of apportioning the Congressional representation among the growing millions of the Union is one which every ten years perplexes the ingenuity of legislators. If the arithmetic of the subject lay within the four elementary rules, the most striking difficulty would not be overmastering. It would be sufficient simply to divide the entire sum of population, less the excepted and the fractional classes named in the fifth article of the Constitution, by the established number of Representatives, and, disregarding fractions, apply the result to the population of the several States. But the process admits of no such dispatch. The fractions are so large in many cases as to exceed the possibility of summary treatment, and to demand especial consideration. When, for instance, as in the apportionment of 1850, the divisor to be applied to the population of the several States is 93,420, it is quite possible that fractions very nearly approaching the unit may occur, which cannot be denied representation; hence the necessity of fixing some standard at which these excesses, may be entitled to representation; and hence the vexatious problem over which legislators have to dispute at the commencement of each decade.

abstract: NATIONAL GYMNASIUM EXHIBITION. -- The exhibition of feats of force and endurance at BEACH's National Gymnasium, in Knickerbocker Hall, corner of Eighth-avenue and Twenty-third street, last evening, attracted a very large audience, of which the fair constituted a fair proportion. Entertainments of this character always find favor with the ladies. The weaker sex admire strength in man, and in the struggle to win woman's smiles, the battle is generally to the strong; for muscular vigor in a measure underlies all effort, mental, moral, and physical. "Mens sana in corpore sano" is a wise saw with many modern instances. The entertainment last evening was uncommonly good. A chosen corps of the numerous members of the Gymnasium, led by Mr. BEACH, the Gymnasiarch, executed acts as amateurs that many a professional would hesitate to undertake. Most noted among them were Messrs. WEIR, RYDER, HALSTEAD, LEFFERTS, LEVICK, BOGERT, CHEVALIER, and others, who, in private circles, have earned a robust reputation as gymnasts. Mr. HALSTEAD, who, in humorous vein, performed such fantastic tricks as kept the audience in a roar, seemed a Hercules and Momus rolled into one. Withal Apollo graced the sports of the tyro Titans, and ravishing music added its charms. It was a pleasant holiday gathering, and to all appearances was vastly enjoyed.

abstract: Secession, proceeding by regular stages, has brought the State of South Carolina and the Federal Government face to face. The State, arrogating to herself dignity and powers equal to those of the Nation, has sent her Commissioners to Washington to treat for a peaceful settlement. The first thing for the Federal authority to decide will be whether the Commissioners can be received; and in deciding that question the main question may never be reached.

abstract: ATTACK UPON THREE LADIES, THREE GENTLEMEN AND A POLICEMAN -- ARRESTS. -- At about 9 o'clock on the evening of the 25th inst., three gentlemen, accompanied by ladies, were walking along Fulton-avenue, and upon reaching Classon-avenue, seven inebriated ruffians made an unprovoked attack upon the party. The gentlemen defended themselves to the best of their ability, but they were unable to cope with the superior number of their assailants. Fortunately, Officer NATHAN SWEETZER, of the Ninth Precinct Police, was near the spot, and promptly went to the assistance of the assailed party. In attempting to arrest one of the most violent of the party, he was seized from behind by two of the ruffians, who held him, while a third twisted the club from his hand. A severe struggle ensued, but Officer SWEETZER, after receiving some pretty severe injuries, succeeded in releasing himself from their grasp. Having lost his club, he ran a short distance, so as to have time to get at his pistol. The roughs pursued him, screeching and yelling, until he got his pistol out, and then he turned upon them. The three pursuers then became the pursued. He chased the ruffians pretty sharply until he found that all were likely to escape, when he commenced firing his pistol at them. Four barrels were discharged without doing any serious damage, when the officer secured one of the party and took him to the Ninth Precinct Station. There the prisoner furnished the officer with the names of those who were with him, and warrants were issued for their arrest. Another of the party was arrested yesterday, and the missing ones will probably be secured within a short time. This is the second time within two weeks Officer SWEETZER has had a severe encounter with ruffians in this District, and received severe injuries. On the occasion previous to this he attempted to arrest three men who were fighting. They turned upon him, knocked him down, beat and kicked him until they supposed he was insensible, if not dead. But he was only playing "possum." As soon as they started to leave, Officer SWEETZER, quite refreshed, sprang to his feet, knocked down the nearest man to him, seized a second, and conveyed the two to the Station-house. The third man escaped. Officer SWEETZER's beat on Christmas night covered about five miles of street.

abstract: We steamed away from Batavia on the 10th instant, and crossing the Sea of Java, we passed through the Strait of Gaspar, then up between Sumatra and Borneo, across the Equator again, and so into the China Sea, where we encountered the first puffs of the Northeast Monsoon, which blew fresh in our teeth until our arrival here on the 22d, having made a fair run of eleven days.

abstract: Egbert Deming, Trustee of the New-York Marble Company vs. The New-York Marble Company, Henry Dwight and James B. Bume, severally and jointly, as Trustees of said Company. -- From the papers used in this motion it appears that in March last an order of reference was made to James W. Fowler, Esq., to appoint a Receiver of the New-York Marble Company, who should manage its affairs and pay its debts under the direction of the Court, during the pendency of the action, the defendants, Henry Dwight and James R. Bume, being enjoined and restrained from any further interference with the property and affairs of the Company, on the ground of their alleged fraudulent mismanagement as officers and Trustees. From this order Dwight and Bume appealed to the General Term, and, pending the appeal, obtained a stay of proceedings, restraining Mr. Fowler, the Referee, from proceeding to appoint a receiver of the Company.
lead_paragraph: Egbert Deming, Trustee of the New-York Marble Company vs. The New-York Marble Company, Henry Dwight and James B. Bume, being enjoined and restrained from any further interference with the property and affairs of the Company, on the ground of their alleged fraudulent mismanagement as officers and Trustees. From this order Dwight and Bume appealed to the General Term, and, pending the appeal, obtained a stay of proceedings, restraining Mr. Fowler, the Referee, from proceeding to appoint a receiver of the Company.

abstract: The People vs. Mary Moran. -- The prisoner was charged with stealing $1,500 in bills on the Chemical Bank, alleged to have been secreted in the "inner garment" of Mrs. Sparks, a lady in this City, a few days since. abstract: The news from Charleston yesterday created a decided sensation. It was announced that Major ANDERSON had evacuated Fort Moultrie in the night, spiking the guns and taking the garrison to Fort Sumter. Everybody saw at once that this was a military precaution of the greatest importance, and that it secured the continued command of the port of Charleston by the Federal authorities, in spite of any movement on the part of the Disunionists.
lead_paragraph: The news from Charleston yesterday created a decided sensation. It was announced that Major ANDERSON had evacuated Fort Moultrie in the night, -- spiking the guns and taking the garrison to Fort Sumter. Everybody saw at once that this was a military precaution of the greatest importance, -- and that it secured the continued command of the port of Charleston by the Federal authorities, in spite of any movement on the part of the Disunionists.

abstract: His Majesty's Netherlands steamer Croningen, with the Dutch Ambassador on board, on his way to Siam, arrived on the 25th ten days from Japan. He received a salute of seventeen guns from the Niagara, which was returned with a like number.  We encamped here on the 6th. On the same evening the Emperor's Summer palace, Yuen-min-Yuen, was taken possession of, and yesterday Messrs. H.S. PARKES and HENEY LOOH were liberated and returned to the Embassy.

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, last evening, a communication was received from the Judges of the Superior Court, setting forth that the recent action of the Common Council, awarding them one of the Supreme Court rooms, was not unjust to the Supreme Court, as it left that Court as well provided for as the Superior Court would be with the new accommodation; and that, when making their application, they little thought they would meet with opposition, because "they had suffered, without complaining, more than all the other Judges of all the other Courts, and only abandoned their rooms after it had been found that they could not transact business in them and live." The reading of the communication was suspended, and the paper was laid on the table.
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, last evening, a communication was received from the Judges of the Superior Court, setting forth that the recent action of the Common Council, awarding them one of the Supreme Court rooms, was not unjust to the Supreme Court, as it left that Court as well provided for as the Superior Court would be with the new accommodation; and that, when making their application, they little thought they would meet with opposition, because "they had suffered, without complaining, more than all the other Judges of all the other Courts, and only abandoned their rooms after it had been found that they could not transact business in them and live." abstract: THE ARION SOCIETY. -- The members of this energetic and thriving musical association have organized three grand vocal and instrumental concerts to be given at Irving Hall during January, March and April. They are for art purposes only, and have no pecuniary object in view beyond reimbursing the members their actual outlays. For this reason the programmes have been selected with rare care, and will contain pieces from the great masters rarely or never played in this country. An orchestra of fifty performers, many soloists of high repute, and the entire choral strength of the Society will assist at each concert. Reserved seats for the series may be secured at a very low rate, and the lovers of good music will do well to be in time. Messrs. ANCHUTZ and BERGMANN are the conductors.

abstract: We are compelled to believe that South Carolina, and perhaps other States, will secede from the Union. We do not admit their right to go out, except on the extreme ground of revolution, which must commonly be effected by more or less of hard fighting. We see that this result is altogether probable, perhaps inevitable. But we all deplore it deeply, and we would still venture to hope that some less terrible settlement of these questions can be effected. It is the duty of each citizen to contribute whatever he can of influence to bring about a peaceful issue; let us "study the things which make for peace." In this spirit what follows is written.

abstract: Charles McKenna, a young Irishman, engaged in the negro minstrel business at No. 444 Broadway, was apprehended on Wednesday evening by Officers King said Simms, of the Ninth Ward, charged with being a fugitive from justice. It is alleged that on the 20th of October last, the prisoner nearly killed a man named Patric Dononue, whom be encountered in a porter-house corner of Hudson and Thirteenth streets, by stabbing him with a butcher's knife.
lead_paragraph: Charles McKenna, a young Irishman, engaged in the negro minstrel business at No. 444 Broadway, was apprehended on Wednesday evening by Officers King said Simms, of the Ninth Ward, charged with being a fugitive from justice. It is alleged that on the 20th of October last, the prisoner nearly killed a man named Patric Dononue, whom be encountered in a porter-house corner of Hudson and Thirteenth streets, by stabbing him with a butcher's knife. He afterwards fled to Philadelphia, where he remained until he supposed the circumstance had passed out of mind, but he was mistaken in his calculation. On Monday night he resumed his business of dancing and concert singing, and having been recognized he was taken into custody. He was committed for trial. The man Donohue is slowly recovering from the consequences of his injury.

abstract: The sagacious philosopher who expressed the conviction that history never reproduces itself, had not attended to the history of Mexico. A few months ago the Liberal armies had surrounded the Capital of that Republic. The reactionary strength, reduced in numbers and without supplies, was shut up in the Capital; the military chest was wholly exhausted, and to the eye of ordinary sense there was no alternative but the surrender of the beleaguered army and the triumph of the Constitutionalists. Gen. DEGOLLADO, sustained by the troops of ALVAREZ, was at Tacubaya, looking down upon the helpless city: the whole valley was thronged by the enemies of the besieged. Yet one bright morning the garrison made a sortie, in numbers not for a moment comparable with the superior strength which it attacked; the troops of DEGOLLADO and ALVAREZ took to flight; a score or two of non-combatants were slaughtered by the victors, and once more the Clerical party was in the ascendant at the capital.
lead_paragraph: The sagacious philosopher who expressed the conviction that history never reproduces itself, had not attended to the history of Mexico. A few months ago the Liberal armies had surrounded the Capital of that Republic. The reactionary strength, reduced in numbers and without supplies, was shut up in the Capital; the military chest was wholly exhausted, and to the eye of ordinary sense there was no alternative but the surrender of the beleaguered army and the triumph of the Constitutionalists. Gen. DEGOLLADO, sustained by the troops of ALVAREZ, was at Tacubaya, looking down upon the helpless city: the whole valley was thronged by the enemies of the besieged. Yet one bright morning the garrison made a sortie, in numbers not for a moment comparable with the superior strength which it attacked; the troops of DEGOLLADO and ALVAREZ took to flight; a score or two of non-combatants were slaughtered by the victors, and once more the Clerical party was in the ascendant at the capital.

abstract: The Tribune, of Wednesday morning, copied conspicuously from the Albany Atlas and Argus an article intended to prove that Mr. LINCOLN holds firmly and unflinchingly to the principles of the Republican Party, -- and that among them, is the principle of Negro Equality. With what special object the Tribune thus gave prominence and a quasi endorsement to this statement of Mr. LINCOLN's position, from an open and unsparing political opponent, it is no part of our purpose to inquire. Probably nothing has done more to embitter the minds of the Southern people towards the President elect than the imputation of such sentiments on this subject. We propose, therefore, to examine the basis on which the allegation rests.

abstract: ACKNOWLEDGE FOR THE NEWSBOYS. The Superintendent of the Newsboys' Lodging-house thankfully acknowledges the receipt of the following donations for a Christmas Dinner for the newsboys: From the Howard House, twelve chickens, seven pies, eight loaves of bread, one-half bushel of potatoes, and one box of oranges; from the Astor House, one turkey, one chicken, two loaves of bread, one pie and a lump of butter; Mr. Small, Park-place, one...
lead_paragraph: ACKNOWLEDGE FOR THE NEWSBOYS. -- The Superintendent of the Newsboys' Lodging-house thankfully acknowledges the receipt of the following donations for a Christmas Dinner for the newsboys: From the Howard House, twelve chickens, seven pies, eight loaves of bread, one-half bushel of potatoes, and one box of oranges; from the Astor House, one turkey, one chicken, two loaves of bread, one pie and a lump of butter; Mr. Small, Park-place, one turkey and one pie; A Friend, four chickens; A Lady, three turkeys; Mr. Dean, a piece of roast beef; Mrs. Scribner, ten pounds of currants and five pounds of raisins; collected by Messrs. J. & C. Quirk, No. 35 Fulton-street, $22; A Gentleman, $1; received per J. Macy, Children's Aid Society, $10. About $20 of the above is reserved for the purpose of furnishing a Christmas Tree on New-Year's night with prizes for the boys of useful articles of wearing apparel, such as jackets, pants, boots, shoes, caps, &c. The poor boys enjoyed the good cheer provided by their considerate and generous friends, socially and gratefully.

abstract: John King et al vs. The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company. This was an appeal from a judgment of non-suit. On the trial of the cause it appeared that plaintiffs were livery-stable keepers, and on the 20th February, 1860, one of their carriages was standing in Grand-street, near Elizabeth, waiting for fares. It stood there from 2  to 5 o'clock in the morning.
lead_paragraph: John King et al. vs. The New-York and Harlem Railroad Company. -- This was an appeal from a judgment of non-suit. On the trial of the cause it appeared that plaintiffs were livery-stable keepers, and on the 20th February, 1860, one of their carriages was standing in Grand-street, near Elizabeth, waiting for fares. It stood there from 2 1/2 to 5 o'clock in the morning. It was in charge of a driver employed by plaintiffs. The driver, however, was not all the time on his box; he stood around and about, on the sidewalk, &c. At this time there was much snow and ice collected on the track and in the street, which prevented the carriage from getting up close to the curb-stone. There were some ten or fifteen other carriages there in waiting at the same time. A policeman gave a general warning to the drivers present, "to get off the track, or they would be smashed."

On 'Change, in the street,
lead_paragraph: The telegraphic dispatches announcing that Fort Moultrie had been evacuated and dismantled by Maj. ANDERSON, was bulletined yesterday about noon, and produced considerable sensation. Crowds gathered about the newspaper establishment, impatiently waiting the appearance of the evening papers; and the various bulletins, where the dispatches were posted, were thronged by an excited multitude eager to catch a glance of the particulars. On 'Change, in the street, in hotels and bar-rooms, the exciting news was the topic of remark, and in some cases of exciting discussion. The motives for the act -- the authority on which Maj. ANDERSON probably acted -- and the results likely to flow from the movement, were earnestly canvassed. All sorts of rumors were current. Some said it was humiliating -- this surrendering a fort of the United States without firing a gun, or before even a summons from the enemy to do so. Others praised the strategic skill which stole a march on the threatening Carolinians -- and, while obtaining possession of a really defensible position, rendered any occupancy of the deserted post impossible. The movement might precipitate events, but would greatly lessen the chances of collision, by giving the commander of Fort Sumter the men and material to resist attack. So averse do the generality of people seem to admitting the possibility of a serious collision -- they will not believe it until actual hostilities occur. The great blunder or crime of leaving Maj. ANDERSON without the necessary reinforcements was everywhere denounced.

abstract: THE MAYOR RETURNED. The Mayor, who had been suddenly invoked home by numerous telegraphic dispatches, announcing the action of his locum tenens, and the Board of Aldermen, returned yesterday, and at 2 P.M. was at his desk administering the oaths of office to the newly-elected City officers. It is presumed that he was not specially pleased at the removal of Mr. PLATT, with whom he had a prolonged interview.
lead_paragraph: THE MAYOR RETURNED. -- The Mayor, who had been suddenly invoked home by numerous telegraphic dispatches, announcing the action of his locum tenens, and the Board of Aldermen, returned yesterday, and at 2 P.M. was at his desk administering the oaths of office to the newly-elected City officers. It is presumed that he was not specially pleased at the removal of Mr. PLATT, with whom he had a prolonged interview. Up to 3 o'clock of yesterday Mr. DEVLIN, the newly-appointed Chamberlain, had not filed his bonds, but on Wednesday afternoon he presented himself at the Mayor's office to be sworn in. Col. BURNHAM, to whom the application was made, declined to fill up the constitutional oath, bill tendered a blank form, which being filled up by a friend at hand, was signed and sworn to before the Acting Mayor. The mere act of taking the oath does not, however, confirm the tenure of office, the filing of the bond being by some deemed a necessary preliminary to the assumption of office, where security is required. Mr. Devlin will file his bond to-day, and that they will be ample to meet any amount which the City or County may require, will not be denied. Mr. Platt, however, does not intend to resign his office and its perquisites as readily as did his predecessor. He holds the purse-strings of the City, and the purse contains at present over four millions of dollars, -- which is certainly worth a law suit, especially as, in any event, the City must foot the bills.

abstract: Our intelligence from Charleston is of the highest importance, and is of a character little calculated to comfort those who may have cherished the expectation that the fortifications at that place would soon be in the hands of the Disunionists. Port Moultrie was on Wednesday night evacuated by Major ANDERSON and his little command, who have proceeded to Fort Sumter, after spiking the guns in Fort Moultrie and burning the gun-carriages and all other war materiel which could be made available in case the fortress should change possession. This movement on the part of Major ANDERSON, of course, caused the most intense excitement in Charleston, as exhibited in the first telegrams relative to the affair which reached this City. In Washington the news created the greatest consternation, in and out of Congress. The Cabinet was immediately called together, and were still deliberating at 12 o'clock last night. Gen. SCOTT, on being consulted by our correspondent, declared that the movement had been made without consultation with him, and whether in accordance with instructions from the President he could not say. He considered that in a strategetical point of view, Major ANDERSON had done perfectly right, as he was now in a position which he could maintain, which was not the case at Fort Moultrie, where his small force could have been overcome in a short time. It remains to be seen whether Major ANDERSON has acted under orders, or upon his own responsibility.

abstract: The official proceedings of Secretary FLOYD imperatively demand the scrutiny of Congress. It seems impossible to doubt that he is using his position and power as an officer of the Federal Government, to give aid and comfort to those who avow themselves enemies of the United States. Nor is it merely his own influence and aid that he thus throws into the hands of traitors; -- he is betraying the rights and the honor of the Government he serves. He is placing the arms and munitions of war which have been intrusted to his care for the defence of the United States, in the hands of their enemies. He is doing precisely the work which BENEDICT ARNOLD attempted at West Point. He is betraying a fortress intrusted to his command.

abstract: WILLIAMS, STEVENS & WILLIAMS exhibit a very beautiful painting, by AMES, of Albany, which is said to be the most accurate likeness of ALEXANDER, HAMILTON in the country. Patriots being scarce in these days, it may be well for our readers to know where they can refresh their memory, as to how such a person looked. They have also a very exquisite miniature landscape, by RONDEL, in which sheep, water view, trees and sky are most satisfactorily arranged, and most choicely painted. The two Niagaras, by CHURCH and GIGNOUX, (1858,) are still in the exhibition room, though they are not open to the public. The faithful photographs of PALMER's Marbles, with which all young-ladydom is in love, are as much in favor as ever.

lead_paragraph: Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday morning Mr. Clark A. Humphrey, a boarder at the International Hotel, was followed a long distance down Broadway by two men, whom he tried to avoid by quickening his pace. They persisted, however, in keeping at his heels, and at the corner of White street both made an attack upon him. Having knocked him down, they beat and kicked him until he became insensible when they robbed him of $27 and fled. Officer Dazet, of the Sixth Precinct, heard the noise which accompanied the assault, but he did not reach the place before the ruffians ran. He followed them, however, and after a long chase, captured one of them in Walker-street, but his confederate escaped. The name of the prisoner is William Malloy, a youth of 17 years. In default of $1,000 bail, Justice WELSH committed him for trial.

abstract: The resolution laid over at the last meeting, to increase the salaries of the Judges of the Supreme and Superior Courts, in the sum of $1,000 annually, was taken up, and, after some discussion, again laid over. On motion of Mr. PURDY, the Comptroller was directed to pay J. McLeod Murphy the sum of $500, being the balance of the appropriation for the survey of the Harlem River. The bills for fitting up election polling places for various Wards elicited considerable discussion, but were finally ordered paid. The salaries of certain Clerks in the office of the County Clerk, to be increased, in accordance with their petition, were reported upon favorably, but were laid ever. Two or three small bills, incurred by parties engaged on the new Harlem Bridge, were ordered paid. The bill of Henry Brull, as interpreter to the Fourth. District Civil Court, at the rate of $800 per year, was over. The bill of James A. Lowe, amounting to $489 25, for administering oaths in cases of violation of the Excise law, under direction of A.O. Hall, then District-Attorney, and certified by him, and which was favorably reported upon by the Committee, was laid over.

abstract: A special meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, President KALBFLEISCH in the Chair. Nearly the whole session was occupied in receiving reports. The Special Committee to whom was referred, for investigation, the charges against Alderman STRONG, of the Thirteenth Ward, who, it was alleged, connived at the leasing of a lot corner of South Second and Fourth streets, belonging to the city, for a long term of years at a nominal rent, reported that the Alderman deserved the censure of the Bond for his conduct in this matter; that the Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies be directed to take the necessary steps to retain possession of the property; that the Comptroller neglected his duty in leasing the property without personally understanding the subject The import provoked a lengthy debate.

abstract: -- It will be seen by an advertisement in another column, that proposals for cleaning the streets of the City for five years, are to be received at the City Inspector's office until noon to-day. This is an enormous contract, of vast importance to the City, and one which ought to enlist the attention of a very large class of our community, besides the professional Contractors for City jobs. The Mayor and Comptroller are to fix the bonds to be given by the successful bidder. This is a matter of great consequence, as the actual validity of the contract that may be made depends upon it. We suggest to Mayor WOOD and Comptroller HAWS the expediency of deciding upon the amount and nature of the security required, before the proposals are opened. It can be done before, just as well as after, -- and none of the parties concerned can then suspect that there is any partiality or unfairness in the case.

abstract: The news from Charleston continues to be of an exciting character, and indicates a determination on the part of the South Carolinians to precipitate a direct collision with the Federal Government. In fact, they have already gone so far as to place themselves in an attitude of rebellion. The Palmetto flag was raised on Thursday afternoon on the Custom-house and Post-office, and in the evening it was displayed on Castle Pinckney and Fort...
lead_paragraph: The news from Charleston continues to be of an exciting character, and indicates a determination on the part of the South Carolinians to precipitate a direct collision with the Federal Government. In fact, they have already gone so far as to place themselves in an attitude of rebellion. The Palmetto flag was raised on Thursday afternoon on the Custom-house and Post-office, and in the evening it was displayed on Castle Pinckney and Fort Moultrie, lately evacuated by Major ANDERSON and his command. These two fortresses were occupied by the State troops, under the instructions of Gov. PICKENS. They found in them only twelve men belonging to the Government forces, who, of course, quietly surrendered. This is the account telegraphed from Charleston; but as the telegraph office there is understood to be under the control of the Charlestonians, who will not permit any matter to be telegraphed which does not suit them, it may or may not be the exact truth. What Gov. PICKEN's proposes to gain by his descent upon the dismantled fortress on Sullivan's Island does not clearly appear, as the ordnance in it was rendered useless by Major ANDERSON, and the guns of Fort Sumter command it in the most complete manner.

abstract: There is no business doing whatever in any department of trade. The weather is bad, and the shipment of goods to the interior much interrupted. There have been several arrivals, but fresh imports do not invite buyers. If any orders exist to realize upon goods for Eastern account, a compliance with them, in the present condition of trade is out of the question. Grain comes in very sparingly, and insufficient to make it any object for export. Buyers offer for a limited demand for consumption. Prices of Wheat and Flour droop for the filling of such orders. There is nothing new in Freights; rates are nominally lower. Money matters are quiet. From the next steamer a good demand may be looked for. Short loans are stiff at 2 cent.
lead_paragraph: There is no business doing whatever in any department of trade. The weather is bad, and the shipment of goods to the interior much interrupted. abstract: -- A by-iaw was adopted by the Board of Education, at the session held on the 19th instant, making Wednesday next, the 2d of January, a holiday. At the adjourned meeting of the Board, held on Wednesday evening last, resolutions were introduced by Commissioner WATERBURY, declaring Thursday and Friday also holidays. These resolutions were adopted after a sharp discussion, in which several members participated, and were finally adopted. This action of the Board extends the present "holiday vacation" to Monday, Jan. 7, on which day the usual exercises of the schools will be resumed.

abstract: -- Chancellor DUNKIN seems to be the only member of the South Carolina Convention who realizes the position in which the people of that State are left by their act of secession, if it has the validity which they ascribe to it. He mentioned before the act was passed that they could have no commerce if they refused to recognize the Custom-House officers, and that their postal service must also be stopped. In a debate after the act was passed, upon a motion to lay aside a resolution for deciding some of these points, he thus referred to another:

abstract: Recruiting for the Army is not very brisk now. Applicants for enlistment are plenty enough, but the lack of money to pay them renders the officers indisposed to enrol their names. The force at present on Governor's Island consists of about 200 men, mostly recruits, who are first-class soldiers in every way. Maj. HOLMES, an officer of lengthened experience, is in command. The head-quarters of the Army in town are presided over by Col. SCOTT, son-in-law to the General. Col. THOMAS is still in Washington, giving the War Department the benefit of his enlarged views on the state of the Array.

abstract: -- Santa Claus appeared in all his glory yesterday, at Niblo's Saloon, for the special benefit of the seventy-eight merry young inmates of the Orphan's Home and the asylum of the Protestant Episcopal Church. Mr. Niblo kindly gave the use of the room for the second time, and the ladies took care that Kriss Kringle -- that jolly personage, who was personified on this occasion by an obese and grotesquely attired effigy, -- was well surrounded with gifts for the juveniles. A healthier collection of happy children never was seen; not one was ailing, and all entered into the spirit of the occasion with an energy that would doubtless be exhibited equally at the celebration of all of the disputed birthdays of our Saviour, -- provided that all the celebrations were equally prolific with presents. No little merriment was caused by the novel sport of allowing each of the youngsters a "grab" in a bag of promiscuous toys, and the experiment was repeated to the delight of both young and old. The sale of articles at the Fair, and the admission fees, realized a considerable sum in aid of the building fund for the new institution to be erected in Forty ninth-street, and to cost $30,000. Altogether, the affair was quite appropriate to the Feast of the Holy Innocents. The annual sermon and collection on behalf of the Church, takes place at Rev. Mr. MONTGOMERY's Church, corner of Madison-avenue and Twenty-eighth-street, on Sunday evening next.

abstract: Jesse T. Lee vs. Cornelius H. Van Wyck and William F. Lindsay. -- This was a motion made to dissolve an injunction which had been granted on a statement of facts alleged as follows: Van Wyck, one of the defendants, some time in February last bought out a drug-store on the corner of Twenty-third-street and Fourth-avenue, in this City, and, as alleged, employed the plaintiff to carry on the business. The plaintiff, it appears, by agreement with defendant, was to conduct the business in his own name, and instead of receiving a regular salary, was to be compensated for his services by a share in the profits. It was shown that the business had been a profitable one-but as alleged, the defendant, Van Wyck, had not realized sufficient from it to pay the rent of the concern.

abstract: The telegraph will have already informed you that Hungary is in a state of rebellion, and about to be placed under martial law. According to all reports which we have thus far received, the outbreak is immature and disconnected. Leaders, plans, even wishes, seem to be wanting. The Imperial Eagle is torn down or painted out on the doors of the tobacco shops, unpopular persons are mobbed, and their houses destroyed; but the movement...

abstract: -- SPEAKERSHIP OF THE ASSEMBLY. -- Our State Legislature meets on Tuesday next. Upon the election of Speaker of the Assembly there is likely to be something of a contest. It is understood that Speaker LITTLEJOHN will be a candidate for reelection, contrary to his original purpose, and partly, at least, on account of the efforts that have been made to defeat him by attacks upon his character. The Tribune demands that he be not chosen, on the ground that his election would emharrass and discredit the Republican Party.

abstract: Francis C. White vs. Haywood & Co., of Manchester, England. -- It appears from the evidence adduced on the trial of this action that the defendants are largely engaged in the manufacture of paper-hangings at Manchester, England. In 1855 the firm of Gilbert & Rockwell -- a firm in this City -- engaged in the sale of Yankee Notions, &c., entered into a contract with a man of the name of Pullen, the agent of the defendants, who came to this country to solicit orders in their behalf. Gilbert & Rockwell and this agent entered into a contract, by which Haywood & Co. were to supply $25,000 worth of paper-hangings and borders, which were selected from samples in the possession of the defendants' agent. Gilbert & Rockwell claim that the purchase was made on their own paper at eight months from the date of shipment at Liverpool. The defendants aver that they were to receive indorsed paper for one-half the amount of their bill. One-half of the order was to be shipped from Liverpool so that it should arrive here by the 1st of February, and the other half by the 1st of April, 1855. The invoice for $10,000 worth of the paper was received by the defendant's agent in this City about the middle of December, 1854, the balance of the order was never sent. The defendants refused to deliver any of the articles mentioned in the invoice, except upon the terms of payment for one-half in indorsed paper. Gilbert & Rockwell claim that they were ready to receive the invoice on their own notes. They accordingly assigned their claim for damages to the plaintiff in this action, who commenced by attaching the property of the defendants in this City. The defendants further claim that after the first order was given it was modified by Gilbert & Rockwell, and that the order so modified was only accepted by them upon indorsed paper for half the amount. It is further claimed that there was a misunderstanding between them as to the terms of the contract. The ground is taken, therefore, that the minds of the parties never having met there could he no contract.

abstract: A SOUTHERN GENTLEMAN ATTEMPTS TO ELOPE WITH A YOUNG MISS -- THE PLANS FRUSTRATED -- MARRIAGE. -- Quite an excitement was caused in Jersey City on Saturday, amongst certain circles, consequent upon an attempted elopement of a young Southern gentleman with a blooming young Miss of fifteen Summers, an adopted daughter of Mr. ISAAC WOOLFE, of No. 17 Grand-street. Mrs. WOOLFE, who is the sister of an Ex-Judge in New-York, is said to have planned the elopement without the knowledge or consent of her husband, and very nearly succeeded in her plans. The knowledge of the affair coming to the ears of a friend, he at once repaired to Williamsburgh, where Mr. WOOLFE is engaged constructing a city railroad, and informed him of what was about to take place. Mr. WOOLFE hurried at once to Jersey City, and consulted with Counselor JELLIFFE, when it was decided that he should proceed to the ferry and wait for the runaways. Hardly had he arrived there when a cart, containing a large box and some trunks belonging to the Southern gentleman and his fair one, came up. After some talk it was decided, in order to prevent the matter becoming public, to have the baggage removed to Mr. GAFFNEY's stable, there to await further action. The indignant father, the gentleman from the Sunny South, and Mr. JELLIFFE, then repaired to the office of the latter, and two hours were occupied in consultation. The father was very angry -- refused to be reconciled to the union, and it is said, used some very strong language. The young Southerner protested that his intentions were honorable, and in the elopement affair he was merely carrying out the plans laid by Mrs. WOOLFE. Mr. WOOLFE was finally prevailed upon to give his consent to the marriage, which he did after examining the baggage. The box contained an outfit, consisting of bedding, &c., which had been furnished by Mrs. WOOLFE, and the trunks the young lady's wearing apparel. The happy couple were united at 2 P.M., and a short time afterwards they left for the purpose of going on board the steamer for Richmond, Virginia. The young man is 22 years of age, and is said to be connected with a highly respectable family in Richmond.

abstract: Detectives Slowey, of this City, and Levy, of Philadelphia, arrested on Saturday night, in the Five Points, a well-known burglar named Charles Williams, alias "Billy, the Cigar-maker," charged with being one of a gang who some weeks ago perpetrated a burglary at the house of Mr. Strickler, of Philadelphia, and robbed not only his house, but a church which joined it, of which Mr. S. was sexton. It appears that the gang broke into the house, and finding Mr. S. and his wife in bed, they tore the sheets into strips, and then bound them, face downwards, to the bedstead, threatening at the time to murder them if they made the least noise. The rascals then ransacked the house, robbing it of a gold watch and chain, a set of silver spoons, a lot of clothing, and other articles, and then entered the church, hoping to find there $300 of its funds. In this, however, they were disappointed, and carried off only the minister's robes. After leaving, Mr. Strickler broke the bands which confined him, released his wife, and then gave an alarm. Three of the burglars and two receivers were subsequently arrested, tried and convicted; Williams, the third, as is charged, fled to this City, and hid himself in the Five Points. On being captured in bed, on Saturday night, he went quietly for some distance with the officers, but suddenly drawing a knife, he made an effort to stab and get away from them; a blow on the head with a locust club brought him to terms, and he was lodged in the Station-house, and yesterday he was started off with Detective Levy, to Philadelphia.

abstract: THE MURDER OF JOSEPH SUTCLIFFE CORONER'S INQUEST. Coroner JACKMEN, on Saturday, held an inquest in the case of JOSEPH SUTCLIFFE late, Steward of the schooner William and Mary, who was robbed and fatally beaten on Christmas Eve, in Thirty-ninthstreet, near Tenth-avenue.
lead_paragraph: THE MURDER OF JOSEPH SUTCLIFFE -- CORONER'S INQUEST. -- Coroner JACKMEN, on Saturday, held an inquest in the case of JOSEPH SUTCLIFFE late, Steward of the schooner William and Mary, who was robbed and fatally beaten on Christmas Eve, in Thirty-ninthstreet, near Tenth-avenue. The evidence showed that deceased and JOHN O'FLAHERTY, a sailor belonging to the above vessel, went ashore on Christmas Eve to make some purchases for presents to a girl named RANDELL, living in Maine, to whom deceased was engaged to be married. After making the purchases, and on their way back to the vessel, they met five young men, unknown to them, who attacked them, and after knocking down and brutally beating the deceased, they robbed him of $40 in money, and then ran off. O'FLAHERTY was also struck by them, but managed to escape without serious injury. The deceased lay upon the pavement nearly all night insensible, and the following morning was found by the police and taken to Bellevue Hospital, where he subsequently died of his injuries. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the above evidence, and after they were discharged, Officer IRVING, of the Twentieth Precinct, brought in a young man named JEREMIAH FLYNN, on suspicion of being one of the five who murdered SUTCLIFFE. He was immediately identified by O'FLAHERTY as one of them, and locked up to await examination. The police are in active search for the others.

abstract: A fire was discovered about 1 o'clock this morning, in BEERS' building, corner of Water and Gilbert streets, in a room occupied by J.J. DUNLOP as a hoop skirt factory. BEERS' foundry was considerably damaged. His loss on stock and building is about $3,500, for which he is insured. DUNLOP'S loss is about $1,500, and he is also insured.

abstract: Our dispatches from the Federal Capital this morning are again of a highly important character, and indicate still further complications in the already sufficiently entangled knot of difficulties. Secretary FLOYD resigned his position as the head of the War Department on Saturday, the resignation to take effect immediately. Although this ...
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from the Federal Capital this morning are again of a highly important character, and indicate still further complications in the already sufficiently entangled knot of difficulties. Secretary FLOYD resigned his position as the head of the War Department on Saturday, the resignation to take effect immediately. Although this event has been anticipated, still the ostensible cause for it has been unexpected. It seems that the movement of Major ANDERSON in evacuating Fort Moultrie and occupying Fort Sumter, was directly contrary to the spirit of assurances which had been given by Secretary FLOYD, with the President's consent, to the authorities of South Carolina, that no change should be made in the disposition of the Government forces in the fortifications in Charleston Harbor, until the State Commissioners could arrive in Washington and have a hearing. As soon as the action of Major ANDERSON became known, the Commissioners called upon Secretary FLOYD for explanations. Mr. FLOYD disavowed the act, but the Commissioners, would not be satisfied with anything short of the withdrawal of the troops from Fort Sumter. This, it appears, Secretary FLOYD was willing to agree to, and he accordingly asked the permission of the President to issue the necessary order. The Cabinet had a very long discussion on the subject; but, finally, the weight of the Cabinet being against complying with the demand of the Commissioners, Secretary FLOYD felt himself called upon to resign. It is intimated that Secretaries THOMPSON and THOMAS may resign today; but there appears to be no certainty about it. It is further intimated that President BUCHANAN may, after all, come to the conclusion to comply with the demand of the Commissioners; but this will be considered hardly probable under existing circumstances. This demand is understood to be the ultimatum of the gentlemen from South Carolina.

abstract: As a matter of course, the Washington Constitution exults in the low point to which the credit of the Federal Government has fallen, as shown by what it styles, correctly enough, the "humiliating failure" of the proposed fivemillion loan. A newspaper which directs all its efforts and its influence fo the encouragement of disunion, naturally rejoices in every blow inflicted upon the credit and honor of the Federal Government.
lead_paragraph: As a matter of course, the Washington Constitution exults in the low point to which the credit of the Federal Government has fallen, as shown by what it styles, correctly enough, the "humiliating failure" of the proposed fivemillion loan. A newspaper which directs all its efforts and its influence fo the encouragement of disunion, naturally rejoices in every blow inflicted upon the credit and honor of the Federal Government. It begins to see fruit from the seed it has been so industriously sowing. It begins to perceive that its assaults upon Union men -- its denunciations of every man, North and South, who ventures to say a syllable in support of the Constitution -- its malignant misrepresentations of the incoming Administration -- its encouragement of secession -- its applause of every blow struck at the Union -- its "regret" that the Federal authorities still hold possession of the Federal forts, and all its other labors for the overthrow of the Union, are beginning to take effect.

abstract: A magazinist may be a very bad novelist. It by no means follows that the author who produces a good story will be equally successful with a continued effort. Many a one who tells a good anecdote would be sadly puzzled to eke out an Arabian Nights' Entertainment. And many a spirited little pony that dashes off a mile at marvelous speed would come in lame and exhausted at the end of a three-mile heat, if, indeed, she did not fail on the way. We are moved to these remarks by glancing through the pages of Struggle for Life, written by the author of The Queen of the Red Chessmen, and published by WALKER, WISE & CO., Boston. We remember The Queen of the Red Chessmen as a very good story, which appeared in the Atlantic Monthly -- so good, in fact, that it was very generally attributed to the same parentage as the Diamond Lens. It would have been well had the author reposed on this one laurel, without jeopardizing the sprig in an attempt to raise a tree. The book which is the result of this ambition does not open very brilliantly, and the reader will be very apt to consider that he is indeed engaged in a struggle for life long before he reaches its end. There is a wonderful suggestiveness about the title which will warn the sagacious reader from going further.

abstract: The report that Secretary FLOYD has attempted to screen himself from the consequences of his official crimes by retiring from the Cabinet, will strike no one with astonishment; but that the President should accept the resignation in due official form, is something which appears almost incredible.
lead_paragraph: The report that Secretary FLOYD has attempted to screen himself from the consequences of his official crimes by retiring from the Cabinet, will strike no one with astonishment; but that the President should accept the resignation in due official form, is something which appears almost incredible. The ceremony of accepting a resignation is one only due to officers who have faithfully discharged their trusts. It is, to a certain extent, an indorsement of their characacters, and is seldom performed in the ordinary course without expressions of regret for "unavoidable differences of opinion," or some other of those circumlocution-phrases in which official chicanery delights.

abstract: Another prop of the Old Public Functionary has  been knocked from under him. The resignation of Secretary FLOYD yesterday, after an excited Cabinet discussion, running through forty-eight hours, will surprise no one, after what is already known. Yet some details, from reliable authority, may be interesting.

abstract: The people of the State of South Carolina in Convention assembled, on the 2d day of April, A.D. 1852, declared that the frequent violations of the Constitution of the United States by the Federal Government, and its encroachments upon the reserved rights of the States fully justified this State in their withdrawal from the Federal Union; but in deference to the opinions and wishes of the other Slaveholding States, she forbore at that time to exercise this right. Since that time these encroachments have continued to increase, and further forbearance ceases to be a virtue.

abstract: The majority of Americans know but little about Art, and care less. This fact Mr. JARVES deplores in the outset of his book; he laments that "the public voice is dumb;" that "there is no universal demand for Beauty." But the riddle of this silence, if riddle it be, Mr. JARVES fails to expound. He does not seem to recognize a truth which is visible on the very face of the fact he deplores: that the public do not hunger for Beauty is very conclusive evidence that the time for its development has not quite arrived. The lap of a Republic

abstract: The Christmas Festival of St. Ann's Church Sunday School, took place at 234 o'clock P.M., yesterday, in the body of the Church, corner of Sands and Washington streets. The Church was well filled, and the proceedings highly interesting. The introductory exercises were a voluntary on the organ, the singing of a hymn and prayer. Singing by the Infant School was followed by the usual annual reports, showing the condition of each school. By these it appears that the schools were better attended last year, than ever before. The children were next asked a variety of Scripture questions, which were generally answered promptly and satisfactorily. Short addresses were followed by the presentation of Bibles to members of the classes for introducing new scholars. Singing and receiving missionary offerings were the next in order, when each member of the schools was presented with a book suitable to her or his age. After a hymn and benediction the children and their friends dispersed. The whole character of the exercises was such as to leave a good impression both on the minds of parents and pupils.

abstract: In this Court on Saturday, Justices KELLY, WELSH and BROWNELL disposed of the calendar as follows : Of twenty eight persons charged with assault and battery, four were discharged on account of nonappearance of witnesses, three by request of complainant and one by suspension of sentence; two were allowed postponement, six were fined and twelve imprisoned. Of forty-three persons charged with lar
lead_paragraph: In this Court on Saturday, Justices KELLY, WELSH and BROWNELL disposed of the calendar as follows : Of twenty eight persons charged with assault and battery, four were discharged on account of nonappearance of witnesses, three by request of complainant and one by suspension of sentence; two were allowed postponement, six were fined and twelve imprisoned. Of forty-three persons charged with larceny, one was discharged on account of non-appearance of witnesses, three by request of complainant, three by suspension of sentence and five by acquittal; four were remanded and twenty-seven were imprisoned. One person was fined for embezzlement, and one fined for indecent exposure of his person.

lead_paragraph: The theatrical events of the week are scarcely of sufficient importance to merit recapitulation. They have had but little direct influence on the business of the theatres which experience of course all the fluc tuations of holiday times. Mrs. FORREST'S performances continue to draw brilliant houses, and have been especially cowded since the production of Dr. BIRD'S "Gladiator," in which the Tragedian is seen to eminent advantage. The "offnights" are very unfavorable contrasts to these tri-weekly jams. On Saturday a change was made in the programme by substituting the "Zouave" for the regular company, and th[???]s producing a very great improvement in the financial result. The Frenchmen are very amusing; there is vivacity, freshness and merit in their entertainment -- although it is not one that will bear much critical consideration. They are good actors for soldiers, and bring to their adopted profession an amount of vigor which is seldom found before the footlights. But when curiosity has been satisfied, appreciation will we suspect rapidly subside. It would be unjust to pretend that as actors merely they have any special excellence to commend them to lengthened consideration. Still for an excitement -- that boon of management -- they serve abundantly well. They will perform twice during the coming week, on Tuesday and Thursday. The Zouaves will be succeeded by Mr. RAREY, the horse tamer, who makes his debut on Saturday afternoon.

abstract: On last Wednesday Supervisor PURDY allowed himself to be made the medium of certain outside parties who are in favor of adding one thousand dollars a year each to the future salaries of GEORGE G. BARNARD, Judge of the Supreme Court, JAMES W. WHITE, Judge of the Superior Court, and EDWARD C. WEST, Surrogate.
lead_paragraph: On last Wednesday Supervisor PURDY allowed himself to be made the medium of certain outside parties who are in favor of adding one thousand dollars a year each to the future salaries of GEORGE G. BARNARD, Judge of the Supreme Court, JAMES W. WHITE, Judge of the Superior Court, and EDWARD C. WEST, Surrogate. The resolution to this effect, introduced by Mr. PURDY, comes up for action to-day, and must be immediately decided one way or other, -- the Constitution providing that no Judges or Surrogates, holding office, shall have their salaries increased during their term of service. Mr. BARNARD's elective term as Recorder expires to-day, as does also the term of Judge WHITE, under Gov. MORGAN's appointment, and the first term of Mr. WEST, as surrogate. It is, therefore, "now or never" with the Supervisors, for if they wait until to-morrow, when all three gentlemen named will be sworn in for their new terms, the increase of salary voted would be unconstitutional and of no effect. Why Judge BARNARD, the youngest Judge of the Supreme Court, should be given $6,000 a year, while all his elder associates on the Bench can receive only $5,000, is not exactly clear; nor can we see any good public reason why Judge WHITE should be allowed one-fifth more pay than the other Judges of the Superior Court.

abstract: Senator BAYARD, of Delaware, has written to Mr. JAMES RIDDLE, of Wilmington, on the present state of public affairs. He has much to say of Anti-Slavery agitation, and of course casts the burden of blame for the present state of affairs upon the Republican Party. The sentiment which has triumphed in the North is, he asserts, of necessity aggressive, and it is vain to hope that the men who have been elevated to office through its force will devise any measures calculated to lessen the cause of excitement and disunion. He thinks it vain to moot the question of coercion or of the right of secession. The former means only civil war, and if that is once commenced, it is impossible to predict where it may end, for it would drive the seceding States into cooperation. Senator BAYARD has hope, if the Legislatures of the larger States will initiate a movement for a National Convention, that when the people come to elect delegates to such a Convention, with the question of Union or disunion directly presented, their choice will fall upon those who will be able to adjust, on a national basis, the subject in controversy. He despairs of anything from Congress, as now constituted, and urges this course -- the calling of a National Convention -- as the only way of escape from impending perils.

abstract: The St. Louis Republican publishes the following: A house in this city received a letter yesterday from Alabama, stating that the head of the Military Department of that State desired to make a contract in St. Louis for a large supply of warlke materials -- powder, lead, cavalry equipments, &c., and that as soon as samples were furnished the order would be given. Accordingly, the samples were prepared, and are now on their way to that State. These preparations for military defences are made, we think, under a law of the last Legislature, which provided $400,000 or $500,000 for this purpose. Every article wanted can be speedily furnished in this city.

abstract: A letter from Senator JOHNSON, of Arkansas, appears in the Little Rock True Democrat. He advises the people of the State to stand firmly on their rights and to attempt to maintain them in the Union, and if she fails in this to follow the example of South Carolina. He does not condemn the course taken by South Carolina, for no less decided stand would have attracted any attention from Northern people; on the contrary, he hopes that other States will follow her, and thus give the movement sufficient strength and dignity to insure the concession of guarantees from the North. The Legislature should demand the prompt repeal of all hostile legislation in every Northern State; protection of the rights of the South in the Territories; it should declare its sympathy with the seceding States, and support the movement for a Constitutional Convention of all the States, that disturbing questions might be adjusted by means of amendments to the Constitution. Senator JOHNSON does not think that the Northern States can refuse to concede all just demands.

abstract: Hon. PIZEBRE SOULS publishes in the New-Orleans Bee a card defining his position as a co-operative candidate for the State Convention. He declares that he is no submissionist; that it is his opinion that resistance to actual wrong is a paramount duty with States as well as with individuals. He denies the
lead_paragraph: Hon. PIZEBRE SOULS publishes in the New-Orleans Bee a card defining his position as a co-operative candidate for the State Convention. He declares that he is no submissionist; that it is his opinion that resistance to actual wrong is a paramount duty with States as well as with individuals. He denies the right of coercion and claims that as soon as the compact ceases to be respected the bond of Union is broken, and that the associates are at liberty to return to their individual and separate existence. Leaving out of consideration the causes which have led to the present difficulties, he says that it is not safe to leave the management of affairs in the present crisis to those who with all the federal power at their bidding have subverted the Government and destroyed the most powerful party ever organized. He adds:

abstract: We have at least something that encourages hope for the honor and stability of the Government. It is stated that President BuCHANAN has actually refused to withdraw the troops from Charleston, or to order Major ANDERSON out of Fort Sumter!
lead_paragraph: We have at least something that encourages hope for the honor and stability of the Government. It is stated that President BuCHANAN has actually refused to withdraw the troops from Charleston, or to order Major ANDERSON out of Fort Sumter! The decision does not seem to amount to much in itself, and under ordinary circumstances would not deserve any special note. But as things have been going on of late, it is a matter of very great importance, and will everywhere reawaken confidence and hope in the heart of the country. It indicates a purpose on the part of the President to make a stand somewhere for the Constitution and the Union. It tends to relieve us from the fearful suspicion, which had begun to creep into the public mind, that the President of the United States was in league with its enemies, and was actually aiding them to overthrow the Government.
headline: {'main': 'A Gleam of Hope!', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Gleam of Hope!', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
